name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-13
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content: Fig.2(a) depicts the arithmetical mean surface roughness $\left( \mathrm { R _ { a } } \right)$ that occurred by different EDs or scanning speeds in the first stage of the study.The roughness had been measured at several places and in several directions on the vertical plane samples.The sample-I-3,fabricated in $6 5 \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { 3 }$ ED and $6 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ scanning speed has the lowest surface roughness.Microcracks have been observed in the side surfaces of the samples fabricated with high scanning speed $\mathrm { 1 0 0 0 m m / s }$ and $8 0 0 \mathrm { m m } /$ s) in sample-I-1 and sample-I-2,and high ED $( 2 6 0 \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { 3 } )$ in sample-I7.The bottom surface of the samples has high roughness,and those contain the remaining broken supportive bars,porosity,a downward moved melt pool,and other defects.These open pores contain partially melted and adhered powder particles,a trench wall,a wavy wall,and microcracks. The pores occupied the spaces inside up to $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m } - 1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ The top surface is the smoothest compared to the other sides of the sample.A rippled surface,tiny open pores and spattered particles,such as a spattered powder particle,a small droplet, and big spattered particles,are noticed on the top surface.Two types of rippled structures exist at the top surface,one of them is high pitched up to $2 5 \mathrm { - } 5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,and the other is small pitched,rippling with a few micrometers,as shown in Figs.5(b)-(d).Interestingly,as depicted in Fig.6,the smoothness of the top surfaces increases if the value of ED increases.
summary: 3.1.Surface morphologies using diferent scanning speeds and EDs - Part 1/9

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-14
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content: The adhered and partially melted powder particles influenced the side surface roughness strongly [27]. In the beginning the ED density was low,which caused high viscosity in the melt pool that attracted the adhered powder particles.The adhered particles did not get enough time to melt a high amount of them,due to rapid cooling as the scanning speed was high. On the other hand,high viscosity resulted in poor fluidity and wettability of the melt pool that hindered the liquid from infiltrating the powders [28]. Hence,poor metallurgical bonding occurred between the vertical surface of the sample and the adhered powder particles [29]. Adequate increasing of ED with decreasing scanning speed dropped the melt pool's viscosity in the sample-I-3, that helped the adhered particles enter into the melt pool partially or fully, and melt well along with higher time [3O].With further increasing of ED,the adhered powder particles melted well on and very close to the scanning track.The higher ED induced higher energy with higher time, as the scanning speed was lower.Therefore,more powder particles sintered and adhered to the surface,that caused higher surface roughness.On the other hand,a steep thermal gradient was developed in the melt pool,due to the high ED that caused surface tension gradient and the Marangoni effect.These phenomena discrete the melt pool and favor the balling effect, which was accompanied by surface roughness [27].
summary: 3.1.Surface morphologies using diferent scanning speeds and EDs - Part 2/9

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-15
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content: High scanning speed caused rapid solidification and cooling of the melt pools,and,as a result,microcracks occurred at the interface of the melt pool and partially melted powder particles.This phenomenon has been discussed in detail in the next subheading.High ED and high thermal gradient caused thermal stress,which elicited microcracks on the surface of sample-I-7,as depicted in Fig.2(b) [9].The bottom surfaces of the SLM samples are made on the supportive bars and a lot of gaps exist between the bars.The gaps are filled up by the powder material,where a melt pool may not get enough support from below [31].Therefore,the melt pool may move downward,as shown in Fig.3(a).On the other hand, the size of the melt pool increased with higherED,and developeda big,pitched ripple surface.The difference in thermal conductivity is high between dense material and the powder bed [3].As the lower side and the next track side of the melt pool are filled with powder particles,the melt pool may bend upwards during solidification,as depicted in Figs.3(a) and (b).
summary: 3.1.Surface morphologies using diferent scanning speeds and EDs - Part 3/9

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-16
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content:
As illustrated in Fig. 3(a),improper adhesion occurs at the time of first layer scanning,due to the presence of the powder bed in the bottom of the melt pool. The powder particles may spatter from the action zone due to high heat-shock during rapid scanning.The molten metal spattered from the action zone due to the explosion of metallic vapor,or an entrapped gaseous bubble.Droplet (small) or splash (big) spattering can occur to reduce the surface tension of the highly viscous melt pool [32]. Therefore,starting samples,such as sample-I-1 and sample-I-2 suffered from droplet and splash spattering due to high scanning speed and low ED.As an example,droplet and splash spattered particles can be observed in the SEM image taken from the top surface,which is shown in Fig.4(d). On the other hand,the samples that were manufactured by high ED and low scanning speed (sample-I-5 to sample-I-7) underwent massive spattering due to the explosion of the melt pools. The mechanism of massive spattering,and a result of it, have been shown in Fig.3 by schematic diagram and SEM image respectively.

![](images/99ef6a6b5a7104819e10a8234fa8a78254c11837ab0d0758d6a546d22856466e.jpg)  
Fig. 2. (a) Surface roughness $\mathrm { ( R _ { a } ) }$ onthe vertical planeof the samples fabricated by diferent scanning speeds,(b) Microcracks on the sample-1-7 side surface.

![](images/d4702e5557da1ff24a225b96e6941a5983f821b9e34fac50c78c00b98398ec52.jpg)  
Fig3Botoceatiesof vertical plane of a sample including a few starting layers.
summary: 3.1.Surface morphologies using diferent scanning speeds and EDs - Part 4/9

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-17
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content:
Moreover,powder particles sometimes move away from the bottom of the keyhole due to the absence of a solid surface below and, thus, the keyhole may collapse during first layer scanning.On the other hand, recoil pressure from the keyhole exerts force on the powder particles at the lower part of it,which causes the lack of materials below the scanning layer.Consequently,these phenomena cause critical defects. The defect at the first layer may provoke the next layers,which leads to bigger pores,as shown in Fig.3(b).The powder particles adhere to the pores by capillary effect and melt partially [7].During cooling,the molten metal shrinks;on the other hand,the partially melted and adhered particle does not shrink significantly,which results in a separation between the melt pool and partially melted adhered powder particle.

However,high physical instability of a melt pool in the first layer scanning creates a porous or mounded zone somewhere [16,31]. A tiny part of the bars may remain on the bottom surface of the sample during removing the supportive bars from a sample,which creates an additional rough surface.Therefore,if a surface of a product needs supportive bars and,eventually,if surface finishing by machining is not possible due to complex shape,the bars add roughness.The complex pores,along with trenches and microcracks,initiate cracking under loading [33].As these pores are open,and contain adhered powder particles and a wavy wall; fundamentally,they increase the surface area,which,consequently,decreases corrosion resistance in the chemical environment [10].
summary: 3.1.Surface morphologies using diferent scanning speeds and EDs - Part 5/9

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-18
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content:
A valley and two peaks of the adjacent melt pool together created a big rippled surface at the top of some samples.The waves are big,as the wavy pitches belong to the melt pool with the mean value of the maximum peak-valley length in $2 0 - 5 0 \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ as shown in Figs.5 (a)-(c). The motion of the laser beam results in a surface temperature difference between the action zone and the solidifying zone,which also creates surface tension.The surface tension of the liquid surface causes a shear force,and it results in a rippling effect on the top surface of the melt pool [3,13]. Relatively lower ED causes higher melt pool viscosity [17]. Moreover, the higher scanning speed is also one of the causes for the higher cooling rate.Therefore,the molten metal didn't get enough driving forces and time to spread to become flattened. Thus,the phenomenon created a radius of curvature of the top of the melt pool, that results in a big wavy-formed surface at the top of the beginning of the samples as shown in Figs.6 (a) and (b). The viscosity of the melt pool decreased due to the increase in ED,as well as the decreasing scanning speed provided enough time against viscous drags to promote the efficient spreading of the molten material [17].

![](images/e8c53918faa8c91fe3c06f4677016f66f03b54e95b2568044654958d29194a50.jpg)

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-20
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content: The top surface of sample-I-1 consists of some spattered particles. The viscosity of the molten materials of the sample-I-pool was high due to the low ED,and,thus,the surface tension was high.To reduce the surface tension the materials formed balls,and a serious balling formation occurred.Thus, small droplets and big splash spattered material were produced,which stuck over the top surface of the sample [32]. Relative lowering of scanning speed induces higher ED and,thus,the viscosity is reduced [34].Consequently,the spattered material reduced onto the next samples'top surfaces.Higher scanning speed spattered a higher rate of raw powder particles,which also added a number of spattered particles at the beginning of the samples.A few open pores on the top surface of sample-I-1 and sample-I-2 have been observed, that occurred due to the entrapment of the gaseous bubble. The inert gas mixes with the molten metal from the interparticle space,as shown in Fig.4(a) [22].Then,the bubble moves with the vortex of the melt pool, as shown in Fig.4(b) [22].The bubble may go out of the melt pool, or can stay with the vortex.As the melt pool solidifies from the bottom to the upper part of the melt pool, the vortex also becomes smaller and moves upward [15]. The bubble also moves up with the vortex. Eventually,the bubble may just stay below the top surface having a tiny layer,or remain to be exposed as an open pore,as shown in Fig.4(c). If the viscosity of the melt pool is low, there would be a lesser probability of gaseous bubble entrapment by the melt pool. Thus,the open porosity reduced from sample-I-3 onwards.Eventually,the top surface of sample-I-7,manufactured with the highest ED $2 6 0 \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { 3 }$ and lowest scanning speed $1 5 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,became the smoothest among other samples in the first stage of the study.
summary: 3.1.Surface morphologies using diferent scanning speeds and EDs - Part 8/9

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-22
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content:
Fig.7 shows that the numbers of adhered powder particles on the vertical surface decreased along with decreasing laser power and scanning speed in the second stage of the study. Table 5 shows the approximate numbers of the adhered powder particles per square-millimeter on the vertical surface.The particles have been quantified by counting them using human eyes.It has been observed that the numbers of the particles decreased by almost $5 0 \ \%$ from sample-II-1 to sample-II-5,and they are 1,0o0-445 per millimeter respectively.

Microcrack and separation between the partially-melted powder particles and solidified well-melted material can be observed in the samples (sample-II-1 and sample-II-2) manufactured with high laser powers (95 W and 85 W) along with the high scanning speeds $( 7 6 0 \mathrm { m m } /$ s and $6 8 0 \mathrm { m m } / s )$ ). Some gaps,as shown in Fig.7(c),between a partially melted powder particle and well-melted material,can be seen in the sample-II-4, manufactured by $6 5 { \mathrm W }$ laser power and $5 2 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ scanning speed. These gaps do not belong to microcracks,and probably these will initiate a crack. Sample-I-5 contained well-adhered powder particles without having any separation,crack,or gap.Therefore,the laser power $5 5 \mathrm { W }$ ,along with scanning speed $4 4 0 \mathrm { m m } / \mathrm { s }$ ,manufactured the best vertical surface from the roughness and microcrack point of view in the second stage of the study.The bottom surface morphology of the samples is similar,as the samples belong to the first stage,where the surface contains big complex pores,along with adhered powder particles.Sample-II-5 has the lowest defected bottom surface in the second stage.
summary: 3.2.Surface morphologies using different scanning speeds and laser powers - Part 1/6

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-23
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content: Though the ED was the same for each sample in the second stage, changes in laser power changed the thermal energy input per short unit time at the action zone.Therefore,a high laser power generated high energy at the action zone and,thus,adhered more powder particles on the side surface by the capillary force and melting them partially [7,35].Lower laser power with slower scanning speed reduced the heataffected zone nearby but melted the material well,with the laser affecting the required melt pool volume for a longer time.The cyclone above the action zone also increased the number of adhered particles. High laser power induced high energy at the action zone that produced a cyclone in the Argon atmosphere.The powder particles were, thus, pulled and assisted to move towards the surface of the melt pool, and adhered to it [36,37].Hence,sample-II-5 got the lowest adhered powder particles,which was manufactured by the lowest laser power, i.e., 55 W.
summary: 3.2.Surface morphologies using different scanning speeds and laser powers - Part 2/6

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-24
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content: However,scanning speed played an important role in solidification timing and shrinking of the melt pool [13].The microcrack generation mechanism has been explained with the help of the schematic diagram in Fig.8.High laser power,along with high scanning speed,induced much higher energy on the focal circle compared to the surrounding heat affected zone.This caused lower viscosity in the center and higher viscosityat the periphery side.Thus,a steep thermal gradient had been generated between the center and periphery of the melt pool, that introduced a high Marangoni effect. This effect evolved a tendency in the molten material to flow radially inward of the melt pool [28].This phenomenon assisted a few adhered and partially melted powder particles to get inside of the melt pool which remained there as partially melted particles.Higher scanning speed was responsible for faster cooling.Hence,the melt pool cooled down faster than the partially melted powder particles in it. In this way,the melt pool shrank during solidification,and the entered and partially melted powder particles did not shrink parallelly because of their solidity.Consequently,microcracks occurred in between their interfaces,as illustrated in Figs.8(b) and (c).If observed closely,it can be seen that the cracks happened where the diameter of the powder particle was approximately $2 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ or bigger,and entered or situated in the melt pool by half of its volume or more.In such circumstances,the particle keeps its solidity inside the melt pool,which causes a significant difference in shrinking tension between the particle and the solidifying melt pool.By decreasing the scanning speed and laser power further while keeping the ED constant, the targeted particles got enough energy and time to melt and mix with the melt pool.Eventually,the particles did not create any significant shrinking difference due to the slower scanning speed.
summary: 3.2.Surface morphologies using different scanning speeds and laser powers - Part 3/6

One more remarkable crack behavior can be observed belonging to the above cracking phenomenon. Most of the cracks happened above or below a powder particle,and horizontally,but not vertically. This happened because a melt pool cools down and solidifies from the bottom to the top [l5].This occurs due to the differentiation of heat transfer rate,where solid material conducts the heat faster than the convection process from the top surface of a melt pool.Thus,the shrinking process occurs from bottom to top.In-between the shrinking process,when the melt at the bottom of a partially melted powder particle solidifies and shrinks,the particle remains as it is,thus,the cracksoccur.Eventually,most of these cracks are below the powder particles,as shown in Fig.9(b),and a few are above it,as shown in Fig. 9(c).
summary: 3.2.Surface morphologies using different scanning speeds and laser powers - Part 4/6

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-26
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content:
However,most of the adhered particles did not go inside the melt pool,and so had no effect on cracking.Even the small powder particles which entered inside the melt pool had no such significant effect to initiate a crack.On the other hand,Ti-6Al-4V alloy is highly reactive with oxygen and nitrogen [4].Hence,the additional possibility of microcracking observed in this entire study is due to the loosening of its ductility and, thus,the oxidation prompted microcracking [38].

Afew SEM images from the side surface of sample-I-1 and sampleI-2 are provided in Fig.9,as some examples,to know the crack behavior intensely.These cracks are $2 0 \mu \mathrm { m } - 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ lengthwise, $1 - 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ widthwise at their middle area,and a few micrometers in-depth inside the samples.The width of a crack may be even bigger if it occurred inbetween two mostly melted powder particles which are situated above and below each other in a melt pool,as shown in Fig.9(c).This occurred due to the shrinkage of the material situated in-between the two particles,which did not shrink,thus,high tension occurred. Therefore,these cracks are critical for propagating themselves under loading conditions.
summary: 3.2.Surface morphologies using different scanning speeds and laser powers - Part 5/6

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-27
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content:
Let's compare the consequences of the side surfaces between the first and second stages of the study considering scanning speed.It can be observed that, though the scanning speeds were higher in the first stage of the study $( 8 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ and $1 0 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ） than the second stage $( 7 6 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ and $6 8 0 \mathrm { m m } / s )$ ,relatively fewer cracks occurred on the vertical surface of the samples belonging to the first stage.Though the scanning speeds were higher in the first stage,the ED was lower than the second stage.Eventually,that caused lower viscosity of the melt pool and, thus,lower volume shrinkage [39].Moreover,in the first stage,the Marangoni effect was lower,and,due to rapid cooling, the Marangoni flow did not pull the adhered powder particles.To keep the ED constant in the second stage,the scanning speed was higher with higher laser power,and the laser provided high energy in a short duration of time.As a result,a partially melted particle did not melt well,due to lesser time of heat spreading.As it remained almost completely solid, this particle had not shrunk neck-to-neck with the molten metal.

The high scanning speed caused a higher rate of powder spattering due to heat-shock and rapid heating of the inert gas. High scanning speed induces more rapid movement of the gaseous cyclone at the action zone that blows away the power particles [37].It is also well known that the higher laser power induces high laser energy in one place,which causesa higher depth of keyhole and,thus,creates higher collapsing possibilities.Sample-II-5 has the lowest defected bottom surface due to the lowest spattering of powder particles,as the scanning speed was lowest, though the ED was the same.Additionally, there were fewer keyhole collapsing possibilities,due to the lower depth keyhole created by the low laser power and low scanning speed,which decreased porosity [40].
summary: 3.2.Surface morphologies using different scanning speeds and laser powers - Part 6/6

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-28

content:
Significant differences were observed on the vertical surface morphologies of the samples manufactured in the third stage of the study,considering different scanning speeds and hatch spacings,as shown in Fig.1O.The number of powder particles adhered to side surfaces increased from sample-II-1 to sample-III-1O and they are 125 and 680 per square millimeter,as presented in Table 6.

A few microcracks were noticed in samples-II-6 to -II-1o. Two types of cracks were detected in this study,one of them is beside a partially melted powder particle,as observed in the previous studies, and the other is an interlayer crack.Sample-III-6 has small cracks, that occurred at the small periphery of the partially melted powder particle, as shown in Fig.11(a). Sample-II-7 has some interlayer cracks,as well as small and big cracks associated with the particles.Samples-III-8 to III-10 have interlayer cracks.The lower surfaces have a similar effect by the big porosities,but samples-III-8 to -III-1O have the lowest defects, which were manufactured with large track overlapping.The top surfaces have a similar effect of big and rippling structures,along with the

Therefore,there is no significant effect by the hatch spacing on the sample's side surface.The scanning speed only influences the practical ED of the melt pool,as the laser power and layer thickness were constant.At the beginning of the samples,the scanning speed was lower, naturally,the input energy was higher,and,thus,the melt pool viscosity was lower. Due to the low scanning speed, the partially adhered powder particles melted well at the inner side of the melt pool. On the other hand, the cooling rate was low,which protected the cracking in samples -II-1 to -I-5.Sample-II-6,manufactured by medium scanning speeds $( 5 6 0 \mathrm { m m } / s )$ ,cooled down faster than before,and the input energy was almost enough.As a result, little cracks occurred in some places on the vertical surface of the sample,as shown in Fig.11(a). These cracks are situated only at the small part of the periphery of the powder particles. Relatively higher scanning speed $( 6 0 5 \mathrm { m m } / s )$ was liable formorerapid cooling,which formed a bigger crack in the associated powder particle, along with the small interlayer cracks observed in sample-II-7.Further increased scanning speed induced lower energy,which did not melt the material adequately,and, thus,the melt pool formed inappropriately. Moreover,rapid cooling occurred at the high scanning speed,eventually,and the cracks occurred at the interlayer face in samples-III-8 to -I-10.Hence,sample-II-1 has the best smooth side surface and bonding.

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-31
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content:
Interesting wide-ranging surface morphologies were observed in the fourth stage of the study,where rescanning by different combinations of the laser processing parameters was employed.Fig.l2 represents the vertical surface morphologies of the samples from samples-IV-1 to -IV5.The balling effect on the side surface can be seen mostly in sampleIV-2 and sample-IV-4.Sample-IV-3 has a balled up and stuck vertical surface with stacked materials.Thus,the side surface of sample-IV-3 has formed such architecture, including big porosities,having 50 - $4 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ width and $3 0 { \mathrm { - } } 7 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ depth.The side surfaces of sample-IV-1 and sample-IV-4 contain adhered powder particles and a smaller number of balling zones than the other samples.The bottom surfaces of the samples have many downward-moving materials,along with stuck powder particles.

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-32
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content:
The top surface architectures are also distinct amongsamples,as displayed in Fig.13.Fig.13(a) demonstrated that the top surface of sample-IV-1 contains pores,spherical spattered particles,and stacked material.These pores are situated in the intertrack region,and they are mostly rectangular,having $2 0 - 5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ length,about $1 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ width,and about $5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ depth.Some of the pores are spherical,with $5 - 1 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ average diameter.The spattered particles might be raw powder particles or droplet spattered particles.The surface contains bumpy patches, along with the valley in between two adjacent tracks.The top surface of sample-IV-2 is with pores and stacked materials,as shown in Fig.13(b). These pores are positioned mostly on the scanning track-line,and the sizes of these porosities are $3 0 { \mathrm { - } } 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .The stacked materials have also appeared on the top surface of this sample.Sample-IV-3 has the smoothest top surface among the samples in the entire study. There is no track induced wave structure,spattered material, stacked material, and pore,as demonstrated in Fig.13(c).Fig.13(d) shows that sampleIV-4 has similar top surface morphology as sample-IV-1 with a lower numberand size of defects.The pores are located at the intertrack at the top of sample-IV-4,and they are smaller in size and number than sample-IV-1 has,and so on.The top surface morphology of sample-IV-5 has similarities to sample-IV-3,but is not as smooth as sample-IV-3.The surface also contains some small intertrack pores and spattered particles,as shown in Fig. 13(e).

Balling formation is a well-known phenomenon that occurs with a decrease in free energy. They occurred in this stage due to the rescanning of each layer. The influences of the processing parameters, mechanism,and formation process are extremely complicated in the
summary: 3.4. Surface morphologies using different rescanning strategies - Part 2/8

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-33
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content:
SLM process,as the phenomenon is caused by the complex thermal, physical,and chemical processes,along with several laser interactions [14-17].According to Li etal.[1],low input of energy by high scanning speedand low laser power causes balling formation,due to insufficient melting and wetting with surrounding parts. Low energy produces a high viscous melt pool with high surface tension.To reduce the surface tension, the balling formation starts,and ejects from the melt pool if it is small,as illustrated in Fig.4(a). Otherwise,this remains attached to the melt pool if it is big,as in the SEM image shown in Fig. 14(e).

The balling mechanism which evolved in this study has been depicted by the schematic diagram in Fig.14.During the first scanning of a layer,only a part of the radiation of the laser is absorbed by the particles at the top surface of the powder layer,and a few of them reflect from the top surface [21].Most of another part laser ray penetrates the powder layer,as illustrated in Fig.14(a).The penetrated laser rays reflect inside the particles and create black bodies [5].The particles absorb the radiation and start melting.As the layers were scanned with low ED $\left( 3 6 \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } } \right)$ ）for first time scanning,the powder particles clustered themselves and made some small balls,with the mixture of molten metal and some solid powder particles.This phenomenon occurs due to the low overall rheological performance of the liquid in aggregation with solid particles [41]. These balls may stay separate by limited liquid formation,or adhere with neck formation between them by sufficient liquid formation [41].This state occurs due to the high viscous formation of the liquid, that acts as the retardation of liquid flow and particle rearrangement. Eventually,the inefficient attachment was acquired between the neighboring balls by the sintering process.
summary: 3.4. Surface morphologies using different rescanning strategies - Part 3/8

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-34
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content:
During the second time scanning of the same sintered layer,as drawn in Fig.14(c),a small part of the laser can penetrate the layer due to the sintered material,which created a coverture.From another part of the laser energy,a small portion can be absorbed by the heat exchange mechanism.Hence,most of the heat reflected out from the top surface of the layer by radiation.As a result,the upper part of the layer acquired much higher energy than the lower part of it. Eventually, the layer acquired relatively lower energy than single scanning.Nevertheless,the scanning speed was high ( $\mathrm { 1 0 0 0 m m } / s$ ）during the second time scanning to fabricate sample-IV-1, that provided low energy into the layer.Consequently,higher sintering occurred,with high viscosity of the melt pool. Therefore,the changes in the side surface are less than in the previous stage of the study.A few balling effects can be observed in this sample.At the top surface of this sample,a lot of droplet spattered particles are present,which were caused by the balling effect and, thus,droplet spattering occurred [3],as shown in Fig.13(a). The balling effect can produce bigger particles,and these particles can't get out from the melt pool due to a higher cohesive force and rapid solidification.The intertrack pores occur due to insufficient mantling and the lack of enough liquid flow against high viscosity and surface tension, which prevents the conjunction between two consecutive tracks. Moreover, some smooth bumpy zone can be observed, that developed by the material stacking. Somewhere,medium-sized wavy forms can be observed by the effect of fluctuation of the melt pool top surface,as depicted in Fig. 15(a).

![](images/1bfec6835e7468de8cdd130125098b7ad0bb5c271959bab72bc91e6aadd074b6.jpg)

summary: 3.4. Surface morphologies using different rescanning strategies - Part 4/8

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-35
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content: The fluid flow mechanism on the top surface of the melt pool, having different ED due to different combinations of laser power and scanning speed,has been illustrated in Fig.15.High scanning speed with low ED generates a high viscous melt pool [42]. Consequently,a limited surface tension difference occurred on the melt pool surface, that cannot contribute enough driving forces against viscous drags.As a result, the molten material cannot spread efficiently and, thus,a radius of curvature took place on the top surface of the melt pool [3],as shown in Fig.15(a). Hence,this caused a slightly rippled top surface in sampleIV-1 and sample-IV-2.Relatively higher ED and lower scanning speed reduced the viscosity of the melt pool. In this situation,higher surface tension develops in the rear part of the melt pool,while laser energy input departs by moving ahead [42].Consequently,the molten materials float towards the rear part of the melt pool from the center and evolve a stack zone [3],as presented in Fig.15(b),whereas,sample-IV2 and sample-IV-4 contain bumpy structures due to stacking.Though the ED was higher in sample-IV-4 compared to sample-IV-2,the laser power in sample-IV-4 was lower,which resulted in lesser melting and highly reduced viscosity [17]. The pores over the track-lines on the top surface of sample-IV-2 might arise due to collapsing of a small keyhole having high scanning speed and high viscosity [14].If compared to sample-IV-1，which was fabricated by applying a higher scanning speed,it can be said that the ED was not adequate to melt the layer well.
summary: 3.4. Surface morphologies using different rescanning strategies - Part 5/8

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-36
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content: Further lowering scanning speed and rising ED dropped the melt pool's viscosity [17].Thus,the molten material at the top surface of the melt pool got the perfect driving force to be flattened,as shown in Fig.15(c).Moreover, the scanning tracks wetted well with the adjacent tracks,along with their flatness.Accordingly, the top surface of sampleIV-3 became smooth,as shown in Fig.13(c). The top surface of sampleIV-5 had been fabricated near and below the scanning speed of sampleIV-3,and a little lower laser power,along with a litle higher track overlapping.As a result, the surface became almost as smooth as sample-IV-3,along with some staking of materials and droplet spattered particles.
summary: 3.4. Surface morphologies using different rescanning strategies - Part 6/8

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-37
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content:
Regressing to the vertical surface morphology of sample-IV-2,it can be noticed that it has many balls,as shown in Fig.l2(b) and Fig.14(e). This was affected by the balling effect caused by the comparatively lower viscosity of the molten material.The lower viscosity occurred due to the relatively lower scanning speed,which induced higher ED.Further lowering of scanning speed caused elevated ED for manufacturing sample-IV-3.At this stage,though the top surface of the layer melted well,the lower part of the layer had insufficient energy to wet the surrounding parts of the action zone.Moreover,the lower part of the melt pool in sample-IV-3 got higher energy compared to sample-IV-2. This molten metal got suficient driving forces against viscous drags, and, thus,created a bigger ball,as shown in Fig.14(d),than the previous scanning shown in Fig.14(a).The small balls had adhered powder particles and,additionally, they adhered by the big ball too.Lowering of scanning speed,along with constant laser power,raised the temperature high at the actioned zone.This caused a high cyclone in the gaseous zone that drove the powder particles to flow onto the melt pool surface and stick on it [37].This incidence increased the adhered powder particles in the vertical surface of sample-IV-3.Eventually, these phenomena create a surface with a complex architecture containing big and small balls,adhered powder particles,and some pores formed by them,as illustrated by the diagram in Fig.14(d) and SEM image in Fig.12(c).

fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content: The side surface morphology of sample-IV-4 regains almost the same morphologyof sample-IV-2.Though sample-IV-4 was fabricated with higher ED,as the laser power was much lower compared to the scanning speed, the lower part did not acquire sufficient energy.As a result,the lower part of the melt pool behaved as in sample-IV-2. Raising the laser power at sample-IV-5,dropped the viscosity of the lower part of the melt pool. Consequently,the molten material formed a lesser number of balls.
summary: 3.4. Surface morphologies using different rescanning strategies - Part 8/8

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-39
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content:
The research has been carried out in four stages,emphasizing the surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V alloy samples using several combinations of different laser processing parameters in the Selective Laser Melting process.The authors have experimented on three surfaces of every sample,respectively,the side surface,bottom surface,and top surface.Influences have been studied of the different energy densities, laser powers,scanning speeds,and hatch spacings.Furthermore,the rescanning process of each layer was performed to observe further plausible variations of surface characteristics.

The number of adhered powder particles reduced due to the lowering of scanning speed,as well as laser power.A previously unknown phenomenon was observed of microcracks initiated by the partially melted powder particles on the vertical surfaces of the specimens. Evidently,some microcracks in between the partially melted adhered powder particle and the melt pool were noticed on the vertical surface of some samples.They were caused by the difference in the shrinking rate between the solidifying melt and the solid powder particle. Different conditions of rescanning produced a wide range of surface architectures.The physical behaviors of materials during different laser processing parameters have been observed,analyzed and interpreted. Eventually,the viscosity of the melt pool and cooling timing are the key factors in regulating surface morphology.

![](images/b657b4ee21b2a6bef17de7ae657f7f60de39f61a83e185555839a9d51bb5a675.jpg)  
Fig5aoe study, (a) High scanning speed $\left( 1 0 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s \right)$ ,(b) Medium scanning speed $( 8 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s )$ ）(c) Low scanning speed( $( 6 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s )$

name: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in-part-40
fileName: 2020 - AM - Pal et al. - As-fabricated surface morphologies of Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by different laser processing parameters in.pdf
content:
Interestingly, the smoothest top surface was achieved by the same parameters as the roughest vertical surface when the rescanning strategy was applied.These outcomes were performed by the 75W laser power, $6 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ scanning speed, $3 0 ~ \%$ track overlapping and $6 5 J /$ $\mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ ED as the second time scanning while the layer was scanned previously by 55W laser power, $8 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ scanning speed, $3 0 ~ \%$ track overlapping and $3 6 \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { 3 }$ ED.

The nullification of defects and porosity from the parts fabricated by the Selective Laser Melting process is still a challenge,and the presented analysis can help engineers to select strategies to avoid these problems.

content:
Full Length Article

# High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal finite element analysis for Ti-6Al-4V
Emrecan Soylemez

partmentofechacalEngineering,stanulechicalUiversityumusuyu447,eyoglustanbul,

# ARTICLEINFO
Keywords: Additive manufacturing Selective laser melting Finite element analysis Deposition rate Defocused beam
summary: High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal finite element analysis for Ti-6Al-4V 前言

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-2
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content:
# ABSTRACT
Selective laser melting (SLM) is acommonly used powder bed fusion metal additive manufacturing (AM) process.Although SLM is preferred due to its near-net-shape partcommitment,the deposition rate of this proces is slower compared with alternative metal processes.A higher deposition rate of SLMcan be obtained by increasing the laser scanning velocity and laser power;however,this results in decreased part quality due to the SLM process's physical limits.This study presents the conditions for a higher deposition rate for various process parameters with defocused beams to eliminate the void defects due to keyholing formed in the melt pool. Single bead experiments were conducted,and the thresholds of the processparameters resulting in voids were identified.A melt pool depth-to-width ratio of O.85 was found to be a critical value for preventing voids in the process.The melt pool aspect ratio was related with the process parameters by using the normalized enthalpy and the volumetric energy density.The threshold values of the normalized enthalpy due to voids were independent from the beam diameters.Moreover,unstable single bead track thresholds were ploted asa function of the beam diameters.In addition to the experiments,a finite element analysis model was built with calibrated absorptivity and heat source parameters to predict the melt pool geometries for a wide range of process parameters (power $= 1 0 0 – 3 7 0 \mathrm { W }$ ,velocity $= 2 0 0 { - } 2 0 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,and beam diameter $= 1 0 0 { - } 2 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ ：

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-3
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content:
The metal additive manufacturing (AM) market has been growing due to the increase in parts that qualify for end use rather than prototyping in industries such as aerospace, biomedical,automotive,dental, and manufacturing.The powder bed fusion method dominates the AM market because it delivers high accuracy,precision,and mechanical properties of the selected metal alloy.Electron beam melting (EBM) and selective laser melting (SLM) are specific powder bed fusion methods that melt metal powder using electron and laser beams,respectively. Selective laser melting is more common than electron beam melting given the recent technological advances in lasers,expired intellectual property rights of the technique,cost reductions in electronic equipment,improved surface finish,wide range of material process ability, and smaller flow channels inside the part.However, SLM is limited due to the inherent nature of fusion physics.

Laser-beam-induced melting involves heat transfer,phase transition,beam energy-material interaction,surface-tension-induced melt pool motion,material vaporization and ejection,and chemical reactions [1]. Controlling these physical conditions through process parameters is essential for production quality.For example,temperature decreases radially from the focus of the beam,causinga surface tension difference in the melt pool and thus creating a mass flow from the center of the melt pool, titled the Marangoni effect [2].Another complex mechanism in the melt pool is “key holing,”and it appears when the metal rapidly evaporates under the beam region, resulting in a recoil pressure of the molten region causing further penetration toward the preceding layers [3].Moreover, the Bernoulli principle,Young-Laplace equation,capillary effects,and supercooling serve as additional mechanisms that can cause defects such as surface rippling,roughness, balling,and hump.

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-4
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content:
These defects create laser track instability,partial distortion,denudation zones,voids,microstructure variations,poor part density,and low mechanical strength. One approach for controlling part defects is to adjust process parameters [4].Process parameters are primarily beam power, beam diameter,beam velocity,hatch spacing,scanning strategy, powder properties,and temperature and environmental controls [5]. Determining the proper process parameters through validated experiments or process parameter maps [4] enables a desired track stability [6],fine microstructure [7],smooth surface topology [6],and targeted mechanical strength [8].Clymer et al.presented process design charts that can deliver the required part properties based on the data of the process maps of density,yield strength,surface finish,precision,and deposition rate [9].

The selective laser melting process's performance regarding the production speed can be evaluated based on the deposition rate [9,10],

$$
D R = t \times h \times \nu
$$

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-5
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content: Here, $t$ represents the powder layer thickness, $h$ represents the hatch spacing,and $\nu$ represents the laser beam scanning velocity. Tang et al. simulated successive overlapping of the melt pools without lack of fusion voids for the standard processing parameters,and they observed the optimal hatch spacing for the semicircular melt pool sections as approximately $h = 0 . 7 \times w i d t h$ [11].Increasing the layer thickness is a common approach for enhancing the deposition rate,while increasing the laser power is done to melt the larger volume.However,deeper melt pool formations can cause part defects.On the other hand,the hatch spacing size depends on the melt pool width and layer thickness, which are affected by process parameters.Alternatively,using multiple beams offers a production capacity increment,inwhich multiple beams simultaneously radiate on different locations of the same working plane to manufacture multiple parts [12].However,these systems remain within the limits of present process parameters when the production is assessed for each laser production zone.To improve melt pool control athigh power and speed, laser beam intensity distribution adjustment is a potential method for quickening the process.

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-6
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content: Collimated fiber laser beam energy distribution on the focused working plane follows Gaussian distribution.Its high intensity at the center evolves temperature gradients in the melt pool,and its low intensity at the periphery of the beam induces a lack of fusion [13]. Furthermore,a high power density at the center causes deep penetration or key holing due to re-melting the preceding layer in exchange for excessive energy.Recent developments in optics enable the adjustment of laser beam intensity distribution with flat-top,inverse Gaussian, hollow,and other non-conventional beam shapes.At the Fraunhofer Institute for Laser Technology (ILT),Buchbinder et al. [14] demonstrated specimen production with a flat-top $_ { 1 \mathrm { m m } }$ beam diameter at $6 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ and an $8 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / s$ build rate,resulting in $> 9 9 \%$ density. Another study conducted by Okunkova et al.[15] measured the experimental laser beam intensities and compared single bead experiments between Gaussian, flat-top,and inverse Gaussian distributions at scanning speeds of $1 0 { - } 1 0 0 \mathrm { m m / s e c }$ and laser powers at 30-150 W.They observed more uniform penetration depth and less powder particle ejection along the radius of the beam when using a flat-top distribution rather than a Gaussian distribution.Both outcomes are favorable in improving process quality.A subsequent study by Gusarov et al.[16] revealed similar results with extended power ranges up to $2 0 0 W$

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-7
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content: Defocusing the laser beam has a similar effect on the melt pool uniformity.Furthermore,it presents the benefits of high DR where the precision is not critical and moderate DR where the precision is significant, such as the outer surface of the part when shifting the focused laser beam diameter [17].Schleifenbaum et al.developed an SLM system that scans with a $_ { 1 \mathrm { m m } }$ beam diameter size at $6 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ up to a deposition rate of $8 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / s$ [17].Buchbinder et al. increased the build rate of AlSiloMgbya factor of four,witha beam diameter of $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and laser power of 1kW[14].Francis conducted single-track defocused beam experiments of SLM $( P = 8 0 { - } 3 7 0 \mathrm { W }$ $\nu = 4 5 0 – 2 5 5 0 \mathrm { m m } / s )$ and EBM $( P \ : = \ : 6 7 0 W$ $\nu = 9 0 { - } 3 7 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s )$ for Ti-6Al- $_ { 4 \mathrm { V } }$ [18]. He suggested a normalized spot size, $D / w ,$ threshold of1.0 to avoid keyholing. The deposition rates for nominal settings increased by $8 1 ~ \%$ while reducing porosity due to the focus offset [18].Shi et al. demonstrated improvements on the mechanical strength,density,and single-track stability of Ti-6Al-4V by increasing the laser beam diameter from $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ at $\mathrm { P } = 4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ and ${ \mathfrak { t } } = 2 0 0 \mu { \mathrm { m } }$ [19].Expanding the effects of the process parameters on the deposition rate of the complex parts can be obtained via computational models.

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-8
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content:
Numerical simulations have been used in the metal AM field to understand the physics of the process and to reduce the experimental cost and time.Detailed complex models are computationally expensive. Therefore,various simplified models can be employed based on the focused region of the process [2O,21]. Thermal models at the microscale resolution provide the temperature distributions to measure the melt pool sizes [22] and to predict the microstructure evolution due to the thermal cycle of the process [23].Thermal-flow models focus on melt pool liquid behavior for understanding the dominant mechanisms such as the Marangoni effect,recoil pressure on pore formation mechanisms,spattering,and denudation zones [24].Laser track formation as a function of laser power,speed,and powder density has been studied with the meso-scale model that considers the effects of the individual particles [25].Furthermore, thermo-mechanical models have been studied to predict the part distortions and residual stresses in the part scale [26-28]. Thermal models that focus on melt pool geometry predictions can be employed in part-scale models with multiple-scale approaches and adaptive meshing techniques.Therefore,accurate melt pool predicting models are critical in defining the optimal process parameters based on melt pool geometry and in developing a building strategy. The accuracy of thermal models has improved with details such as powder effects [29],element birth and death for layer adding [30], convection in the melt pool [27],and evaporation during laser interaction [31].However,the primary parameter that determines the model's power input is laser absorption efficiency.Based on this value, melt pool geometry is either over- or under-predicted.Most studies presume a constant coefficient in their models.Promoppatum et al. simulated melt pool geometry predictions in the range of 5O-4oo W at a velocity of $1 3 5 7 \mathrm { m m } / s$ for Ti-6Al-4V,demonstrating an adequate match of melt pool width simulation results compared with experimental ones [32].Missing experimental data of the melt pool depth can be explained by single-track experiments of Promoppatum et al.,which were conducted on the samples fabricated by SLM,in which crosssection images of the melt pool were not clearly distinguished. Zhang et al. proposed a model that used anisotropic conductivity properties and varying absorption [36].They studied Steel 17- 4PH with a $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ EOS M290 laser diameter at a power of 170-220 W and $\mathbf { v } = 6 0 0 { - } 1 3 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ .They derived linear functions for anisotropic conductivity properties and varying absorption with coefficients,which were calibrated based on the experimental melt pool results [36]. ![](images/c13e49a4b488fc0d7f8a839df2dd10d6aaed6edeffffa3cdf19a65d830f79df1.jpg) Fig.5.(a) Three-dimensional model geometry and mesh. name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-11
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content: In this article,single bead experiments were conducted of Ti-6Al-4 V ranging from 100 to $3 7 0 W$ with varying laser beam diameters such as $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ， $1 3 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $1 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $2 2 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $2 4 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,and $2 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .Melt pool cross-section micrographs were investigated,and thresholds of the void and unstable track forming volumetric energy density and normalized enthalpy values as a function of the beam diameters were found.Deposition rate improvements were presented as a function of the defocused beam in the process parameters range in which the investigated defects vanished. The FEA model was calibrated by adjusting the 3D heat source parameters and laser absorption efficiency to accurately predict the melt pool geometry.Thus,a reliable FEA model of Ti-6Al-4V was developed for SLM through the wide range of process parameters for numerous beam diameters.

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-12
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content: Single bead experiments were run by EOS M290 with a $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ peak continuous wave (cw) laser power at a wavelength of $1 0 6 0 \mathrm { n m }$ . A base square Ti-6Al-4V plate was used with a side length of $1 3 2 \mathrm { m m }$ and thickness of $5 \mathrm { m m }$ . It was ground to pass below a $5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ flatness. Nine conical holes along the edges and one conical hole in the middle were cut,and the plate was screwed on the EOS aluminum substrate $( 2 5 2 \mathrm { m m } \times 2 5 2 \mathrm { m m } \times 3 0 \mathrm { m m } )$ .Ti-6Al $. 4 \mathrm { V }$ powder was purchased from EOS. The ISO 13320-1 laser diffraction particle size analysis was operated using Shimadzu SALD-23oo laser diffraction particle size analyzer. The powder particles revealed a size distribution of $\mathrm { D } _ { 1 0 } = 2 5 \mu m$ ， $\mathrm { D } _ { 5 0 } = 3 8 \mu m$ ,and $\mathrm { D } _ { 9 0 } = 5 0 \mu m$ with a mean diameter of $4 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .Fortyfour different combinations of the laser power and velocity of the heat source,displayed in Fig.11 of ref.[37],were analyzed to reduce the number of combinations of defocused experimental process parameters to 16 by eliminating the high and low energy density single beads. Table l presents the power and velocity values of the single bead experiments.A $3 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ Ti-6Al-4 V powder layer was spread on the plate. Prior to the laser scanning,the ambient temperature was maintained at $3 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } ,$ ,and the oxygen concentration in the chamber was dropped to $<$ $0 . 1 ~ \%$ Defocused laser beam single bead experiments in $4 0 \mathrm { m m }$ length were conducted on the same plate with a spacing of $1 . 5 \mathrm { m m }$ between each line,and spacing between each group of defocused experimental lines were designed to be able to mount the cross section of each defocused single bead lines in one sample.

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-13
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content:
A defocused laser beam was obtained by shifting down the build plate from the focal plane of the FTheta lens with $4 1 0 \mathrm { m m }$ focal length. This shift causes the exposure of the divergent beams on the scan area and has been described as positive defocus [38]. Metelkova et al.compared the positive and negative defocused beam effects on the melt pool geometry,in which the laser beams were divergent and convergent, respectively [39]. They presented the significantly lower melt pool depth values of 316 L when the defocused beam was divergent, and compared this with a convergent laser [39]. Sixteen process parameter single bead experiments were performed for six different defocus distances (see Table 1). The calibration measurements of the Gaussian laser beam diameter for the different focus offset values were provided by EOS for the SLM M290 machine.Fig.1 illustrates the $9 5 \%$ transmission beam diameter $D$ with respect to the focus offset position.

Following the experiments,single bead morphology was examined under optical microscopy. Afterward, plates were cut using an electrical discharge machining (EDM) process in which three samples were collected from the center location of the single bead lines and $5 \mathrm { m m }$ from the center in either direction.These samples were mounted with Bakelite black by applying a hot mounting press.Next, the samples were sanded with 24O-grit sandpaper and 8oo-grit sandpaper.Then, the samples were polished with alumina, $9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ diamond, $1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ diamond, and $0 . 0 3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ colloidal silica,respectively.Finally,the samples were etched with Kroll's reagent etchant ( $\mathbf { \nabla } ^ { \circ 1 } \mathbf { m } \mathbf { l }$ water, $6 { \bmod { \mathrm { H N } } } 0 _ { 3 } ,$ and $3 \mathrm { m l }$ HF) for approximately $3 0 s$ to observe the melt pool area details under the optical microscope.

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-15
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content:
High-speed scanning velocity tends to form droplets [1],as displayed in Fig.3(a),due to low energy density. Similar section view exist for the humping regime in which humps and valleys formed along the scan track [4O]. Humping and balling conditions in this study was referred to the unstable track.If there is a semi-circular melt pool area,as in Fig.3(b),the conductive mode is believed to exist.A high energy density results in a keyhole-shaped melt pool,which could include void defects after cooling,as illustrated in Fig.3(c).Large voids due to the insufficient filling of the melt pool volume during solidification and small voids as a result of entrapped gas bubbles are the two main types of keyhole defects [41].The reasons for porosity are mainly voids in the powder,lack of fusion,un-melted powders,and keyhole defects.This study investigates the voids due to keyhole defects.Focus offsetting helps to evolve the keyhole geometry into semi-circular melt pool area shapes due to the increasing laser beam diameter on the scanned surface.

The results of the defocused beam single bead experiments confirmed this behavior.Fig.4 displays the melt pool area images of four different process parameters for all focus offset values presented in Table 1.As the beam diameter increases,the melt pool depth tends to become flatterand the depth/width decreases.Ata laser power of $1 5 0 \mathrm { W }$ and velocity of $2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,the keyhole-inherited void disappears at $D =$ $1 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,and the melting regime becomes conductive as the beam diameter increases.Similar behavior is observed for the process parameter combination of $2 5 0 \mathrm { W }$ and $2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ .For higher energy density,the keyhole void vanishes at $D = 2 2 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .The melt pool is semi-circular at

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-16
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content: $D = 1 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in the same row,as opposed to the larger and smaller beam diameters.Melt pool area of this line was expected to be in the form of a keyhole with a larger depth value.However, this could be the result of possible instability of the SLM machine (explained in ref.[37]).The third row in Fig.4 presents the images of the $3 7 0 W$ and $2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ single bead cross sections.A high energy density leads to the keyhole modes for all beam diameters. The larger depth value of $D = 1 6 0 { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ compared with most of the other cases could be interpreted by the melt pool depth fluctuation during the keyhole mode [42].The final row in Fig.4 does not differentiate the melt pool area images from one another.A low energy density of $2 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ and $8 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ might explain this behavior.Laser absorptivity is higher for large beam diameters at low power [35]; therefore,a lower energy intensity and higher absorptivity for larger beams results in similar melt pool areas for this specific 200 W and $8 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ case.

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-17
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content: A 3D FEA model was created to estimate the single bead melt pool geometry for various laser beam diameter cases.Autodesk Netfabb Local Simulation 2O18.2 software was used to conduct the FEA. However,the steps for model setup are not restricted to a specific software package.The simulation substrate size,as illustrated in Fig.5(a),was $4 . 2 \ : \mathrm { m m } \times 3 . 9 \ : \mathrm { m m } \times 4 \ : \mathrm { m m }$ in the $x , y ,$ and $\mathscr { z }$ directions, respectively.Large volume of the model was selected to be able to simulate any single bead simulation in the range of the EOs M290 system without interfering the boundary conditions and side effects of the model. In addition, a $3 0 \ \mu m$ top layer was added to define the powder layer.The powder material properties defined the powder elements. When the temperature of the powder element reached melting temperature,the element's material properties transformed into a solid structure due to an irreversible transformation from powder granules to the solid volume.The initial,ambient,and bottom face nodal temperatures were set to $3 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ 、The top surface of the model included radiative and convective heat losses (see Table 2).The remaining surfaces have the insulation conditions.To reduce computational time,the element's resolution was biased toward the middle of the $y$ axis,in which the laser source moved along that axis ina positive $x$ direction on the top face.The refined region element size was $1 6 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $8 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in $x , y ,$ and $\mathscr { z }$ axes,respectively.Refined region was set to $4 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ or $6 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in $\mathscr { z }$ axis based on the selected process parameters.Minimum allowable time increment was $6 . 7 \mu s$ 、Automatic time increment option was selected to set the beam movement as one radius length per each step.

FEA accuracy was first checked by running the simulations with constant material properties to compare the results with Rosenthal single point moving heat source [43] analytical calculations.Melt pool geometry was in agreement less than $5 \%$ deviation,and small variation was expected due to the distributed heat source in the FEA model. Mesh sizes were also iterated until the melt pool geometry deviated less than $2 \%$ ．After finalizing the FEA model details,melt pool steady-state temperature profile was obtained when the melt pool depth and width values deviated less than $4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in each step.Fig.5(b) illustrates the cross section in the $x - z$ plane where the melt pool tail and melt pool penetration can be examined.

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-22
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content: Another significant parameter in the simulations was the laser absorption efficiency.Heat absorption efficiency can alter due to powder size,powder bulk density, laser wavelength，and material composition.The powder absorptivity is higher due to the penetration of the incident light by multiple reflections of the powder surfaces [46]. Boley et al. measured metal flat surface and powder absorption efficiencies by exposing a $9 7 0 \mathrm { n m }$ wavelength laser limited to $5 0 \mathrm { W }$ cw laser power [47].Boley et al.presented O.4 and 0.74 absorption efficiency values of Ti-6Al-4 Valloy for a flat surface and the powder layer, respectively [47].Recent studies further demonstrate that absorption efficiency varies with laser power [34] and velocity [48].Absorption efficiency commonly increases as velocity decreases and power increases.Additionally,it increases with decreasing laser beam size [34,35].However,the increasing absorptivity can reverse in the low energy density regions in which the powder layer or rough surface becomes a smooth reflective surface due to the wetting of the beam interaction region [35].Therefore,in the simulations,the laser absorption effciency was set to a value based on the beam diameter,laser power,and velocity.To find accurate constant values for different combinations,the melt pool width and depth results were compared to the experimental values.The melt pool width and depth of the model were calculated by finding the corresponding melting point locations that causes the largest values from the top view and section view as in Fig.5(b),respectively. Simulations were iterated to settle the final values.
