name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-24
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content: Here, $a , b ;$ ,and care the parameters that define the volumetric ellipsoid. The local coordinates were represented by $x , y ,$ and $\mathscr { z } _ { : }$ and $P$ represents the laser power and $\eta$ the absorption efficiency.For the best representation of the moving melt pool,the power density distribution was parted out to O.7 and O.3 to the back and front of the heat source, respectively [51].In this study, $a$ and $^ { b }$ were kept constant at 1,as is applicable to a Gaussian heat distribution on the $x { - } y$ plane. The intensity variation of the heat source in the $\boldsymbol { \mathscr { z } }$ direction depends on the parameterc.This value was iterated as was performed also for the laser absorption efficiency value.Fig.7 displays the melt pool cross-section images of the simulation in addition to the experimental results.The red area corresponds to the molten area in the simulation,and the black dashed line represents the melt pool boundary result transferred from the optical microscope image of the experimental sample cross section. Fig.7(a) and (b) represent the $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $2 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ beam diameter results,respectively.Contour plot of the melt pool section appears with discontinuity at the boundary due to the post-processing algorithm in the software.In total,24 simulation models were fitted to the experimental results.To accurately predict the different cases,the absorption efficiency and c were second-order surface polynomial fitted using the curve fitting tool of Matlab R2018b. Six input parameters including power and velocity were used,and six target data of the absorption efficiency and $c$ were used for each $D$ value.Fittings were obtained with $R$ squared $^ { \textrm { \scriptsize = 1 } }$ . The input data and polynomial functions to predict the $\eta$ and c are available in the appendix.

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-25
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content: Fig.8(a) illustrates the melt pool depth for seven beam diameters. Each marker is equivalent to the average value of the measured melt pool depth of the three samples.The relative standard deviation changes from $1 \ \%$ to $6 5 \ \%$ .Keyhole mode typically causes the high deviations from the mean measured values.In Fig.8(a),different-colored plots correspond to six process parameters.All single bead results are not presented because the selected process parameters serve as a clear image of trends in the full range.As the beam diameter increases, the depth initially decreases ina linear fashion.Afterward,the decline in depth either stops or the declining slope decreases significantly. Green and orange lines reveal increments of the melt pool depth after a decrease,which is due to their high energy density in which keyhole mode fluctuations can be experienced.The melt pool width mean values,which deviate $2 0 ~ \%$ maximum from the mean,are displayed in Fig.8(b)as a function of the beam diameters for six different process parameters.The colored lines are parallel to one another.For higher energy density,higher width values are observed.However,beam diameter does not seem to affect the width values,as concluded similarly elsewhere [19].Furthermore,melt pool width and depth increase while power increases and velocity decreases,which is consistent with the literature [52].

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-26
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content:
To identify the thresholds of the stable process conditions,the melt pool aspect ratio $( d / w )$ was utilized.Approximately $d / w \geq 0 . 5$ corresponds to the keyhole melting mode transition [42,53].Keyhole mode is typically not preferred because it could cause void defects during solidification.When a stable keyhole develops,improved micro-structure and mechanical properties are possible compared with conductive mode [54].Furthermore,high deposition rates are possible in keyhole mode.Therefore,it would be useful to identify the threshold that causes the defects in the Ti-6Al-4V laser scanning process.Experimental data was used to correlate the volumetric energy density (VED) to the $d / w$

Volumetric energy density was used to define the thresholds of the melt pool stable regimes [54,55].

$$
V E D = \frac { P } { \nu \times D \times t }
$$

Results reflecting seven different beam diameters and 112 calculated values are provided in Fig. 9(a). Each marker type in the figure represents different beam diameter results,and hollow markers imply that the melt pool cross section has a void defect.The VED increases from approximately $2 5 { - } 6 0 0 \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { 3 }$ asaspect ratio increases from around O.2 to 2.6.Scattered data results from the different slopes of the aspect ratio increment for each beam diameter.As the beam diameter decreases,the aspect ratio increases.Based on the experimental observations,the aspect ratio $d / w = 0 . 8 5$ was found to be the threshold plotted as a horizontal dashed line in Fig.9 where the voids in the melt pool section images begin to appear.In addition, $V E D \ge 1 5 5 \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { 3 }$ also corresponds to the void defects appearance as indicated by the dashed vertical line in Fig. 9.

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-27
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content:
The experimental data was further employed to plot another figure useful in defining the thresholds.The normalized enthalpy derived in ref.[56] against the normalized depth by the beam diameter values were plotted [53],and this distinguished the keyhole threshold for the different beam diameters.Metelkova et al.also demonstrated the thresholds of the keyhole mode of $3 1 6 \mathrm { L }$ in the figures depicting normalized enthalpy versus normalized depth [39].The normalized enthalpy equation is given as follows [56]:

$$
{ \frac { \Delta H } { h _ { s } } } = { \frac { \eta P } { \pi h _ { s } \sqrt { \alpha \nu D ^ { 3 } } } }
$$

where $h _ { s }$ represents the enthalpy at melting point,and $\alpha$ represents the thermal diffusivity.Table 3 presents the constant values taken from ref. [57] of Ti-6Al- $_ { 4 \mathrm { V } }$ for calculating the normalized enthalpy. The absorption efficiency is assigned as O.5 even though it is not a constant value in reality.

The aspect ratios versus the normalized enthalpy are displayed in Fig.lO(a).This plot presents much less scattered data as opposed to the $d / w$ versus VED plot.The aspect ratio increases at a slope value of 0.35 as a function of normalized enthalpy.Fig.1O(b) zooms in on the lowervalue data points,which reveals that the region where the normalized enthalpy is lower than1 has a shallow slope.Moreover,Fig.1O suggests $\Delta H / h _ { s } \cong 2 . 1$ asa threshold for the stable scanning condition.After the threshold,void defects in the melt pool cross-sections begin to appear.

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-28
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content: Fig.11 clearly distinguish the effects of the beam diameter on the unstable or defective tracks.It illustrates the normalized enthalpy and volumetric energy density values of the thresholds where the void defects and unstable tracks begin.The solid blue line with circular marks corresponds to the minimum normalized enthalpy value at which the void defect is observed for the corresponding beam diameter.This line displays a horizontal trend,signifying that the threshold of the normalized enthalpy is independent from the beam diameters.The volumetric energy density increases as beam diameter increases,but on the other hand,the bead track stability drops non-linearly for both VED and $\Delta H / h _ { s }$ .Lower values of VED and $\Delta H / h _ { s }$ cause unstable tracks as beam diameter increases.

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-29
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content: After excluding the process parameters that led to defective results, the deposition rate performance of the defocused beams was displayed in Fig.l2.Fig.l2(a-c) present the deposition rates for the same process parameters and the defocused beams assumed at different thicknesses contributing the deposition rate.Fig.13 illustrates the deposition rate calculation for each case.Hatch spacing was used as the minimum melt pool width of three experimental measurements at the aimed depth $( 3 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ， $6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ，or $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ .Based on these varied layer thicknesses, Fig.12(a) reveals the maximum $D R$ value at $5 . 4 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / s$ ,with defocused $D = 1 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ at the highest power and velocity.If the machine is limited by 20o W laser power,the focused beam has the highest $3 . 3 \ \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / s$ building rate.At $6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ layer thickness, $2 0 0 W$ and $8 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ has a building rate of $5 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / s$ ,and $3 7 0 \mathrm { W }$ and $1 2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ deposits at 8.6 $\mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / s$ 、Fig.l2(c) displays bars that can deposit at a $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ layer thickness,and the maximum rate occurs when $\textit { D } = 1 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ at $3 7 0 \mathrm { W }$ and $8 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ as $1 0 . 7 ~ \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / s$ .The deposition rate results reveal that different beam diameters can be effective in depositing the layers at different process parameter combinations.Defective depositions can be fixed by beam diameter adjustment.As the layer thickness increases, either an alternative process parameter or the beam diameters for the successful depositions reduce,as observable in Fig.12(c).

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-30
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content: Experimental single bead trials for defocused beam scans enlighten the stable and defect-free regions of the process.However,different scan strategies,edge effects,and types of powder mixtures can cause variations in the melt pool sections.Thus,numerical modeling is critical.The results of the single bead FEA of the melt pool depth and width are illustrated in Figs.14 and 15,respectively. The results of six different process parameters for beam diameters of $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ， $1 3 0 \mu \mathrm { m } .$ $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m } .$ and $2 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ were compared to the experimental results.The simulation predictions are in close proximity to the experimental ones. The melt pool depth average error is $1 0 . 3 ~ \%$ Moreover,17 of 24 comparisons feature an error deviation less than $1 0 ~ \%$ ，High energy density combinations such as $3 7 0 \mathrm { W }$ and $4 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ cause larger melt pool depth values due to the lack of fine detail of melt pool physics in the simulations (see Fig.14).However,melt pool depth predictions of the simulations remain high,and this serves as a clear sign to not use that parameter to eliminate defective product manufacturing.Melt pool width comparisons perform with an average of $3 . 8 ~ \%$ error,and all are less than $1 0 \ \%$ .These results indicate that the proposed simulation setup,which includes a calibrated heat source with varying absorption values,is capable of accurately predicting the melt pool geometries in a wide range of process parameters with various laser beam diameters.

name: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi-part-31
fileName: 2020 - AM - Soylemez - High deposition rate approach of selective laser melting through defocused single bead experiments and thermal fi.pdf
content:
# 5.Conclusions
This work investigated the various process parameters of defocused single bead melt pool geometries to increase the deposition rate of Ti6Al-4V for the SLM process.The results indicated process parameters caused keyhole voids and unstable tracks.If the aspect ratio of the melt pool is greater than O.85,melt pool cross sections of the single beads begin to include void defects.A plot of VED versus $d / w$ or $\Delta H / h _ { s }$ versus $d / w$ reveals linear behavior that helps to identify the defects.Moreover, the thresholds of the keyhole void defects and the unstable tracks are described by the VED and $\Delta H / h _ { s }$ as a function of the $D$ The $\Delta H / h _ { s }$ value behaves independently from $D$ for the void defect threshold.After selecting the capable process parameters from the findings,higher deposition rates are achievable with larger beam diameters and thicker powder layers without causing defective voids at high power process parameters.However, $2 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ limited systems deposit at high rates with the focused beam of $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$

The FEA model predicts the melt pool geometry close to the experimental results by implementing the varying absorptivity and heat source geometry.Absorptivity and heat source geometry shaping parameter c are defined as a function of the power,velocity,and beam diameter.High deposition rates can be simulated for the complex geometries.FEA model can pick up the lack of fusion regions,and FEA model results can guide for changing the process parameters according to the location of the part geometry to increase the deposition rates. Multi layered simulation and experimental study that compares the results at different part of the geometry with defocused beam suggested here is recommended for future work.

# Declaration of Competing Interest
None.

summary: ABSTRACT, Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I: The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturing, and post-process conditions on the resulting microstructure and defects - Part 1/2

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-2
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content: Additive manufacturing provides an appealing means to process titanium alloy parts with new levels of conformability,complexity,and weight reduction.However,due to the heating/cooling ratesand heat transfer associated with directed energy source material procesing,the as-built AM parts contain unique material and microstructural features.In order to confidently manufacture fatigue critical additive manufactured (AM) Ti-6Al4V parts,a better understanding of the interrelationships between powder feedstock,AM processs,structure of the processed parts,their resulting mechanical properties,and their performance under realistic loadings is necessry.Part Iof this two-partcolection focuses on the powder-process-structure relationships and how powder feedstock,manufacturing,and post-processing conditions can affect the microstructure and defect features that ultimatelycontribute to the fatigue performance of Ti-6Al-4V parts.The material and physical phenomena inherent to the AM process of Ti-6Al-4Vare discussd in detail and related to the phase composition/structure,grain morphology,surface characteristics,defect size/distribution,and post-process treatments available for AM parts.This investigation is thefoundation for the structure-performance relationships that wil be discussed in detail in Part I.
summary: ABSTRACT, Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I: The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturing, and post-process conditions on the resulting microstructure and defects - Part 2/2

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-3
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content:
Additive manufacturing (AM),as opposed to traditional reductive manufacturing such as milling,turning and drilling,can build near-netshaped parts from the“bottom-up”ina layer-by-layer fashionas guided bya computer-aided drawing(CAD) model [1,2]. Machining and assembly steps can be eliminated through the use of AM,which can significantly reduce the fabrication and assembly time for complex Ti-6Al4V parts [3-5].AM can also be used to deposit new material atop damaged/worn components per user-designed profiles,enabling the repair of components that are otherwise too expensive or not feasible to replace [3-5]. The layer-wise nature of AM enables the production of parts with relatively complicated geometries,such as lattice-like metastructures [4] that were previously exceedingly expensive,if not impossible,to make.

AM technology is referred to using several different designations [3,6,7].Depending on the specific apparatus used, these technologies may be categorized according to the energy source including laser, electron beam,and plasma;and material feedstock form including powder bed,blown powder,and wire feeding [6].Despite these differences,AM technologies (excluding sintering) share the same basic methodology - a mobile melt pool is formed by a directed energy source,which performs line scans according to a predetermined CAD scan strategy. These line scans are repeated to consolidate a layer of solid material,and the part is then built incrementally layer-by-layer in a “bottom-up”fashion.The setup and operations of AM machines is covered in great detail by numerous reviews [8-11] and will not be reiterated in this work.

Titanium alloys such as Ti-6Al-4V are used extensively in the biomedical and aerospace industries due to their high strength,low density,biocompatibility,excellent corrosion resistance,and acceptable high temperature properties.They are a proven workhorse in a broad range of engineering applications,such as air frames,jet engines,biomedical devices,and chemical processing equipment [1O].Given the general good weldability of titanium alloys,they quickly became popular for AM processes.

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-5
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content:
The mechanical behavior of Ti-6Al-4V,like other alloys,is governed by its underlying microstructural characteristics.Pure titanium is allotropic, having a BCC crystal structure ( $\mathrm { . } \mathrm { | } \mathfrak { s }$ phase) at high temperature and an HCP crystal structure ( $\mathbf { \dot { a } }$ phase) when cooled below $8 8 2 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ .The $\mathsf { a } { - } \beta$ transformation temperature ( $\mathrm { B }$ -transus） is sensitive to chemical composition,and thus,alloying elements can be used to stabilize the $\alpha$ and/or $\beta$ phase in a desired temperature range [1O]. Commercial titanium alloys are categorized into three families based on their phase composition at service temperature: (1) $\alpha$ alloys and commercially pure titanium, (2) $\beta$ alloys,and (3) ${ \tt a } + { \tt \beta }$ dual phase alloys.The most widely used titanium alloy is Ti-6Al-4V,which is a ${ \mathfrak { a } } + { \mathfrak { \beta } }$ dual phase alloy.

During production from a melt, Ti-6Al-4V solidifies as $\beta$ phase then transitions to its ${ \tt a } + { \tt \beta }$ dual phase structure as it cools.If cooling rates are high enough,a martensitic transformation can occur,which produces an $\scriptstyle { \mathtt { a } } ^ { \prime }$ phase that is metastable at room temperature.This phase is common in laser processed additive manufactured (AM) Ti-6Al-4V. Both the $\alpha$ and $\mathbf { \Delta } \mathbf { a } ^ { \prime }$ phases nucleate and grow from phase boundaries, i.e. $\beta - \beta , \alpha - \beta$ ,and $\alpha ^ { \prime } \cdot \beta$ depending on the cooling rate.The morphology of the $\alpha$ and $\scriptstyle { \mathtt { a } } ^ { \prime }$ phases reflects the prior $\beta$ microstructure that existed at high temperature.The evidence of the prior high temperature $\beta$ structure in the room temperature microstructure is termed prior- $\beta$ microstructure.

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-6
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content: The unique characteristics of the AM heat source,i.e.its rapid movement,high intensity,and small size,bring challenges not encountered in traditional manufacturing.The prior $\beta$ microstructure of AM Ti-6Al-4V parts can be highly textured,with aligned elongated grains [8,l2-l4]. This can lead to a textured final $\alpha ^ { \prime } - \alpha \cdot \beta$ microstructure [12] and contributes to the anisotropic mechanical/fatigue properties [1O,15].Optimal AM build parameters generally favor the formation of elongated prior $\beta$ grains along,or at a certain angle to, the build direction [12,14,16]. The formation of these elongated prior- $\beta$ grains,combined with AM-driven epitaxial crystal growth,leads to the highly textured prior $\beta$ microstructure [3].

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-7
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content:
AM Ti-6Al-4V parts typically contain microscopic defects,such as gas entrapment and flat lack-of-fusion (LOF) defects [3,4,17-22]. Such defects can degrade fracture toughness and ductility under monotonic loading [12,18,19,21-33]. Under cyclic loading,pores and LOF defects can overshadow any effects of microstructure,substantially degrading the fatigue life by serving as crack initiation sites (CIS) [22,34-36].The LOF defects tend to be aligned perpendicular to the build direction.The presence of these LOF defects can result in strong anisotropy in the fatigue strengths of AM samples [22].Optimization of AM process parameters has been shown to be successful in reducing the defect size and population by reducing LOF defects [37].However,porosity, partially due to gas entrapment, still exists and reduces the fatigue strength of many AM materials. The presence of these gas entrapment pores in AM Ti-6Al-4V has significantly limited its use in fatigue critical applications and has driven recent research efforts to better understand the link between defects and mechanical behavior.Currently,much of the focus has been directed toward understanding the relationship between defect size and location on the resulting fatigue behavior [38]. To improve the mechanical properties and deal with the inherent defects, post-process treatments such as hot isostatic pressing (HIP) and traditional heat treatments or a combination of the two have proven necessary [39-43].These post-process treatments affect both the defect size and distribution as well as the final microstructure.

![](images/e0e502ff24146751d806d74ccec9f7c497f13088e70bda632a626a308b160f1b.jpg)

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-8
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content:
The characteristics of the defect populations and microstructure in AM Ti-6Al-4V are controlled by many factors,e.g.component size and geometry,build system/parameters,batch size,powder feedstock,and more.This,together with the sensitivity of defect and microstructure characteristics on these factors,makes prediction complex [8,13,44] and canlead to substantial variability between AMmachines,and even builds on the same machine in some cases [45].This motivates the quest to better understand microstructure and defect formation/evolution during AM part processing,as well as the inter-relationship between build process,microstructural characteristics,and part performance (process-structure-property).

This two-part review on the fatigue behavior of AM Ti-6Al-4V aims to better illuminate the powder-process-structure-property-performance (PPSPP) relationships that are critical to producing fatigue critical parts.Part Ireviews the physical aspects of the microstructure and defect evolution during the additive process,including post-processing, and centers on the process-structure portion of the overall PPSPP relation.This work lays the foundation for Part II, the review on the structure-property-performance relationships,with an emphasis on fatigue.While the review touches on aspects of many AM processes,a focus is given to powder bed fusion systems as they are the most prevalent in the literature and widely accepted across several industries [46].

fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content: Typical AM Ti-6Al-4V microstructures are shown in Fig.1.It can be seen that with post-processing heat treatment (HT) and/or HIP,microstructures similar to conventional wrought Ti-6Al-4V can be produced - such as the fully lamellar structure shown in Fig.la and duplex/bi-modal structure shown in Fig.1b.However,as discussed in later sections,HT schedules for AM parts often differ from the wellestablished wrought procedures.Without post-process treatments,the microstructure of as-built Ti-6Al-4V fabricated from electron beam powder bed fusion (EB-PBF) typically consists of a very fine Widmanstätten/basket weave structure (Fig.lc) due to the high cooling rates $( 1 0 ^ { 3 } \sim 1 0 ^ { 5 } \mathrm { K } / s$ [47]) combined with beam heated substrates $( \sim 9 7 0 \mathrm { K } ,$ higher than the decomposition temperature of martensitic phases) [28,29 32].Laser-based AM has even higher cooling rates $( 1 0 ^ { 4 } \sim 1 0 ^ { 6 } \mathrm { K } /$ s [47]) and build plates that are typically not heated to the extent of EBPBF processes,and therefore tends to produce martensitic structures [32,48],which contains ultra-fine acicular features (Fig.1d and e show typical $\scriptstyle { \mathtt { a } } ^ { \prime }$ martensite phase).An ultrafine Widmanstätten (Fig.1f) can also result from laser-based AM processes, since the repeated reheating during the fusion of subsequent layers may bring the part temperature above the martensite decomposition temperature [49 32].The microstructure of Ti-6Al-4V is determined by the specific thermal history that a region of AM material has experienced, namely the repeated meltingsolidification-reheating-cooling during the AM build and post-build heat treatment procedures.Below,a description of the continuous cooling behavior and the resulting phases of Ti-6Al-4V is provided for a broad range of cooling rates (from $0 .

content:

![](images/81c68261660fd7d402c31ca523d7bc8df824f05be4e19e471130aebba1eabf64.jpg)  
Fig.2.Schematic illustrations of phase transformation mechanisms during continuous cooling of Ti-6Al-4V from temperatures above $\beta$ -transus. Gray regions are $\beta$ phase,white regions are $\alpha$ phase in (a)-(e),the grain in (f) with thin,orthogonal lines denotes a fully martensitic grain (can be $\scriptstyle { \mathtt { a } } ^ { \prime }$ or $\alpha ^ { \prime \prime }$ while the black lines are $\beta$ grain boundaries.Note that only the phase transformation activity in the center grain is depicted in each subfig.for simplicity,although the surrounding grains experience the same phenomena.

Above the $\beta \cdot$ -transus temperature,Ti-6Al-4V is purely ina BCC $\beta$ phase (Fig. 2a). The grain size of the $\beta$ phase depends on the cooling rate from the liquidus to solidus temperatures.Nucleation-dominated solidification is favored under higher cooling rates and this results in smaller $\beta$ grain sizes,while grain growth dominated solidification is favored under lower cooling rates,resulting in larger $\beta$ grain sizes.

When Ti-6Al-4V is cooled from above the $\beta \cdot$ -transus temperature (1267K),the resulting phase compositions and structures depend mostly on cooling rate (Fig.2) [50,51] and prior $\beta$ grain size,which is discussed in more detail below.
summary: 2.1. Processing condition and phase compositions - Part 2/11

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-12
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content: As the temperature drops below the $\beta \cdot$ -transus temperature,the HCP $\alpha$ phase first nucleates and grows at/along grain boundaries and triple points of the $\beta$ phase schematically illustrated in Fig.2b.The length of the $\alpha$ phase that forms at the prior grain boundaries of the $\beta$ phase depends on its nucleation Vs growth rate and,to some extent, the size of the prior $\beta$ grain.The interface between $\alpha$ and $\beta$ phases is semi-coherent,i.e.it contains misfit dislocations.As cooling continues, the $\alpha$ phase nucleates and grows from the phase boundaries (Fig.2c),as well as directly from the $\beta$ grain boundaries (if it is not completely covered by grain boundary α). This $\alpha$ phase grows as a plate (lamella). In many cases,it occurs at a rate that perturbs the distribution of alloying elements such that neighboring plates are nucleated,leading toa lamellar structure of $\alpha$ and $\beta$ phases. Such structures are often referred to as colonies.
summary: 2.1. Processing condition and phase compositions - Part 3/11

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-13
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content: If the cooling rate is relatively low,the $\alpha$ colonies grow and meet the ones emanating from the opposite side of the $\beta$ grain, and a fully lamellar ${ \mathfrak { a } } + { \mathfrak { \beta } }$ microstructure is formed (Fig. 2d,Fig.la). In this case, the size of the colonies is governed by the prior $\beta$ grain size.At increased cooling rates,the tendency for nucleating new colonies increases,and colonies will nucleate from existing ones.This leads to a reduction in the average colony size.The resulting microstructure is often referred to as Widmanstatten or basket weave (Fig.2e),and is commonly observed in AM Ti-6Al-4V parts. Overall,higher cooling rates cause finer“weaving"; for example,the microstructure in Fig.1f (wire-fed laser deposition,faster cooling) is much finer than Fig.ld (electron beam melting,slower cooling) and contains inter-protruding $\alpha$ plates which indicate interrupted/poorly-developed $\alpha$ colonies due to rapid nucleation of $\alpha$ phase.During the $\beta \to \alpha + \beta$ phase transformation, the $\alpha$ and $\beta$ phase stabilizing elements,namely Al and $\mathrm { v }$ respectively,are redistributed into the respective phase.If Ti-6Al-4V is cooled ata sufficiently high rate,a total martensitic transformation is expected and pure $\scriptstyle { \mathtt { a } } ^ { \prime }$ or $\alpha ^ { \mathfrak { n } }$ ,ora combination of $\scriptstyle { \mathtt { a } } ^ { \prime }$ and $\boldsymbol { \alpha } ^ { \mathfrak { n } }$ phases,are expected as shown in Fig. 2f. The martensitic transformation process occurs without diffusion; and therefore,the resulting phases have the same composition as the parent $\beta$ phase. The $\mathbf { \Delta } \mathbf { a } ^ { \prime }$ phase has an HCP crystal structure, but with slightly different lattice parameters than $\alpha$ ,while the $\alpha ^ { \mathfrak { n } }$ phase has a face centered orthorhombic (FCO) crystal structure [52].
summary: 2.1. Processing condition and phase compositions - Part 4/11

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-14
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content:
A useful perspective of the Ti-6Al-4V phase composition is provided by the continuous cooling transformation (CCT) diagram.Fig.3 shows CCT diagrams generated by two groups,i.e. Sieniawski et al.[51] and Ahmed and Rack [5O].According to Sieniawski etal. [51] (phase field boundaries coded in reddish colors in Fig.3),when cooled from above the $\beta \cdot$ -transus temperature (such as after homogenization at $1 3 2 3 . 1 5 \mathrm { K }$ used ina typical HT,and at reheating after solidification during AM) at coolingrates below $1 . 5 \mathrm { K } / s$ ，the $\beta \to \alpha + \beta$ phase transformation starts at about $1 2 5 0 \mathrm { K }$ and finishes at $9 5 0 \mathrm { K }$

At cooling rates higher than $1 0 \mathrm { K } / s$ ，the $\beta \to \alpha ^ { \prime \prime }$ martensitic transformation becomes active.However,when cooling rates are below $1 2 0 \mathrm { K } / s$ ,the $\mathtt { a } ^ { \prime \prime }$ martensite is unstable and recovers to the ${ \mathfrak { a } } + { \mathfrak { \beta } }$ phase with continued cooling (phase field marked by dash dotted line in dark red).Microstructures such as fully lamellar and Widmanstätten can form for cooling rates below $1 2 0 \mathrm { K } / s$ 、At cooling rates higher than $1 2 0 \mathrm { K } / s$ ， $\beta \to \alpha ^ { \prime \prime }$ martensitic transformation (starts at $1 1 2 5 \mathrm { K }$ and finishes at looo K) takes over and the resulting phase is martensitic $\mathfrak { a } ^ { \prime \prime }$ It is worth mentioning that although the CCT diagram from Sieniawski et al. [51], suggests a pure $\beta \to \alpha ^ { \prime \prime }$ transformation, their accompanying works suggests both martensitic phases occur for Ti-6Al-4V i.e. $\beta $ $\alpha ^ { \prime } ( { \boldsymbol { \alpha } } ^ { \prime \prime } )$ .This agrees with a number of other works [32,50].
summary: 2.1. Processing condition and phase compositions - Part 5/11

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-15
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content: Ahmed and Rack [5O] suggest different phase transformation processes (phase boundaries and fields coded in bluish colors Fig.3) for cooling rates above $2 0 \mathrm { K } / s$ .At a cooling rate between $2 0 \mathrm { K } / s$ and $4 1 0 \mathrm { K } /$ s,the phase transformation is not purely martensitic $\beta \to \alpha ^ { \prime } ( \alpha ^ { \prime \prime } )$ or $\beta $ $\mathtt { a } ^ { \prime \prime }$ ,as suggested by Sieniawski et al.[51]. Instead, the transformation is $\beta  \alpha + \alpha ^ { \prime } + \alpha _ { \mathrm { { m } } } ^ { \prime }$ (light blue phase field in Fig.3),where $ { \mathbf { a } } _ { \mathrm { ~ m ~ } } ^ { \prime }$ isa massive phase,with an HCP crystal structure identical to $\mathbf { \Delta } \mathbf { a } ^ { \prime }$ phases. Cooling rates higher than $4 1 0 \mathrm { K } / s$ ,however,lead to $\beta \to \alpha ^ { \prime }$ martensitic transformation below $8 4 8 \mathrm { K }$ (in the cyan phase field in Fig.3) and a pure $\mathbf { \Delta } \mathbf { a } ^ { \prime }$ phase (such as shown in Figs.1d,e and 2f) as a result.This cooling rate,and the associated martensitic microstructure are often observed in laser beam powder bed fusion (LB-PBF) processes.
summary: 2.1. Processing condition and phase compositions - Part 6/11

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-16
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content: The martensitic phases ( $\mathbf { \tilde { \rho } } _ { a ^ { \prime } , }$ and $\alpha ^ { \prime \prime }$ ）and the massive phase $\left( \alpha _ { \mathrm { ~ m ~ } } ^ { \prime } \right)$ formed due to the fast cooling rates are meta-stable and decompose upon reheating [32].The $\mathbf { \Delta } \mathbf { a } ^ { \prime }$ phase decomposes upon reheating at temperatures as low as $6 7 3 \mathrm { K }$ [32]. This suggests that a stress relieving HT,if performed above $6 7 3 \mathrm { K } ,$ decomposes the $\mathbf { \Delta } \mathbf { a } ^ { \prime }$ martensite easily. The decomposition can also be achieved in situ during laser AM when previously deposited layers are repeatedly reheated and more slowly cooled due to the deposit of successive layers,as shown by Xu et al. [32].Accordingly,an increased power density favors the decomposition of the $\scriptstyle { \mathtt { a } } ^ { \prime }$ martensite during laser AM processes in that previously deposited layers will be more likely to experience slow cooling from above the martensite decomposition temperature.In EBM AM processes,the build chamber is evacuated and the powder bed can be held at an ambient temperature above the martensite decomposition temperature and slowly cooled at the finish of the build,leading to consistent ${ \mathfrak { a } } + { \mathfrak { \beta } }$ phase structure [28,29].
summary: 2.1. Processing condition and phase compositions - Part 7/11

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-17
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content:
The crystallographic orientation relation between the HCP $\alpha$ and BCC $\beta$ phases strictly follows the Burgers relationship of $[ 1 \bar { 1 } 1 ] _ { \beta } / / [ 1 1 \bar { 2 } 0 ] _ { \alpha }$ and $( 1 1 0 ) _ { \beta } / / ( 0 0 0 2 ) _ { \alpha }$ ,as shown in Fig. 4 [10]. The $\alpha$ plates are always parallel to the (il2) planes of the $\beta$ matrix and the(i1oo) planes of the $\alpha$ phase. Since a BCC lattice has twelve independent $\{ 1 1 2 \}$ planes, there are twelve possible variants in the $\alpha$ -colony orientation inside a single prior $\beta$ grain.In addition,lattce strain is associated with the $\beta \to \alpha + \beta$ transformation. The lattice constant for the $\beta$ phase is $a _ { \mathrm { \ B } } = 3 . 3 2 { \mathring { \mathrm { A } } } ,$ and $a _ { \alpha } = 2 . 9 5 \mathring \mathrm { A }$ and $c _ { \alpha } = 4 . 6 8 \mathring \mathrm { A }$ for the $\alpha$ phase.The atomic volumes for the two phases are $\Omega _ { \mathrm { { \beta } } } = 1 7 . 6 4 \mathring { \mathrm { A } } ^ { 3 }$ and $\Omega _ { \alpha } = 1 8 . 3 0 \mathring { \mathsf { A } } ^ { 3 }$ ，which corresponds to a volumetric strain of $3 . 6 \%$ . The $\beta$ to $\alpha$ transformation stain is anisotropic with strains of $2 . 5 \%$ in the $[ 1 \bar { 1 } 1 ] _ { \beta }$ direction, $- 0 . 3 \%$ in the $[ 1 1 0 ] _ { \beta }$ direction,and $6 \%$ in the $[ \bar { 1 } 1 2 ] _ { \beta }$ direction.To minimize the overall strain energy associated with the $\beta \to \mathsf { \alpha } + \mathsf { \beta }$ phase transformation, the orientation of the $\alpha$ colonies tend to be“randomized".As a result, the population of $\alpha$ colonies in each orientation is roughly equal in a prior $\beta$ grain.

The Widmanstätten structure,schematically shown in Figs. 2c, d and 3e,is perhaps the most commonly observed microstructure in EBM
summary: 2.1. Processing condition and phase compositions - Part 8/11

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-18
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content:

Fig.3.Continuous cooling transformation (CCT) diagram for Ti-6Al-4V from above $\beta$ -transus temperature to $5 0 0 \mathrm { K }$ and showing the $\mathtt { \Gamma } \mathtt { q } ^ { \prime \prime }$ (blue) and $\mathbf { \Delta } \mathbf { a } ^ { \prime }$ (cyan) regions according to Refs.[5O,51].(For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend,the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

![](images/dcd9368f82880ae370a9121aabd9061d266157cd617ca0999b77ed4a913b99f8.jpg)  
Fig.4.Schematic illustration of the crystallographic orientation relation between α and $\beta ;$ image recreated based on Ref.[iO]. The BCC $\beta$ lattice is represented by blue atoms,while the HCP $\alpha$ lattice is represented by red atoms. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend,the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

Ti-6Al-4V while the martensitic microstructure is mostly observed in LB-PBF Ti-6Al-4V.As previously discussed,the orientation of the $\alpha$ colonies/plates,although seemingly random, is well-defined and along any of the twelve $\{ 1 1 2 \}$ family planes in the prior $\beta$ grain. The $\{ 1 1 2 \}$ planes always form certain angles with respect to each other,i.e. $3 3 . 6 ^ { \circ }$ $4 8 . 2 ^ { \circ }$ ${ { 6 0 } ^ { \circ } }$ $7 0 . 5 ^ { \circ }$ and $8 0 . 4 ^ { \circ }$ Fig.5a shows three {112} planes,namely (112),(i12) and(li2),as examples.Depending on the cuting plane, the trace of these three planes may form triangles with different angles.It is therefore very common to observe triangular patterns in very fine Widmanstätten microstructures.Fig.5b-d show such patterns,marked by dashed lines,obtained from different studies.Note that the triangles have different angles due to the orientation of the $\alpha$ plates and the polishing planes.
summary: 2.1. Processing condition and phase compositions - Part 9/11

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-19
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content:
This subsection has shown that the phase composition and structure of an AM Ti-6Al-4V part is dependent on its experienced thermal history,including initial cooling，and subsequent in-build reheating/ cooling and annealing (such as one experienced with heated build plates). The phase structure ranges,in a decreasing order with cooling rate,from martensite（ $\acute { \alpha }$ and/or $\alpha ^ { \prime \prime } )$ ，fine Widmanstätten $( \alpha + \beta )$ coarse Widmanstätten,to fully lamellar $( \alpha + \beta )$ .The martensite is metastable and is subject to decomposition due to the repeated reheating during AM process.For ${ \tt a } + { \tt \beta }$ microstructures,the thickness of individual α plates,as well as the size of the α colonies,decrease with increasing cooling rate.As will be discussed in Part I, these dimensions of the $\alpha$ colonies may affect the tensile and fatigue strengths of the Ti6Al-4V parts,and are of critical relevance.

Many factors have been found to affect the cooling rate during AM. For instance,as was mentioned earlier,the EBM AM technologies have much higher ambient temperature compared to laser AM technologies, sometimes as high as $0 . 5 \mathrm { T _ { m } }$ ,leading to much lower cooling rates,as evidenced by much coarser Widmanstätten structures [28,29,52,53].It has been shown [32] that for LB-PBF,by varying the processing parameters,such as powder feed rate,scanning speed and laser power, cooling rates and the corresponding coarseness in phase structures can be controlled to some degree.In addition,the geometry of the build affects the cooling rate.
summary: 2.1. Processing condition and phase compositions - Part 10/11

name: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi-part-20
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Fatigue - Pegues et al. - Fatigue of additive manufactured Ti-6Al-4V, Part I The effects of powder feedstock, manufacturi.pdf
content:
Even within the same build,the cooling rate may be very different depending on the local geometry.For instance,when the heat source is near the surfaces,the mass of material available to conduct heat away from the source can be much less than that in the bulk.It is well demonstrated [32] that if the location is thicker or connected to effective heat sinks,higher cooling rate is induced,vice versa.The last factor, among others,is the batch size,i.e.the number of parts being built simultaneously.Larger batch size means longer inter-layer time interval (dwell time) for the part to cool down between each deposited layers, leading to much higher cooling rates and much finer $\alpha$ plates or martensitic transformation [44].

![](images/5c705777542b7fa8c13a5f225e11aacd58c00789989708fe803567aefedfb820.jpg)
