name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-3
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content: In this paper,we propose a model to predict the average surface roughness $( S _ { \mathrm { a } } )$ and analyse the effect of related process parameters on laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) selective laser melting (SLM)of Ti-6Al-4V.The additive manufacturing (AM) process has various independent parameters that affect the quality of the produced parts and is complex to analyse.Although the process parameters can be selected separately in LPBF,they do however affect ach other.Therefore,large adjustments of process parameters is not possble due to the negative effect they have on each other which can lead to problems such as cracks,baling,unmelted powders,porosity,and distortion.A range of process parameters using Taguchi L25 design of experiment (DOE) with five repetitions for each sample has been selected.Then,anartificial neural network (ANN) is applied to the model to predict the value of (arithmetical mean height)/(average surface roughness) $( S _ { \mathrm { a } } )$ . The selected processing parameters are laser power,scan speed, hatch spacing,laser patern increment angle,and heat treatment (HT) condition.The present work revolves around ANN modeling and using a wide parameter range and a large number of test samples under ASTM standards as well as adding HT to the DOE to analyse the simultaneous effect of HTand changing process parameters on surface characteristics.A large and precise data set with high generality and reliability obtained by 3750 profilometries on 125 samples.The contribution of this paper is using ANNas an accurate tool in surface modelingand characterizing the efective parameters on the surface ofLPBF parts.The existence phenomena and governing factors were explained by introducing new parametric mechanisms in rheology of melting pool.In AMof metals,the variation of average roughnessin overlapof hatches can be 5-7 times higher than the centre of the track.

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-4
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content: Therefore, $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ was selected to have consistency in the measured roughness values. Results showed heat treatment above beta phase transus leads toa local flow of material at the surface causing an increase of $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ .The ranking of influential factors on $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ from the highest to the lowest was found to be: heat treatment $>$ laser power $>$ scan pattern angle $>$ hatch space $>$ scan speed.

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-5
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
Ti-6Al-4V is one of the most common titanium alloys with particular properties such as high specific strength,excellent corrosion resistance and good fatigue resistance.These properties characterize it as one of the best materials for lightweight and high strength components used in aerospace and biomedical applications.Surface quality and dimensional accuracy are among the critical factors in manufacturing for such applications,especially for parts which are assembled in multi-component systems.Selective laser melting (SLM) is additive manufacturing (AM) technology,sub-classified as in laser powder bed fusion (LPBF),that generates poor surface quality,often making it necessary to carry out further post-processing and metal cutting[1-3].

During LPBF,a few defects may occur with negative effects on the process and surface quality of the produced parts. Porosity is a wellknown problem in AM of metals [4],generally referring to pores created during laser material processing which are mostly classified into two types: keyhole and balling. Keyholes generally occur when a huge amount of energy is focused on a small area resulting in the formation of a melt pool which is narrow and deep.Gasses trapped in this region form aclassical keyhole shaped void [5,6].Semak andMatsunawa[7] found that balling defects in laser material processing were mainly created due to the high flow of fluids in the melt pool that is affected by temperature and surface tension.Teng et al. [8] reviewed the occurrence of defects in the laser melting process and how it can be modelled.A literature survey of thermal modelling in metal laser sintering shows the development of various models by combining material thermal nonlinearity, latent heat, laser heat source distribution and (interaction between) the laser beam and powder bed,leading to the generation of various surface qualities [9].

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-6
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content: Powder characteristics and process parameters are key factors affecting surface quality during the LPBF process.The connections between the foremost LPBF parameters (laser control thickness,scanning speed, and layer thickness),properties of the powder and geometrical attributes of single tracks have been investigated by Yadroitsev [1O].This investigation shows smaller particles can fill small voids between larger powder particles and improve density and surface quality. Finer particles provide a larger surface area and absorb more laser energy, thus generating bigger melting pools and improving surface quality. The surface quality of SLM CoCrMo parts has been shown to be affected by process parameters. Single layer analyses on surface quality were carried out to identify optimum input parameters.For the manufacture of parts with a smooth surface,the scan space should be kept low.Also during the melting process,surface tension affects the roughness [11,12]. The particle size and distribution was also shown to change the surface quality of LPBF parts. Processing of powders with coarser particles results in higher porosity and a rougher surface [13-15].By increasing the scan speed,balling was observed due to low wettability,reduced contact between substrate and melt,and Rayleigh instability. Large overlap occurs with low hatch spacing,which increases the roughness of the surface [16].Thijs et al.[17] assumed that the formation of pores in a Ti and Al-based alloy is associated with powder deposited around the melt pool within a layer and an accumulation of the surface roughness across the layers and also the formation of keyholes.These phenomena were therefore thought to affect surface roughness and decrease the value of $\mathrm { R _ { a } }$ and surface quality of produced parts [18].

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-7
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content: The size of droplets in the balling region tended to increase with increasing laser power and decreasing scan speeds and a large softening area was identified which changed the surface quality of 24-carat gold.In this investigation, the vast majority of the porosity was observed to be between two subsequent layers [19].Colignano etal.[2O] showed the choice of parameters of the STL file changes the accuracy and dimensional deviations without creating too many triangles.This can improve the design and increase the speed of the process.

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-8
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content: In order to observe the contour profile of the melt pool with respect to the scan types,LPBF parts were fabricated with various hatch spacing while keeping other process parameters constant. Controlling and optimization of the process parameters and modification of the initial design are key factors in the tailoring the surface quality of AM parts. For instance,the scan speed is directly proportional to a physical density where it reaches a maximum at higher scan speeds for the same energy density.However, increasing the scan speed reduces the surface quality of the parts.Therefore,it is necessary to optimize the process parameters in order to achieve a high-density material with good surface quality.However,the optimization of process parameters is not an easy task as most of the materials exhibit different conductivity and reflectivity [16,21-25]. Savalani et al.[26] showed that a preheating process improves the surface of magnesium parts used in bio-implant applications.This isalso shown for Ti-6Al-4V parts made by SLMwhere the numerical response surface (RSM) revealed that surface roughness and microstructure are greatly associated with process parameters and preheating.However, preheating has a lower impact on microstructure compared to scan speed [27]. Using larger powers slightly decreases the surface roughness by reducing the formation of balling and increasing wettability of the melt pool [28,29].A fractional design approach [30] has been proposed to improve the surface quality when a complex objective function exists and by optimizing process parameters in SLM of steel $1 7 { - } 4 \mathrm { P H }$ to improve surface quality. Surface properties of the parts fabricated by LPBF highly depend on each single laser-liquefied track and every single layer,and additionally the quality of the interaction between them.

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-9
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
The most common ways to deal with the issue of dimensional accuracy and surface qualityis by experimental models,by means of design of experiment,ANN and analyse of vriance (ANOVA) and different optimization methods [31].To model and predict the effect of process parameters on part quality various approaches such AI-based methods are available.Our previous research showed that ANN exhibit the potential to predict and analyze the effect of process parameters on density with high accuracy [32].To optimize the density,shape,dimensional accuracy and surface quality of LPBF parts,utilization of laser surface re-melting (LSR) has been suggested [33,34]. Post-processing such as metal cutting,ball-pinning and laser or electron beam remelting are suggested to solve the mechanical and surface problems of PBF parts [12,35-38].

All discussed methods to analyse the LPBF process are highly reliant on the accuracy of transfer functions that is related to the number of test sets.Usinga small number of test specimens due to the cost of each experiment results in generating low accuracy of the presented models. Also,in the reviewed investigations the average roughness was reported which can vary significantly between two subsequent measurements and is associated with the place of measurement (e.g.in overlap regions or at the center of the hatches).

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-10
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content: Therefore,in this research to obtain more accurate results,an artificial neural network (ANN) is used to model, predict and analyse the effective parameters in the LPBF process.In this work,based on Taguchi L25,samples were printed with different process and post-process parameters including laser power (LP),scan speed (SS),hatch space (HS), pattern angle (PA) and heat treatment (HT).Then surfaces were investigated using non-contact propfilometry method and the results were used in an ANN method to develop a predictive model for process parameters.Analysing the interaction of each parameter revealed the ranking of influential factors on average surface.The existence phenomena are drawn by introducing the rheological mechanisms of the melting pool.

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-11
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
# 2.1.Powder material and LPBF operation
An SLM Solutions 125HL LPBF machine with maximum laser power 200 W equipped with a YLR-Fiber-Laser and minimum spot size $5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ was used.Fig.1(A) illustrates spherical Ti-6Al-4V powder used for this research.In order to achieve samples with high density,a meander scanning pattern with an incremental angle change in every layer has been used to print dog-bone samples based on ASTME8-E8Mstandard for further works.Fig.1 (B,C) shows the CAM process,(D) shows the powder particle size distribution and (E) Meander scanning pattern.

Table 1 shows the LPBF parameters and specifications which kept constant based on original equipment manufacturer (OEM) recommendations

content:
To decrease the number and cost of the experiments without significant loss in accuracy the Taguchi method with orthogonal array was selected.Factors in each column needs to be analysed independently and therefore the number of replications in each column is balanced. In this case,the design is stated as orthogonal. Three important factors affecting energy density including laser power,scan speed and hatch space were selected.To determine the effect of the laser scanning patternangle in every two subsequent layers, this factor also added to DOE. In order to determine the effect of heat treatment on the results different temperatures were added to DOE to allow simultaneous analyse of process and post process parameters.Table 2 shows the DOE and selected parameters for each factor,based around the default manufacturer's recommendations. name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-15
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
# 3.Surface roughness measurement
An optical profilometer (Alicona Infinite Focus) equipped with $^ { 5 - }$ $1 0 0 \times$ objective lenses was used for scanning the printed samples and surface roughness measurement to investigate the surface characteristics.For all conditions,five different areas of the topmost surface,each with $1 0 \times 5 \mathrm { m m }$ size and containing 8oo points,were scanned according to the standard requirements.The average roughness of the as-built samples generally shows significant fluctuations (sometimes as high as 20 fold) due to surface defects such as balling,residual powder,trapping gas under melt pool,evaporation and boiling [27].To have a consistent and comprehensive analysis for average surface $( S _ { \mathrm { a } } )$ Eq. (1) was used.

$$
\displaystyle { S _ { a } = \frac { 1 } { M N } \sum _ { J = 1 } ^ { N } \sum _ { i = 1 } ^ { M } \left| \eta \left( { x } _ { i } { / } _ { y _ { j } } \right) \right| }
$$

where $M$ and $N$ are the numbers of scanned measurement points in X and Y directions.Normalized value of surface parameters was measured by the profilometer based on ISO 4288 and high pass Gaussian filter (ISO 11056).

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-16
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
# 4.Analysing the obtained data from DOE
To validate the accuracy and the trend of the obtained data,signalto-noise (SN) ratio needs to be calculated based on the Taguchi SN relationship.Generally,signal-to-noise shows the ratio of signal or the obtained values to the noise (errors). This criterion shows the accuracy and performance of the measurement in each experiment. In the production of LPBF parts,one of the problems for as-built samples is low surface quality so improving the roughness is a goal.Therefore,the criteria‘smaller is better'was adjusted in such a way to minimize the average surface.When different levels of each factor influence the response contrarily‘main effect' becomes an important statistical factor [43].In this case,horizontal lines show less‘main effect'and vertical lines are representative of sharper effects of each input on each output.The analysis of‘main effect'and SN is shown in Fig.2.If the lowest value in‘main effect'plots are equal to the highest values in SN plots,the designed experiment and obtained data are correct.In other words,the trend of mean values should be reverse of signal-to-noise diagrams which are related to the criteria of the smaller is better $( \mathsf { S } / N = - 1 0 ^ { * } \mathrm { l o g } ( \Sigma ( \mathrm { Y } ^ { 2 } ) / \mathrm { n } ) )$ As it can be seen in Fig.2 the‘main effect'and SN plots show the trend of this experiment is correct and no significant noise and problems were observed.

Different methods can be applied to model and optimize the process parameters on mechanical properties and surface quality of PBF parts. For instance,artificial intelligence (AI) based methods or mathematically based modeling such as Gaussian process-based surrogate modeling [44-46]. In this research, based on our previous experiments and subsequent performance of AI,we used ANNs to model the process.

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-17
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
Artificial neural networks (ANNs) are numerical approach models stimulated by the behavior of biological systems.This tool can draw logical relationships between inputs and outputs in multi-dimensional space and are used to predict,model and analyse the contribution of each input to the obtained results.Moreover, this tool can show the interaction of different parameters on the results and explain the linear and non-linear behavior of input parameters on outputs [47-49]. ANNs are based on three stages; train,test and recall/validation.In this method initial parameters such as momentums and weights are tuned in training and to solve the problem of falling into localized errors/traps, a test stage is necessary.Process validation is carried out in the recall stage.Multi-layer perceptron (MLP) ANN is the proper tool for modelling and prediction of an industrial process (such as AM) when the inputs and outputs are not linearly separable combinations of each other.

The Qnet program was used to model the process and post process parameters.This software has the capability to show the interaction of parameters on the modeled results. In this research process parameters ofAM including LP,SS,HS,PA and the post-process parameter that was HT were selected as input parameters and $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ was selected as an output. With AM the outputs are not linearly separable combinations of inputs and therefore we used an MLP neural network.The best results were obtained by using a 5-layer network $5 \times 4 \times 3 \times 2 \times 1$ with Sigmoid transfer function between layers and 5o,ooo iterations.To train and test the network 17 and 3 datasets have been used respectively,and the remaining 5 datasets were used in the recall process.The fitting procedure for MLP neural networks is shown in the Appendix.

Table 4 Results of the cross-validation.

content:
# 4.2. Cross-validation To verify each model,cross-validation/rotation is one of the best solutions that evaluates how the results of the statistical computation will generalize to an independent data set. Cross-validation was carried out five times in our experiment.In each cross-validation, five samples were used froma DOE list with equal dispersion.Therefore,statistically, all tests were used in both training,test and recall steps which provide a general and comprehensive model for average roughness prediction. The data set was quite independent for both Train $^ +$ Test and recall. Table 4 shows that the correlation of the training, test/validation,and recall for all cross-validations were higher than $9 5 . 2 7 6 \%$ and proved that the designed network is applicable for function approximation in this study. Fig.Al (appendix) illustrates the target values (experimental measurements) and network outputs for training,test,and recall in each cross-validation.As shown in Fig.A1 (A,C,E,G and I) the designed network is well trained regarding the prediction of values and the trend in the average surface.Fig.Al (B,D,F,H and J) shows the potential of the trained network in the prediction of the values and the trend of average roughness in the recall/validation process.Fig.3 shows the results of all cross-validations for recalls (five cross-validations each including five values).In all five cross-validations,the designed network followed the experimental measurements thus proving the accuracy and performance of the network. name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-20
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
# 5.1.Average contribution of input nodes on outputs using ANN and analyse of variance (ANOVA)
To determine the most effective process parameters on the average surface an interrogator analysis using the proposed ANN was carried out.Moreover,to prove this procedure ANOVA analyses were performed and the most effective parameters on the alternation of the average surface were determined.The average contribution of input nodes on outputs Was obtained from ANN analysis and ANOVA.In ANOVA,based on standard procedures,the probability value of O.O5 was selected to determine the effective parameters.A small p-value (typically $\leq 0 . 0 5 )$ shows influential evidence against the null hypothesis.It means the smaller P-Values the strongest effect on the obtained results.Fig.4 and Table 5 provided a ranking of the most influential parameters on the average surface from highest to lowest: heat treatment $>$ laser power $>$ scan pattern angle $>$ hatch space $>$ scan speed.

# 5.2. Interaction of process parameters on outputs using ANN
The main categories of parameters that affect surface quality during LPBF are (I) pre-process parameters such as particle distribution,powdersize,substrate temperature and LPBF chamber characteristics (contamination);(II) process parameters like laser power,scan speed,hatch space,laser increment pattern angle,layer thickness,point distance and scanning strategy; and (III) post-processing such as heat treatment, finishing and metal cutting[13].In this section, the interaction and effect of each two process parameters on the average surface and related mechanisms have been discussed based on parametric rheological relations.
summary: 5.1.Average contribution of input nodes on outputs using ANN and analyse of variance (ANOVA), 5.2. Interaction of process parameters on outputs using ANN

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-21
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
Heat treatment was found to be the most effective parameter on the average surface,proven by the average contribution of input nodes on outputs using ANN and ANOVA.However,no significant changes occurred in the surface roughness of the samples before annealing at $6 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ Therefore in Fig.5,the interaction of surface roughness is only shown for the heat treated samples.Increasing HT temperature leads to increasing the value of average roughness when observing the interaction of LP and HT.This trend was also observed when analyzing the interaction of HT and SS,HS and PA. The microstructure of the asbuilt PBF samples has a small grain size which is associated with a high cooling rate $( 1 0 ^ { 3 } – 1 0 ^ { 8 } \mathrm { K } s ^ { - 1 } )$ [50-52]. In PBF,phase constitution and microstructure are highly related to the scanning pattern used for the laser. In this work a meander pattern has been used and,due to temperature elevation and high cooling rate formation of $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ martensite,was found in consistent with the privious studies e.g.[53-55].Alpha heat treatment has no significant effect on the $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ value due to the fact that no thermal softening occurs at temperatures below beta transus temperature [56].

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-22
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content: The typical surface topography of the samples heat treated at different temperatures is shown in Fig.6.As can be seen, the characteristics of the surfaces heat treated at $9 2 5 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ and $1 0 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ are quite different.For the samples heat treated atlower temperatures,the surfaces look smooth but containing bulges where highlighted in Fig.6 as defects.The formation of the bulge defects can be related to the nature of the AM process.In our previous studies,it was found that the occurrence of such bulge defects including balling,residual powder and keyholes is due to the interface phenomena which can be surface tension (capillary force),Marangoni's flow (thermo-capillary force),recoil pressure,drag force as a result of solid/liquid transition via Darcy's term,and buoyancy force.However,for the samples heat treated in $\alpha { + } \beta$ $( 9 2 5 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ and $\beta$ $\mathrm { 1 0 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } C ) }$ regions,the surfaces appear rougher but with no sign of the bulge defects.This which is more significant in $1 0 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ annealing condition can be due to the localized melting and micromotion at the surface during the heat treatment process [42,54,57,58]. The localized melting and micromotion lead to removing the bulge defects but causing an increase of peaks and valleys per unit area. LPBF works under controlled atmosphere.However,it has been reported that a small amount of oxygen $( 0 . 2 \% )$ and nitrogen $( 0 . 1 2 \% )$ may exist in the bulk of the materials so the solution of these elements in titanium may lead to decreasing the melting point temperature on the surface of the samples and causing micro-flowing which is shown in Fig.6(E) [59,6O].This is consistent with what we found from ANN modeling (Fig.5) where it was shown that with increasing heat treatment temperature the value of average surface roughness increases (red area).
summary: 5.2.1.Interaction of HT versus process parameters - Part 2/3

The value of tangent for the boundary of contour colours for Fig. 5 shows $\theta _ { 2 } > \theta _ { 4 } > \theta _ { 3 } > \theta _ { 1 }$ . The higher tangent, the lower fluctuations in Y axis movement in contour plots thus, this trend proves that LP,HS,PA,and SS are the most influential factors in determining $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ ，

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-24
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
Fig.5(A) and 6 (A-C) show that increasing laser power leads to increasing $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ and in the range of higher than $1 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ the value of $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ increases up to $2 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .In this research,LP is the second most influential factor on the surface roughness of LPBF parts and the most important one when comparing all process parameters in agreement with Pupo's investigations [11]. Surface roughness is a function of melt pool size and energy density.In the case of higher energy density (laser power) partial melting occurs in a wider area and overflow at the surface,leading to a reduction of surface quality.In this case,more peaks and troughs are found on the top surface of the samples [27].The width of the track is associated with LP,SS and interaction of these two parameters.In the case of higher LP and lower SS (Fig.7(A)), by increasing the width of the melt pool, temperature increases and higher Marangoni convection occurs in the center of the melt pool and bigger mush area and heat affected zone is observed.The gradient of speed for melting flow is zero in the mush areas,therefore; higher temperature accumulates in these regions that leads to increasing thermal stress,and decreasing surface tension.Therefore,in higher energy density smoother surface was observed in agreement with the literature [61,62].

According to Eq. (2) increasing temperature leads to increase the ratio of unit-less temperature ratio $\xi$

$$
\xi = { \frac { T - T _ { 0 } } { T _ { c } - T _ { 0 } } }
$$

where $\mathrm { T } _ { 0 }$ is initial temperature and $\mathrm { T _ { c } }$ is critical temperature.In critical temperature,according to Eq. (3) the surface tension $\gamma$ becomes zero.

$$
\gamma = \sqrt [ 3 ] { \frac { 1 ^ { 2 } } { v _ { l } } } \left( T - T _ { c } \right)
$$

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-25
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
where $\nu _ { l }$ is molar volume.In LPBF the working temperature for Ti-6Al4V reaches a maximum value of $2 2 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ while the surface tension is zero in boiling temperature which is $3 5 6 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } .$ Therefore,in LPBF the surface tension never becomes zero. Increasing $\xi$ in Eq. (2) leads to decreasing surface tension due to thermo-capillary effect and this phenomenon is called Marangoni's effect.

$$
\gamma = \gamma ^ { * } \left( \frac { T _ { c } - T _ { 0 } } { T _ { c } } \right) [ 1 - \xi ]
$$

where $\gamma ^ { * }$ is constant for each liquid.The interaction of surface tension force $^ +$ hydrostatic force versus vapor pressure is not balanced and keyholes and fusion appear which reduces the value of surface roughness [63,64].Irregularity on layer tracks was observed for lower scan speeds which is related to the previously mentioned mechanisms (Figs. 5(B) 7(A) and 10 (A and B) [30].

Higher surface quality was obtained by decreasing LP and increasing HS (Fig.5D) which is associated with a reduction in higher temperature,bigger mush area,and the keyhole effect.Therefore,the bottom contour of the melt pool becomes a horizontal oval.In the case of higher LP and lower SS, the temperature of melt pool increases and stronger Marangoni's effect and flow were observed.The consequences were an unstable melt pool,migration of unmelted powders into the melt pool and increasing $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ [65].

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-26
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
Optimizing hatch spacing controls the overlapping area on the top surface which leads to enhanced surface characteristics.This is shown in Fig.7(B),in constant laser power of $1 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ with increasing hatch spacing from 65 to $8 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ Fig.5(C) 7(B) and 10(C) reveals that higher hatch spacing leads to lower overlapping and generates better surface quality [3O].Formation of keyholes highly depends on convective heat transfer,especially for materials with different thermophysical properties [63,64,66-68].

![](images/6b759a07d12fefee40c5d208c24784ed312a2e2408d6d8921508de28c5d031f8.jpg)  
Fig.7.ANN interaction of LP versus SS,HS and PA.

Lower scan speed causes slower movement of fluid in the melt pool. The fluid moving out from the center carries heat and enhances heat transfer and the region with no fluid velocity tends to generate keyholes.In this situation, the Marangoni convection brings the heat from the bottom of the keyholes to the surface and then outward and this recirculating flow of hot liquid increases the width of melt pool at the top and generates a cone-shape melt pool which increases the value of surface roughness.Based on Atthey's number when Reynold's number is higher than 6oo,the melt pool becomes turbulent [69].

Reynold's number is obtained based on Eq. (5):

$$
R _ { e } = { { \rho } { u } _ { m } } { \omega } / _ { \mu }
$$

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-27
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
where $\rho$ is density, $u _ { m }$ is scan speed, $\omega$ is melting pool width and $\mu$ is viscosity.By increasing SS,the cooling rate and subsequently viscosity increases and with respect to the mentioned mechanism width of melt pool decreases.Therefore,Reynolds number becomes smaller so a less turbulent surface is expected. Moreover, vapor pressure is required to keep the holes open due to the balance of forces between surface tension and hydrostatic force on the liquid/solid interface at keyhole walls. Therefore the pressure increases by increasing depth and decreasing radius of the keyhole [69,7O]. Surface tension and hydrostatic pressure tend to close the walls of keyholes while vapor pressure has a tendency to keep the wals open (Fig. 9A). Hydrostatic and vapor pressures are obtained based on Eqs. (6) and 7 [71]:

$$
\begin{array} { l } { P _ { h y d r o } = P _ { 0 } + \rho g z S i n { \theta } } \\ { \displaystyle } \\ { P _ { v a p o r } = P _ { 0 } + \frac { \gamma ( T ) } { R ( z ) } + \rho g z } \end{array}
$$

where $P _ { \mathrm { v a p o r } }$ is vapor pressure inside the keyhole, $P _ { 0 }$ is the ambient pressure, $\gamma ( T )$ is the surface tension at the local wall temperature $^ { \mathrm { T } , }$ $\operatorname { R } ( \mathbf { z } )$ is the average radius of curvature of the keyhole at distance z from the surface,which is taken to be half of the keyhole diameter along scanning direction and $\theta$ is angle with a vertical line. $\mathrm { P _ { h y d r o } }$ is hydrostatic pressure, $\rho$ is density, and $g$ is gravity acceleration.

It is known that the working temperature for Ti-6Al-4V is less than the boiling temperature so based on Fig.9 at the end of keyhole:

$$
\{ \begin{array} { l l } { \displaystyle \operatorname* { l i m } _ { z  0 } \frac { \gamma ( T ) } { R ( z ) } \sim \infty } \\ { \quad \gamma ( T ) \neq 0 } \end{array} 
$$

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-28
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
The value of specific surface tension is not infinite (even in solid phase) and by considering non-equilibrium equations:

$$
\sum P _ { x } = P _ { 0 } + \rho g h + \frac { \gamma ( T ) } { R ( z ) } - \gamma ^ { * } \left( \frac { T _ { c } - T _ { 0 } } { T _ { c } } \right) \left[ 1 - \frac { T - T _ { 0 } } { T _ { c } - T _ { 0 } } \right] - P _ { 0 } + \rho g h S i n \theta
$$

![](images/87c460dea9c3144ddc5df8bb495d021202db9b598a633d678175469a96f13e8a.jpg)  
Fig.8.Measured HS in (A) sample 4 (B) sample 22.

![](images/82265265cd5959215b1156f8dd4c5df5ae3c0bca158add0f517322c85ba31160.jpg)  
Fig.9.(A)Keyholeandrelatedpresures(B)Sketchofinterfacemotioninducedbyatheralgradientbetween tworegionsofthesurface.

![](images/0448900535e28088261879c17ee3da874326cdd275dcdeb0aaf01515994928b5.jpg)  
Fig.10.ANN interaction of other process parameters.

![](images/3cc9a0e63538ddbe7677f6847b9260cb56fc26bb12e2bb750487abc04786b378.jpg)  
Fig.11.The effect of PA on coverage of overlap for previous layers.

According to Eq. (7):

$$
P _ { v a p o r } \gg P _ { h y d r o } + \gamma \Rightarrow \sum P _ { x } \neq 0
$$

Therefore,this trend shows the tops of keyholes stay open and surface quality decreases.

Fig.5(C),7(B) and 10(C) show that by increasing hatch spacing the value of $s _ { \mathrm { a } }$ decreases.It is reported that in overlap area the value of $\mathrm { R _ { a } }$ is five to seven-fold higher than the center of the track. Increasing HS also leads to increasing of the radial acceleration and speed.Therefore,melting flow speed is not zero and higher conduction occurs on the melt pool due to lower conduction effect in overlap and contact regions.Therefore,the size of the melt pool increases and average surface roughness improves [65] (Fig.8 shows average surface versus small and big hatch space).

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-29
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
Another reason for increasing $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ for the case of smaller HS values can be related to the promotion of particle attachment in the overlaparea.Larger overlap leads to enabling the previously fabricated track to absorb more energy and increases the temperature. The results would be a bigger heat affected zone and more partially melted powder attached to a solid interface causing larger average roughness [16].

Figs.5,7 and 1O show that SS has the lowest impact on the value of $\mathsf { S } _ { \mathsf { a } }$ consistent with Alrbaey et al.work on the re-melted surface (postprocessing) [34].

Figs.5D,7C and 10C show that by decreasing PA the value of $s _ { \mathrm { a } }$ has a raising trend. The reason is related to coverage of overlap (rough area) by the center of subsequent layers (smooth area) [65].Fig.11 shows when the second layer has lower PA then the area of coverage of overlap for the previous layer is a parallelogram A'BCD'while for higher PA $( 9 0 ^ { \circ } )$ this coverage is rectangular ABCD.It is known that the surface of a parallelogram is $A ^ { \prime } B \times B D ^ { \prime }$ is higher than the surface of the rectangularABCD.Therefore,the coverage of overlap by subsequent layers is a direct function of PA.In other words,the lower PA the lower overlap area and based on the mentioned notes and mechanisms (in lower PA) subsequent layers cover the surface problems such as balling,cracks and keyholes. Thus,increasing PA reduces the quality of the average surfaces.

name: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame-part-30
fileName: 2020 - Int. J. Mechanical Sciences - Khorasani et al. - Modelling of laser powder bed fusion process and analysing the effective parame.pdf
content:
# 6.Conclusions
This research investigates the key contribution parameters influencing average surface roughness and shows a numerical model to predict $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ and provides practical information to explain the behavior of process parameters on average roughness and enhance the surface quality of LPBF parts.This can therefore help to minimize post-treatment such as machining and polishing.The obtained data can be used to adjustthe process parameters to produce higher surface quality, especially when using hybrid (e.g. LPBF $^ +$ Remelting) processes for more quality improvements.

Results showed that for Ti-6Al-4V alloy printed via LPBF method, heat treatment above the beta transus temperature causes lower surface quality due to formation of some defects such as localized surface melting,balling,unmelted and residual particles.Surface quality decreases at Higher LP and lowers SS because of the Marangoni effect that causes the formation of mush area and increasing the chance of keyholes. $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ is a direct function of HS due to the fact that at larger HS values smaller overlap occurs so the chance of adherence of unmelted particles becomes less.Due to geometric coverage of subsequent layers on former layers,lower PA provides better surface quality.

This research showed ANN is an accurate tool to predict the value and trend of $\mathsf { S } _ { \mathsf { a } }$ when different process and post process parameters are applied.

# Declaration of Competing Interest
We confirm that we don't have a conflict of interest with other scientists in the field.

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m-part-1
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m.pdf
content:
Dinh Son Nguyen, Hong Seok Park\*, Chang Myung Lee

)epartment of Mechanical Engineering, University of Ulsan,93 Daehak-ro,Ulsan,44610,South Korea

# ARTICLEINFO


# ABSTRACT
Keywords:   
Deep learning   
Supervised learning   
Selective laser melting   
Ti-6Al-4V

Ti-6Al-4V products manufactured by selective laser melting (SLM) have been extensivelyused in biomedical, aerospace,and many other industries.However,SLM's many process parameters and their vast range are barriers to efficiently printing desirable products.Because SLM requires so much time,expenditure,and expert knowledge about the process and materials,SLM printing of Ti-6Al-4V products needs apre-processng optimization system.In this paper,an SLMoptimization system is developed based on a supervised deep neural network by applying the Python programming language and the TensorFlow library.The outputs of this optimization method are the optimal SLM process parameters,which can be used to produce a product that satisfies a user requirement.With this optimization system,an SLM operator does not need much experience or to spend much time on experimentation to print adesirable product.This system is a significant, important module for pre-processing SLM printing.
summary: Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy manufacturing using deep learning

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m-part-2
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m.pdf
content:
Due to its excellent mechanical properties such as good stability, good corrosion resistance,and high specific strength, the titanium alloy Ti-6Al-4V is widely used in many industries [1].However,its high cost and challenging machinability somewhat restrict its use in conventional manufacturing methods,namely forging and casting [2].

However,the use of Ti-6Al-4V in selective laser melting (SLM) powder bed fabrication,an additive manufacturing (AM) process,offers the benefits of recycling the remaining unprocessed metal powder, geometrical freedom in product design,and time and energy efficiencies [3,4].In this process,ametal powderis applied layer-by-layer in building up a formed product,each layer anchored to the previous one by the complete fusion of the metal powder by a laser beam.The laser spot moves along a scanning pattern which is generated and controlled by a CAD model of the part to be built. Fig.1 presents a schematic of a typical powder-bed fusion system.

SLM is an attractive manufacturing process for the aerospace,automotive,and other technological industries [5-7].However，many factors affect the final printed products,namely,the laser power,laser scanning speed,the thickness of the metal powder layers,the printer's accuracy,and other printing conditions.Additionally,the ranges of these factors are quite wide.For example,the maximum laser power can reach more than $1 8 0 \mathrm { W }$ ,the laser scanning speed can reach7 $\mathbf { m } / s$ and the metal powder layer thickness is unlimited.Using an unsuitable process parameter can result in low-density powder fusion,which would have a significant impact on the mechanical properties of the printed product [8,9]，and could cause unexpected behavior like cracking [1O],balling[11],or deformation [12].

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m-part-3
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m.pdf
content:
Many papers have described high-density Ti-6Al-4V products fabricated by SLM[13-15],but the results show that there is variability in part density obtained by several different process parameters.Many papers have tried to optimize SLM process parameters by applying, for example,response surface methodology (RSM),Taguchi robust design methods [16],direct optimization [17],D-optimal design of experiments(DOE)[18],using energy density [19],and Doehlert matrix design [2O]. It is clear in all of these approaches that investigating process parameters independently is incorrect because the printed product quality is a function of relationships between several crucial process parameters.

Similar energy densities can be attained by different combinations of the crucial process parameters,such as layer thickness,hatch distance,laser power,and laser scanning speed [2l].However, to achieve reliable printed quality,the SLM process requires highly experienced users,is expensive,and the experimentation is time-consuming.(Density can be improved by employing heaaat treatment methods [22].)A fully dense SLM product is not always a target that must be achieved at all costs,and it should be negotiated with other specifications.

![](images/e3926f955dfa3a57d92da92ec14709d4cd554cbdc7e7e8bdaea163f7946165d3.jpg)  
Fig. 1. A schematic of selective laser melting.

Therefore,determining the optimal process parameters to print a desirable density product is the goal of this research.

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m-part-4
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m.pdf
content: Artificial neural networks (ANNs) have been a boon in optimizing engineering problems, having excellent applications in modelling, prediction,and analysis in various industries,including welding processes [23,24] and manufacturing [25].Patterned after human brains and nerve cells,ANNs currently use neuro-modelling techniques associated with powerful optimization [26,27].Here,we use an ANN to concurrently optimize four crucial SLM process parameters - laser power,laser scanning velocity,hatch distance,and layer thickness 一 for a printed product of required density.

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m-part-5
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m.pdf
content:
# 2.1. Experiment setup
The material selected for this study was the titanium-alloy Ti-6Al$4 \mathrm { V }$ ELI,Grade 23 (SLM Solutions Group AG,Germany),supplied in powder form with an average particle size of about $2 0 - 6 3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .Table1 shows the chemical composition,while Figs.2a and 2b show the morphology of the particle powder by scanning electron microscope (SEM),and particle size distribution bya laser scattering analyzer (LA960),respectively.An SLM printer (MetalSysl50;Winforsys Co.,Ltd., Korea)with an IPG ytterbium fiber laser,(YLR-2OO-AC-Y11;IPG Photonics) $2 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ maximum output,air-cooled,was used to process the powder. The technical parameters are presented in Table 2.

A series of printing models used the meander laser scanning strategy in which the laser scan direction in the nth layer is perpendicular to that of the $\mathbf { n } + \mathbf { 1 } \mathrm { { t h } }$ layer,which is the same as the n-lth layer,as shown in Fig. 2c.Argon gas was filled into the chamber to maintain the oxygen level below $0 . 1 ~ \%$ .The chamber temperature was at $2 8 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m-part-6
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m.pdf
content:
# 2.2.Experiment dataset
The selection of the experimental test to be measured is of great importance for the deep learning process.Therefore,the experimental dataset must be suficiently broad and representative of the problem to be modelled [28]. Here, the four investigated process parameters were laser power,laser scanning speed, hatch distance,and layer thickness; the levels of each parameter were selected by experience and some references [29-32].The database that was selected for the experiment was created by thoroughly combining each level of each parameter.In this method,a total of 2048 test cases representing the SLM 3D printing technique and the manufacturer cartography were obtained. The process parameters for the experiments and their levels are shown in Table 3.

After printing,the SLM processed parts were tested for density.A GR-200 analytical balance (A&D Company,Ltd.,Tokyo,Japan） was combined with that company's AD-1653 density determination kit to measure the density of the printed parts. The density of the samples was obtained according to the weight of the sample in air,the weight of the sample in liquid,and the density of the liquid (distilled water).

# 2.3.Network parameters
In this research,ANN implementation, training,and the optimization system were developed using the Python programming language [33],in which the TensorFlow library [34] was applied. The ANN included four input nodes as the four process parameters,while the output was the relative density of the printed part.Large differences in the values of the four investigated process parameters as the inputs,and the required product quality as the output,complicated the ANN learning process.Therefore,all inputs and the output were previously normalized by using a standard normalization:

$$
z = { \frac { x - \mu } { \sigma } }
$$

\sigma = \sqrt { \frac { 1 } { N } \sum _ { i = 1 } ^ { N } { ( x _ { i } - \mu ) ^ { 2 } } }
$$

The rectified linear unit (ReLU), $f ( z ) = \operatorname* { m a x } ( 0 , z )$ ，was used when going from one layer to the next as an active function [35].This is currently the most widely used non-linear function because it learns much faster in networks with many layers [36]. The sigmoid function, $f$ $( z ) = 1 / ( 1 + \exp ( - z ) ) \ / { }$ ，was used as the active function for the output layer because of real-valued output.

During training the ANN model to optimize hyperparameters,the mean square error was used as a loss function with the Adam optimizer algorithm [37]. The loss function was calculated as:

$$
E _ { 0 } ( w ) = \frac { 1 } { 2 } \frac { \sum _ { n = 1 } ^ { N } | \widehat { y } - y ) ^ { 2 } | } { N }
$$

where $\widehat { \boldsymbol { y } }$ and $y ,$ and $N$ are predicted value of the model, the real value of the experiment output, and the total number of samples, respectively.

# 2.4. $K$ -fold cross-validation training the neural network
For training the model, the dataset is usually split into training data and test data.The training dataset includes a known output,and the model learns on this data in order to be described to other coming data. The test dataset is used to test the prediction of the model. However, splitting data that is required to reflect the essential characteristics of the problem is not easy.
summary: 2.4. $K$ -fold cross-validation training the neural network, Standard deviation: - Part 1/2

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m-part-9
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m.pdf
content: Additionally,by partitioning the available data into other sets,the data will significantly reduce the number of samples which can be used for learning the model,and the results can depend on a particular random selection for the pair of sets.Therefore,in this article, the k-fold cross-validation is applied to solve the mentioned problems.In k-fold cross-validation,the original sample is randomly partitioned into k equal-sized subsamples.Of the k subsets,a single subsample is retained as the validation data for testing the model,and the remaining $\mathbf { k } { \cdot } \mathbf { 1 }$ subsamples are used as training data.The cross-validation process is then repeated k times (the folds),with each of the $\mathbf { k }$ subsamples used exactly once as the validation data.The k results from the folds can then be averaged to produce a single estimation [38].The advantage of this method is that all observations are applied for both training and validation,and each observation is used for validation exactly once.In this article,the 1O- fold approach was selected.
summary: 2.4. $K$ -fold cross-validation training the neural network, Standard deviation: - Part 2/2

fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m.pdf
content:
Overfittng is a problem that often occurs in machine learning,when the model is very accurate on the training data but will probably not be very accurate on the testing data. Generally,when overfiting happens, the model learns the noise in the training data instead of the actual relationships between variables in the data.To avoid overfitting,the weight decay regularization and the dropout methods are used.Weight decay is a method to prevent the weights from growing too large unless it is really necessary,by adding a term to the loss function that penalizes large weights [39,40]:

$$
E ( w ) = E _ { 0 } ( w ) + \frac { 1 } { 2 } \lambda \sum _ { i } w _ { i } ^ { 2 }
$$

where $\lambda$ is a regularization parameter governing how strongly large weights are penalized. $w$ is the weight vector which contains all free parameters of the network. In this research, $\lambda = 0 . 0 5$ was used.

Dropout is another method to prevent overfitting.In the dropout technique,units are randomly dropped from the neural networks during training [41-43]. In this research, the probability of retaining a unit in the network was 0.7.

# 2.6.Optimizing algorithms
The optimization algorithm is shown in Fig. 3 and the following:

1 First,develop an ANN.   
2 Calculate the density ratio from the generated data that were

Fig.3.Algorithms for optimization system.

created by combining levels of the four process parameters.The laser power changes from $8 0 \mathrm { W }$ to $1 8 0 \mathrm { W }$ in $5 \mathrm { W }$ increments.The laser scanning velocity values change from $8 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ to $2 5 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ in $1 0 0 { \cdot } \mathrm { m m } / s$ increments,while the layer thickness and hatch distance change from $2 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $8 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $3 0 \mu \mathrm { m } - 1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,respectively, in $5 \mathrm { - } \mu \mathrm { m }$ increments.

# 3.Results and discussions

content:
The training process aims to optimize the hyperparameters of the neural network model by minimizing the loss function.The weights are given randomly at the beginning.Based on the inputs and outputs of the training data,which are split from the experiment data,the network calculates and compares its resulting outputs against the desired outputs.Errors are then propagated back through the system,causing the system to adjust the weights.This process is repeatedly performed until it achieves a minimal loss.After training,the test dataset,which is the rest of the experimental data, is used to test the network.Finally, the error estimation is averaged to get the total effectiveness of the neural network model. To assess the performance of the prediction of the neural network, the mean absolute error (MAE) that follows Eq.(6) was applied. $$ M A E = { \frac { 1 } { N } } \ | { \widehat { y } } \ - y | $$ Fig.4 illustrates the 1O-fold cross-validation processes of the neural network within 3oo epochs for each fold,a 0.oo1 learning rate.The convergence of the training and validation curves indicates that the developed neural network is not overfitting.Additionally,Table 4 shows the results of the developed neural network model for prediction. name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m-part-14
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m.pdf
content:
100 percent of the density ratio was used as a request of the user to assess the performance of the developed system.To determine the optimal values,the indexed data were filtered byaconditionof the SLM process known as productivity. The productivity $( { \dot { V } } ) , { \dot { V } } = \nu . h . \ t$ is described by the material volume being created from the metal powder over time.The productivity is a function of the layer thickness t, laser scan speed $\nu ,$ and hatch distance $h$ 、In case there are several indexed process parameters that satisfy the user requirement, maximizing productivity is the ultimate condition that needs to be filtered.

The results of the developed optimization system are shown in Table 5; the optimal process parameters are: layer thickness is $2 0 \mu \mathrm { m } .$ hatch distance is $8 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ，the laser power is $1 8 0 \mathrm { W }$ ,and the laser scanning velocity is $9 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ with the meander scanning strategy.

Using the optimal process parameters suggested from the system, a product was printed one more time to confirm its performance. Applying the Archimedes principle,the result indicated a 99.8 percentage of relative density; the porosity of the manufactured part is shown in Fig.5.Comparing with the MAE of the developed system, the optimal process parameter set satisfied the user requirement.

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m-part-15
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Nguyen, Park, Lee - Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy m.pdf
content:
# 4.Conclusions
The density of a product manufactured by selective laser melting of Ti-6Al-4V was optimized by determining four optimal process parameters:laser power,laser scanning speed,layer thickness,and hatch distance.The developed optimization system applied supervised deep learning as a core function,using process parameters as input and product relative density as output. The dropout and weight decay methods addressed the overfitting problem that often happens in deep neural networks.The predicted outputs were compared with the user requirement,and the parameters of which the outputs satisfied that requirement were indexed conversely. The productivity of the SLM printing process was used to filter the indexed data anew to finally obtain the optimal process parameters.To assess the performance of the developed system,the optimal parameters were set for a final SLM printing,and the relative density of the new fabricated part confirmed that it met the user requirement as predicted by the SLM optimization system.

# Supplementary information
Supplementary information will be provided upon requesting the author in the article titled “Optimization of selective laser melting process parameters for Ti-6Al-4V alloy manufacturing using deep learning".

# ARTICLEINFO
summary: Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechanical properties of printed Ti-6Al-4V parts

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-2
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content:
# ABSTRACT
Associate Editor:M Merklein

Keywords:   
Additive manufacturing   
PBF-LB   
Ti-6Al-4V   
Laser power   
Microstructure   
Mechanical properties

This study investigated the efectof laser power on the properties of Ti-6Al-4V alloy parts produced by additive manufacturing.The printing study was carred out using the laser beam powder bed fusion (PBF-LB) technique (Renishaw RenAM 5ooM).The laser power was altered in the range of $1 0 0 { - } 4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ ,in order to evaluate the effects of changing the input energy received by the powder particles on the as-built parts.The impact of changing laser power was investigated based on printed part dimensions,porosity,morphology,micro/nanostructure,wear,hardness and tensile properties.It was determined that laser power has a direct influence on part dimensional accuracy,with larger dimensions compared with CAD design under the processng conditions used, obtained at higher powers i.e. $2 ~ \%$ at $2 5 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ ,while $4 \%$ a $4 0 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ .The border thickness for rounded edges was found to be $\sim 0 . 2 \pm 0 . 0 6 \ \mathrm { m m }$ greater than that obtained for straight edges,printed on the same quarter circle samples.A more homogeneous morphology,along with an improved surface finish,was obtained for parts printed using the higher laser powers.The microstructure of the high power alloy,was characterised by wider prior $\beta$ grains with longer and finer $\acute { \alpha }$ needles,along with superior as-built mechanical properties,when compared to parts produced using lower laser power (1Oo W).Additionaly,shifts in the XRD peak position for parts printedatthe lower and higher laser powers,indicate some reduction in the level ofresidual stress for parts produced at higher powers.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-3
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content: Additive manufacturing (AM),commonly referred to as three-dimensional (3-D） printing,is a production method which offers the ability to build near net-shapes with complex geometries (Dutta and Froes,2O15).3-D printing yields a significant degree of freedom in design,allowing parts to be made using a single continuous process in comparison to traditional subtractive methods,that often require numerous machining steps to achieve the same finished part complexity and geometries.The technology is increasingly being adopted for precision component fabrication in the aeronautical, medical device and automotive sectors,due to its ability to produce consolidated parts for specific end-use applications (Thomas, 2016). As a result, AM can significantly reduce material usage and lead processing times,along with cost savings for small batch runs. While there are a range of processing technologies used for the AM of metallic parts,one of the most widely applied commercially is the Powder Bed Fusion (PBF) technique. This method of manufacturing uses a raking mechanism to evenly spread the metal powder across the work area,which usually involves layer heights of $2 0 { - } 2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .The metal powder is then exposed to an energy source (electron beam or laser beam),which scans the bed following a specific toolpath,melting or sintering the powder into the desired geometry.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-4
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content:
This paper is focused on the printing of Ti-6Al-4V alloy parts. There is significant interest in this alloy for biomedical applications,due to its corrosion resistance,biocompatibility,high specific strength,superior mechanical properties and fracture toughness (Toh et al.,2Ol6). Ti-6Al4Valloy parts are generally printed using the laser beam PBF process. Both continuous and pulsed wave laser modes can be used for melting powders in laser based technologies.In continuous mode, the output power remains constant independent of time;whereas in pulsed mode, the laser fires for short specified periods.The latter yields a localized high energy discharge which instantaneously heats up the material with minor thermal energy dissipation to the surrounding material due to the formation of relatively narrow tracks,which might cause increased porosity.In contrast, the continuous wave mode results in a greater diffusion of energy to the surrounding materials,which can result in a larger melt pool with inferior geometrical accuracy (Caprio et al., 2017).There have been a relatively limited number of publications however,which have reported on the mechanical properties of the alloy printed using the PBF-LB process,examples are given in Table 1.It is clear from this table that there are significant disparities in the literature between the mechanical properties of the resultant Ti-6Al-4V alloy parts.These variations are likely to be due to the different PBF-LB processing conditions,which for example influence factors such as the thermal cycling and cooling rate.Amongst other factors influencing the mechanical performance of the printed parts such as scan strategy, surface finish and post-process heat treatments.These factors will have a significant impact on the printed alloy microstructures.

Table 1 Examplesofalpoereordiauefdiaactelh coefficient of friction (COF).

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-6
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content: In the AM process,the cooling rate is influenced by many different factors such as chamber temperature,part geometry,argon flow,layer height, energy deposition etc.During printing,the laser melts the alloy and the area directly heated is known as the‘melt pool'.Thijs et al. (2010) reported that a change in energy input for example will result in a change in melt pool dynamics,geometry and solidification rate.The melt pool size is typically in the order of one to two hundred microns, this limits macro-segregation and causes very high,localized cooling rates of $\sim 1 0 ^ { 3 } - 1 0 ^ { 8 } ~ \mathrm { K } / s$ (Loh et al., 2015). This suggests a significant deviation from the global equilibrium of $\sim 0 . 5 \mathrm { K } / s$ used in casting of these alloys (Dehghan-Manshadi et al., 201O). Mukherjee et al. (2018) and Yang et al.(2Ol6) observed that this rapid cooling and thermal cycling,due to the remelting of subsequent layers,has a direct impact on the characteristics of the final microstructure and can cause the build-up of internal stresses. Zitnansky and Caplovic (2004) and Ding et al.(2Oo2),are examples of authors who have highlighted the importance of the microstructure on the mechanical properties of the printed alloy parts.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-7
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content:
It is reported that in the PBF-LB process,several parameters are responsible for the formation of the as-built microstructure,including laser power, hatch distance,exposure time,focal distance,scan speed, scan strategy etc. (Khorasani et al. 2019). Gong et al. (2014) propose that variations in laser input energy has been shown to be one of the main factors influencing the melt pool. Yadroitsev and Smurov (2010) reported that if insufficient energy is applied,instabilities can occur during the melting process,due to a decrease in the diameter of the cylindrical melt tracks.Under optimal printing conditions,there is likely to be an overlap between hatch distance and melt tracks.However,under non-optimised print conditions,splashing of the molten metal may occur from the surface of the thin discontinuous tracks, which in-turn can induce the formation of spherical defects ("balling" effect) within the part (Gong et al., 2015). Kasperovich et al. (2016) and S.Biamico et al.(2011) both observed that porosity defects are primarily generated due to insuffcient laser energy.These defects are reported to be more detrimental to the parts mechanical properties compared to those generated with excessive laser energy. Conversely, Mezzetta (2Ol7) reported that the use of high laser energy has been shown to have negative effects on the density of the final part. Murr et al.(2Oo9) for example,highlights that the formation of pores of $\sim 5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in diameter are associated with entrapped gas bubbles due to aluminium (in Ti-6Al-4V) evaporation,known as the“keyhole”effect.

Conventional Ti-6Al-4V allys are routinely produced by forging

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-8
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content:
The alloys microstructure has been shown to typically exhibit a bimodal or lamellar microstructure,which consists of equiaxed or acicular $\alpha$ -phase as well as $( \alpha + \beta )$ lamellar grains,also referred to as “basket weave”or $\alpha$ Widmanstatten microstructure (Kelly and Kampe, 2004).Wrought Ti-6Al-4V alloy microstructure formed at standard cooling rates,results in a predominantly coarse acicular $\alpha$ phase microstructure with very small amounts of $\beta$ grains in the $\alpha$ phase boundaries.At high cooling rates however,a lamellar microstructure with finer $\alpha$ grains and limited retained ß phase forms.As a result, $\alpha$ colonies typically originate at the prior f grain boundaries and grow towards the interior of the prior f grain (Banerjee and Williams, 2013). This growth follows the Burgers relation given in Eq.(1） (Burgers, 1934).

$$
\begin{array} { c } { { ( 1 0 0 ) _ { \beta }  ( 0 0 0 1 ) _ { \alpha } } } \\ { { } } \\ { { \langle 1 \bar { 1 } 1 \rangle _ { \beta }  ( 1 1 \bar { 2 } 0 ) _ { \alpha } } } \end{array}
$$

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-9
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content:
Considering the AM process for the fabrication of Ti-6Al-4V alloys, the rapid solidification results in the formation of a fully metastable hexagonal close packed (HCP) fine acicular martensitic phase by diffusionless, shear-type transformation (Zitnansky and Caplovic (2004)). The $\beta  \alpha$ transformation at fast cooling rates can result in a highly stressed microstructure (Vandenbroucke and Kruth,2Oo7).These α plates typically contain a high density of crystal defects such as stacking faults and twins compared to the equilibrium α phase (Qazi et al., 2001).Kobryn and Semiatin (2OOl） studied the efect of laser power and scan speed on microstructure in direct energy deposition process which is another type of laser additive manufacturing technology. Based on their findings,the average grain width is directly influenced by both the incident laser energy deposited during printing and subsequent effect on cooling rates.They also reported that using high laser energy and low scan speed reduced the localised cooling rate,which resulted in an increase in grain width.Furthermore,variation in microstructural features such as prior $\beta$ grains size and $\alpha$ colony size are known to impact mechanical properties of parts,directly influencing the slip length during deformation (Litjering,1998).

To the authors knowledge there have been no reports which analyse the effect of systematically altering the AM laser power on the morphological and mechanical properties of the printed Ti-6Al-4V parts. The objective of this study is to evaluate the effect of laser power variation in the range 1oo-4oo Watts,on the net shape,microstructural evolution,as well as the mechanical properties of the as-built parts.
