name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-11
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content: Extra-low interstitial Ti-6Al-4V(Grade 23,ELI-0406) powder with particle size in the range of $1 0 { - } 4 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,was sourced from Renishaw Plc. This powder exhibits a spherical morphology and is reported by the provider to have low thermal expansion and conductivity (see Appendix A for material specification).Printing studies were carried out using a production scale Renishaw system (RenAM 5OoM) that operates under an inert gas atmosphere.This system uses up to a $5 0 0 W$ pulse wave emission laser with wavelength of $1 0 7 0 \mathrm { n m }$ ，modulated with $_ { 1 0 \mathrm { m s } }$ delay between exposures.The laser follows a Gaussian beam profile that is achieved through the use of a dynamic focusing system which uses two galvo mirrors,correcting the near-parabolic focal length change required as the beam travels across the bed, maintaining the beam in focus.Additionally,this AM system is equipped with the InfiniAM Spectral system for in-situ process monitoring,which provides visual feedback on the laser energy input and the level of emissions emitted from the melt pool during processing (Renishaw Plc,2018). The data is recorded and then reconstructed into both 2-D and 3-D views in near real time.The software facilitates a visual output (based on colour change),associated with changes in the level of laser energy used during printing. The laser emissions are given as variations in pixel contrast from O to 1,where O represents no emission,while 1 represents the highest possible emission.The emission measurements obtained in this study were $0 . 2 3 \ \pm \ 0 . 0 2$ $0 . 3 9 ~ \pm ~ 0 . 0 4$ and $0 . 6 2 \ \pm \ 0 . 0 5$ for the 100,250 and $4 0 0 W$ ，treatments respectively.These results are the average obtained from 433 print layers/sample.For each power, these were positioned at 5 locations across the build plate,as illustrated in Fig.1.In this study laser power (P) was systematically altered in the range of 1oo-4oo W.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-12
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content:
In-depth characterisation studies were carried out using laser power of 1oo,250 and $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ ,which represent low,medium and high energy inputs (Fig.1 (right)). Corresponding energy densities are $6 \times 1 0 ^ { 4 }$ $1 5 \times 1 0 ^ { 4 }$ and $2 4 \times 1 0 ^ { 4 } \mathrm { J } / \mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 }$ ,respectively, calculated using Eq. 2 (Repossini et al., 2017).

$$
E = T . \ P / d _ { h } . \ d _ { p } . \ t \ [ J / c m ^ { 3 } ]
$$

E is the volumetric energy density, $\mathrm { ~ T ~ } [ \mu \mathbf { s } ]$ is the laser exposure time, P [W] is the laser power, $d _ { h } \ [ \mu \mathrm { m } ]$ is the hatch distance (distance between two adjacent scan vectors), $d _ { p } \ [ \mu \mathrm { m } ]$ is the point distance (distance between adjacent points along each hatch) and t $[ \mu \mathrm { m } ]$ is the layer thickness.Additional test samples were manufactured using 150,200, 300 and 35o W to provide both quantitative and qualitative results for hardness,wear and tensile testing.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-13
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content:
As the objective of this study is to evaluate the influence of laser power on printed part geometry,morphology and microstructure, the printed part shape will clearly be an important parameter. The part was designed to incorporate both a sharp edge along with a quarter circle (Fig.1 (left)).This design thus facilitates monitoring the effect of energy input on print features such as wall length,radius of curvature and border thickness.Additionally,as illustrated in Fig.1 (middle),the quarter circle parts were deposited with the narrow point facing the recoater blade.This orientation minimises the effect of the recoater on the parts during the build by reducing the initial contact area between fresh powder and molten alloy,evenly distributing the powder during each recoating. The $1 0 \times 1 0 \times 1 0 m m ^ { 3 }$ samples were built using pulse laser mode with a $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ hatch distance according to a meander “zigzag”scan strategy (rotated $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ between each layer),2 borders with distances of $1 1 0 \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ spot size of $8 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,layer thickness of $3 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ，point distance of $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and with an exposure time of $9 0 \mu \mathrm { s }$ In modulated wave emission, the scan speed between exposure points, $s _ { \mathrm { p } }$ $[ \mathrm { { m m } } / s ]$ ,can be determined by dividing the point distance,by the exposure time (et) plus the delay between exposures $\left( \mathrm { e _ { d } } \right)$ as follows (Renishaw Plc, 2018):

$$
s _ { p } = d _ { p } / ( e _ { t } + { \bf e } _ { d } )
$$

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-14
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content: Using Eq.3,the approximate scan speeds between points was $5 . 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ，for the print studies carried out in this investigation.The delay time between each recoating of powder was $\sim 3 0 s$ and gas flow rate (Ar) of $\sim 2 9 \ m ^ { 3 } / h$ was used during printing.As illustrated in Fig.1 (right),the five test parts for each of the three laser powers evaluated, were located in an uniform arrangement across the build plate and received a homogeneous amount of energy throughout the process.The support used to hold the printed parts to the substrate plate were designed to facilitate ease of removal (by cutting) from the plate.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-15
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content:
# 2.2.1. Sample preparation
As-printed Ti-6Al-4V parts were prepared by grinding and polishing,followed by etching using Kroll's solution ( $\mathrm { 5 m l H N O _ { 3 } }$ ,10 ml HF $( 4 8 \% )$ _， ${ 8 5 } \mathrm { m l }$ distilled water).This analysis was performed at the same layer height for each sample.This is an important factor,as variations in layer height has been shown to affect the microstructural formation and mechanical properties of parts due to thermal conductivity (Zitnansky and Caplovic (2004)).

# 2.2.2.Porosity measurements
Computed tomography measurements were obtained using a Phoenix Nanotom system.This facilitated part density and structural information to be obtained. Scanning took approximately 10 mins at $1 8 0 \mathrm { k V }$ .Under these scanning conditions the system has a resolution of $1 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .The processing of the CT image data was carried out using VG studio Max 3.2.Phoenix Datos|X and ImageJ software to analyse the data.

content:
# 2.2.3.Microstructural analysis
Optical Microscopy (OM) was carried out using the Digital Microscope VHX-20oo Series and Nikon Optiphot 2, Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) was carried out using FEI Quanta 3D FEG Dual Beam (SEM/FIB) using $2 0 \mathrm { k V }$ and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) analysis was conducted using both FEI Tecnai and FEI Titan using $2 0 0 \mathrm { k V }$ and $3 0 0 \mathrm { k V }$ ，respectively.Thin lamellae specimens $( \sim 7 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ were prepared for samples built using 1Oo,250 and $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ via focus ion beam (FIB) milling. In addition, X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using a Siemens D5oo Diffractometer (Cu-Kα source; $3 0 \mathrm { m A }$ $4 0 \mathrm { m V }$ with a Bragg-Brentano geometry.Acquisition for phase identification was carried out in a scan range between $3 2 ^ { \circ }$ to $4 5 ^ { \circ }$ using a dwell time of $3 0 s$ at step size of $0 . 0 4 ^ { \circ }$

![](images/fe400e1c9692276bb67cb8f544cda4402ac01bdbcffa8a21052180dcf5df88cd.jpg)

(Middle) Photograph of the $2 5 0 \times 2 5 0 \mathrm { m m }$ diametersubstrate plate,onto which as-built test parts are printed on. (Right)Imageof the printed parts obtained using thfA segments treated with laser powers of 10o,250 and $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ ,respectively.(For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend,the reader is referred to the web version of this article).

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-17
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content:
# 2.2.4.Hardness
Vickers microhardness measurements samples were performed using the Leitz Microhardness Tester with an applied load of $3 0 0 g$ (HV $0 . 3 , \mathrm { ~ F ~ } 3 \mathrm { N } )$ foraperiodof $3 0 s$ .Measurements were carried out on five Ti-6Al-4V test samples per test condition (1oo-40o W),after they had been ground and polished (down to $1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ diamond paste).The hardness values obtained correspond to an average of 15 indentations across the samples surface with 5 different measurements taken for each indentation.A Nikon Optiphot 2 microscope was used to measure the average diagonal lengths of the indentations.Hardness values were calculated using Eq.3 [ISO 6507-1:2005(E)].

$$
H V = 0 . 1 8 9 1 \times ( F / d ^ { 2 } )
$$

# 2.2.5.Tribological investigation
Wear testing was carried out using a Teer Coatings PoD-2 pin-ondisc wear tester.Testing was performed on each of the five Ti-6Al-4V test samples after hardness testing.This study was carried out under dry sliding conditions,at room temperature and in the ambient environment.A track diameter of $5 \mathrm { m m }$ with a load of $\ 3 \mathrm { N }$ and rotation speed of $5 0 \mathrm { r p m }$ were used,against a $5 \mathrm { m m }$ diameter stainless 316 GD 100 ball. The friction coefficient values obtained correspond to 36oO s of abrasive wear.The friction coefficient curve was recorded and plotted.The level of material removal from the wear track was evaluated using an optical profilometry (Bruker NP FLEX 3D Optical Profiler)，operating in Vertical Scanning Interferometry(VSI) using a white light source.Data analysis was carried out using the built-in software (Bruker Vision64) for surface roughness and volume loss.

content:
# 3.Results & discussion The objective of this study is to determine the effect of laser power variation between 1oo-4oo Watts,on microstructural evolution as well as the mechanical properties of the as-built Ti-6Al-4V parts.The quarter circle part shape shown in Fig.2 was selected,as it combines both a sharp edge and a rounded feature ina single test piece.This facilitates an evaluation of the effect of laser power on different feature designs i.e.sharp versus rounded edges. The printed alloy samples were examined by microstructural characterisation using microscopy／SEM/ TEM.The hardness,wear and tensile tests of the printed parts were performed on sample groups using seven different laser powers and with five test specimens per group. content: As demonstrated by the optical images of the alloy printed at 100 and $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ laser power (Fig.2),the former part exhibits a rough, inhomogeneous surface morphology.In contrast, that obtained at 400 W exhibits the distinctive‘meander' scan pattern used,which produces mutually perpendicular hatch lines parallel to the borders,due to the applied hatch angle of $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ (Thijs et al., 201O). Small sized metallic balls with diameters in the range of $2 5 \mathrm { - } 5 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (satellite particles),were observed throughout the surface of the as-built part. Satellite formation mainly occurs due to insufficient melting of powder particles which cannot penetrate the melt pool before melt pool solidification (Mumtaz and Hopkinson, 2O1O). The dimensional measurements given in Table 2 demonstrate the small increase in the printed coupon size with increase in laser power.Analysis of these geometrical features showed that a laser power of $1 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ produced parts with dimensions close to that of the specified CAD design of $1 0 . 0 \times 1 0 . 0 \times 1 0 . 0 m m ^ { 3 }$ Compared with this design,the overall diameters of the printed samples increased by 0.60, 2.02 and $4 . 1 7 ~ \%$ ，when printed using laser power of 10o,250 and 400 W,respectively.To obtaina close correlation between the CAD and printed part dimensions for a given power, it would be necessary to optimise the laser beam compensation value used for each laser power (Ning et al., 2OO6). The value used in this work was fixed at $1 2 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .A feature which noticeably increased with laser power was the border thickness of the part (Fig.2),that obtained at $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ samples is nearly 4 times $( \sim 0 . 2 ~ \pm ~ 0 . 0 6 \mathrm { { m m } } )$ ）higher than the designed dimension of $0 .

As demonstrated in Fig. 2 for the quarter circle shape, this is more significant for the curved border edge,rather than for the straight edges.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-22
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content: Further visual examination of the as-built parts printed at the different laser powers indicates a high degree of morphological similarity between parts printed at a given power. The relatively uniform morphology of the printed parts would indicate that for this study,the level of laser power applied across the powder bed is relatively homogenous. As detailed earlier,the Renishaw RenAM 50oM melts the powder using a modulated wave emission,a schematic of this is shown in Fig.3. Under ideal conditions there is an overlap between hatch distance and melt tracks;incorrect overlapping of adjacent tracks can result in increased porosity.The width of the melt track,which is a product of the hatch parameter,increased notably from an average of 2o4.1,212.6 and $2 3 5 . 6 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,with increased laser power from 1o0 to 250 and $4 0 0 W$ respectively (Table 2).This increase is attributed to the increase in energy input at the higher laser power which in turn can affect the melt pool homogeneity and size,inducing larger melt tracks.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-23
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content:
CT analysis of parts fabrication using the three-laser powers facilitated the measurement of defect volumes, pore size and geometry (Table 3).Based on porosity measurements,detected areas were irregularly shaped.These areas are normally caused by non-sintered zones attributed to insufficient energy density during scanning (Gong et al., 2014).A relationship appears to exist between the defect volume and changes in laser power.When low (1oo W) and high (4oo W) powers are compared, the corresponding defect volume ratios were $0 . 2 7 \%$ and $0 . 0 5 ~ \%$ ，respectively.In contrast,the $2 5 0 \mathrm { W }$ samples displayed the lowest defect volume ratio of $0 . 0 2 \%$ . Ithas been reported that there is a general relationship between power/exposure,time/point distance/ layer thickness and the melt tracks which in turn result in porosity if the parameters result in insuficient localised energy (Yadroitsev and Smurov, 2OlO).Pore size does not appear to be affected by changes in laser power,however,low (1oo W) laser power displayed increased porosity as a combination of balling'and ‘keyhole'defects in comparison to porosity formed due to higher laser powers,which mainly appeared as ‘keyhole'defects.This observation is in agreement with Table 3 Results from CT image analysis of defect volume ratio $\%$ and largest pore recorded in as-built parts with laser power of 1oo,25O and 400 W.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-24
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content: Kasperovich et al. (2Ol6) who also observed an increase in‘baling' defects due to insufficient laser energy,while surplus energy resulted in the formation of ‘keyhole’defects.Furthermore,the porosity values obtained for the $1 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ samples,illustrates the effect of insufficient energy on track homogeneity.Decreased energy deposition results in reduced melt track overlap which can induce the formation of internal voids;a combination of the‘balling effect'and‘keyhole'formation, resulting in spherical pores of $1 1 1 \pm 2 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in diameter and nonhomogenous cavities $\sim 3 9 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in length,respectively.Pores formed due to laser power above $1 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ are most likely to be produced due to ejected molten metal causing keyhole defect up to $2 9 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in diameter. These voids and keyholes are likely to have a deleterious effect on the part's mechanical properties. Other processing factors such as the argon flow regime can influence powder morphology during the fabrication process and cause increased porosity (Ferrar et al.,2O12).In this study however,little variation was shown for both geometry and porosity for parts printed across the build chamber,despite variations in argon flow regime over the print bed.It is concluded therefore,that for the experimental conditions investigated, the influence of the argon regime is minimal on pore formation,compared with that associated with laser energy.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-25
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content: Based on microscopy and SEM examinations of the printed parts obtained for all three laser power investigated,it was concluded that the as-built microstructures are martensitic.This observation is similar to that reported by a number of other authors for PBF-LB printed parts. Upon inspection of the top layers of the parts,it was found that for all samples there were thin needle-like structures,scattered across the surface,which is a characteristic of $\propto ^ { ' }$ phase (Vracken et al., 2012).The direction of these needle-like martensitic phases, is randomly organised across all samples, which can be associated with the rapid cooling rates, resulting in erratic phase formation and growth. Examination of the parts side view reveals long,columnar grains which grow epitaxially during the build. The average widths of the prior $\beta$ grains measured closest to the polished top surface layer are 110,197 and $2 0 8 \mu \mathrm { m }$ for the 100,250 and $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ ，respectively.The widths of the prior $\beta$ grains appear to increase with an increase in laser power.Additionally, it can be observed in Fig.4 (a) that due to high levels of porosity in the sample, the prior $\beta$ grains grow perpendicular to the pore independent of the build direction,whilst parts with reduced porosity exhibit grain growth towards the print substrate, in the z-plane (Fig. 4 (c)). Kobryn and Semiatin (200l） observed in their studies that upon increasing incident energy, prior $\beta$ grain width increased as the cooling rates decreases. Thus,increased energy deposition by increase in laser power results in decreased cooling rates and also results in an increased level of remelting of the underlayer,which promotes the grain growth phenomena. The scan strategy used will also have a direct influence on the grain structure.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-26
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content: As the design of the part used is small, there could be increased localised heating around the borders,particularlyas the laser is turning,which may promote some grain growth.Furthermore,the grain structure could be clearly observed in the case of the 250 and $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ samples,however in the case of the $1 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ samples, the morphology exhibited an irregular and inconsistent grain structure (with a standard deviation of $5 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ between grain widths).A further factor influencing grain growth is the increased number of pores formed in within the structure formed using the $1 0 0 W$ laser power. The length of the primary $\acute { \alpha }$ martensite needles were found to increase with increased laser power. Yang et al. (2016) reported that $\mathbf { \Delta } \mathbf { a } ^ { \prime }$ martensites always extend across the entire parent $\beta$ phase,however in this study the primary $\alpha$ martensite needles were found not to fully extend across this $\beta$ phase. This is possibly due to the formation of dislocations and twins in the prior $\beta$ grain as a result of thermal cycling,which interrupts primary $\acute { \alpha }$ needle growth.Furthermore, based on 20 measurements per printed sample,the average lengths of the primary $\propto ^ { ' }$ martensitic needles were found to be 94,114 and $1 4 8 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,for the100,250 and $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ samples,respectively (Table 4).Wu et al. (2004) reported a similar observation in their studies,where the length of the $\propto ^ { ' }$ needles increased with increased laser power.As the length of $\alpha ^ { ' }$ needle is limited to the prior $\beta$ grain width,as this width increases at higher input energies, there is a corresponding increase in the length of the $\alpha ^ { ' }$ needles.This is demonstrated in Table 4,as the power is increased from $1 0 0 { - } 4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ .

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-28
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content:
A possible reason for the changes observed in both prior $\beta$ grain width, $\alpha$ thickness and length with increasing laser power,may be due to higher melt pool temperatures,giving rise to increased re-melting of the underlying layers.These higher temperatures may also induce some localised annealing.This in turn could promote epitaxial growth of the prior $\beta$ grain and increased grain coarsening rates with refined martensitic $\propto$ phase (Wu et al., 2004). For the $1 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ samples,a large amount of fine acicular martensite of varying lengths was obtained.In contrast，the 250 and $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ samples appeared to possess a more homogeneous distribution of these acicular martensite needles,however with a higher aspect ratio.Yang et al. (2Ol6) reported that the hierarchical martensitic structure is directly influenced by the energy deposition and thermal cycling.

Another factor which can influence the type of martensitic structure is the presence of a higher concentration of $\beta$ stabilizing V.At high energy depositions due to the evaporation of aluminium (Al),it is reported that a higher V content is present,which favours a more ‘basket weave’ type structure (Ahmed and Rack,1998). These basket weave structures have been reported to directly influence the surface mechanical properties,increasing the microhardness of parts (Li et al., 2017).In summary,there is a direct relationship between $\alpha$ needle morphology and the laser power used in the fabrication of the sample.A reduction in needle thickness,accompanied by an increase in needle length,occurs with increased laser power.This also results in a more homogenous crystal microstructure.

XRD and TEM Selected Area Diffraction Analysis (SAED) analyses of the Ti-6Al-4V alloys were carried out in order to obtain a more detailed understanding of phases present in as-built structure.Fig.5 illustrates

content:
![](images/f0dbbb71dd7bd93a56fb556d7db8e10256183280f402e4a69f7192e697fcd4e5.jpg)  
Fig.5.X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of as-received Ti-6Al-4V powder and asbuilt Ti-6Al-4V samples manufactured using laser powers of 1Oo,250 and $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ ，showing the presence of primary $\alpha$ and $\vec { \mathbf { a } } ^ { \prime }$ martensite with lattice parameters which differ slightly due to the crystal structure and internal residual stresses.

XRD patterns of the as-received Ti-6Al-4V powder and of the as-built parts produced using laser power of 10o,250 and $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ .The diffraction peaks had corresponding lattices: $( 1 0 0 ) _ { \alpha / \alpha ^ { ' } }$ ， $( 0 0 2 ) _ { \alpha / \alpha ^ { ' } }$ and $( 1 0 1 ) _ { \alpha / \alpha ^ { ' } }$ ： Both the as-received powder and PBF-LB Ti-6Al-4V samples were found not to show the presence of the $\beta$ phase at $\sim 3 9 . 5 ^ { \circ }$ ,suggesting its absence or its presence at very low concentrations.Additionally,the PBFLB Ti-6Al-4V samples showed a relatively low count for the $( 0 0 2 ) _ { \alpha / \alpha ^ { ' } }$ phase at $3 8 . 6 8 ^ { \circ }$ ,when compared to the as-received powder. This could be explained by the morphologyof this sample type,which is relatively coarse,possessing directional prior $\beta$ grains, limiting the number of grains that can be measured via XRD,hence resulting in low counts for certain peaks. Cullity (2oo1),explained that commonly in polycrystalline metals,due to the manufacturing process,a tendency occurs where grains aggregate,slip and rotate in complex ways resulting in a preferred,non-random orientation,or texture.Consistently，peak intensities varied substantially across all samples.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-30
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content: In this comparison XRD study,both peak broadening and peak shifts,were observed in the PBF-LB samples,when compared to the asreceived Ti-6Al-4V powder. The lattice parameters $a$ and $c$ of the HCP phase were determined for the PBF-LB samples as $a = 0 . 2 9 2 { \mathrm { n m } }$ and $c = 0 . 4 6 5 \mathrm { n m }$ ,are in good agreement with those reported in the literature of $a = 0 . 2 9 3 \mathrm { n m }$ and $c = 0 . 4 6 8 \mathrm { n m }$ for the $\alpha$ phase (Welsch et al.,1993). Yang et al. (2016) reported that both peak broadening of the $( 1 0 0 ) _ { \alpha }$ and $( 0 0 2 ) _ { \alpha }$ ，as well as higher 20 values occur due to the presence of $\propto ^ { ' }$ martensite.The latter has a slightly different lattice parameters to the equilibrium $\alpha$ phase.Some additional factors which may also contribute to an increase in the 20 value,are the solid solution content,as well as residual stress (Ungar,2Oo4).Based on EDS analysis of the printed samples there was no significant variation between the elemental composition,indicating that the solid solution did not significantly vary.Thus,the residual stress is considered to be the most significant factor influencing peak shift. Evidently,the peak angle of the $( 1 0 1 ) _ { \alpha } \cdot$ lattice for the $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ sample $( 4 0 . 8 4 ^ { \circ } )$ is much closer to the asreceived peak angle $( 4 0 . 6 8 ^ { \circ } )$ ,while both peaks of the $1 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ and $2 5 0 \mathrm { W }$ are approximately $4 1 . 0 4 ^ { \circ }$ .From this observation,it is concluded that high energy deposition promotes in-situ stress relief,as observed by the shift in peak positions (Vasinonta et al., 2Ooo). Furthermore, there is an increase in the intensity of the $3 8 . 9 2 ^ { \circ }$ peak for the $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ sample,when compared to the other laser powers.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-31
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content: A possible explanation for this is that higher energy input during deposition may facilitate some crystal reorientation favouring the formation of the $\{ 0 0 2 \}$ planes.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-32
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content: Mercelis and Kruth (2OO6) in their studies reported a highly distorted crystal structure,when they analysed the microstructure of PBFLB Ti-6Al-4V.TEM imaging of the as-built samples in this study also depict a staggered morphology with high density of dislocations at the three laser powers investigated (Figs.6 (a-c)).This staggering is commonly associated with the slip of the equilibrium $\alpha$ phase HCP (Aggarangsi and Beuth,2Oo6).This is likely to be associated with the thermally induced residual stresses that form as a result of the rapid cooling,causing the phase morphology to be highly distorted.These results are commonly seen in the formation of $\alpha ^ { ' }$ martensite,which is often induced via thermal stresses.Based on the SAED analysis,the crystal structure of the martensitic phase (250 W) agrees with HCP $\mathbf { B } =$ [0002], $d _ { 1 0 0 } ~ = 0 . 2 5 8 \mathrm { n m }$ and $a = 0 . 2 9 5 \mathrm { n m }$ ),which is consistent with the XRD measurements belonging to the $\alpha ^ { ' }$ phase as seen previously. Additionally,structural defects such as twinning associated with the rapid cooling during the additive process (Fig.6d) were observed across all samples.Moreover, Inverse Fast-Fourier Transform (IFFT)analysis of the brightfield TEM images revealed the nanostructure of the samples to be highly distorted.Fig.7 depicts a high-resolution HR-TEM image of overlapping planes obtained for the alloy printed at 25o W.By means of visual inspection and measurements of the angle between planes,a value of $3 0 ~ \pm ~ 2 ^ { \circ }$ was found which represents the mismatch between planes. Additionally, values of $d _ { 0 0 2 } \ = \ 0 . 2 3 1 \ \pm \ 0 . 0 1 \mathrm { n m }$ and $d _ { 1 0 0 } =$ $0 . 2 5 8 ~ \pm ~ 0 . 0 3 \mathrm { { n m } }$ was acquired for planes Aand B,which correspond to the $( 0 0 2 ) _ { \alpha } \prime$ and $( 1 0 0 ) _ { \alpha } { } ^ { \prime }$ planes,respectively.

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-33
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content: Micro/nanostructural analysis showed that increased laser energy deposition promotes both grain and needle growth.Additionally, it was observed that the application of the $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ laser power promotes a reduction in internal residual stress of parts,with no direct change in the nanostructure of the crystals.These observations suggest that even though microstructural tailoring can be achieved,with variation in energy deposition through changes in laser power,the overall as-built microstructure still remains martensitic.The crystal structure is largely dependent on the rate of cooling,which in the case of AM printed alloy is still in the order of $1 0 ^ { 3 } ~ \mathrm { K } / s ,$ ，which gives rise to the martensitic structure (Murr et al., 2009). To achieve an $( \alpha + \beta )$ structure, powder bed heating would be required above the $1 7 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ temperature currently used, this would help to further reduce the cooling rate during printing (Ali et al., 2017).

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-34
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content:
Pin-on-Disk measurements of the Ti-6Al-4V alloy samples yielded dynamic coefficient of friction (COF) values in the range 0.62 to 0.69 (Table 5).These are in the range typically found for this alloy in the literature (Qu et al.,2Oo5).A possible explanation for the slight variation in friction obtained for the printed alloys is the presence of varying levels of martensitic protrusions on the surface of samples, from each sample group.Furthermore,visual inspection of the samples surface after wear testing exhibited large amounts of wear debris. Zivic et al.(2Ol1) explained that due to the direct contact between the oxide layers of the sample and the ball, the formation of debris and chemical bioproducts occurs.

Analysis of the wear tracks obtained after 36oO s of abrasive wear, using profilometry showed noticeable differences across the laser powers used. The tracks obtained for theloo W coupons displayed an uneven,aggressive wear with an average track depth of $5 . 3 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and wear volume of $0 . 0 6 ~ \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ . The $2 5 0 \mathrm { W }$ samples displayed a much more even but deeper wear track,with an average depth of $4 . 6 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and wear volume of $0 . 0 8 ~ \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ .While 40o W track showed an average depth of $4 . 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ with wear volume of $0 . 0 5 ~ \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ (Table 3). Qualitative inspection indicated that the wear profile for parts formed using 1oo W laser were less homogeneous,compared to those obtained for parts printed at higher power.This observation is supported by literature reports,where the microstructure has been shown to have a direct influence on the wear resistance of the titanium alloy surfaces (Ding et al.,2Oo2 and Khorasani et al., 2019).

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-35
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content: As demonstrated in Table 5,as the laser power increases there is a corresponding increase in hardness from 365 to $4 0 0 \mathrm { H V }$ .The hardness variations within a given sample type is likely to be due to variations in the martensitic morphology.For example,it was generally observed that areas which were found to have a higher number of needle-like structures,exhibited higher hardness.The microhardness values are similar to those reported for AM Ti-6Al-4V parts in the literature (Table 1). The values are generally higher than the $3 4 9 \mathrm { H V }$ typically obtained forthewrought mill annealed alloy(AMS4911). Chandramohan et al.(2O18) studied the heat treatment effect on the mechanical properties of additively manufactured Ti-6Al-4V.Results obtained in their study are in good agreement with that observed in this study,where a COF of 0.62,wear depth of $0 . 0 8 ~ m m ^ { 3 }$ and hardness of $3 6 0 \mathrm { H V }$ were obtained for as-built parts.In summary,it is concluded that there is a clear correlation between laser input energy and surface properties.Both wear resistance and hardness increasing for samples fabricated at higher laser powers.With increase in power there was a reduction in porosity and a change in grain morphology.This included the formation of wider prior $\beta$ grains with longer primary $\alpha$ needles, exhibiting a decrease in thickness.In addition, there was a relatively small variation in mechanical results for parts printed with the same power,at the 5 locations across the build plate.This observation supports the results from the InfiniAM in-situ measurements,which indicates that there was a relatively homogeneous exposure to laser energy at each of the 5 print locations.This result is similar to that observed by Egan and Dowling (2019),who reported that a broadly linear relationship between input energy, the mechanical properties of the part and the data generated by the process monitoring system.

content: Fig.8 shows the distribution of ultimate tensile stress (UTS) and elongation for tensile test specimens,obtained using the laser powers investigated in this study. The average Young's modulus for test samples increasedfrom $6 3 . 0 6 ~ \pm ~ 7 . 8 7$ ， $9 0 . 6 1 ~ \pm ~ 1 5 . 6 3$ and $9 6 . 6 1 ~ \pm ~ 5 . 0 2 \mathrm { G P a }$ for samples built using l0o,25O and $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ ,respectively.UTS as well as elongation increases with laser power.The standard deviation for samples made using both low power $( 1 0 0 \mathsf { W } )$ and high power (4oo W) are significantly larger when compared to the laser power of 250 W.Comparing the test samples printed at higher powers, the coupons built using $3 5 0 \mathrm { W }$ exhibited not only high tensile strength, but a relatively small deviation between the five test samples investigated at this power.Just to highlight that due to both the higher porosity and brittleness of samples printed using 1Oo and $1 5 0 \mathrm { W }$ powers,it was not possible to accurately record their yield strengths. Moreover,it appears that parts produced at $1 5 0 \mathrm { W }$ showed greatest variation in tensile properties,yielding at around $4 0 0 \mathrm { { M P a } }$ .This variation is most likely associated with the higher level of porosity present when compared to tensile samples produced using high powers.It has been reported that during tensile deformation,pore coalescence is the main crack formation mechanism (Ellyin, 2O12 and Krakhmalev et al., 2016).Additionally,Castany et al. (2Oo7） proposed that during deformation,all gliding dislocations have an a-type Burgers vector, resulting in a large density of rectilinear long screw dislocations.This suggests that during tensile testing,agglomeration of smaller α' needles occurs within the parent prior $\beta$ grains almost perpendicular to the active Burgers vector,restricting lattice accommodation resulting in brittle fractures.Ali et al.(20l7) and Liütjering et al.

content:
(1998) both reported that $\alpha$ needle size is a determining factor for the mechanical properties for SLM printed parts.In this study,as the laser power increased from $1 0 0 { - } 4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ ,a significant increase in tensile performance was observed.The relatively poor performance at lower power is likely to be associated with increased porosity and variation in microstructural features.Flower (l99O） investigated the effect of grain structure on ductility of titanium produced by hot working.In his study it was concluded that with reduction in feature size (such as $\alpha$ and prior $\beta$ grain),there was an enhancement in ductility.In the current study there did not appear to be a strong correlation between the level of elongation and the input power (and hence feature size),in the range 200-40o W. There was a notable effect at lower powers (down to $1 0 0 \mathsf { W } )$ ,however the significantly enhanced level of porosity would also impact on grain growth.

It is clear that varying point distance has a significant influence on the tensile strength of PBFLB parts.By increasing the point distance above $6 3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,the mechanical properties decrease significantly,elongation being the most affected. Similarly,as exposure time is decreased from $7 2 \mu \mathrm { s }$ ，the mechanical properties of the parts decrease.These results are most likely influenced by the formation of discontinuous tracks,which results in increased porosity and associated brittleness,as discussed earlier.It is worth noting that using both $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ and exposure time of $1 4 4 \mu \mathrm { s } ,$ resulted in a decrease in mechanical properties,whilst using a point distance of $3 1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ yields superior tensile properties even at elevated energy inputs. name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-42
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content:
The effect of systematically varying laser power on geometry,microstructural evolution and mechanical properties for Ti-6Al-4V parts produced using the laser powder bed fusion process,was examined in this study.

The main conclusions are as follows:

1 Part geometry was shown to alter with input laser energy.A laser power of $1 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ produced parts with dimensions closer to that specified using the CAD design. However, due to insuficient energy during printing, inconsistencies in the melt pool occurred inducing an increased level of porosity.Laser power of $2 5 0 \mathrm { W }$ resulted in an increase of $2 \%$ in bulk size with reduced porosity,while the 400 W resulted in a further increase to $4 \%$ ,with additional pore formation due to the “keyhole”effect.

2 All samples exhibited a martensitic structure.The average $\beta$ grains widths increased from 110 to $2 0 8 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and average $\propto$ needle thickness decrease from 2.24 to $0 . 6 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ respectively,with increased laser power from 1oo-40o W.These changes are attributed to the partial in-situ annealing caused by a higher laser energy input favouring grain growth.

3 The microstructures of samples manufactured using the three different laser power investigated were all shown to be martensitic $\mathfrak { a } ^ { ' }$ ： The use of increased laser power (4oo W) appears to reduce internal residual stress as observed with the shift in the $( 1 0 1 ) _ { \alpha } { } ^ { \prime }$ plane towards the theoretical value.Additionally, the presence of the $( 0 0 2 ) _ { \alpha } ,$ plane was more evident,suggesting that higher laser deposition promotes reduced texture.

content:
4 The mechanical properties of the printed alloys displayed a direct correlation with changes in microstructure.Pin-on-Disk measurements demonstrated that wear rates do not directly correlated to microhardness or porosity of martensitic structures.The tensile test results,however,were found to be directly influenced by porosity where samples manufactured using $2 5 0 \mathrm { W }$ yielded the lowest porosity,in addition to the smallest distribution of yield strength and elongation.

![](images/46308156403835bede383cc26f2066e63c51caa9f930ac7d95d92ca776632de0.jpg)

name: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan-part-44
fileName: 2020 - J. Materials Processing Technology - R. Kaschel, Celikin, Dowling - Effects of laser power on geometry, microstructure and mechan.pdf
content: It was demonstrated from this study that variation of laser power, results ina distinctive influence in the microstructure and mechanical properties of as-built parts.Whereby high energy deposition resulted in a more homogenous microstructure with superior tensile properties. Optimisation of the point distance results in alloy parts exhibiting superior mechanical properties and lower standard deviation,when compared to laser power and exposure time at equivalent energy densities. XRD and grain analysis suggests that microstructural tailoring is achievable,however changes in the overall crystal structure appears unattainable through simply changing key parameters in the additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-4V alloy.The peak shift observed in the XRD results for parts printed at the lower and higher laser powers,would indicate some reduction in the level of thermal residual stress for the latter parts.While the focus of this paper has been particularly on laser power and to a lesser extent on exposure time and point distance, amongst the other parameters which will influence the properties of the printed part are hatch distance,focal distance,scan speed and scan strategy. Just to stress that the effect of these parameters will also have to be considered in order to optimise part performance.

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-3
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content: The application of the Ti-6Al-4V alloy is known in diverse industries,such as aerospace,automobile, chemical,and medical ones [1-3]. This popularity is attributed to the low density-to-strength ratio, exceptional corrosion resistance,and biocompatibility of this $\alpha + \beta$ Titanium (Ti) alloy [4]. In Ti-6Al-4V, Ti is alloyed with 6 wt $\%$ aluminium (Al), which is an $\alpha \cdot$ -stabiliser, and $4 \mathrm { w t } \%$ vanadium (V), which is a $\beta$ -stabiliser lowering the transus temperature [5]. Hence, Ti-6Al-4V exists as a mixture of $\alpha + \beta$ equilibrium microstructure at room temperature. Even though it is known for its high performance in various aspects, the industrial use of Ti-6Al-4V remains limited to specific applications due to its high cost. The major cost manifests from the processng steps involved in the manufacturing of Ti components, which require high energy inputs while creating a significant amount of waste [6-8]. Therefore, the need for alternative manufacturing methods is growing, and additive manufacturing (AM) is one of the top contenders.

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-4
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content: AMplays an essentialrole in mitigating the aforementioned issue with conventional manufacturing of Ti-6Al-4V [9]. In any AM proces,a computer-aided design (CAD) file is used as an input, and it is then primarily fabricated in a layered pattern [10]. Due to the layered approach, AM alows high design complexity freedom [11]. Apart from the well-established complexity advantage, AM permits minimal raw material wastage, except in the case of support structures [12]. This study focusses on the laser powder bed fusion (L-PBF) process, commonly known as selective laser melting (SLM) [13]. The operational concept of the technology can be found in [14]. The material flexibility and ability to produce components with high precision due to small beam diameter (typically $2 0 { \mathrm { - } } 1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } )$ lasers are some of the added advantages of SLM when compared to other metal-based AM technologies [15,16]. SLM has reached a point where nearly $1 0 0 \%$ $( 9 9 . 7 \%$ or more) dense parts can be fabricated [17]. SLM parts have shown evidence of possessing comparable or even often superior mechanical properties when compared with traditionally manufactured parts [18,19]. Complexity freedom of AM and the exceptional properties of Ti-6Al-4V opens the opportunity for numerous high-end applications [20,21]. For instance, the "buy to fly" ratio for conventionally produced large aerospace parts can be in range of 8-12:1 and sometimes as high as 30:1, whereas it is approximately1.5:1 in the case of components manufactured by AM [22].

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-5
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content: The increasing use of SLM, especially with Ti-6Al-4V, in high-value applications, necesitates the manufacturing process becoming highly consistent and reliable. However， defects，such as hydrogen porosity,lack-of-fusion pores,keyhole defects, cracks,and impurities,are common [23,24]. The significant influence of defects on the mechanical properties of Ti-6Al-4V parts is not unusual[25,26]. Hence,it is essential to analyse and suppress defect formation to ensure a reliable manufacturing system for large-scale industry acceptance. Gibson et al. [27] reported that melt pool size, layer thickness, scan speed, scan strategy， etc.， are highly significant parameters to manufacturing high density components using SLM. Melt pool size and depth are majorly dependent on the energy absorbed by the powder bed when scanned by the laser [28]. Numerous studies have been performed to produce highly dense SLM parts by optimising the process parameters [29-33]. Gibson et al. [27] categorically listed the process parameters which affect the density, and hence the mechanical properties of SLM parts, including the laser power, scan speed, hatch spacing, layer thicknes,and scan strategy. Process parameter optimisation for defect suppression and overallbuild quality in the case of Ti-6Al-4V SLM parts has also been extensively studied [34-37]. There are several studies also focusing on the microstructure and mechanical properties of SLM Ti-6Al-4V parts [38-41]. However, minimal studies have recognised the importance of the size of the features on the quality of these parts; i.e., how the size of a feature can influence the density, microstructure, and mechanical properties of a particular part due to variations in the thermal profile within these features during processing.

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-6
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content: There have been a few studies that indicate how the overall microscopic and macroscopic quality of SLM parts can be size-dependent [42-45]. However, the current literature lacks a systematic study which reports on the influence of the size of a sample on the porosity and microstructure of as-built Ti-6Al-4V samples. Further, studies on the impacts of changes in size on the performances of stress-relieved Ti-6Al-4V specimens under tensile loading are scarce. Therefore, the current study aims at filling the research gap by attempting to explore the influence of the "size of features" on SLM parts' densities, hardness values, microstructures, and mechanical properties.

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-7
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content:
Plasma atomized Ti-6Al-4V Grade 23 powder supplied by LPW Technologies (UK) was used in this study. The chemical composition of the powder is presented in Table 1. The powder size distribution was determined using a Mastersizer 3000 (Malvern, UK), which uses the laser diffraction method [46]. D10, D50,and D90 values for powder particles were 19.6,31.5, and $4 9 . 1 \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ respectively. The powder particles had a spherical morphology with a few satellites attached to the particles. Table 1. Chemical composition of Ti-6Al-4V Grade 23 powder provided by LPW.
ElementNCHFeAlVTi
CompShetin lt %)0.030.080.01250.255.5-6.53.5-4.5Balance
All samples were manufactured with a Realizer SLM50 system, equipped with a $1 0 0 W$ yttrium fibre laser, using a fixed set of process parameters. Samples were fabricated using $8 2 . 5 \ W$ laser power, $2 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { s }$ exposure time, $2 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ point distance, $9 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ hatch distance, and $4 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ layer thickness. These parameters were optimised for $5 \mathrm { m m }$ cubes in prior research. A double scanning strategy, where each layer was scanned twice using alternate parallel scanning vectors, was employed. The process chamber was flushed with argon to attain an oxygen level below $0 . 5 \%$ ：

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-8
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content:
Two sets of specimens were manufactured for the various tests conducted in this study (Figure la,b). Orthogonal planes of each sample category were defined as per ASTMF2921-11[47]. Cuboidal samples C1-C5 were manufactured to analyse porosity and microstructure related changes. For each sample, three repetitions were fabricated in order to analyse one orthogonal plane per repetition for every size. This was done to attain statistical confidence in the data. All orthogonal planes (frontal YZ, lateral $\mathrm { \times } Z ,$ and horizontal XY) were analysed for porosity and microstructure using a Nikon Optiphot 100 (Nikon, Japan) optical microscope (OM) and image processing using Image J[48]. The polished samples were tested for micro-hardness using Buehler Wilson VH3100 vickers hardness tester (Buehler, Germany) with a $5 0 0 \mathrm { g }$ load and 10 s dwell time.

![](images/f64e93573841ef91112a161a17209f935208b7b03ef97ec26b30e3d540277423.jpg)  
Figure 1. (a) C1-C5 samples with a fixed Z height of $5 \mathrm { m m }$ and variation in length and width from 1 to $5 \mathrm { m m }$ . Height was fixed as $5 \mathrm { m m }$ to avoid poor handling of smal samples. (b) CAD drawing of tensile samples (T1-T5) and their size parameters. (c) Representation of T1 sample oriented in Flat $_ { \textrm { X Z } }$ direction.

Non-standard tensile bars (Figure 1b) were designed in order to fit in the Realizer system's cylindrical build volume ( $7 0 \mathrm { m m }$ diameter and $4 0 \mathrm { m m }$ height). The tensile samples were built in flat XZ direction (Figure 1c). Depending on the gauge width variation from 1 to $5 \mathrm { m m }$ , the name varied from T1 to T5, respectively. The naming convention defined in Figure 1 willbe used hereafter. Block support structures were added to support overhang features in the tensile bars (Figure Ic). Three repetitions for each tensile bar were manufactured for statistical confidence.

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-9
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content: All tensile specimens were stress-relieved at $7 3 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $^ { 2 \mathrm { h } }$ in argon environment. The samples were tested using an Instron 5969 universal testing machine (Instron, MA, USA). A black and white speckle pattern was applied to the samples to collct strain data using a video gauge. The crosshead speed was $2 \mathrm { m m / m i n } ,$ and tests were performed at room temperature. A Hitatchi TM3030 scanning electron microscope SEM (Hitatchi, Japan) was used for fractography analysis on the tensile specimens after the tests.

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-11
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content:
The 3D reconstructions of the cross-sectioned samples and their porosity percentages are presented in Figure 2. In the majority of the samples,defects preferentially aligned around the edges of the cross sections. This preferential alignment could be linked to the porosity emerging between the contour scan and core scan regions. This is in agreement with an earlier study by Yang et al. [49] for Al alloys.

![](images/5355a0a4c269c2a23b1359d3fc87c8bcc5319e45f2b947c18b163768d745a011.jpg)  
Figure 2. Variation of porosity percentage with respect to the size parameters of the samples. C1 had the highest porosity, and ${ \mathrm { C } } 4$ had the lowest. Error bars in the plot represent the standard deviations of the values.

In a study by Koutney et al. [42], Al alloy cubes with varying edge lengths were manufactured. The study reported that the porosity in the top plane of the cubes increased from $0 . 0 3 \%$ to $5 . 9 5 \%$ on changing the size from 5 to $1 3 \mathrm { m m }$ , respectively. Analysing the size effect was, however, not the focus of that tudy. In another study by Dong etal.43],an increase inporosity was reported withdecreasing the gauge diameter of AlSil $0 \mathrm { M g }$ samples; porosity changed from $1 . 8 7 \%$ to $0 . 1 \%$ by increasing the gauge diameter from 1 to $5 \mathrm { m m }$ , respectively. This agrees with our findings supporting the hypothesis that only a specific window of sizes can be manufactured with high density by using a fixed set of parameters. Once beyond this window, the process parameters will require readjustment. Based on the current results, we conclude that there was an increase in porosity with the decrease in sample size. To define an acceptable size window for a particular set of parameters,an extensive set of samples with size variation is required. It was noted that larger samples (C3,C4,and C5)had lesser variations in their porosities; however, smaller samples (C1 and C2) showed much higher density variations.
summary: 3.1. Influence of Size on Density, Microstructure, and Hardness of As-Built SLM Ti-6Al-4V Parts - Part 1/6

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-12
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content: Upon decreasing the sample size from C5 to C2, porosity increased by nearly $1 2 0 \%$ . The increasing porosity with size decrease could be atributed to the temperature distribution (thermal profile) intrinsic to the process. Sample C1 is the extreme case with porosity exceeding $4 \%$ , the defects in C1 being comprised of a mixture of keyhole and lack-of-fusion pores. However,lack-of-fusion defects dominated over the keyhole defects in majority of the cross-sections along allthe orthogonal planes.Lack-of-fusion defects typically correspond to insufficient energy received by the metal powder, limiting the melting and fusion of layers and resulting in pores/voids with unsintered powder trapped inside the pores [23]. The high number of lack-of-fusion defects in C1can be atributed to the fewer number of scan tracks as the size decreased, which might have led to insuficient energy inputs, resulting in poor melting and fusion of the powder.
summary: 3.1. Influence of Size on Density, Microstructure, and Hardness of As-Built SLM Ti-6Al-4V Parts - Part 2/6

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-13
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content:
To confirm this hypothesis, we trialld four sets of process parameters (varying the laser power and exposure time) for C1 samples and analysed the density variation. As shown in Figure 3, upon increasing the laser power (i.e., increasing the energy density), porosity reduced significantly. Unexpectedly, upon reducing the laser power, internal porosity still reduced; however, the surface roughness increased significantly,leading to poor qualitysamples. It was also observed that on fixing the laser power and reducing the scan speed (stillincreasing the energy density using a different approach), porosity improvement was beter than the case of increasing the scan speed. Conclusive proof requires further research on process parameter optimisation with small samples to deal with uncertainties. However, the current results still prove the insufficiency of the input laser energy in the original C1 samples. The study by Sun et al. [50] suggests that Ti-6Al-4V samples possess high density when manufactured using high laser power and low scanning speeds. This statement holds for C1 samples manufactured using a range of process parameters (Figure 3).

![](images/5710abe0ff336ab5debf97febf58804c63f38503bd0cf4aa43c1b5ce7ebd7313.jpg)  
Figure 3. Changes in porosity percentages by varying laser current and exposure time process parameters. Original C1 samples had $3 . 6 2 \%$ porosity resulting from a $8 2 . 5 \ W$ laser and exposure time of $2 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { s }$
summary: 3.1. Influence of Size on Density, Microstructure, and Hardness of As-Built SLM Ti-6Al-4V Parts - Part 3/6

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-14
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content:
In terms of the metallurgical properties, studies show that the microstructure of SLM as-built Ti-6Al-4V comprises $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ martensitic phases. The $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ grains “grow within elongated prior $\beta$ grains, which grow through the deposition of consecutive layers" [40,51]. In the samples analysed in this study, lateral and frontal planes comprised of fine $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ acicular grains with prior $\beta$ grain boundaries are visible in the micrographs in Figures 4 and 5. This is in agreement with the literature. $\beta$ grains had a lenticular morphology, while $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ ones were organized within the prior $\beta$ grain boundaries [52]. Top planes, on the other hand, revealed cros-sections of the $\beta$ grains (Figure 4).

$\beta$ columnar grains were present because solidification of Ti-6Al-4V in SLM takes place in the $\beta$ phase field, and heat is mainly conducted away vertically [38]. The orientation of $\beta$ grain boundaries has a high dependence on heat conduction direction when the laser is scanning a layer [40]. Therefore, with the double scanning strategy used in the current study, prior $\beta$ grain boundary vectors were expected to be parallel to the build direction. This held for the samples in this study, with some misorientations observed in the smallest sample C1 (Figure 5). Thijs et al. [40] reported extreme dependence of the prior $\beta$ grain boundary's orientation on the scanning pattern, and hence, on the local heat transfer conditions in the powder bed; i.e.,the thermal gradient. Therefore,the misorientations observed in C1 could be attributed to the limited local heat conduction in any particular direction resulting from insufficient energy input, as discussed in case of porosity variation due to change in size.
summary: 3.1. Influence of Size on Density, Microstructure, and Hardness of As-Built SLM Ti-6Al-4V Parts - Part 4/6

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-15
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content:
![](images/990300a7eceeb8595fb845c23a1cd5b05ae828f57efc9dd118bf49113c214770.jpg) Figure 4. Optical micrographs representing the microstructures of samples $C 1 { \mathrm { - } } C 5 ,$ ，showing the isometric reconstruction in the three orthogonal planes for each sample. BD: build direction. ![](images/590bf07cda6243035700d2341539089f307e0b0ec274cedffe8e2f84edeb5828.jpg) Figure 5. Optical micrographs representing the microstructures of the lateral XZ planes of C1-C5. The $\beta$ grain boundaries in samples C1-C5 spanned across tens of layers,with each layer being $4 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ in height. The $\beta$ grain width was mostly consistent in all the samples, as ${ \approx } 9 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ which corresponded to the hatch distance used in the study. Table 2 lists the $\beta$ grain size for each sample size. Therefore, the morphologies and sizes of the prior $\beta$ grain boundaries in the as-built Ti-6Al-4V parts were not significantly affected within the acceptable size range, as also noted by Zhao et al. [45]. Table 2. Prior $\beta$ grain width in as-built Ti-6Al-4V samples (C2-C5).

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-16
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content:
Figure 6 represents the micro-hardness profile map for samples C1 and C5. Figure 7,on the other hand, shows a plot for the overallhardness variation with respect to the sample size. There was no particular trend in hardness values with the change in size. Considering the error bars, hardness values for all te samples were comparable, and the two extreme samples (C5 and C1) had a rather close average hardness value ( ${ \approx } 3 8 6 $ HV). This is comparable to the micro-hardness of Ti-6Al-4V reported in the literature, which typically varies between 340 and $5 0 0 \mathrm { H V }$ [40]. Since the change in the sample size did not have a significant influence on the material's microstructure,the hardness of the material was not affected. This is owing to the nature of hardness as a material property, which mainly corresponds to the microstructure and not necessarily to the defects to a certain extent. It is important to note that the pore fraction in a sample can influence the hardness of a material once it surpasses a critical limit [53,54], which is material dependent. For the case of Ti-6Al-4V within the range investigated in the current study, this was not substantial.

![](images/4529bed971a232bc9fe23c51a8ddacc731dd62ae367435cc6c4b1f1410ada96b.jpg)  
Figure 6. Micrograph representing the microstructure of sample C1 in (a) showing the prior $\beta$ grains slightly misoriented alongside the corresponding micro-hardness profile. (b) The microstructure of sample C5 showing the prior $\beta$ grains growing parallel to the build direction, along with the respective micro-hardness profile.

![](images/64e0e3aa82ca69d2698237bfd6971e575e7fe88c6ae8777e53e80c36c104e36c.jpg)  
Figure 7. Average hardness Values for samples C1-C5. Error bars in the plot represent the standard deviation values.
summary: 3.1. Influence of Size on Density, Microstructure, and Hardness of As-Built SLM Ti-6Al-4V Parts - Part 6/6

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-17
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content:
The microstructure of as-built SLM Ti-6Al-4V might not be appropriate for the present applications of conventionally produced $\alpha + \beta$ alloy. This limitation stems from the as-built components showing poor ductility, even though the strength is usually noted to be higher than conventionally manufactured Ti-6Al-4V [55]. In order to maintain a balance between strength and ductility, various post-process treatments have been introduced in the past [39,56]. Figure 8 presents plots for the mechanical properties of tensile (T1-T5) samples.

![](images/3c053785893b28cc4e7db49a9ebea66b3fe58fcf0418d6d22252b19e191222c3.jpg)  
Figure 8. (a) Young's modulus and elongation at break. (b) Tensile stress at yield and ultimate tensile strength of tensile samples. Dashed lines represent the properties for cast Ti-6Al-4V. The average porosity for each sample size is quoted between brackets next to the sample name on the $x$ -axis.
summary: 1.2. Influence of Size on Tensile Properties and the Fracture Mechanism of Stress Relieved Ti-6Al-4V - Part 1/5

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-18
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content: By decreasing the gauge width of tensile samples from 5 to $1 \mathrm { m m }$ , tensile stress at yield (YS), ultimate tensile strength (UTS),and Young's modulus (E) experienced decreases of approximately $1 2 \%$ $1 5 \%$ and $1 4 \%$ , respectively. However, the elongation at break (El) was found to be more sensitive to change in size and decreased by $\approx 5 7 . 6 \%$ . The variation in the tensile properties can also be correlated to the amount of porosity in the samples by parallelism [57]and the gauge size [58]. Literature on the latter shows that the use of non-standard tensile test bars does not affect the strength significantly but can influence Young's modulus and the elongation to break. However, the responses of these properties to variations in the gauge size are not consistent and can be material dependent,as demonstrated by these articles: [58,59]. The lowest values of porosity in samples T3-T5 granted them higher tensile properties. As the porosity content almost doubled in sample T2, the tensile properties of the material started deteriorating. An increase in porosity by almost 15 times in sample T1 resulted in the most significant deterioration in properties within the range investigated in this study. This suggests that the size of features had a significant effct on the mechanical properties of parts processed by SLM due to the correlation between the sizes of the features and the amount of porosity forming in the samples during processing using a fixed set of process parameters.
summary: 1.2. Influence of Size on Tensile Properties and the Fracture Mechanism of Stress Relieved Ti-6Al-4V - Part 2/5

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-19
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content: Figure 9 highlights terrace-like features in both T1 and T5 samples, also known as “layered fracture"[6O]. The fracture surfaces had a relatively flat central portion and shear lips inclined at $4 5 ^ { \circ }$ to the loading direction. The images reveal that the most reasonable fracture mode for the Ti-6Al-4V SLM samples was inter-granular, which is in agreement with the discussion presented by Simoneli et al.[51]. Overall,fracture surfaces were composed of shallow dimples, cleavage facets, and open pores in both cases, suggesting a combination of brittle and ductile fracturing. The maximum porosity or the region with the most unfused powder particles was where the support structures were created during manufacturing. However, T1 possessed greater porosity than T5 when comparing their porosity regions per overall area of the sample's surface (Figure 9).
summary: 1.2. Influence of Size on Tensile Properties and the Fracture Mechanism of Stress Relieved Ti-6Al-4V - Part 3/5

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-20
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content: Interestingly,in the results reported by Dong etal.[43]for AlSi10Mg samples,strength deterioration due to size variation showed a similar overal trend in the change of mechanical properties due to the change in features size to the case of Ti-6Al-4V samples used in the current study. This suggests that size of features had a significant effect on the mechanical properties of the parts processed by SLM,and that the magnitude of its influence is dependent on the set of optimised SLM parameters used. The current study shows a greater influence of change in size on mechanical properties and microstructure compared to the results reported by Zhao et al. [45]for SLM Ti-6Al-4V samples. Zhao et al. [45] manufactured samples in the form of cylinders which were machined down for testing. Therefore, the results might not wholly be comparable to the case of a sample solely manufactured additively without further machining. This is mainly because the thermal profile would be different in the case of printing small features directly (as has been shown in the current study)from printing large structures and then machining out a smaler feature. The former is more relevant to the AM community, since ultimately, SLM is a net shape manufacturing process. This is clearly supported by the porosity distribution presented in Figure 2, which shows that porosity in the smallest samples was mainly located near the edges of the samples. Had these samples been machined,the results may have been in agreement with what has already been published in the literature due to machining out the defected region. This research willalso be more applicable to areas where using the design freedom in AM is of paramount importance, such as the work on fabricating laticed structures where part machining is difficult or impossible.
summary: 1.2. Influence of Size on Tensile Properties and the Fracture Mechanism of Stress Relieved Ti-6Al-4V - Part 4/5

content:
![](images/653652dd1565ea8a76dcd6f6274e5d8956f7d2a23cbdd20578ff187864173fce.jpg)  
Figure 9. Fractography images of (a) T1 and (b) T5 tensile bars. Yellow regions mark the pores on the surface.

Considering the overal results, it is interesting to note that larger samples (T3-T5) displayed higher consistency in terms ofE, UTS,and YS when compared to smaller samples (T1 and T2). A similar trend was also evident in porosity and microstructure variation in the as-built Ti-6Al-4V samples (C1-C5),as discussed earlier. Since hardness is fundamentally related to the yield strength of a material, the yield strengths of the samples with two extreme feature sizes were expected to be of similar scale in this study, when considering the hardness values of samples presented in Figure 7. Therefore, any variation in mechanical properties of the tensile bars with differences in gauge width can be considered dependent on the defect formation induced due to the change in size and not the material itself.
summary: 1.2. Influence of Size on Tensile Properties and the Fracture Mechanism of Stress Relieved Ti-6Al-4V - Part 5/5

name: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise-part-22
fileName: 2020 - Materials - Phutela et al. - The effects of feature sizes in selectively laser melted Ti-6Al-4V parts on the validity of optimise.pdf
content: Thisstudy investigated the influence of feature size on the defect formation, microstructure homogeneity,and mechanical performance of Ti-6Al-4V parts produced by SLM. One of the motives behind this work was to assess the applicability of a fixed set of "optimised" process parameters to features of a wide range of sizes. Various parts were manufactured using a fixed set of parameters, originally optimized for $5 \times 5 \times 5 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ samples, as typically done in SLM, while varying the size between 1 and $5 \mathrm { m m }$ . The results of this study confirmed the dependence of the quality of the samples on their size at a given set of process parameters. As the sample size decreased beyond a certain threshold, porosity increased significantly, resulting in poorer tensile properties (strength and ductility). The yield strength decreased by ${ \sim } 1 2 \%$ , ultimate tensile strength by ${ \sim } 1 5 \%$ and elongation by $\sim 5 6 \%$ , upon decreasing gauge width from 5 to $1 \mathrm { m m }$ . The effects of the sample size on the microstructure and hardness were, however, negligible. The variation in porosity with sample size was attributed to the significant change in the thermal profile and gradients within the material during processing. Lack-of-fusion defects in the smaller samples was exacerbated by the low energy inputs, and increasing the energy density successfully reduced porosity in these samples. This shows that a tweak in the process parameters is necessary to cope with this phenomenon to ensure the fabrication of parts of reliable structural integrityfor allfeature sizes.Massive efforts in the research community are directed towards optimizing the process parameters for materials to be processed by SLM.

content:
However, without taking into account the influence of the feature size,as this study has shown, the applicability willbe compromised, particularly when it comes to applications in the areas where topology optimized and lattced structures are of paramount importance, where standard optimized process parameters might not be reliable.

# HIGHLIGHTS
·Additively manufactured pure Ti exhibits excellent strength,low toxicity and high cost affordability,by a designed strength-ductility tradeoff.   
·As-printed HDH-Ti displayshigh ultimate tensile strength and yield strength,as well as good elongation.   
· In vitro biocompatibility test shows the as-printed HDH-Ti having better biocompatibility than the as-printed atomized Ti samples.   
·The obtained Ti materials have great potential for replacing Ti-6Al-4V in biomedical applications.
