fileName: 2020 - Materials and Design - Dong et al. - Additive manufacturing of pure Ti with superior mechanical performance, low cost, and biocom.pdf
content:
# ABSTRACT
Although numerous reports have elucidated the neurotoxic impacts ofTi-6Al-4V(Ti64) due to the presence of vanadium,itis the most widelyused biomedical Ti material.This is because it exhibits significantlybeter mechanical performance characteristics than thoseof pure Ti. Inaddition to the possibilityoffacilitating the production ofcustomized medicines,selective laser melting (SLM) additive manufacturing (AM) can enable pure Ti to match the properties of Ti64 by utilizing several mechanisms such as grain refinement and solid solution strengthening.These results can be obtained due to the high cooling rate of the AM processand viaapossible modification in the alloy chemistry ofTi. Herein,we reporta novel approach that endows the pure Ti prepared via AM with excellent mechanical properties (ultimate tensile strength,yield strength,elongation,and microhardness of 1057.05 MPa,784.59 MPa, $2 4 . 0 9 \%$ ,and 307 Hv,respectively),corrosion resistance,and biocompatibility,while significantly reducing the costof the powder.The pure Ti material developed in this study has significant potential for useas an advanced biomedical material in a variety of applications such as dental and bone structure replacement.Furthermore,itcan actas a low-cost alternative to biomedical materials such as Ti-6Al-4V.

summary: ABSTRACT, Additive manufacturing of pure Ti with superior mechanical performance,low cost, and biocompatibility for potential replacement of Ti-6Al-4V - Part 2/2

name: 2020 - Materials and Design - Dong et al. - Additive manufacturing of pure Ti with superior mechanical performance, low cost, and biocom-part-3
fileName: 2020 - Materials and Design - Dong et al. - Additive manufacturing of pure Ti with superior mechanical performance, low cost, and biocom.pdf
content:
Compared to biomedical $3 1 6 \mathrm { ~ L ~ }$ stainless steel (316 L SS）and vitallium(CoCrMo),Ti and Ti alloys are more suitable for biomedical applications due to their favorable properties such as lower Yong's modulus and hypotoxicity [1-5]. These properties are promising for the utilization of Ti and its alloys in applications such as artificial hip joints, artificial knee joints,bone plates,dental implants,and stents in blood vessels [6].Among the various Ti alloys,biomedical $\beta$ -typealloys such as Ti-Mo and Ti-Nb-Ta-Zr(TNTZ) alloys are designed to reduce the Young's modulus of Ti-6Al-4V(Ti64) and commercially pure Ti （CPTi)in order to eliminate the so-called stress shielding efect [2]. Unfortunately, many $\beta$ -type alloys contain expensive and/or high melting point elements such as Mo,Nb,and Ta,limiting their clinical applications.Thus,Ti64 and pure Ti are still the most widely used biomedical Ti-based materials [7].

It is well-known that Ti64 exhibits a high corrosion resistance and good biocompatibility.However,it may also release vanadium (V) ions and aluminum (Al) ions into the human body [8]. Both these ions have been documented to exert neurotoxic effects on humans and may be associated with Alzheimer's disease,neuropathy, and osteomalacia [9].In contrast,pure Ti not only displays good corrosion resistance and biocompatibility,but also shows better plasticity $( \sim 3 0 \% )$ and lower Young's modulus (\~110 GPa) than those of the Ti64 alloy.Nevertheless,the use of pure Ti in biomedical applications is hindered by its significantly lower strength and hardness than those of Ti64 [10]. Table S1 further provides details about typical biomedical Ti and Ti alloys in terms of their mechanical properties,corrosion resistance,wear resistance,and biocompatibility.

name: 2020 - Materials and Design - Dong et al. - Additive manufacturing of pure Ti with superior mechanical performance, low cost, and biocom-part-4
fileName: 2020 - Materials and Design - Dong et al. - Additive manufacturing of pure Ti with superior mechanical performance, low cost, and biocom.pdf
content:
Selective laser melting (SLM) is a common additive manufacturing (AM) technology [11,12]. SLM can be used to produce both bulk and dense Ti materials as well as lattice structures for reducing the modulus mismatch between implants and bone structures [13,14].For instance, Attar et al.[15] prepared CP-Ti parts using SLM with a microhardness of 261 Hv and an ultimate tensile strength of $7 5 7 \mathrm { M P a }$ In comparison, Choi et al.[16] fabricated CP-Ti by using electron beam melting (EBM),another mainstream AM technology; the obtained specimens exhibited an ultimate tensile strength of 711 MPa and a yield strength of 661 MPa.From another EBM report, the as-prepared CP-Ti showed microhardness at ${ \sim } 1 5 0 ~ \mathrm { H v }$ [17]. Comparing between SLM and EBM, the latter is more capable to process high melting point materials and/ or brittle materials due to the associated high beam power and low residual stress [18].The precision of EBM,however,is often lower than SLM due to a few factors,including coarser powder material to be used and a larger beam size [18].To process CP-Ti and Ti-6Al-4V, SLM is the most desirable AM approach for the associated better geometry accuracy, surface quality and overall mechanical performance [18].

Although the aforementioned SLM-prepared CP-Ti shows superior mechanical properties than those of the conventionally fabricated CPTi,its mechanical properties are still lower than those of Ti64.Thus, improving the CP-Ti performance is a challenging but rewarding task. The successful development of CP-Ti with the necessary high mechanical performance will enable the replacement of Ti64 with CP-Ti ina wide range of biomedical and/or structural applications.

name: 2020 - Materials and Design - Dong et al. - Additive manufacturing of pure Ti with superior mechanical performance, low cost, and biocom-part-5
fileName: 2020 - Materials and Design - Dong et al. - Additive manufacturing of pure Ti with superior mechanical performance, low cost, and biocom.pdf
content:
While the strength ofCP-Ti is low,its ductility is signifcantly higher than that of Ti64,with ultra-pure Ti showing an elongation of up to $65 \%$ [19]. Such high ductility leaves a large space for the strength-ductility trade-off, implying that it may be possible to produce CP-Ti with superior strength by slightly reducing its ductility.Such a change in the mechanical properties of pure Ti may be achieved by exploiting the solid strengthening effect of oxygen,which is a powerful and convenient approach for strengthening Ti-based materials [20].

Based on the above-mentioned rationale,we investigated the use of SLM in this study for the development of pure Ti with superior properties; this was aimed at replacing Ti64as a biomedical Ti material, based on the following pathway:

a.Modify a hydrogenated-dehydrogenated Ti (HDH-Ti) powder with a high oxygen content (\~ O.3 wt.% oxygen) and render it printable.   
b.Print HDH-Ti into a dense bulk material.   
c.Realize the solution hardening potential of the HDH-Ti and improve its mechanical properties to match those of Ti64.   
d.Demonstrate that the developed material exhibits a high mechanical performance,biocompatibility,and low cost, enabling it to compete with Ti64.

The particles of the HDH-Ti powder used in this study are nonspherical, rendering its direct printing using SLM difficult if not impossible. Irregularly shaped powders do not flow easily and tend to be mechanically interlocked and entangled with each other,thereby hindering their flow on the powder bed.However,our recent research found that it is possible to modify the low-cost HDH-Ti powder into a spherical, printable Ti powder using a dedicated mechanical ball milling process [21,22]. Compared to the atomized Ti powder,the preparation of the HDH-Ti powder is significantly simpler,rendering it a highly cost-competitive material.

name: 2020 - Materials and Design - Dong et al. - Additive manufacturing of pure Ti with superior mechanical performance, low cost, and biocom-part-6
fileName: 2020 - Materials and Design - Dong et al. - Additive manufacturing of pure Ti with superior mechanical performance, low cost, and biocom.pdf
content: In this study,a series of processing techniques have been used including SLM printing and ball milling modification.Further,several methods were used to achieve sample characterization such as highresolution transmission electron microscopy(HRTEM) and cell immunofluorescence staining for the biocompatibility test.The underlying mechanism for achieving a high mechanical performance was also elucidated.The final SLM-developed HDH-Ti displays outstanding mechanical properties and low cost,while demonstrating its high potential for use in biomedical applications,including as a possible replacement for the well-known Ti64 alloy.

# 2. Methods


# 2.1. Raw material and powder modification
Fragmented HDH-Ti powders ( $\mathrm { \dot { Q } } _ { 1 0 } = 1 4 . 8 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ${ \mathrm { d } } _ { 5 0 } = 4 1 . 9 { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ${ \sf d } _ { 9 0 } =$ $9 2 . 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,provided by Northwest Institute for Non-ferrous Metal Research, China) and spherical gas atomized Ti (GA-Ti) powders ( $\mathrm { { ( } d } _ { 1 0 } =$ $1 0 . 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $\mathrm { d } _ { 5 0 } = 2 8 . 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $\mathrm { d } _ { 9 0 } = 4 8 . 1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,produced by AP & C, Canada) were used in this study.A laser particle size analyzer (Master 3000, Worcestershire Corporation, UK) was used to determine the particle size distribution of the powder.The chemical composition of the powder was measured by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry(ICP-AES) and an oxygen & nitrogen analyzer(ON736, LECO Corporation，USA)．A planetary ball milling machine (Pulverisette5,Fritsch Corporation,Germany)was conducted to modify the original HDH-Ti powder using an agate grinding ball.The powderto-ball weight ratio is 1:3.The modification process was carried out under high-purity argon atmosphere using a small amount of alcohol as particle control agent (PCA) with a rotation speed of $1 2 0 \mathrm { r p m }$ and a ball milling duration of $^ { 4 \mathrm { h } }$

# 2.2. SLM processing
The HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples were fabricated using an SLM125HL instrument,which was equipped with a single 4Oo W fiber laser that exhibited the laser powers of 110-250 W and scanning speeds of $6 0 0 { - } 1 0 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ . In the printing process,a layer thickness of $0 . 0 3 \mathrm { m m }$ and a hatch distance of $0 . 1 2 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ were used.Each layer was scanned in the continuous laser mode,wherein the angle was constantly changed by $7 5 ^ { \circ }$ ; the scanning pattern was observed to be zigzag.
summary: 2. Methods, 2.1. Raw material and powder modification, 2.2. SLM processing

content: Rigaku Smartlab? diffractometer in the 20 range of $3 0 ^ { \circ } - 9 0 ^ { \circ }$ under $4 5 \mathrm { k V }$ and $2 0 0 \mathrm { m A C u K \alpha }$ radiation.A field emission scanning electron microscope(SEM,Zeiss Merlin,Germany) operated at $5 \mathrm { k V }$ was used to study the morphologies of the original powder,modified powder,and the asprinted sample.Prior to the microstructure analysis,a polished sample was etched for $4 0 ~ s$ using a solution consisting of $4 ~ \mathrm { v o l \% }$ HF, $6 \ : \mathrm { v o l \% }$ $\mathrm { H N O } _ { 3 }$ and $9 0 ~ \mathrm { v o l \% }$ distilled water.Electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD） measurements were performed at an acceleration voltage of $2 0 ~ \mathrm { k V }$ in an SEM equipped with an EDAX Velocity TM EBSD camera (AMETEK Incorporation, USA).The samples were ground and polished using standard metallographic methods and were further polished by a vibratorypolisher(VibroMet $\textsuperscript { \textregistered 2 }$ ,Buehler Corporation,USA) at $5 0 \mathrm { H z }$ for $^ { 4 \mathrm { h } }$ to prepare the samples for EBSD.Transmission electron microscopy(TEM,Tecnai F3O,USA) was performed at $3 0 0 \mathrm { k V }$ and the associated selected area electron diffraction (SAED) was used to elucidate the details of the microstructure and the crystal structure of the phase. The samples for the TEM study were prepared using a focused ion beam system (Helios Nanolab 6OOi, Thermo Fisher Scientific Corporation, USA).The Archimedes method was used to calculate relative density of the as-printed samples:(a) Mass of the as-printed samples was measured in two different ways,one in pure water and one in air, using a precision electronic balance;(b) a measured density was then determined based on the Archimedes' principle;and (c) its value was then used to calculate the relative density by dividing it against the theoretical density of CP-Ti $\mathrm { \Omega } = 4 .

content:
# 2.4. Mechanical properties
A tensile machine (CMT 5504,MTS Systems Corporation,USA) equipped with a $1 0 \mathrm { m m }$ gauge length extensometer was used to perform the tensile tests at a constant strain rate of $0 . 2 \mathrm { m m / m i n }$ at room temperature.The parallel section of the as-printed tensile specimen has a thickness of $2 \mathrm { m m }$ and a width of $4 \mathrm { m m }$ Dimension of the tensile samples and the corresponding laser scanning strategy are shown in Fig.S1.A microhardness tester (HXD-100OTMC, Shanghai Taiming Optical Instrument Corporation, China) was used to measure the microhardness of the as-printed sample at a load of $1 0 0 0 { \mathrm { g } }$ and a dwell time of $1 0 s .$

# 2.5.Surface roughness and static contact angle
A 3D optical microscope(Contour GT,Bruker Corporation,Germany) was used to characterize the surface roughness of the as-printed HDHTiand GA-Ti samples.At least three samples were measured for each material,and three different areas were tested for each sample.The surface roughness parameter, Ra (arithmetic mean deviation of contours, ISO 4287-1997),was evaluated using the Vision analyzer software after polishing both materials using monocrystalline diamond suspension $( 1 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ . The static contact angles of the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples were measured using a contact angle goniometer (VCA Optima,AST Product, Inc., USA) by studying the digital photographs of a drop of deionized water in direct contact with the surface.All the presented data were the mean values of at least six independent measurements.
summary: 2.4. Mechanical properties, 2.5.Surface roughness and static contact angle

To obtain a good surface,the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples with a diameter of $1 2 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ and a thickness of $3 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ were polished with silicon carbide sandpapers with the particle sizes of 36O #, 600 #, 1000 #,1500 #,and $2 0 0 0 \# .$ Analytically pure NaCl was dissolved in deionized water as a corrosive medium,and a $3 . 5 \%$ NaCl aqueous solution was prepared.An electrochemical workstation （CS310,Corrtest

Corporation, China) and a three-electrode battery consisting of a platinum plate as the counter electrode,a saturated calomel electrode (SCE)as the reference electrode,and the as-printed samples as the working electrode (WE）were used for the electrochemical measurements.First, strong cathodic polarization was performed at $- 5 0 0 \mathrm { m V }$ (vs.SCE) for $0 . 5 \mathrm { { h } }$ to remove the initial passivation film from the WE surface.Prior to the polarization measurements,the open-circuit potentials(OCPs) of all of the WEs were monitored for $^ { 1 \mathrm { h } }$ until a stable OCP was reached.After obtaining a stable OCP,electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS） measurements were performed in a frequency range of $1 0 0 \mathrm { k H z }$ to $1 0 \mathrm { M H z }$ ,using a sinusoidal voltage with an amplitude of $5 \mathrm { m V } .$ Potential dynamic polarization curves of the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples between $- 0 . 5 \mathrm { V }$ and $1 . 6 \mathrm { V }$ were recorded.

# 2.7.1. Cell culture
MG-63 cells (American Type Culture Collection,USA) were seeded in a $2 5 \mathrm { c m } ^ { 2 }$ tissue culture flask with the High Glucose Dulbecco's Modified Eagle Medium(High-GDMEM) containing $1 0 \%$ fetal bovine serum (FBS)and antibiotics( $1 0 0 \mathrm { U } \mathrm { m L } ^ { - 1 }$ penicillin G, $1 0 0 \mathrm { m g } \mathrm { m L } ^ { - 1 }$ streptomycin sulfate,and $0 . 2 5 ~ \mathrm { m g ~ m L ^ { - 1 } }$ amphotericin B) and maintained in an incubator(HF9o,Heal Force Corporation, China) containing $9 5 \%$ air and $5 \% \mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ at $3 7 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } .$ The medium was changed every three days.

# 2.7.2. Cell adhesion testing
MG-63 cells were seeded at a density of $5 \times 1 0 ^ { 4 }$ cells/specimen onto specimens in a 24-well tissue culture polystyrene (TCP) plate. After $^ { 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ of incubation,each well was rinsed three times with a phosphatebuffered saline(PBS) solution.The cells were fixed with $2 . 5 \%$ glutaraldehyde for $1 2 \mathrm { h }$ at $4 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } .$ The samples were washed three times with PBS for $5 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ each.Then,a gradient ethanol solution (i.e. $1 0 \%$ $3 0 \%$ $5 0 \%$ $7 0 \%$ $8 0 \%$ $9 0 \%$ $9 5 \%$ and $1 0 0 \%$ )was used to dehydrate the cells for $1 0 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ ,respectively.The treated samples were dried ina freeze dryer overnight, and then were sputter-coated with platinum and observed by SEM.

# 2.7.3. Immunofluorescence staining
To study the distribution pattern of the osteoblast cytoskeletons on the surface of the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples,MG-63 cells were observed by confocal laser scanning microscopy(SP8,LEICA Corporation, Germany).MG-63 cells were seeded on the surfaces of different samples at a density of $5 \times 1 0 ^ { 4 }$ cells/specimen.After incubation for $^ { 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ ,all of the samples were washed three times with PBS and were fixed with $4 \%$ paraformaldehyde for $^ { 1 \mathrm { { h } } }$ ,followed by permeabilization with $0 . 1 \%$ triton-1oo.The cells attached to the samples were stained with FITC-Phalloidin for $^ { 1 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ and further stained with DAPI (Dalian Meilun Biotechnology Corporation, China） for $1 5 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ .Then, the samples were washed with PBS three times,and the F-actin and cell nucleus were examined by confocal laser scanning microscopy.

# 2.7.4. Cell proliferation
Cell proliferation was evaluated by a cell counting kit 8 (CCK-8, Shanghai Yisheng Biotechnology Corporation,China） assay.The succinate dehydrogenase in the mitochondria of living cells reduces CCK-8 to water-soluble yellow crystals (formazan),and the number of methylazate formed is directly proportional to the number of living cells.MG-63 cells were seeded on the samples in 24-well TCPs at a density of $5 \times 1 0 ^ { 4 }$ cells/well.Fresh medium was renewed every two days, and the amount of the cells was measured after 24,72,and $1 2 0 \ \mathrm { h }$ A CCK-8 solution $( 5 0 \mu \mathrm { L } )$ was added to each well containing the culture medium $( 5 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { L } )$ and incubated at $3 7 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $^ { 1 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ 、Then,the yellow formazan reaction product was transferred to a 96-well plate.The absorbance of each well was examined using an enzymatic marker (IMark, BIO-RAD, China) at $4 5 0 \mathrm { n m }$

content:
Fig.1(a) and (b) show the SEM images and the particle size distributions of the unmodified HDH-Ti and modified HDH-Ti powders,respectively.The unmodified HDH-Ti powder particles have an irregular polygonal shape,and the particle sizes were determined as $d _ { 1 0 } =$ $1 4 . 8 \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ $d _ { 5 0 } = 4 1 . 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,and $d _ { 9 0 } = 9 2 . 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (Fig.1a).Moreover, small particles of the HDH-Ti powder adhere to the surface of the large HDH-Ti powder particles (Fig.1c).

However,after modification,the sphericity of the HDH-Ti powders is significantly improved,and most of the powder particles become uniformly near-spherical or spherical,and the particle sizes are determined as $d _ { 1 0 } = 1 5 . 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $d _ { 5 0 } = 3 8 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $d _ { 9 0 } = 7 1 . 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (Fig. 1b). The slightly increased $d _ { 1 0 }$ value compared to the original unmodified powder $\gamma _ { d _ { 1 0 } } = 1 4 . 8 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,Fig.1a) suggests that a small amount of very fine particles was polished off during the modification process.Examination of the microstructure at a higher magnification indicates that the modified HDH-Ti powder shows grinding marks,occasionally flaking structure,and much smoothened surface (Fig.1d） without those fine particles that originally adhering to the original powder (Fig.1c).Further evidence of the grounding effect can be found from the images shown in Fig.S2.Fig.1(e) shows a schematic diagram of the HDH-Ti powder modification process.When the ball mill rotates,the HDH-Ti powder is stirred and squeezed by the grinding balls;this ensures that the powder and the grinding bowl are mutually ground and that the powder particles become spherical.
summary: 3.1. Modification of the HDH-Ti powder and the SLM printing - Part 1/2

content: Fig.3a and b show the XRD patterns of the unmodified HDH-Ti powders,modified HDH-Ti powders,and as-printed HDH-Ti samples.It was found for both the powders and the as-printed samples that the diffraction peaks correspond to hexagonal-closed packed （hcp）Ti and no peaks of rutile or anatase were observed, indicating that the powders were not oxidized during the modification process (Fig.3a).However, compared to the original HDH-Ti powders, the profile of the modified powders is broadened and shifted towards the lower diffraction angles relative to the standard 20 locations (Fig.3b).In addition, this phenomenon was also observed in the as-printed samples,indicating that micro-strain and residual stress were generated during the bal milling modification and SLM processing. Similar findings have been reported by other studies of the SLM-prepared CP-Ti [15].
summary: 3.2.Microstructural characterization of the as-printed,modified HDH-Ti - Part 1/2

content: Fig.3c and d show SEM images of the longitudinal (X-Y plane) and the cross-sectional views (X-Z plane) of the as-printed HDH-Ti samples. The sample regions observed in the longitudinal views and the crosssectional views are composed of parallel or fine zigzag acicular $\alpha / \alpha ^ { \prime }$ grains.For the longitudinal view,the grain length and width are $\sim 3 0$ and $\sim 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,respectively (Fig.3c),while for the cross-sectional view the grain length and width are $\sim 5 0$ and $\sim 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (Fig.3d). This is due to the high cooling rate during the SLM processing $( 1 0 ^ { 3 } – 1 0 ^ { 8 } ~ \mathrm { K } / s )$ [24]. Chemical analysis by EDS mapping shows all composing elements uniformly distribute in the microstructure,including the needle phase feature,see Fig.S3 for the details.To further study the microstructure and crystal structure of the as-printed HDH-Ti samples,TEM analysis was performed on the as-printed samples,with the results shown in Fig.3e and f.Laths were observed in the bright field image (Fig.3e). The SAED pattern shown in the inset of Fig.3e confirms the hcp crystal structure of the matrix.In addition,Fig.3f shows a high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of the typical single $( 0 0 0 2 )  { \alpha }$ with the lattice-fringe separation measured as $0 . 2 3 3 \mathrm { n m }$ Therefore,the crystallographic lattice parameterc is calculated to be $0 . 4 6 \mathrm { n m }$ ,which is similar to the result obtained by Yan et al. $\mathrm { ^ { \prime } 0 . 4 7 n m } ,$ [25].The change in the lattice parameters may be caused by the dissolution of the interstitial elements into $\alpha$

It was found that a large number of dislocations are distributed at the grain boundaries,forming dislocation walls,while dislocation cells appear within the crystal (Fig.5c). In addition, dislocation tangles were observed in the vicinity of stacking faults (Fig.5f),and sub-grain boundaries were also found (Fig.5g).Formation of the dislocations and their impact on mechanical performance of the SLM-prepared materials are studied extensively [27],and they will be briefly discussed in the Discussion section.

To study the corrosion resistance of the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples,electrochemical tests were performed on the two materials. Upon immersion in the 3.5 wt% NaCl aqueous solution, the OCP values of all of the samples decreased with time and then reached a relatively stable state.Fig.6a shows the potential polarization curves of the asprinted HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples,and it is observed that the polarization curves of the two materials are quite similar.Moreover,the corrosion potential and corrosion current density of the two materials were evaluated by $R p$ fitting to determine the corrosion rate,as shown in Table 1.An examination of the data presented in Table 1 shows that the as-printed HDH-Ti samples exhibit a lower corrosion current density $\left( I _ { c o r r } \right)$ and approximately the same corrosion potential $\left( E _ { c o r r } \right)$ compared to the as-printed GA-Ti samples.In addition, the corrosion rate of the as-printed HDH-Ti samples is lower than that of the as-printed GA-Ti samples.

content: Fig.6(b-d) show typical Nyquist and Bode plots for the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples in 3.5 wt% NaCl solution.An examination of the Nyquist plots shows that the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples are composed of single capacitor arcs (Fig.6b).Inaddition,to better fit the EIS data of the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples,an equivalent circuit (EC)was used to simulate the corrosion behavior [28]. Table 2 summarized the EIS spectrum fitting results of the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples in the $3 . 5 \%$ NaCl solution. The low Chisquare $( \chi ^ { 2 } )$ values of $0 . 1 3 \times 1 0 ^ { - 4 }$ and $8 . 4 1 \times 1 0 ^ { - 4 }$ for the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples,respectively, indicate that the quality of EIS data obtained by the fitting is satisfactory.It was found that the $R _ { f }$ value of the as-printed HDH-Ti sample $( 6 6 9 \mathrm { k } \Omega \mathrm { c m } ^ { 2 } \cdot$ ）is significantly larger than that ofthe as-printed GA-Ti sample $( 7 7 \mathrm { k } \Omega \mathrm { c m } ^ { 2 } .$ ),indicating that the corrosion resistance of the as-printed HDH-Ti samples is improved relative to that of the as-printed GA-Ti samples [28].

content:
# 3.5.Biocompatibility of the as-printed,modified HDH-Ti
Fig.7a and b show the morphology of the MG-63 cells adhered to the surface of the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples after $^ { 2 \mathrm { h } }$ of culture. It is observed that the cells of the two samples grew well,and flat cells that are tightly bound to the matrix were observed on the surface.It is important to note that the cells had many filamentous filopodia extensions on the surface of the as-printed HDH-Ti sample(Fig.7a),while fewer filamentous filopodia extensions were observed on the asprinted GA-Ti samples (Fig.7b).Immunofluorescence staining was used to further confirm the cell adhesion ability of the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples,as shown in Fig.7c and d.The cell staining results show that both materials maintain a good adhesion morphology, and the cytoskeleton is relatively complete.In addition, the number of stained cells on the as-printed HDH-Ti sample is slightly higher than that on the GA-Ti sample.

Fig.8 shows the proliferation of the MG-63 cells on the as-printed HDH-Ti and as-printed GA-Ti samples for $2 4 \ \mathrm { h }$ $^ { 7 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ ,and $1 2 0 \ \mathrm { h }$ of culture.MG63 cells show a time-dependent growth pattern for the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples.Higher CCK-8 absorption of MG63 was observed with longer incubation times.While no discernible diferences between the two substrates are observed for the cell proliferation after culturing for $^ { 2 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ ,the cell proliferation is significantly improved on the as-printed HDH-Ti samples after 72 and $1 2 0 \ \mathrm { h }$ of culture as compared to that on the as-printed GA-Ti samples $\begin{array} { r } { P < 0 . 0 5 } \end{array}$ ).These results indicate that the as-printed HDH-Ti is more conducive to promoting the adhesion and proliferation of osteoblasts than the GA-Ti samples.

fileName: 2020 - Materials and Design - Dong et al. - Additive manufacturing of pure Ti with superior mechanical performance, low cost, and biocom.pdf
content:
In this study,non-spherical HDH-Ti powder was modified to spherical Ti powder. The as-printed HDH-Ti sample with the strength comparable to that of the Ti64 alloy and elongation of more than $2 0 \%$ was prepared by SLM.In addition,the HDH-Ti sample shows better corrosion resistance and biocompatibility than the as-printed GA-Ti while its cost is only $\sim 1 4 \%$ of that of the as-printed GA-Ti. Below, we will discuss the strengthening mechanism, corrosion performance,biocompatibility,and powder cost of the as-printed HDH-Ti samples.

# 4.1.Discussion of the mechanical properties of the as-printed,modified HDH-Ti
As shown in Fig.9,compared to CP-Ti prepared by conventional powder metallurgy (PM) and SLM processing, the as-printed HDH-Ti examined in this study has outstanding ductility and higher yield strength [26,29-35]. It is important to note that the yield strength of the as-printed HDH-Ti is equivalent to that of the Ti64 alloy prepared by the traditional PM method,while its elongation is higher than $2 0 \%$ In addition,the as-printed HDH-Ti samples have a microhardness of $3 0 7 . 6 \pm 2 . 5 7 \ : \mathrm { H v }$ ,which is nearly $3 0 \%$ higher than the microhardness of the as-printed GA-Ti samples ( $2 3 9 \pm 5 . 9 7 \ : \mathrm { H v }$ ).The origins of these excellent mechanical properties are discussed based on the efect of the grain size [36] and the effect of the solution strengthening by interstitial elements [37].

# 4.1.1.Effect of grain size on the mechanical properties
The contribution of grain refinement to mechanical properties is described by the well-known Hall-Petch relationship.According to the Hall-Petch relationship,the relationship between grain refinement $\left( \sigma _ { r e f i n } \right)$ and yield strength can be expressed by [38]:

$$
\sigma _ { r e f i n } = \sigma _ { 0 } + k D _ { 1 } ^ { - 0 . 5 }
$$

content: where $\sigma _ { 0 }$ is the constant pressure, $k$ is the strengthening constant,and $D$ is the average grain size of the material.Thus,the average grain size of the material has a strong influence on mechanical properties.To measure the grain size of the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples,an electron backscatter diffraction(EBSD) analysis was performed,with the results shown in Fig.1O(a-d).It is observed from the inverse pole figure (IPF) that the crystal grains of the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples are both needle-shaped.In addition, the average grain size was calculated as $3 . 8 ~  { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and $7 . 6 ~  { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ，respectively. Compared with the asprinted HDH-Ti, the impurity amount, in particular O,is at a lower level in the as-printed GA-Ti material, Table 3.

content:
Another important contribution to enhancing mechanical properties is provided by the solid solution strengthening effect of the interstitial elements in the matrix.Due to the use of diferent preparation methods, the oxygen (O) content of HDH-Ti powders is higher than that of the GA-Ti powders [39]. Table 3 lists the chemical composition of the HDH-Ti powder,as-printed HDH-Ti and as-printed GA-Ti samples. It Was found that the oxygen content of the HDH-Ti powder is equivalent to that of the ASTMGrade 3 Ti [26]. Interstitial oxygen has a significant influence on the movement of dislocations and can give rise to an energy shielding effect on the dislocations,which is called “solid solution strengthening"[40]. Solid-dissolved oxygen and Ti have very strong chemical bonds,increasing the strength relative to that of pure Ti while maintaining good plasticity [41,42]. Moreover,oxygen atoms can give rise to the strong pinning of the highly mobile screw dislocations, preventing the further gliding of the dislocations [12,37].The oxygen solid solution strengthening effect, $\Delta { \sigma } _ { Y S }$ where $\sigma _ { Y S }$ means the yield strength,was evaluated according to the Labusch model [43,44]:

![](images/59d379ba319c3735775cb48212bd0211f8ed18f86810b1da28262d31e980bec6.jpg)

![](images/c349a59749dc3c1e4e8cca4d0b727254dcc20852a349b3cfd04b999e392d04ed.jpg)  
e (d) phase angle with the inset showing the equivalent circuit model.

$$
\Delta \sigma _ { 0 . 2 \% \mathrm { Y } S } = \frac { \tau _ { 0 } } { S _ { F } } = \frac { 1 } { S _ { F } } \left( \frac { F _ { m } ^ { 4 } c ^ { 2 } w } { 4 G b ^ { 9 } } \right) ^ { \frac { 1 } { 3 } }
$$

content: where $\tau _ { 0 }$ is the shear stress, $S _ { F }$ is the Schmid factor, $F _ { m }$ is the maximum basic interaction force between the dislocations and solute atoms,c is the atomic concentration of the solutes,w is the distance between the solute atoms and the dislocation, $G$ is the modulus of rigidity,and $b$ is the Burgers vector. By applying known values to the eq.[44], the increase of yield strength due to the oxygen solid solution strengthening is approximately 1O3 MPa for the as-printed HDH-Ti samples.

name: 2020 - Materials and Design - Dong et al. - Additive manufacturing of pure Ti with superior mechanical performance, low cost, and biocom-part-29
fileName: 2020 - Materials and Design - Dong et al. - Additive manufacturing of pure Ti with superior mechanical performance, low cost, and biocom.pdf
content: A comparison of the electrochemical test results for the as-printed HDH-Ti and GA-Ti samples shows that the as-printed HDH-Ti samples show better corrosion resistance than the GA-Ti samples,and the corrosion rate of the as-printed HDH-Ti samples is lower than that of the GA-Ti samples.This may be because the grains of the as-printed HDH-Ti samples are finer than those of the as-printed GA-Ti samples. For passive metals such as Ti and Ti alloys,finer grains have a higher grain boundary volume fraction and can provide a higher number of active atoms.This enhances the ability of the material to form a passivating film on its surface,thereby improving the corrosion resistance of the material [45-48].Balyanov et al. [49] compared the corrosion resistance of ultrafine-grained and coarse-grained CP-Ti samples and found that the ultrafine-grained CP-Ti samples have better corrosion resistance than coarse-grained CP-Ti because ultrafine-grained CP-Ti is prone to rapid passivation. Liu et al.[5O] studied the electrochemical corrosion behavior of the $\mathrm { N i } _ { 5 0 . 5 } \mathrm { T i } _ { 4 9 . 5 }$ and $\mathrm { N i _ { 4 5 . 6 } T i _ { 4 9 . 3 } A l _ { 5 . 1 } }$ alloy with different grain sizes.Their results showed that NiTi alloys with smaller grain sizes have better corrosion resistance because the structure with fine grains has a higher grain boundary density that leads to the rapid formation of a protective film.

content: For long-term use in the human body,metal implants not only require superior biocompatibility,but also must bear the effects of various forces such as extrusion, torsion,and bending.To obtain implants with good mechanical compatibility, the implant material must have sufficient strength and low elastic modulus,and to provide good mechanical support for and match with the hard tissue [51]. Generally speaking,Ti materials are not with high wear resistance [52]. In the case of total hip implants,conical inserts on femoral stems are often made of CoCrMo alloys or Ti alloys such as Ti-6Al-4V; inserts' head can be made of Co-based alloys, $\mathsf { A l } _ { 2 } \mathsf { O } _ { 3 }$ or $Z \mathrm { { r } } 0 _ { 2 }$ [2]. In this study,we found that the as-printed HDH-Ti samples are close or even better than the mechanical properties of the Ti-6Al-4V alloy that used for surgical implants (ASTM F1108-14).Meanwhile,hardness of the as-printed HDH-Ti is\~310 Hv,close to that of the CoCrMo alloy,which is a material of high wear resistance [52]. Therefore,the currently developed lowcost,as-printed HDH-Ti has the potential to be used in hip or knee joint applications.The elastic modulus values of Ti and Ti alloys used in clinical applications are in the 75-125 GPa range and their compressive strength values are in the range of 480-1100 MPa [53].While this is sufficient to meet the requirements of clinical use,the elastic modulus of these metals is still high and does not match the elastic modulus values of human cancellous bone,cortical bone,and teeth.Therefore, increasing research attention has been directed to the design of Ti alloys (e.g. low modulus $\beta$ Ti alloys and lattices） with improved mechanical compatibility with human bone.We summarize the mechanical properties of the relevant additively manufactured medical Ti alloys in Fig.11 [3,54-63].
summary: 4.3.Discussion of the biocompatibility of the as-printed,modified HDH-Ti - Part 1/6

content:
The mechanical properties of the as-printed α, $\alpha + \beta ,$ and $\beta$ Tialloys are no different from those of the Ti alloys that have been used in clinical applications.Furthermore,the low modulus requirement of cancellous bone can be met by customizing the Ti implants lattice using additive manufacturing methods.It is evident that a series of geometric lattices and porosities with good manufacturability, good mechanical matching with the surrounding bone tissues,and a preferred range of pore sizes is beneficial for hosting bone ingrowth [64]. The mechanical properties of the as-printed HDH-Ti samples in this study meet the requirements even though the elastic modulus is slightly higher than that of the GA-Ti used in clinical applications.Moreover, if necessary,for clinical applications,the elastic modulus of the asprinted HDH-Ti can also be reduced through the design of porous lattice structures. The results of the cell adhesion test show that the cells adhere well to the surfaces of the two materialsafter $^ { 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ ,and the cell adhesion of the as-printed HDH-Ti sample is better than that of the as-printed GA-Ti sample.Meanwhile,the results of the cell proliferation test show that the cell viability on the as-printed HDH-Ti sample on the fifth day (120h) is significantly higher than that on the as-printed GA-Ti sample, indicating that the as-printed HDH-Ti sample is more conducive to cell growth; this may be related to the interaction between the material surface and the cells and the information provided by the surface of the material.For bone tissue materials,the interaction between the surface of the implant and bone cells is crucial for the success of the implantation [65].When the implant is implanted into a human body and comes in contact with bone tissue and bone cells,the protein on the surface of the cell will quickly adhere to the surface of the material. Surface proteins can transform information (topology, chemical properties,etc.） provided by the implant surface into biological signals.More profound understanding of the biological reponse to the implant surface by human cells can be found in related studies [66-68].In addition, the cells respond to the generated biological signals and achieve stable adhesion,which in turn affects cell proliferation and differentiation [69,7O].The wettability of a material is also an important factor affecting the interaction between the material and the cells.Previous studies have shown that good wetting properties of materials effectively promote cell surface protein adhesion and cell adhesion [71-73].

Based on the initial cell adhesion and cell proliferation results,the as-printed HDH-Ti samples also showed better biocompatibility,which is consistent with the above results.In addition, the initial cell adhesion and cell proliferation (24 h) results indicate that the wettability of the two materials at fist has only a slightly beneficial effect on the cells.However,the promotion of cell growth by the good wettability was gradually amplified with the extension of the cellculture time (72 h and $1 2 0 \mathrm { h }$ ),and became highly significant.

content: Fig.13 compares the cost of the modified powder with other Ti materials,including GA-Ti powders [74]. The price of HDH-Ti powders is only one-seventh of that of the traditional GA-Ti powders.While the prices of the powders may vary in different countries or regions,the overall trend of the much lower price of HDH-Ti is valid in all cases. In addition,ball milling for the powder modification is a routine laboratory technology and the milling time is not long(e.g.4 h), inducing only a small additional cost to the powder modification approach developed in this study.The combination of such a low price and the mechanical properties and biocompatibility demonstrated for the as-printed HDHTi samples indicates that the use of HDH-Ti powders in biomedical materials is highly advantageous.

fileName: 2020 - Materials and Design - Dong et al. - Additive manufacturing of pure Ti with superior mechanical performance, low cost, and biocom.pdf
content:
# 5. Conclusions
In this work,a low-cost spherical HDH-Ti powder was developed by powder modification.The relative density,microstructure,mechanical properties,electrochemical properties,and in vitro biocompatibility of the as-printed samples were studied.The main conclusions are as follows:

（1）Using the method of mechanical ball milling,the non-spherical HDH-Ti powder was modified into a printable spherical CP-Ti powder.By adjusting printing parameters,the relative density of the as-printed HDH-Ti samples of greater than $9 9 . 5 \%$ was achieved.Micro-CT examination found that the interior of the as-printed samples contained randomly distributed pores with a size of less than $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$   
(2）The XRD,SEM,and TEM analyses of the as-printed HDH-Ti samples revealed that they have the hcp crystal structure of Ti,and the modified powder produces micro-strain.In addition,dislocations,stacking faults,and sub-grain boundaries were found near the cross-section.   
(3）The as-printed HDH-Ti samples display high ultimate tensile strength $( 1 0 5 7 . 0 5 \ \mathrm { \ M P a } \ \pm \ 2 9 . 1 4 \ \mathrm { \ M P a } )$ and yield strength $( 7 8 4 . 5 9 \mathrm { M P a } \pm 3 3 . 2 5 \mathrm { M P a } )$ , good elongation $( 2 4 . 0 9 \% \pm 1 . 8 1 \% )$ _， and microhardness of $3 0 7 . 6 \pm 2 . 5 7 \ : \mathrm { H v } .$   
(4） The electrochemical performance test found that the as-printed HDH-Ti samples display a lower corrosion current density $\left( I _ { c o r r } \right)$ ,improved corrosion potential $( E _ { c o r r } )$ ,and lower corrosion rate than the as-printed GA-Ti samples.   
(5）The in vitro biocompatibility test showed that the as-printed HDH-Ti samples have better biocompatibility than the asprinted GA-Ti samples.

# Declaration of Competing Interest
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

name: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b-part-1
fileName: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b.pdf
content:
# Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels by understanding process-structure-property relationships
Jonathan W. Pegues, Michael D. Roach & Nima Shamsaei

To cite this article: Jonathan W. Pegues, Michael D. Roach & Nima Shamsaei (2020) Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels by understanding process-structure-property relationships, Materials Research Letters,8:1,8-15, DOl: 10.1080/21663831.2019.1678202

To link to this article: https://doi.0rg/10.1080/21663831.2019.1678202

# Additive manufacturing offatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels by understanding process-structure-property relationships
Jonathan W.Peguesa,b,Michael D. Roach and Nima Shamsaeia,b

aDepartmentfeaicalEineing,ubnUivesitubu,U;tioalCnterforiieaufacturingEee (NCAME),s MS,USA

# ABSTRACT
Thelimited understanding of additive manufacturing process-structure-propertyinter-relationships raises someconcerns regarding thestructural reliability,whichlimits theadoptionof this emerging technology.In this study,laser beam-powder bed fusion is leveraged to fabricate an austenitic stainless steel with a microstructure containing minimal known crack initiation features. Ex-situ microstructural observations of the crack initiation features and mechanisms are caried out for interrupted fatigue tests via electron backscatter diffraction mapping of the micro-cracks. Results show that the additive manufactured stainless steel alloy has improved fatigue resistance compared to its wrought counterpart as a result of the unique microstructural features.

# ARTICLEHISTORY
Received 24 June 2019

# KEYWORDS
Laser beam-powder bed fusion; crack initiation; microstructure; twin boundary; cyclic deformation

![](images/649504851781bff87d2933d4462dc7ef9d039f59a08d2c7d1eb78758400b0017.jpg)

# IMPACT STATEMENT
Using an experimental ex-situ microstructural investigation, the fatigue resistance of additive manufactured 304L stainless steel was shown to be superior to the wrought counterpart by avoiding the typical failure mechanisms.
summary: ABSTRACT, Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels by understanding process-structure-property relationships, Additive manufacturing offatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels by understanding process-structure-property relationships, ARTICLEHISTORY, IMPACT STATEMENT, KEYWORDS

name: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b-part-2
fileName: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b.pdf
content:
# Introduction
Additive manufacturing promises to revolutionize the fabrication process of structural components in several industries. The layer-by-layer fabrication process results in a wide design-space with the freedom to create complex geometries and, more importantly, the ability to have direct localized control of the thermal history. There is an intimate relationship between the thermal history and the resulting microstructure [1],such that tailored, or even functionally graded, microstructures may be realized through additive manufacturing [2]. For example, in areas where high strength and resistance to fatigue crack initiation (FCI) is required,high cooling rates may be beneficial to produce finer microstructures. On the other hand,as larger grains are beneficial for areas where crack growth is critical, a reduction in the cooling rate can lead to a coarsening of the microstructure [3].

The extension of additive manufacturing to fatigue critical applications has been hindered by processinduced defects such as lack-of-fusion (LoF)， gas entrapped pores,and surface roughness [4-6]. Defects act as stress concentrators inducing early FCI, severely limiting the potential for producing reliable,fatigue resistant additive manufactured (AM) parts. This study aims to better understand process-structure-property relationships as they relate to the fatigue performance of laser beam-powder bed fusion (LB-PBF） 304L stainless steel (304LSS). The majority of research efforts regarding AM parts have focused on understanding the structure-property relationships as they are related to processed induced defects [7-11]. This work instead focuses on materials that are less sensitive to defects to elicit the microstructure's role in FCI of AM materials. The results presented in this study give early insight into the true potential of additive manufacturing to produce targeted microstructure for application-specific desired properties.

name: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b-part-3
fileName: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b.pdf
content:
Austenitic stainless steels (SSs) in their wrought form are known to be more susceptible to FCI at annealing twin boundaries (∑3-TB) and high angle grain boundaries (HAGB) than nano/micro-scale defects such as intermetallic inclusions and voids [12-15]. The deformation behaviour at $\Sigma 3$ -TB and HAGB has been shown to result in both elastic and plastic incompatibilities across the boundary [13-20].For low applied stresses, such as those in the high-cycle fatigue (HCF) regime, the small differences in elastic deformation near $\Sigma 3$ -TBs result in elastic mismatches across the boundaries.The increased localized stresses promote FCI along the boundary which can be exacerbated when higher loads are applied, expediting the crack formation. Additionally, HAGB are also capable of promoting FCI in wrought austenitic SSs as dislocations are not easily transferred across the grain boundary. As these dislocations pile up,edge dislocations of different signs attract each other resulting in the accumulation of vacancies and the formation of micro-cracks [21].

While microstructural features such as $\Sigma 3$ -TB/HABG are difficult to avoid in the manufacturing of wrought materials,additive manufacturing provides a means to produce net shaped/near-net shaped parts without the need for post-processing steps such as forming and /solution annealing. Austenitic SSs exhibit exceptional toughness and have been successfully implemented in LB-PBF processes [22,23].
summary: Crack initiation in austenitic SSs, Ex-situ experiments to observe FCl mechanisms - Part 1/2

name: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b-part-4
fileName: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b.pdf
content:
# Ex-situ experiments to observe FCl mechanisms
Rectangular LB-PBF specimen blanks with dimensions of $1 3 \mathrm { m m } \mathrm { - x } \mathrm { - } 1 3 \mathrm { m m } \mathrm { - x } \mathrm { - } 7 0 \mathrm { m m }$ were fabricated horizontally on an EOS-M290 and stress relieved at $4 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $1 \ \mathrm { h r }$ The process parameters followed manufacturer recommended parameters for 316L SS with a laser power of 195 W, scan speed of $1 0 8 3 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,and a hatch distance of $9 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .The powder feedstock was provided by LPW with a particle size distribution of $1 5 { - } 4 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and composition given in Table 1. Specimens were then machined to a cylindrical uniform gage section following ASTM-E606 [24] and polished longitudinally to a mirror finish.Nontraditional square gage crack initiation (CIS) specimens were also machined and electro-polished, as previously described in [14],to investigate the FCI mechanisms associated with LB-PBF(304LSS).

All standard fatigue specimens were tested until failure using a servo-hydraulic test frame with a $1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { k N }$ capacity. Quasi-static tension tests were performed at a strain rate of $0 . 0 0 1 \ s ^ { - 1 }$ . The CIS were tested under force-control only and were interrupted periodically and investigated using a Zeiss FE-SEM with an EDAX-EBSD detector and OIM software.Micro-cracks were located and mapped using EBSD to observe the microstructural characteristics associated with FCI.
summary: Crack initiation in austenitic SSs, Ex-situ experiments to observe FCl mechanisms - Part 2/2

name: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b-part-5
fileName: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b.pdf
content:
Differences in microstructure in relation to the drawing and build direction for wrought and LB-PBF(304LSS), respectively,are shown in Figure 1. The YXZ plane relates to the faces which were perpendicular to the build direction while the ZXY plane relates to the faces parallel to the build direction. The LB-PBF microstructure analysis revealed a strong $< 0 1 1 >$ texture as a result of the $< 0 0 1 >$ easy growth direction and the high solidification rate [25-27]. Additionally, the LB-PBF microstructure evolution results in a much finer average grain size (12 and $1 3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in the YXZ and ZXY planes,respectfully） than the wrought counterpart ( $5 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ equiaxed). The LB-PBF material also showed a high density of low angle grain boundaries (LAGB) $\left( > 1 5 ^ { \circ } \right)$ and a low density of HAGB $( > 4 5 ^ { \circ } )$ and $\Sigma 3$ -TB $( \sim 6 0 ^ { \circ } )$ ，as shown by the misorientation histograms in Figure 1. This contrasts with the wrought material which shows a higher density of HAGB and $\Sigma 3$ -TB boundaries. The measured grain boundary lengths and number fractions for LAGB $( 5 ^ { \circ } - 1 5 ^ { \circ } )$ , grain boundaries in the range of $1 5 ^ { \circ } - 4 5 ^ { \circ }$ HAGB $( 4 5 ^ { \circ } - 5 4 ^ { \circ } )$ ,and $\Sigma 3$ -TB are given in Table 2.

The cyclic deformation behaviour of wrought 304LSS results in complex stress responses as affected by microstructural characteristics and evolution [28]. The cyclic deformation behaviour for the LB-PBF(304LSS)

The stress response in Figure 2(a) reveals three distinct deformation stages: initial work hardening, cyclic softening[14],and secondary hardening [29]. The secondary hardening stage has been correlated to the deformation-induced martensitic phase transformation that occurs for 304LSS [28].

name: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b-part-7
fileName: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b.pdf
content:
The complex stress response of 304LSS results in nonstabilized hysteresis loops during cyclic loading as the stress amplitude evolves through the related deformation stages. The half-life hysteresis loops are presented in Figure 2(b) along with the quasi-static tensile behaviour. The initial work hardening of the material at the strain amplitude of $0 . 2 \%$ results in a higher peak stress at half-life compared to the quasi-static tensile behaviour while the next strain amplitude step of $0 . 5 \%$ falls below the quasi-static stress-strain curve.Increasing the strain amplitude results in further cyclic softening as observed for strain amplitudes of $0 . 7 5 \%$ and $1 . 0 \%$ ：

Figure 2(c) shows the cyclic stress-plastic strain relationship for both wrought and LB-PBF(304LSS). The LBPBF material shows a slightly lower cyclic hardening rate, as indicated by the lower slope of the curve,as well as a lower fatigue strength coefficient ( $\overleftarrow { \boldsymbol { \sigma } } _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ at $\epsilon _ { \mathsf { a } - P } = 1 . 0 \% )$ ： However, the LB-PBF material exhibits a much higher cyclic yield strength $( \sigma _ { y } ^ { \mathrm { ~ \prime ~ } } = 4 2 4 \mathrm { { M P a } ) }$ than the wrought material $( \sigma _ { y } ^ { \mathrm { ~ \tiny ~ } } = 3 3 4 \mathrm { { M P a } } )$ . This is mostly attributed to the finer microstructure and smaller slip length of the LB-PBF material.

name: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b-part-8
fileName: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b.pdf
content:
The quasi-static tensile engineering stress-strain and fatigue behaviour of the LB-PBF material in comparison to its wrought counterpart are presented in Figure $_ { 3 ( \mathsf { a } - \mathsf { c } ) }$ . The LB-PBF material shows a slightly higher tensile yield strength and elongation to failure with a slightly lower ultimate strength. The increased yield strength can be related to the finer microstructure observed for the LB-PBF material. It should be mentioned,however, that the wrought material was evaluated using standard E8 test specimen geometry while the AM materials did not strictly follow the ASTM E8 [30] requirements.

![](images/f61fa1da049c0159f4de92210c96bb39a65c61bf00163cfbe5fb19dfc802d402.jpg)  
Figure 2. Cyclic deformation behaviour of LB-PBF showing (a) stress response under strain-controlled conditions,(b） cyclic stress-strain hysteresis loops,and (c) strain hardening behaviour in comparison with wrought material.   
fatigue behaviour,and (c) stress-life fatigue behaviour.

The strain-life fatigue data and curves shown in Figure 3(b) indicate the LB-PBF material has slightly higher fatigue resistance in the low-cycle fatigue (LCF) regime,while the HCF behaviour is very similar to the wrought counterpart. The improved LCF resistance can be explained by the higher cyclic yield strength of the LB-PBF resulting in a reduced level of extrusions and intrusions on the surface. The similarity of the wrought and LB-PBF HCF fatigue behaviour suggests that defects such as LoF and gas entrapped pores,which typically deteriorate the HCF performance of most AM materials, are not greatly influencing the LB-PBF(304LSS).

name: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b-part-9
fileName: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b.pdf
content:
The stress-life fatigue data and corresponding Basquin curves shown in Figure 3(c) remarkably indicates the LBPBF(304LSS) has improved stress-life fatigue resistance across all stress levels. The fatigue life of LB-PBF material for any given stress amplitude was one-two orders of magnitude longer than the wrought material. While most AM materials fail under cyclic loading due to the presence of process-induced defects [6,9,31,32], the majority of the dominating cracks in the LB-PBF(304LSS) specimens initiate at the surface without the presence of defects. Figure 4 details two fracture surfaces from (a) strain control test at $\epsilon _ { \mathrm { a } } = 0 . 3 \%$ and (b） force control test at $\sigma _ { \mathrm { a } } = 4 0 0 \mathrm { M P a }$ . In both cases a dominant crack initiates at the surface (indicated by arrow-1） without any indication of the presence of defects then coalesces with a smaller crack which shows evidence of FCI at a defect (indicated by arrow-2). Surprisingly, in these cases and for many other specimens,the dominant crack did not initiate from a defect suggesting that microstructural features are responsible for crack initiation.

The dominating effects of microstructure rather than defects occur despite the defect sizes being much larger than the average microstructure size. Previous works have shown improved fatigue performance of AM titanium alloys after HIP related to defect sizes being smaller than the grains [33-35]. For the present study, however, no HIP was performed and defects present in the material were much larger than the grain size,as indicated by Figure 4.

name: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b-part-10
fileName: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b.pdf
content:
Considering the majority of the fatigue life in HCF regime is spent in nucleating a crack, the observed differences in the 304LSS microstructural features,are most likely responsible for the improved HCF behaviour. Under strain-controlled conditions,the similar HCF behaviour between wrought and LB-PBF 304LSS can be explained by the deformation being limited by the utilized control mode. Contrastingly, under forcecontrolled conditions,the deformation for the LB-PBF material with a higher cyclic yield strength would be expected to be less severe than the wrought counterpart. The lower cyclic deformation leads to improved fatigue resistance for the LB-PBF(304LSS).

The ex-situ CIS results for both the wrought and LB-PBF material at the stress amplitude of $3 3 0 \mathrm { M P a }$ are shown in Figure 5 with their corresponding inverse pole figure (IPF) orientation overlays.The crack for the wrought material (Figure 5(a)) developed into a dominant crack approximately $3 1 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ long by 35,000 cycles, while the longest crack observed in the LB-PBF material (Figure 5(c)) was stillin the initiation stage at $7 6 \mu \mathrm { m }$ long by 100,oo0 cycles.The overlays of the EBSD orientation data on the LB-PBF cracks in Figure 5 show the relationship between the crack and underlying microstructure. The crack in Figure 5(c) occurred at a HAGB approximately $5 1 ^ { \circ }$ and propagated along the boundary until it reached a LAGB. The crack shown in Figure 5(b) initiated at a $\Sigma 3$ -TB boundary which was surprising considering the lack of these boundaries within the LBPBF(304LSS) microstructure.Interestingly, the $\Sigma 3$ -TB is oriented approximately $4 5 ^ { \circ }$ from the loading direction similar to what was observed for the wrought material [14].

name: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b-part-11
fileName: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b.pdf
content:
![](images/0694ba140445c2c4dad1b080fbee6fc467c308c211bca1aade68bd1ca4ed122b.jpg)  
Figure 4. Fracture surfaces of (a) strain control test at $\epsilon _ { \tt a } = 0 . 3 \%$ and (b) force control test at $\sigma _ { \mathfrak { a } } = 4 0 0 \mathsf { M P a }$

The microstructural CIS investigation revealed that the majority of cracks in the LB-PBF material initiated at HAGB. This observation is in contrast to the wrought material where FCI was dominated by $\Sigma 3$ -TB [14].The solidification characteristics of LB-PBF process,and subsequently, the presence of $< 0 1 1 >$ texture results in a high density of LAGB and lower density of HAGB/ $\Sigma 3$ -TB. The nature of FCI in 304LSS and the unique microstructure for LB-PBF 304LSS, lead to a reduction in $\Sigma 3$ -TB, shifting the dominant FCI mechanism of the LB-PBF(304LSS) to HAGB.More importantly,the higher cyclic yield strength of LB-PBF(304LSS) results in much less cyclic deformation,even at stress amplitudes approaching the quasi-static yield stress. This is noticeable in Figure 4,where the slip lines,that are easily distinguishable in Figure 4(a) for the wrought material, are mostly absent in Figure $^ { 4 ( \mathrm { b } , \mathrm { c } ) }$ for the LBPBF material. This combination of finer microstructure and lower HAGB/ $\Sigma 3$ -TB density results in the improved fatigue performance for LB-PBF(304LSS) compared to its wrought counterpart.

name: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b-part-12
fileName: 2020 - Materials Research Letters - Pegues, Roach, Shamsaei - Additive manufacturing of fatigue resistant austenitic stainless steels b.pdf
content:
# Conclusions
These profound results show that while most AM materials are susceptible to early fatigue failures,austenitic SSs can be successfully fabricated via LB-PBF to offer superior strength,ductility, and fatigue resistance compared to their wrought counterparts. Taking advantage of the intimate relationships among the localized thermal input during the AM process and the resulting microstructure and mechanical properties,the fatigue performance was improved by avoiding the typical FCI mechanisms associated with the wrought counterpart.

These findings for LB-PBF(304LSS) offer early insight into how additive manufacturing can be used to fabricate superior fatigue resistant materials by further establishing the process-structure-property-performance relationships and taking advantage of the increased designspace.By leveraging the intimate relationship between local thermal input and the resulting microstructure/properties it may be possible to tailor microstructure to meet specific loading requirements. The ability to fabricate AM materials with increased resistance to crack initiation and/or growth can expedite the adoption of this technology for fatigue critical applications across many industrial sectors to deliver lighter, stronger, and safer products.

It is important to note that the internal porosity is also influenced by the thermal history and deviations outside of an optimal process window could result in defects dominating the fatigue behaviour despite the improved microstructure.More in-depth studies focusing on various process/post-process effects on the resulting microstructure,dislocation density,and deformation characteristics are needed to fully establish the processstructure-property relationships for LB-PBF(304LSS).

# Disclosure statement
No potential conflict of interest was reported by the authors.

# Funding
Partial funding for this work was provided by the National Science Foundation under grant number l657195.
