name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-1
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content:
Research Paper

# Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-4V alloy
Thomas Acheea, Gabe Guss b, Alaa Elwanya,\*, Manyalibo Matthews b

a Wm MichelBarnes‘64DepartmentofIndustrialandSystemsEngineering,TexasA&MUniversity,College Station,TX,USA b Lawrence LivermoreNationalLbratory,Livermore,CA,UA

# ARTICLEINFO


# ABSTRACT
Keywords: Additive manufacturing Powder denudation Laser material processing Entrainment modeling

As a fundamentally different process for creation of complex parts,laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) additive manufacturing exhibits complex behavior at the melt pool that has a direct influence on the macroscopic properties of the final material.Powder denudation,a previously studied deleterious phenomenon,is the displacement of powder due to entrainment ina jet of rapidly vaporized metal created by the proces laser.To minimize the effct of denudation and inspired by methods inadjacent fields,a laser pre-sintering(LPS)method was studied in an effort to reduce denudation.LPS was found to be most effective in the $\scriptstyle 1 - 4 \ J / \mathbf { m } \mathbf { m } ^ { 3 }$ volumetric energy density processing regimes,minimizing the common experimentally observed problems with the LPBF process Scanning electron microscopyof the LPS-treated powder bed revealed insight into the acelerating fect morphological irregularities along the powder particle surface have in the pre-sintering processTo further understand the process,an estimation of the sintered neck sizes necessary to eliminate denudation in LPS is made,qualitatively affirming the low energy densities needed to prevent denudation.The results presented in this work represent an initial step towards understanding and implementing LPS as a quality-enhancing step in LPBF.
summary: Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-4V alloy 前言

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-2
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content: Metal additive manufacturing (AM) is a new manufacturing paradigm that has recently experienced rapid growth,in part due to its ability to produce parts with complex geometries from increasingly diverse materials with minimal tooling. Laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) is one of the more common metal AM processes in which metallic particles ina powder bed are selectively fused usinga high power laser. LPBF is a complex process that involves laser-material interaction, extreme thermal gradients and cooling rates,melt pool fluid flow, temperature-dependent surface tension effects,and gas-phase fluid dynamics resulting from the rapid evaporation of metal.These effects and phenomena dictate the stability of the melt pool (interface between the laser and powder particles) during the micro-welding process,which in turn drives final part microstructure and properties.A particular phenomenon of interest recently reported in LPBF is powder denudation [1],defined as the redistribution of metal powder due to its interaction with the induced flow of the ambient atmosphere caused by a jet of metal vapor from the melt pool.Denudation, first mentioned in fundamental studies of single track formation [2],has been the subject of several experimental investigations and is key to understanding the dynamics of the LPBF melt pool environment. In addition to drawing powder particles into the melt pool [3],denudation also results in the creation of oxidized spatter [4] due to a portion of the denuded powder particles melting mid-flight upon interaction with the hot vapor plume and incident or scattered light.These airborne particles exit the laser interaction region [5] and can then result in lack of fusion porosity sites due to shielding underlying powder particles from laser irradiation [9]. Modeling of denudation,however,has yetto be fully realized in order to match the experimental findings.

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-3
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content:
Finite element models that are capable of modeling the two-phase flow with appropriate particle contact mechanics are only starting to emerge [1O].Some previous works have also modeled the vapor plume during welding [11].Despite these studies, prediction of the extent of denudation under arbitrary process conditions has yet to be accomplished.

The denudation process can produce unfavorable effects to successive melt tracks and layers which should be minimized. Recent modeling work has shown that denudation in the LPBF process is potentially responsible for generating spatter from large powder clumps obstructing the path of the laser.This obstruction can cause microporosity by creating a transient cold spot in the melt pool [12].This also can create further spatter when the laser is no longer interrupted,as the sudden increase in laser intensity in the melt pool causes a sudden increase in melt pool depth.This increase in depth then creates a jet of metal behind the melt pool known as back spatter.At the same time,the clump of powder which originally obstructed the beam is rapidly melted and ejected,leading to further spatter.Although denudation can also be seen as a mechanism of mass transport into the melt pool, transport does not occur uniformly:initial weld tracks in a given area draw in powder particles from both sides of the weld due to denudation. Subsequent welds,however,draw in powder from only one side,causing uneven deposition of material and resulting in the tracks adjacent to the initial track having less volume.This effect necessitates hatch distances that minimize the uneven deposition [2],where hatch distance is defined as the distance between two successive laser tracks within the same layer. The non-uniform mass transport mechanism also limits the theoretical minimum feature size achievable,since it draws excess powder into the melt pool in addition to the powder directly in the path of the process laser,increasing the diameter of the weld track.

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-4
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content: One approach to reduce the effects of powder redistribution due to denudation has been reported in another metal AM process:electron beam melting (EBM).EBM is a powder bed fusion metal AM process that shares some similarities with LPBF,with the primary difference being the use of an electron beam instead of a laser as the energy source for welding.In EBM,a method of powder pre-heating is used to prevent powder redistribution due to coulombic repulsion arising from charge buildup on powder particles.Pre-heating forms small necks between powder particles to prevent this repulsion,which can cause a diffuse cloud of electrostatically suspended particles in the EBMbuild chamber if not sintered a priori. It is typically implemented with volumetric energy densities ranging between 4.12 and $8 . 2 2 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ to the weld area prior to melting [13,l4]．Although pre-heating has demonstrated reasonable success in EBM processes,to our knowledge no previous studies have been conducted to investigate using a laser beam to achieve it in LPBF.A pre-heating process for LPBF that reduces denudation has the potential to minimize the complicating effects of the interaction between the vapor plume and the powder bed.It could also lead to a more stable melt pool environment with fewer active mechanisms for defect formation.This is depicted through a simplified illustration shown in Fig.1,where the redistribution of powder is nullified by growing small necks between the particles in the powder bed.

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-5
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content:
The focus of the current work is to reduce powder redistribution due to denudation in LBPF processes through laser pre-sintering (LPS) similar to EBM pre-heating.LPS investigated in the current work is different from previous literature studies using laser sintering to fabricate near-full density parts [15,16].More specifically,LPS proposed here aims to find a threshold degree of necking between the particles through sintering in the powder bed such that they are restrained from entrainment in the induced flow during the subsequent welding step. This is achieved by reducing the velocity of the laser beam on the powder bed and increasing the laser beam diameter,achieving both longer dwell times and lower laser irradiances needed for the diffusion-mediated LPS process.We note there is a delicate balance between restraining the powder particles but not pre-sintering them to a degree that makes it dificult to separate the finished part from the pre-sintered powder bed.

The key contribution of the current work is providing a first investigation of the efficacy of using LPS as a denudation reduction technique in LPBF.We study the effect of LPS on powder layer roughness after presintering,and post-LPS denudation using high-fidelity structured light microscopy.A demonstration of pre-sintering effectively reducing the number of airborne particles is made using high-speed video,while SEM imaging of pre-sintered beds elucidates the role of satellite particles in accelerating sintering.An estimation of the forces acting on particles is made to determine the threshold of neck radii required for denudation reduction using analytical expressions.The results of these investigations offer a multi-view understanding of considerations for the eventual implementation of LPS into practical use.

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-6
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content: In order to probe the LPS process,single track experiments were carried out to investigate denudation reduction upon implementing LPs as well as other effects related to it.These experiments were carried out in a two-step procedure: a pre-sintering step followed by a welding step. In the pre-sintering step,separate $4 \mathrm { m m }$ long single tracks of presintering were executed on a small test plate of Ti-6Al-4V (Ti64) with a single layer of gas atomized Ti64 powder from Carpenter Technology Corporation (Formetly LPW Technology Ltd) using a $1 0 7 0 \mathrm { n m }$ ，600W fiber laser model JK6oOFL by JK Lasers.The powder had $d 5 0$ and $d 5 0$ of $3 2 . 0 2 \mu m$ and $4 8 . 0 3 \ : \mu m .$ ,respectively,and a mean particle size of 32.71 $\mu m$ ，The full powder particle size distribution is available in the supplementary information. The laser volumetric energy density (VED) applied to each track was varied by applying multiple passes of a presintering beam of known energy density. The laser volumetric energy density (VED) was used as a measure of energy density,and is defined as $\psi = P / \nu t w$ where P is the laser power in watts,v is the laser spot velocity,tis the powder layer thickness,and w is the width of the laser beam at focus defined by the $1 / e ^ { 2 }$ diameter as measured and verified by two systems.The first system uses a Point Grey Chameleon (FLIR Systems,Oregon,USA) CCD camera to take images of the beam then the beam diameter is calculated using MATLAB. The second system is an SP920s beam profiler (Ophir-Spiricon,LLC,Utah,USA)．VED was deemed as an acceptable aggregate parameter to use in the current study as the LPS process stays below the melting temperature [17].Since entrainment forces occur not only in the immediate vicinity of the melt pool, but in an area approximately $2 0 0 \mu m$ on either side of the melt pool [11],the LPS laser was defocused to generate a laser diameter of 1000 $\mu m$ during the LPS step.

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-7
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content: LPS parameters used were: $\begin{array} { r } { \mathbf { w } = 1 0 0 0 ~ \mu m _ { ; } } \end{array}$ $\mathrm { P } = 5 . 2 \mathrm { W }$ ， $\mathbf { v } = 1 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ，and $\mathbf { t } = 5 0 \ \mu m$ .With theseparameters,the VED per pass was approximately $1 . 0 \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ .The $3 0 \ \mu m$ thick powder layer was applied to a sandblasted substrate with a razor blade by scraping a small amount of powder over the substrate,which is recessed into a sample holder allowing for even coats of powder to be applied. The layer thicknesses was validated with a Keyence VR-3ooO structured light microscope (Keyence systems) to ensure that the calculated VED was accurate.This pre-sintering track was applied multiple times until the target VED was achieved. VED values for the pre-sintering step were probed from 1.0 to $4 2 \ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ .Values less than $1 . 0 \ : \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { \bar { 3 } }$ were not probed due to the minimum lasing threshold of the process laser and limits on beam defocusing.In the welding step,each of the pre-sintered regions were welded with fixed laser parameters of $\mathbf { v } = 1 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ $\mathrm { P } = 2 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ ,and $\mathbf { w } = 5 0 \ \mu m ,$ to assess the performance of the treatment during standard process conditions.For comparison,control tracks usingthesame welding conditionswerepreformed without pre-sintering.The single track experiments were conducted on an in-house developed LPBF testbed previously described in [1].

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-8
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content:
![](images/15aeecb7e9624546c3280e35f4f12b52e2a4b395198c52bd4e4f518ccf0d1edc.jpg)  
Fig.1.Simplified graphical representation of the changes in the LPBF melt pool environment during LPS.(Left) the standard LPBF melt pool environment.The process laser creates a metal vapor plume,which induces a flow in the ambient atmosphere towards the melt pool. Powder particles are drawn into the melt pool, as well as ejected up and away from the vicinity. This forms a denudation zone devoid of particles.(Right) the welding environment after laser pre-sintering.Necks formed during the pre-sintering step resist the entrainment forces on the powder particles in the bed during the welding step.

Characterization of the morphology of the pre-sintered areas in the powder bed due to the LPS treatment was done by analyzing the point cloud obtained from scanning the surface of the LPS treated region using the Keyence VR-3ooo after removing the sample holder from the welding chamber.Probability density functions for the heights were approximated witha gaussian kernel density estimator[18].The highest peaks for each VED were calculated as the difference between the maximum height for each sintered area minus the median bed height for each plate.Areas with post-LPS denuded powder were calculated by determining the areas in an LPS treated region that were below $3 3 \%$ of median height of the entire powder bed after welding,Images of the post-LPS denudation labeling can be found in the supplementary information.

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-9
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content: High speed video of the effects of the LPS process on welding were collected using a Photron FASTCAM SA-X2 (Photron USA,Inc) at a frame rate of 12,5oo frames per second on a similar experimental setup. Pre-sintering was applied as described previously,with $\overline { { 4 \ : \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { 3 } } }$ applied VED.In order to determine if LPS was efective at extreme processing regimes,welding parameters were chosen at $\mathbf { v } = 3 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ $\mathrm { P } = 5 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ and $\mathbf { w } = 5 0 \ \mu m$ weld laser.Particle counts were made using software ImageJ by counting the number of areas above an intensity threshold in each video frame.This intensity threshold is calculated usinga crossentropy minimization technique [19].The counts of particles above 10 pixels in area were then reported for each frame to reduce noise from reflections on the substrate.SEM imaging of the pre-sintered necks was performed on a Phenom pure desktop SEM(Thermo-Fisher Scientific, Waltham,MA,USA).LPS treated powder beds were lifted off the substrate by applying double-sided tape to the pre-sintered bed and lifting off the entire powder layer. Imaging of the powder beds was performed on the powder that adhered to the tape after sputtering a several angstrom coating of silver to ensure conductivity during SEM and prevent surface charging.

content:
# 3.1.Powder bed nonuniformities
As illustrated in Fig.2,pre-sintering reduced denudation at all probed pre-sintering VED conditions. Some side-effects due to pre-sintering are observed. The surface of the powder bed experiences warping away from the substrate after pre-sintering.The warping of the pre-sintered bed is visible in the bottom of Fig.2,which shows a height map of the pre-sintered regions.Warped regions can be seen in the red and orange sections of the height map.This is potentially a problem,as even a small amount of warping of the powder bed can cause problems if the sintered mass is dragged across the bed during powder recoating,since the maximum warpage in the range of $2 5 0 \mu m$ would certainly be disturbed by the recoater blade.Fig.3a illustrates the overall upward shift in the distribution of heights in a single pre-sintered area at $1 0 . 4 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ (black) opposed to a control untreated area of powder (red).Fig. 3b shows the roughening of the powder bed as a function of VED by plotting the maximum height region measured in LPS treated areas.This maximum height has an increasing trend until $3 \ : \mathrm { J } / m m ^ { 3 }$ ,afterwhich it remains constant around $1 5 0 \ \mu m$

![](images/7c763df400e134421322d6ff41da3468759a1e744d2af7213f9abc50c9f3befb.jpg)  
Fig.2.Optical images (top) and height maps (bottom) of pre-sintered regions with the subsequent welds for several applied energy densities,as well as the control weld (far right).Pre-sintering VEDs from left to right are 1.O4,4.16, 9.86, $1 0 . 4 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ，Each track was welded after pre-sintering.Note the discontinuous balled tracks in the pre-sintered regions,as well as the warping of the pre-sintered bed denoted in the height maps as orange and red regions.The yellow scale bar on the right represents $4 0 0 \ \mu m .$ (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend,the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-12
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content: After LPS,as the subsequent welding process laser moves past a presintered region large sections of the powder bed may detach and be blown away by the welding plume.These regions can be seen as denudation regions, though distinct from denudation prior to pre-sintering. This post-LPS denudation is visible in the high-speed camera videos included as supplementary information,as well as in Fig.4a.We quantify them by finding the area around the weld track with height below $3 3 \%$ of the fitted pre-sintered bed height.The denudation area as a function of applied VED is plotted in Fig.3b.Although these denudation regions appear to be at a minimum below VEDs of $8 \ : \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ,the two samples that were not included in the analysis fully detached during the welding phase after being pre-sintered at 5.2 and $9 . 1 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ,weakly suggesting that higher VED's have more chance of breaking away from the underlying substrate.

content:
# 3.3.Reduction in airborne particles
The reduction in denudation in turn reduces airborne particles during welding,even at extreme welding processing regimes.Fig.4b and 4c show the difference in the denudation of powder particles during the welding at 500 W, $3 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ 、Fig.4d shows the number of particles airborne as a function of elapsed time during the weld,showing an average reduction of airborne particles by $9 3 \%$ .It can be concluded that

![](images/391bc36fef7ca082577bdcf3eddd056ca3ce235726455cb0b99b27a943c2a52f.jpg)  
Fig3.Quaoeudeaai estimation (KDE) estimations of the height distributions for an area treated with $1 0 . 7 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ (black)and an untreated control region (red).b) Highest point relative to the surface of the powder bed as a function of VED,showing an upward trend which reaches a plateau around $3 \mathrm { J / m m m ^ { 3 } }$ .Red circles represent the highest peak for anutreatedsl control (red circles) but is minimal in the region from O to $4 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ .(For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend,the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

LPS reduces the number of visible particles greatly, though the particles visible here are only hot denudation events due to the lack of illumination,which account for about $6 0 \%$ of the total particles that are airborne from entrainment due to the vapor jet [2O].Videos of this demonstration can be found in supplementary information.

# 4．Discussion

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-14
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content: Investigation of evidence for particle necking in the powder due to sintering is summarized in Fig.5a-d.Evidence of the effect of LPS on the bed was evident as compared to the base powder by increased cohesion and clustering of the powder bed,as well as the deformation of satellite particles.This initial cohesionat low VED's is seen in Fig.5a-b,where at low VED's,the powder in the lifted LPS powder layer has supported multiple layers of powder compared to the untreated powder.More concrete evidence of necking is visible in Fig.5b-c,where flat areas are visible on particles that were broken away from their neighbors,and some particles are still seen attached to their neighbors.In addition, darker areas are visible on the topmost particles in Fig.5,which may be indicative of previously bonded neck regions between particles.These dark areas were visible in only a portion of the powder beds studied, likely because beds that warped away from the substrate were unable to maintain contact with the substrate.These darker areas are indicative of more conductive areas in SEM,allowing us to speculate that sintered necks are forming,and not simply deformation of the particles.This also reaffirms that the distribution of laser energy in LPS is uniform enough

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-15
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content:
The side-effects of LPS on the pre-sintered bed point to an ideal range for applying the process to a production scenario.Understanding and minimizing the side effects -roughening and post-LPS denudation -is a necessary for LPS to be a viable industrial process.It seems likely that the uneven distribution of laser energy in the depth predicted by previous ray-tracing studies of laser interactions with powder beds [21] causes a larger degree of sintering in the top layers of the powder.This uneven sintering could cause to differential uneven consolidation on a length scale that would be difficult to see in the SEM investigation in Fig.5,but could cause this warpage.This post-LPS denudation area increases with LPS VED,which is counterintuitive,as one would expect more highly sintered beds to denude after LPS less often.One possible reason is that lower VED's allow the pre-sintered powder particles to break away into smaller sections,instead of being more strongly bonded together asa large region that gets carried awayatlarge VED's.Itis also possible that the warping in the higher VED's starts to break necks away from the substrate and create a crack network inside the pre-sintered bed,allowing small sections of the bed to become entrained and

content: Fig.4.a) Close-up optical microscopy image of a weld track detailing the control (left) and with LPS (right). The denudation zone is reduced to nearly zero using the LPS preprocessing step, although new post-LPS denudation regions are seen.The morphology of the weld track is also changed,with wetting of the bed side walls visible.b,c) High speed video still frames of the welding without (b) and with (c) LPS at $4 \mathrm { { J } / }$ $\mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ .The cyan line indicates the path of the weld,with the laser spot traveling to the left. The reduction in spatter and denudation of particles even in this extreme keyholing regime show the effectiveness of pre-sintering for controlling the denudation phenomenon. The weld parameters are: beam size: $5 0 \mu m$ ，Gaussian profile,power: $5 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ ，speed: $3 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ . All scale bars are $4 0 0 \mu m$ 、d: Counts of airborne particles for each frame of the source videos for section b) (red) and c) (black).This serves as a demonstration of the effectiveness of presinteringin in an extreme case of high drag forces from the induced flow around the meltpool during the keyholing regime. Videos of this demonstration can be found in Supporting information. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend,the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-17
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content: increase the post-LPS denudation area.If this pre-sintering treatment were to be implemented in a full scale build,studies would need to be conducted to minimize this total detachment,as the detached sintered area would potentially act similarly to a large spatter particle in the recoating step,leaving deep troughs as it was dragged through the powder bed by the recoating roller.Minimization of these effects prompts us to choose the minimal VED necessary to achieve denudation reduction. Considering the data in Fig.4a-c,optimal VED's for LPS on Ti64 powders should fall in the range of $\mathrm { 1 - 4 ~ J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ .This range is slightly lower than the VEDs applied in the electron beam preheating process [13],the difference likely stemming from the fact that laser sintering distributes thermal energy on the surface of the powder bed opposed to volumetrically [22].This optimal VED for single tracks is an initial guess for the ideal VED for full production implementation,and future studies to implement LPS in full part builds should determine ideal VED's taking into account hatch spacing and scan strategies to that minimize the adverse aspects of the LPS process.
summary: 4.1．Mechanisms for LPS bed roughening and post-LPS denudation - Part 3/3

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-18
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content:
# 4.2.Pre-sintered bed-melt pool interactions
Asseen in Fig.4a, the welds made on pre-sintered powder have little to no denudation zone.With this reduction in denudation the track is discontinuous,with balling occurring at welding parameters that resulted in continuous tracks in the control.This onset of balling is likely due to the interaction of the melt pool inside the changed melt pool geometry.In LPBF,an individual melt pool welding on virgin powder can be seen as close to a cylindrical laser melt pool on a flat plate,as denudation draws powder from the region around it and clears powder from the area at the liquid-solid boundary.In the LPS treated powder, the melt pool can be seen as sitting inside a quasi-rectangular channel with the‘walls'made of the now static pre-sintered powder bed.If the volume between the walls were entirely filled, the Plateau-Rayleigh instability conditions [4] would predict a more stable weld track in contrast to a less stable one.We can thus infer from the balled geometry that the weld is breaking up because there is not enough volume of liquid to fill the weld track.As pre-sintering minimizes powder redistribution during welding,powder is unable to add to the melt pool by denudation [3],and lower weld volumes would be expected.Furthermore,the shape of the melt pool depends on the wettability of the pre-sintered bed. The thermal environment may have been modified by heat conduction through the walls of the pre-sintered bed.From these changes it is evident that to incorporate pre-sintering into a LPBF process,welding parameters and pre-sintering parameters must be optimized concurrently.

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-19
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content: This reduction in denuded particles is expected to increase the amount of energy delivered to the melt pool, as particles are no longer interacting with the laser and then leaving the vicinity of the melt pool, which removes heat from the melt pool region.This is can be expected to reduce formation of large oxidized spatter particles [8,2O]. The reduction in entrainment is expected to decrease spatter and microporosity from beam eclipses as well,as predicted by computational pre-sintering studies [12].Considering this,pre-sintering should reduce the likelihood of a number of defects by the reduction in denudation and thus improve the quality of LPBF parts.The reduction in denudation also will make the LPBF process more efficient, as the powder that was originally meant to be welded is not redistributed to the rest of the bed.The powder should also be useful for more printing cycles,as oxidation and spatter combination during denudation,which become unusable powder waste,will be minimized.

![](images/1fa4963fe4892598aeb958df0075d1d98e8145faf8132f381e97c34f540a58d7.jpg)  
Fig.5.a) SEM inspection of the evolution of the powder bed after laser pre-sintering passes, highlighting the morphological change in the melt pool as the process progresses. SEM micrographs corresponding to VED values of a) $0 \ : \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ b) $2 . 8 \ : \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ，c) $6 . 2 \ : \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ，d) $1 6 ~ \mathrm { J / \Omega }$ $\mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ 、Unseen sintered necks in part (b) allow for more layers of powder to remain on the double sided tape compared to the base powder in part (a).Some examples of the sintered necks as well as their remnants are highlighted by yellow boxes.Dark regions in part (c)are likely more conductive regions of the inside of the necks after they were broken off of the substrate.Pre-sintering is visible in the generation of flat surfaces on the satellite particles in multiple samples,as well as neck growth in part d.(For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend,the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-21
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content: The mechanism of pre-sintering was investigated using SEM, revealing the role that satellite particles have in making pre-sintering possible.Satellite particles,small particles that adhere to the larger powder particles during manufacturing of LPBF feedstocks [23],are nearly always present in LPBF powders.While these particles are usually seen as a nuisance due to their negative effect on the spreadability of powders,they have a surprising positive effect on the pre-sintering of powder beds due to their smaller radii of curvature increasing their surface energy,driving the initial stages of sintering more quickly due to the extra contribution to the surface tension predicted by the Young-Laplace equation.These sintered necks are visible as circular flat regions on the satellite and main particles,which are what remains after the pre-sintered bed was lifted off the base.Evidence of sintering is also seen in the deformation of the satellite particles,where the satellite particles in Fig.5a are undeformed with no necks visible,but the particles in Fig. 5c-d nearly all have been deformed and have necked regions.These broken necks are the consequence of the fragility of the powder bed,as they are broken in the transfer of the powder bed to the SEM stage.Satellite necks are visible in Fig.5d,where the small satellite particles have deformed,while the larger particles have deformed little. Some deformation of the larger particles is also seen,though it is difficult to attribute this to the LPS treatment,as particles can stick together in the gas atomization process.Were these satellite particles not a fortuitous consequence of the gas atomization process,LPS may not have beenable to prevent denudation at such low energy densities.This effect has also been found in the EBM pre-heating literature [14],but this is the first mention of the same effect in a laser pre-sintering process.

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-22
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content:
# 4.5.Comparison of EBM preheating and LPS
It is interesting to highlight differences between pre-heating in EBM versus LPBF.First, EBM is performed in vacuum whereas LPBF is performed in inert atmosphere,typically argon.This vacuum environment insulates the powder bed causing it to retain heat longer.This extends elevated temperatures in the bed and thus should widen the processing window for the sintering diffusion process.The gaseous environment also allows the chance for competing oxidation,which needs to be minimized to allow pre-sintering to be successful.EBM also allows for much faster scanning speeds,upwards of $1 4 , 0 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ because beam movement is controlled through magnetic coils.LPBF systems,on the other hand,use scanning mirrors which limit maximum scan speeds to approximately $3 0 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ .While EBM systems are capable of simultaneously heating large areas of powder through rapid rastering of the beam,an LPBF system can only achieve this in a point-wise fashion in single tracks. Perhaps most importantly,in LPBF laser heating only occurs at the surfaces of the powder particles and substrate,whereas the electron beam in EBMcan be considered a volumetric heat source on the scale of a full single layer of powder [22].This effect may explain the lower threshold for LPS by localizing the energy deposition on the surfaces that link particles together.These differences distinguish the two processes as separate,though they are quite similar.Images of preheated beds are reprinted for comparison in Fig. S4 in the Supplementary Information.

# 5.Estimation of entrainment threshold and minimum neck radius
summary: 4.5.Comparison of EBM preheating and LPS, 5.Estimation of entrainment threshold and minimum neck radius

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-23
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content: In this section,an analytical model is used to gain understanding of the order of magnitude of the forces on the powder in the immediate vicinity of the melt pool.Flow geometries that share similar characteristics with the LPBF vapor jet have been of interest in the fluid mechanics literature.Squire [24] first studied the problem in 1952,although this seminal work does not necessitate a zero fluid velocity condition at the surface of the powder bed.Recently,the work of Gusarov [25] allows the evaluation of the average radial velocity and pressure field around the vapor jet under this condition,which can in turn enable the estimation of the necessary neck diameters needed to reduce denudation or eliminate it entirely.The initiation of powder entrainment is also a thoroughly studied problem [26].The available literature related to various aspects of the denudation process enable reasonable estimation of the balance between radial lift and contact forces.The velocity field and pressure fields around the vapor jetare assumed to be described by the analytical similarity solution of Gusarov for fluid entrained by a jet in a half space [25]. The velocity field $\mathrm { v } _ { r } , \mathrm { v } _ { z }$ and the pressure field $\scriptstyle { \mathtt { p } } _ { r z }$ obtained from this solution are matched to the specific case of a microscale LPBF jet under argon by aphysical parameters relevant to the analytical solution which match the Reynold's number of the jet (assumed to be at mach1) [11].The thermophysical properties of the jet are assumed to be those of argon at $2 5 \mathrm { ^ \circ C } _ { \mathrm { i } }$ ，as this model predicts the entrainment of the ambient atmosphere.Inspection of the analytical velocity field gave velocities that approximately match the velocity fields in the numerical solutions of Bidare [3].
summary: 5.1.Modeling the powder bed under entrainment forces - Part 1/4

content:
The lift force can then be estimated by the lift force component from the model by Ali and Dey [27] which is given by the sum of two terms,the turbulent lift $F _ { L T }$ and the Saffman lift due to the velocity gradient $F _ { L S }$ Lift forces are assumed to act on the upper hemisphere of the particles,without interaction from neighboring particles.The assumption that solely lift forces affect the particles was justified by assuming that the LPBF feed mechanism creates a nearly flat bed surface, occluding the particles from lateral drag forces.

$$
F _ { L T } = \frac { \pi ^ { 3 } } { 4 } a ^ { 3 } ( \frac { \partial \overline { { p _ { r z } } } } { \partial z } ) | _ { a }
$$

$$
F _ { L S } = C _ { L S } \rho _ { a r } a ^ { 2 } \nu _ { r } | _ { a } \sqrt { ( \nu \frac { \partial \overline { { { \nu _ { r z } } } } } { \partial z } ) | _ { a } }
$$

Where a is the diameter of the powder particles, $\nu$ is the kinematic viscosity of argon $1 . 2 7 ~ \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } / \mathrm { s } , \rho _ { a r }$ is the density of argon, $1 . 7 3 \mathrm { k g } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 3 }$ ,and $C _ { L S }$ is the Saffman lift coeficient, which is a function of the shear Reynolds number, $\begin{array} { r } { R _ { * } = D _ { P } \sqrt { \frac { 1 } { \nu } \big ( \frac { \partial \overline { { \nu _ { r z } } } } { \partial z } \big ) \big | _ { a } } } \end{array}$ [27].

$$
\begin{array} { l } { { C _ { L S } ( R _ { * } \leq 5 ) = \displaystyle \frac { 2 1 . 2 5 } { R _ { * } } } } \\ { { { } } } \\ { { C _ { L S } ( 5 < R _ { * } \leq 5 \times 1 0 ^ { 4 } ) = 0 . 4 7 + \displaystyle \frac { 3 1 } { R _ { * } ^ { 1 . 2 } } - \displaystyle \frac { 2 . 9 } { R _ { * } ^ { 0 . 9 } } } } \\ { { { } } } \\ { { C _ { L S } ( R _ { * } > 5 \times 1 0 ^ { 4 } ) = 0 . 2 1 } } \end{array}
$$

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-25
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content: The stress distribution in these necks is difficult to estimate,as the powder bed is randomly ordered. To move forward, the assumption is made that the powder bed is monodisperse,with the number of contacts equal to the number found by earlier numerical simulation works [28] at a boundary，which is close to 6.To prevent the need to perform exhaustive monte carlo calculations,it is assumed that these necks are evenly distributed about the hemispherical region.The shape that most evenly distributes these is the lower half of a triaugmented triangular prism,with three equatorial contacts evenly distributed about waist of the particle,and three contacts evenly distributed lower on the particle [29].This configuration is visible in Fig.6a.To evaluate the stresses on the necks,the necks were assumed to be composed of the solid alloy and break at the yield stress.This is intended to capture the brittleness of the sintered necks,which have a single grain boundary bisecting the connection between the two particles.The lift force is assumed to be evenly distributed to each neck,which is offset by the vertical components of the contact adhesion forces $\begin{array} { r } { F _ { c } = - \sum _ { n e c k s } { 4 \pi \gamma a c o s ( \phi _ { n e c k } ) } } \end{array}$ where $\gamma$ is the surface energy of Ti64 powder,previously measured to be 0.1 $m J / m ^ { 2 }$ for realistic Ti64 surfaces [3O],and $\phi _ { n e c k }$ is the angle between the normal vector of the neck and the $\mathbf { z }$ axis.Gravitational forces on the powder particles are assumed to be negligible.In the case where pre-sintering has been applied and necks have formed,the stress is assumed to be evenly distributed to all necks.The equatorial necks are assumed to break at the Von Mises yield criterion, $\tau _ { u p p e r } > \sqrt { 3 } \sigma _ { y i e l d }$ .These upper necks,existing in pure shear,would break first,owing to the lower yield strength of Ti64 in shear as opposed to tension.
summary: 5.1.Modeling the powder bed under entrainment forces - Part 3/4

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-27
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content:
# 5.2.Estimation results
Given the multitude of assumptions made,the results of this analysis compare favorably to experimental results.In the balance of forces the threshold for entrainment,the lifting force overwhelms contact adhesionat approximately $2 5 0 \ \mu m$ which approximately matches the radial denudation threshold seen in the experimental studies in this work as well as in previously published work[1].Even the drop in lift force as nearer to the melt pool is similar to the welding images of Bidare,where some particles drop towards the melt pool as they are drawn close by the flow of argon.From this model of the lift forces,determining the neck radii necessary for the cessation of denudation was accomplished by a simple numerical search until no region of the bed experiences stress greater than the yield criterion.The determined neck radius of $2 7 \mathrm { n m }$ for reducing denudation for $3 0 ~ \mu m$ diameter powder particles agrees with the experimental results in this work showing that the necessary LPS treatment for denudation prevention corresponds to a small amount of energy applied to the powder bed compared to the amount of energy required for full powder consolidation.The exact amount of energy that is needed is difficult to quantify,as there is a nonlinear dependence of the rate of sintering on the temperature of the powder bed as well as a nonuniform distribution of laser energy in the bed during sintering, especially for deeper powder beds where sintered area liftoff is likely without a layer underneath on which to sinter.Future experimental characterization of the process space will aid in better understanding of the energetic requirements of the LPS process.

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-28
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content: Although this analysis yields a reasonable estimate for the LPS threshold,more detailed modeling of LPS for arbitrary powders presents several hurdles that need to be overcome.Powder bed warping and postLPS denudation need to be further studied to determine LPS settings that minimize these effects to prevent this new process improvement from creating more defects than it solves.The warping of a of realistic, polydisperse LPBF powder bed with random packing is difficult to predict analytically,and will likely require more involved numerical approaches.Full, complete simulation of the LPS process is a challenging multi-scale problem,as the parameters and phenomena that determine the final effectiveness are likely to include microscale aspects like geometry of the powder,the size and distribution of satellite particles on the powder,the initial dispersion of powder particle sizes,and the thermal history of the powder and its subsequent oxidation state,as well as the strength of the formed sintered necks.The chemistry of the powder may also limit this technique to certain materials that can sinter in an argon atmosphere. Ss316L, for example,is a common engineering alloy that usually only sinters well in hydrogen atmospheres.Finally,the meso-scale geometry of the powder bed and welding parameters thatare used will contribute as to the forces encountered at the bed surface,since random deviations from a planar bed might increase drag.This increased drag might increase the forces on the particles at that point, and particles entrained there could create a deeper defect. It could be possible that this could initiate a cascade of entrainment from a single bed defect,and require larger necks to prevent denudation.LPS also can change the angle of the laser plume,as demonstrated in Fig.
summary: 5.3.Further directions for modeling and characterization of the LPS process - Part 1/3

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-30
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content: Experimental characterization and qualification of the process would need to accompany modeling to develop a robust LPS process. Statistical data for bed warpage and post-LPS denudation over a range of process conditions and materials could be done to determine suitable parameters for a range of denudation-prone alloys.The cause of the post-LPs denudation regions could also be aggravated by many factors not covered in this initial experimental probing,and could be investigated. Forinstance,in thicker powder beds where VED is not evenly distributed through the depth,necks may not be able to form to the previous welded layer.The entire sintered powder bed may then be lifted off by the induced flow,which occurred twice in the experiments in this work even with a minimal bed thickness,even though this minimal bed should provide the best process conditions for necks to be formed between the bed and substrate.Experimental work to analyze the cause of the increase in post-LPS denudation with VED would need a more efficient method of probing the network of formed necks that does not disturb the delicate LPS powder bed.Furthermore,LPS has been shown to create a novel melt pool environment that may need different weld parameters to produce successful, continuous weld tracks.Different scan strategies may be the answer to controlling the wetting of the powder bed on the pre-sintered walls of the weld track.From the range and number of potential studies to explore from using LPS to simply eliminate powder redistribution it is clear that slight changes in the dynamics of the melt pool lead to highly different LPBF process states.
summary: 5.3.Further directions for modeling and characterization of the LPS process - Part 3/3

name: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al--part-31
fileName: 2021 - AM - Achee et al. - Laser pre-sintering for denudation reduction in the laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-.pdf
content:
# 6．Conclusion
LPS is a potentially promising technique inspired by similar methods in electron beam welding that is equally effective in LPBF for elimination of denudation at a range of volumetric energy densities,finding that an optimal VED range for pre-sintering should lie from 1 to $4 \ : \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ for Ti64 powders to minimize the side-effects of LPS,post-LPS bed denudation and warping.The effect of canceling denudation on airborne particles from LPS is pronounced,with an average reduction of hot airborne particles during welding by $9 3 \%$ .The role of satellite particles in pre-sintering was established,givinga mechanism for the success of pre-sintering at low energy densities.Finally,a rough estimate of the radius of sintered necks required for LPS to be effective was found to be on the order of tens of nanometers,which qualitatively verified the small VEDs that were experimentally found to reduce denudation.The current work paves the path for further investigations to improve,and potentially optimize,the LPBF process through better control of the melt pool environment.

G.Guss: Conceptualization, Methodology, Investigation, Resources,Project administration， Supervision.A.Elwany (Corresponding author): Conceptualization, Methodology，Investigation, Writing -original draft,Writing-review & editing,Visualization, Supervision,Project administration, Funding acquisition.M.J.Matthews: Conceptualization,Methodology,Investigation,Writing-original draft, Writing-review & editing,Visualization,Supervision,Project administration,Funding acquisition.

Featured Application: A complete analytical approach was proposed to predict the occurrence of lack-of-fusion, balling, and keyholing defects in laser powder bed fusion. The boundary heat loss was considered in the presented analytical models. The effect of powder bed porosity on thermal property of powder material was considered in the presented analytical model.

name: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu-part-3
fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content:
Abstract: This paper proposes analytical modeling methods for the prediction of balling,lack-offusion and keyholing thresholds in the laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) additive manufacturing. The molten pool dimensions were first predicted by a closed-form analytical thermal model. The effects of laser power input, boundary heat loss, powder size distribution and powder packing pattern were considered in the calculation process. The predicted molten pool dimensions were then employed in the calculation of analytical thresholds for these defects.Reported experimental data with different materials were compared to predictions to validate the presented analytical models. The predicted thresholds of these defects under various process conditions have good agreement with the experimental results. The computation time for the presented models is less than 5 min on a personal computer. The optimized process window for Ti6Al4V was obtained based on the analytical predictions of these defects.The sensitivity analyses of the value of threshold to the laser power and scanning speed were also conducted. The proposed analytical methods show higher computational efficiency than finite element methods, without including any iteration-based computations. The aceptable predictive accuracy and low computational time wil make the proposed analytical strategy be a good tool for the optimization of process conditions for the fabrication of defects-free complex products in laser powder bed fusion.

Keywords: analytical prediction; boundary heat transfer; powder size distribution; lack of fusion; balling behavior; keyholing defect
summary: Analytical Prediction of Balling, Lack-of-Fusion and Keyholing Thresholds in Powder Bed Fusion - Part 2/2

name: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu-part-4
fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content: Laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) additive manufacturing has been proved to have superior advantages in fabricating products with complex geometries when compared with traditional manufacturing techniques [1,2]. However, the defects occurring in the additive manufacturing process have serious detrimental effects on the quality of the final products and will limit the wide application of this kind of manufacturing technique [3,4]. Thus, good prediction methods for the occurrence of the defects willbe very helpful to figure out the suitable process conditions to fabricate products without defects. Lack-of-fusion is a common defect in LPBF which is induced by incomplete melting of powders and incomplete overlap of adjacent molten pools [5,6], which willfinally lead to lack-of-fusion porosity in products. Balling behavior is another kind of defect which is mainly caused by the poor weting between solidified molten pools and the solid substrate, which will lead to unstable and discontinuous melting tracks [7,8]. Severe balling defect can cause high surface roughness and porosity in the final products. Keyholing behavior is a defect occurring under very high laser energy-density regime. It is related to the evaporation of components in molten material, which wil produce gas in the molten pool. Some gas may be trapped by the solidification front of the molten pool, which willead to high porosity in the final product [1,9]. This paper focuses on the prediction of the generation of the three kinds of defects in laser powder bed fusion.

name: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu-part-5
fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content: Experimental, numerical, and analytical methods have been developed by researchers to investigate the mechanisms of the generation of the defects in the additive manufacturing process. Dilip et al. [10] investigated the influence of process conditions on the melting tracks, molten pool shapes and porosity of Ti6Al4V in selective laser melting with the help of SEM images and optical photographs. Cunningham et al. [1] employed ultrahigh-speed X-ray imaging to study the keyhole formation mechanism in additive manufacturing. Shrestha et al. [11] investigates the keyhole-induced porosity by the micro-CT analysis. Zhao et al. [12] used the technique of high-speed X-ray imaging and diffraction to study the in-situ formation process of keyhole pores and molten pools in laser powder bed fusion systems. Bayat et al. [13] employed X-ray computed tomography to study the keyholeinduced pores in powder bed fusion. These experimental techniques have offered some valuable information on the formation process of defects. However, the high cost of the experimental equipment and complex measurement procedures limit the wide adoption of these techniques.

name: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu-part-6
fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content: To avoid the inconvenience of the experimental measurements, some researchers employed numerical methods to study the defects formation and their influence on the performance of the products. Bayat et al. [13] developed a numerical model to study the keyhole pores formation and keyhole-induced porosity in powder bed fusion processes. Bruna-Russo et al. [14] proposed a finite element-based thermal model for the calculation of molten pool dimensions and employed the predicted molten pool to study the occurrence of lack-of-fusion defect. Lee et al. [15] presented a numerical simulation strategy to study the temperature profile and molten pool size in powder bed fusion. The powder bed packing pattern was considered in the simulation by a discrete element method. Khairallah et al. [16] employed a 3D powder-scale model to study the mechanisms of pores formation in powder bed fusion processes. Although numerical methods can avoid the high cost on experimental equipment, the high computational cost is still a fatal drawback.

name: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu-part-7
fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content: Analytical modeling methods have obtained significant interest from researchers due to their acceptable accuracy and high computational eficiency in the prediction of temperature distribution,molten pool dimensions and related defects in AM. Elsen et al. [17] summarized several thermal models for the prediction of temperature profiles in laser processng techniques. Ning et al. [18] proposed a closed-form temperature prediction model for AM processes,which could consider the boundary conditions. Ji et al. [19] proposed a physics-based analytical modeling approach to calculate the grain size in the products fabricated by additive manufacturing. Ning et al. [20] employed an analytical thermal model to predict the molten pool size in metal additive manufacturing and then correlated the molten pool size with the part porosity evolution by regression analysis. Ning et al. [5] developed an analytical strategy to calculate the lack-of-fusion porosity in powder bed fusion processes,considering the influence of un-melted powders on the final porosity of the products. Promoppatum et al. [8] improved Rosenthal's thermal equation by using a heat source with Gaussian distribution and employed the improved thermal model for the prediction of molten pool size. The calculated molten pool geometries were then used as inputs for the prediction of defect generation in additive manufacturing. However, the boundary conditions were not considered in that paper. Moreover, the properties of powder materials were not incorporated. Analytical methods to consider boundary heat loss, effects of powder bed packing onpowder material properties are not available yet in the prediction of thresholds for defects formation in LPBF.

name: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu-part-8
fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content: In this paper, analytical modeling methods were proposed for the prediction of defects generation in laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing. The molten pool dimensions were first calculated by an analytical thermal model, with the consideration of heat input from laser power, heat loss at part boundaries and effect of powder bed porosity (void fraction in the powder bed) on material properties. The predicted molten pool geometries were then employed in the calculation of the thresholds for the lack-of-fusion, balling and keyholing defects to occur. One criterion for the generation of lack-of-fusion defect, one criterion for balling and one criterion for keyholing were employed in this study. The presented analytical methods did not incorporate any iteration-based calculations, which ensure their high computational efficiency. The predicted results were compared to experimental observations of Ti6Al4V, Inconel 718 and 316L stainless steel for validation of the presented analytical models.

name: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu-part-9
fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content:
This study proposed analytical modeling methods for the prediction of defects generation in laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing. The occurrence of lack-of-fusion, balling and keyholing defects were predicted under various process conditions and validated by experimental investigation of Ti6Al4V, Inconel 718 and 316L stainless steel. The molten pool dimensions were first predicted by a temperature prediction model with closed-form solutions. The heat input from power source,boundary heat loss, and the effects of powder bed porosity on the thermal properties were considered in the calculation process. The powder bed porosity was calculated by an advancing front approach based on the information of powder size distribution and powder packing pattern. The predicted molten pool dimensions were then employed into the calculation of thresholds for the lack-of-fusion,balling and keyholing defects.

The analytical thermal model employed in this study consists of a linear heat input solution and a linear heat loss solution. A point moving heat source model is employed as the heat input solution, which was developed by Carslaw and Jaeger based on the assumption of semi-infinite medium [21]. The heat input solution was used to calculate the temperature increase due to the heat input from power source; it can be expressed as

$$
\theta _ { l a s e r } ( x , y , z ) = \frac { P \eta } { 2 \pi k R ( T _ { m } - T _ { 0 } ) } e x p \left( \frac { - V ( R + x ) } { 2 \kappa } \right)
$$

name: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu-part-10
fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content:
where $T _ { m }$ denotes the melting point, $T _ { 0 }$ represents the room (initial) temperature, and $\begin{array} { r } { \theta _ { l a s e r } = \frac { T - T _ { 0 } } { T _ { m } - T _ { 0 } } } \end{array}$ represents the dimensionlesstemperature. $P$ and $V$ represent the process conditions, which are laser power and scanning speed. $\eta$ is the absorptivity of the laser power. $\begin{array} { r } { \kappa = { \frac { k } { \rho c } } } \end{array}$ is the thermal diffusivity of material, which can be calculated with the information of density $\rho _ { \mathrm { . } }$ ，specific heat $c$ and thermal conductivity $k$ $R = \sqrt { x ^ { 2 } + y ^ { 2 } + z ^ { 2 } }$ represents the distance from the calculated location to the laser source.

The heat loss solution was used to consider the temperature drop due to the boundary heat transfer, which was derived from the point moving heat source model with equivalent power loss and zero moving velocity. The mechanisms of boundary heat loss in the process of laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing are shown in Figure 1. The blue arrows above the part represent the thermal radiation and convection from the part to the ambience,which has obvious influence on the temperature profile in the part. The red arrow denotes the laser power source. The purple arrow on the part represents the scanning direction of the heat source. To calculate the heat loss at boundaries, the boundary surfaces are discretized into plenty of small rectangular sections, as shown in Figure 1. Each section can be considered as a small heat sink with equivalent heat loss as a stationary point heat source at its center. Thus, the equivalent heat loss from thermal radiation and convection [5] can be expressed as

$$
Q _ { c o n v } = A h ( T - T _ { 0 } )
$$

$$
Q _ { r a d } = A \varepsilon \sigma \Big ( T ^ { 4 } - T _ { 0 } ^ { 4 } \Big )
$$

name: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu-part-11
fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content:
where $Q _ { c o n v }$ is the boundary heat loss through thermal convection, and $Q _ { r a d }$ is the boundary heat loss through thermal radiation. $h$ is the heat transfer coefficient, and $\varepsilon$ is the emissivity. $\sigma$ represents the Stefan-Boltzmann constant, of which the value is $5 . 6 7 \times 1 0 ^ { - 8 } \mathrm { W } / ( \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } { \cdot } \mathrm { K } ^ { 4 } )$ $T _ { 0 }$ represents the initial temperature, $T$ is the temperature of each heat sink center, which can be obtained through the heat input solution. $A$ is the surface area of each heat sink.

![](images/2db1c49a506ab7696ba638b17cd22162df9b3eab058fb60f8901d9f71be86e74.jpg)  
Figure 1. Mechanisms of heat transfer in LPBF.The red arrow represents the heat source, the blue arrows represent the heat loss through convection and radiation to the ambience.The purple arrow shows the scanning direction of the laser. The small squares are heat sinks on the top surface [5,18].

Then, the temperature drop due to the thermal radiation and convection [5] can be əxpressed as

$$
\theta _ { l o s s } ( x , y , z ) = \sum _ { i = 1 } ^ { n } \frac { A _ { i } } { 2 \pi k R _ { i } ( T _ { m } - T _ { 0 } ) } \Big [ h ( T _ { i } - T _ { 0 } ) + \varepsilon \sigma \Big ( T _ { i } ^ { 4 } - T _ { 0 } ^ { 4 } \Big ) \Big ]
$$

In this equation, the $i$ represents the index of heat sinks on the top surface of the part, and $n$ is the total number of the sinks. The total temperature distribution in the part can be obtained by the superposition of the linear heat input solution and linear heat loss solution, which can be expressed as the following equation

$$
\theta ( x , y , z ) = \theta _ { l a s e r } - \theta _ { l o s s }
$$

The molten pool dimensions were determined by comparing the temperature profile with the melting temperature of the material.

name: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu-part-12
fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content:
The effect of powder bed porosity on the thermal properties of the powders was also considered in the prediction of temperature profile and molten pool geometries. An advancing front approach was employed to compute the powder bed porosity based on the information of powder size distribution and powder packing. Several assumptions are enforced in this approach.First, the shape of the powders is assumed to be a circle. Second, the powder bed is assumed to have the maximum packing density in the manufacturing process. Third, this approach calculates the packing porosity in a 2D domain. Figure 2 shows the strategy of the advancing front approach. Three circles are generated first as the initial front. The following circles are generated based on the initial front along the positive directions of the blue vectors, as shown in Figure 2. It should be noted that the positive direction of the vector is along the anti-clockwise direction.The generated circles show the densest packing pattern in this 2D domain [22]. The effect of powder bed porosity on the thermal conductivity of the powder material was developed in [23], which can be expressed as

$$
k _ { p } = \frac { k _ { s } ( 1 - \varepsilon ) } { 1 + \psi _ { k _ { g } } ^ { k _ { s } } }
$$

$$
\psi = 0 . 0 2 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 ( \varepsilon - 0 . 3 ) }
$$

![](images/a714601cc4fe8de4cc7e13c9bb58f4144dc56ef1451e700931ea1a4c5d7830a9.jpg)  
Figure 2. Generation process of powder packing pattern using advancing front approach [22].

In this equation, $k _ { p } , k _ { s }$ and $k _ { g }$ represent the thermal conductivity of powders, solid material and gas, respectively. For Argon, $k _ { g } = 0 . 0 1 7 6 \mathrm { ( W / m K ) }$ . ε represents the void fraction of the powder bed, and $\psi$ denotes a factor in the calculation process [24].

name: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu-part-13
fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content:
Lack-of-fusion defect is induced by incomplete melting of powders. The threshold for the lack-of-fusion defect was first developed by Tang et al. in [6], with the assumption of dual half-ellipse molten pool shapes. This threshold can be expressed as

$$
\frac { H ^ { 2 } } { W ^ { 2 } } + \frac { L ^ { 2 } } { D ^ { 2 } } \leq 1
$$

In this equation, $H$ and $L$ represent the hatching space and layer thickness, respectively. $W$ and $D$ represent the molten pool width and depth, respectively. When the equation is not satisfied, the lack-of-fusion defect will occur in the manufacturing process.

The balling defect usually happens in the low energy density regime, and it is caused by the poor wettability of the molten pools to the solid substrate. The threshold for the occurrence of balling behavior was proposed in [25], which can be expressed as

$$
\frac { \pi w } { l } > 1
$$

where $w$ and $l$ represent the molten pool width and length, respectively. The balling defect will occur when the equation is not satisfied.

The keyholing defect is related to the evaporation of materials during the manufacturing process. A criterion for the generation of the keyholing defect was developed in [26], which can be expressed as

$$
\frac { \Delta H } { h _ { s } } = \frac { A P } { \pi h _ { s } \sqrt { D u a ^ { 3 } } } , ~ h _ { s } = \rho C _ { p } T _ { m }
$$

$$
\frac { \Delta H } { h _ { s } } > \frac { \pi T _ { b } } { T _ { m } }
$$

fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content: In this equation, $\frac { \Delta H } { h _ { s } }$ represents normalized enthalpy, with $\Delta H$ as the specific enthalpy and $h _ { s }$ as enthalpy of melting. $P$ and $u$ are the process conditions, which are the laser power and scanning speed. $A$ denotes the absorption coefficient of laser power, and a represents the diameter of the laser beam. $T _ { m }$ and $T _ { b }$ represent the melting temperature and boiling point of the material, and $D$ and $C _ { p }$ are the thermal diffusivity and specific heat, respectively. The keyholing defect wil form in manufacturing process when the Equation (11) is satisfied.

fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content:
This study proposes analytical methods to predict the defect generation in laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing. The occurrence of lack-of-fusion, baling and keyholing defects were predicted under various combinations of process conditions and validated by experimental study of different materials. All the experimental data used in this study are adopted from the literature. The prediction accuracy of the proposed analytical thermal model has been validated in previous papers of our group. The presented model has shown acceptable accuracy in the prediction of molten pool dimensions in powder bed fusion. Furthermore, it has been validated that the consideration of boundary heat loss can improve the prediction accuracy for the molten pool dimensions [18]. Table 1, Table 2 and Table 5 show the predicted molten pool dimensions for three different materials under various process conditions.The energy density in the table is defined as

Table 1. Results of lack-of-fusion for Ti6Al4V [27].

fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content:
For the prediction of the formation of lack-of-fusion defect, Ti6Al4V and Inconel 718 were employed as the materials. Tables 1 and 2 show the process conditions for Ti6Al4V and Inconel 718, respectively. Table 3 shows the thermal properties of Ti6Al4V and Inconel 718. The powder size distributions of the two materials are shown in Figure 3. With the advancing front approach, the powder packing pattern was obtained, as shown in Figure 4. By image analysis of the packing pattern using Image J, the porosity of the powder bed was calculated,as shown in Table 4. To investigate the influence of the powder numbers on the calculation of powder bed porosity, the porosity was calculated at least triple under different levels of powder number. From the results,it shows that the influence of powder number is negligible during the calculation of powder bed porosity. The average porosities were used in this study, which is $1 2 . 8 8 \%$ for Ti6Al4V and $1 3 . 4 7 \%$ for Inconel 718.

With the results of molten pool geometries, the lack-of-fusion thresholds were computed. The calculated results are shown in Tables 1 and 2,which is $1 1 0 \mathrm { J } / \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ for Ti6Al4V and $1 6 0 \mathrm { J } / \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ for Inconel 718. To validate the prediction accuracy of the proposed analytical methods, the predicted thresholds were compared with experimental measurements, as shown in Figure 5. The predicted results have good agreements with experimental data for the two materials.

Table 2. Results of lack-of-fusion and keyholing for Inconel 718 [28].

The thresholds for the balling defect were calculated with the information of the predicted molten pool width and length. The 316L stainless steel was used to validate the proposed analytical method for balling prediction. The boundary heat loss and effects of powder bed porosity were not considered in this calculation,because the information of part size and powder size distribution were not given in the reference paper. Table 3 shows the thermal properties of 316L. Table 5 shows the process conditions and predicted results. The experimental observation of balling behavior is shown in Figure 6. The balling defect becomes obvious when the scanning speed is over $3 5 0 \mathrm { m m } / \mathrm { s }$ which is very close to the predicted result.

The prediction for the occurrence of keyholing defect was carried out with the information of material properties and process conditions. The calculated results are shown in Tables 2 and 6. The predicted thresholds are 5.4 for Ti6Al4V and 6.2 for Inconel 718. The comparison of experimental results and analytical predictions are shown in Figure 7. Acceptable agreement can be observed between experimental results and analytical predictions.

Table 5. Results of balling for 316L.

content:
The sensitivity of the threshold models for the lack-of-fusion,balling and keyholing defects to the laser power and scanning speed were also carried out. The detailed results are shown in Figures 8 and 9. It can be observed that the value of the balling threshold formula and lack-of-fusion formula have a negative relationship with the laser power, while the keyhole formula has a positive relationship with the laser power. As for sensitivity to scanning speed, the balling formula and keyhole formula have negative relationships with scanning speed, while lack-of-fusion formula has a positive relationship with scanning speed.

![](images/a09aec22b6de790fe42a2fa30455e25fd21b0dbd8b6e3e295001d875602fce12.jpg)  
Figure 8. Sensitivity of thresholds to laser power.

The process window of the Ti6Al4V in laser powder-bed fusion additive manufacturing was also predicted by the presented analytical models. The laser power changes from $2 0 W$ to $2 0 0 W ,$ with $2 0 W$ as an increment. The scanning speed changes from $2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / \mathrm { s }$ to $1 4 0 0 \mathrm { m m / s } ,$ with $2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / \mathrm { s }$ as an increment. Table 7 shows the detailed prediction for defects under various process conditions. This table can be used to optimize the suitable process conditions for the fabrications of products without any defects.

![](images/1c4438918f9dd1a5513a34f75c9fdbc6d77ed0595b4b290ea2fc5da479bbabd3.jpg)  
Figure 9. Sensitivity of thresholds to scan speed.

Table 7. Process window of the Ti6Al4V. LOF represents lack-of-fusion defect.
