content: The presented analytical models in this study have been validated by experimental measurements of different materials under various process conditions.In addition, the computational time for the presented models on a personal computer is less than five minutes, which shows their high computational efficiency. In the future, the temperaturedependent material properties and sensitivity to laser power absorption can be considered in the calculation process so as to improve the prediction accuracy of these analytical models. The proposed analytical modeling method can be a promising tool for future study of manufacturing conditions for large and complex products.

name: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu-part-26
fileName: 2021 - Applied Sciences - Wang, Ning, Liang - Analytical prediction of balling, lack-of-fusion and keyholing thresholds in powder bed fu.pdf
content:
In this paper, analytical modeling methods are proposed to predict the defect generation in laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing, without relying on iteration-based computation. The thresholds for the generation of lack-of-fusion, balling and keyholing defects were predicted under various process conditions. The molten pool dimensions in the additive manufacturing process were first calculated by a closed-form analytical thermal model. The heat input from laser source, heat loss at part boundaries and effect of powder bed porosity on thermal properties were considered in the thermal model. The obtained molten pool information was then employed in the calculation of the thresholds for defects. One criterion for the calculation of threshold for lack-of-fusion defect was presented; one criterion for balling and one criterion for keyholing were also proposed.

The experimental investigations of Ti6Al4V, Inconel 718 and 316L in powder bed fusion were employed to validate the proposed analytical methods. The predicted thresholds of these defects have good agreement with experimental results. The computational time for the presented models is less than five minutes on a personal computer with a Intel i5 processor running at $3 . 4 \ : \mathrm { G H z }$ . The balling threshold has negative relationships with both laser power and scan speed. The lack-of-fusion threshold has negative and positive relationships with power and speed, respectively. The keyholing threshold holds positive and negative relationships with power and speed, respectively. The acceptable prediction accuracy and high computational efficiency of the proposed methods will make them good tools for the optimization of process conditions in powder bed fusion. Furthermore, the presented models can be a good basis for future research on the prediction of defects of complex parts in additive manufacturing.

summary: Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6Al-4V alloy using neural networks

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6-part-2
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6.pdf
content:
# Abstract
Direct energydeposition (DED)isahighlyappicable additive manufacturing (AM)methodand,terefore,widelyemployed in industrialrepair-based applications tofabricate defect-free and high degreeprecision components.Toobtainhigh-quality products by using DED,it is necessary to understand the influence of the processparameters on the product quality.The optimization ofsuch procesing parameters provides several advantages such as minimization ofthe loss ofmaterial and time. However,theoptimizatioofthecomplexrelationshipbetween the processparameters-geometry-propertiesofthefabricated sampleis dificultorealizeandrequires significant experimentation.Herein,acomputational model basedonartificial neural networks was developed to optimize process parameters for DED-processed Ti-6Al-4V alloy.The model was developed to estimate thedensityandbuildheight (theactualbuildheightrealizedafter fabrication)ofthesampleasafunctionofpower,scan speed,powderfeedrate,andlayer thickness.Theoptimum model withhigh-accuracy predictions was employedtoconstructthe process maps forthe DED-processed Ti-6Al-4V.The relative importance indices ofprocess parameters on thebuild height and density were investigated.Further,the efect of powerand scanspeedonthe microstructureofTi-6Al-4Valloywas discused. Finaly,based on theobtainedresults,theoptimum fabrication conditions forthe DED-processed Ti-6Al-4Vally were determined.

Keywords Additive manufacturing $\cdot$ Artificial neural networks $\cdot$ Ti-6Al-4V alloy $\cdot$ Process parameters $\cdot$ Direct energy deposition

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6-part-3
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6.pdf
content:
Additive manufacturing (AM) based on direct energy deposition (DED) is critical in industrial repair-based applications due to its high deposition rate,production of 3D structures, and deposit the feedstock to small-scale areas,which facilitate the build and repair of significantly large components when compared with powder bed fusion AM methods [1-3].

To attain a high-quality product or repaired part, the optimization of the many processing parameters that are involved during the manufacturing is required. The improper combination of process parameters results in poor build quality with a significant number of defects in the as-built parts. Among the various alloy systems processed by AM techniques,the Ti-6Al-4V alloy exhibits remarkable characteristics such as high fracture toughness,corrosion resistance, and considerable strength levels [4].However, to obtain high-quality products, it is necessary to examine the quality of the as-fabricated Ti-6Al-4V alloy components based on the processing parameters of AM techniques.For instance, the influence of the selective laser melting (SLM) process parameters on the microstructures,mechanical properties, and melt-pool geometries of various Ti-based alloys was reported in [5-10]. On the other hand, variations in the process parameters and their influence on the physical and mechanical properties of alloys fabricated using DED are rather limited.Corbin et al.[11] pointed out the effect of DED process parameters on fabricated parts of Inconel 718 while

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6-part-4
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6.pdf
content: Wang et al. [12] explicated the process parameters effect on the austenitic stainless steel 304L alloy. In particular, regarding the DED-processed Ti-6Al-4V alloys, only a few studies were aimed to investigate the influence of the process parameters on the geometry and properties of the build parts. Among them, Kobryn et al.[2] considered the power and transverse speed effect on laser deposited Ti-6Al-4V alloy microstructure, porosity,and build height. The effect of processing conditions (substrate thickness and initial substrate temperature, interlayer dwell time, hatch pattern, and a number of deposited layers) on microstructure, porosity,and mechanical properties of Ti-6Al-4V repairs has been reported in [13]. However, the influence of the major parameters in DED such as the (i) power, (ii) scan speed, (ii) layer thickness,and (iv） powder feed rate on the geometry and the properties of Ti-6Al-4V alloy parts has not been extensively investigated. The appropriate selection of such parameters is critical for the manufacture of quality products. Therefore, further investigation is required to better understand the influence of the process parameters on the characteristics of the DED processed parts,to obtain defect-free and high-quality products.

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6-part-5
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6.pdf
content: The design of optimum process variables with minimal experimentation that results in the minimization of time, cost, and material wastage is quite difficult. Thus,a technique that demonstrates significant cost-effectiveness with respect to process optimization is required.As a consequence,plethora of studies focused on the use of statistical methods such as the Taguchi design approach for the design of experiments for various AM processes [14-18]. Bartolomeu et al. [19] proposed the predictive model (analysis of variance, ANOVA) for the prediction of the mechanical properties of SLMprocessed Ti-6Al-4V alloys.Recently,the implementation of effective machine learning tools in various research fields has increased [2O]. In particular, with respect to AM, machine learning (ML） algorithms have been successfully employed for the detection and identification of defect formation, melt pool signatures,in the laser powder bed fusion process [21-23]. The significance of such methods is based on the correlation of mutually dependent parameters and the simplification of the complex relationships among the parameters, which can serve as a guide for the design of actual experiments.

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6-part-6
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6.pdf
content: Among various ML algorithms, the usage of artificial neural networks (ANN)-based ML method in the field of AM significantly increased in recent times [24-27].For instance, the neural network-based ML method has been used to optimize the powder bed laser sintering process parameters [28]. Jiang et al. [29] used a backpropagation neural network to predict the printable bridge (support) length in fused deposition techniques. The ANN model helps to reduce the number of required experimental trails and thereby minimizes material waste and fabrication time.Thus,the present study outlines the significance of the ANN based ML method in the optimization of the process parameters of DED-processed Ti-6Al-4V alloy parts with optimum build height and density. The experiments conducted for the development of the ANN model were designed using the Box-Behnken design method [30]. To optimize the model parameters of DED, the power,scan speed, powder feed rate,and layer thickness were considered as inputs for the ANN model,whereas the density and build height of the samples were considered as outputs of the model. Using the developed model, process parameter maps were constructed,which allowed for the identification of the optimum ranges of the process parameters. The effect of individual process variables on the densities and build heights of Ti-6Al-4V alloy parts have been investigated. The processing regions of developed process maps were validated by conducting real experiments.

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6-part-7
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6.pdf
content:
# 2.1 Box-Behnken design of experiments
The major process parameters in DED are the power (W), layer thickness (mm),powder feed rate $( \mathrm { g } / \mathrm { m i n } )$ ，and scan speed $\mathrm { ( m / m i n ) }$ ,which were considered in this study for optimization.The Box-Behnken design method was employed for the design of the experiments conducted in this study.A total of 27 sets of experiments (tabulated in Table 1） were conducted, and all the sets of experiments were applied to the neural networking modeling for the evaluation of the optimum process parameters with respect to the density $( \mathrm { g } / \mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 } )$ and build height (mm).

# 3 Results and discussion


# 2.4 Macro- and microscopic analyses
The XZ plane of all the specimens was mechanically polished using 20o-40oo grit papers,followed by diamond suspensions with diameters of $1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,and then etched using Kroll's reagent. Macro-images were captured using Dino Capture 2.0,whereas the microstructures were examined using an optical microscope(OLYMPUS-GX51, Republic of Korea). The electron backscattered diffraction (EBSD,

content:
The macroscopic images of the DED-processed Ti-6Al-4V alloy with variations in the process parameters are shown in Figs.1, 2,and 3. The images were captured along the XZ plane.In all the samples, the macrostructure exhibited clear columnar grains parallel to the building direction. For comparison, the samples were divided into three groups based on the layer thickness,as follows: 0.2 (Fig.1), 0.25 (Fig.2), and

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6-part-13
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6.pdf
content: $0 . 3 \mathrm { m m }$ (Fig. 3). The other process parameters namely power, scan speed, and powder feed rate were then varied.As can be observed from the figures,as the laser scanning speed increases, the build height of the sample decreased. Among all the samples, irrespective of the layer thickness and powder feed rate, the sample with the low power (250 W) and high scan speed $( 1 . 2 ~ \mathrm { m / m i n } )$ exhibited the minimum build height. This is mainly because a high scan speed leads to a decrease in the laser-metal interaction time, energy input, and the amount of powder deposition per unit area, which results in a lower build height [2].Besides,a higher scan speed with an increase in power tends to increase the build height. This is a similar behavior observed in the case of laser-metal-deposited aluminum and Ti/TiC tracks [31]. Sobiyi et al. [32] reported that the lower deposited height is due to larger melt pool formation with higher scan speeds resulting in a decreased rate of solidification which leads to mixing substrate material with deposit material. In contrast to a high scan speed, a low scan speed with low power significantly increases the build height of the sample. For example, the sample fabricated at a low power $( 2 5 0 ~ \mathrm { W } )$ ， low scan speed $( 0 . 3 ~ \mathrm { m / m i n } )$ , and high powder feed rate (2 $\mathrm { { g } / \mathrm { { m i n } } ) }$ ） exhibited the maximum build height of ${ \sim } 1 1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ (Fig.2). In general,an increase in powder feed rate is found to increase the build height of the samples [33], yet the effect is strongly dependent on the combination of other process parameters.

content:
With respect to defects,the samples fabricated with low values of power and scan speed $( 0 . 3 ~ \mathrm { m / m i n } )$ exhibitedalack of fusion defects. However, at $4 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ (higher power) with 0.3 $\mathrm { { m } } / \mathrm { { m i n } }$ (lower scan speed),all the remaining samples were free from a lack of fusion defects. It has been observed that these defects are generally formed due to insufficient power to carry out the melting of the previously deposited layer [34]. Moreover, this type of defect mainly occurs along the layer boundaries as shown in Fig.2. The optical micrographs of the lack of fusion defects present in various samples: (i) at $3 2 5 \mathrm { W }$ power, $0 . 3 ~ \mathrm { m / m i n }$ scan speed, $0 . 2 5 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ layer thickness, $2 \ \mathrm { g / }$ min powder feed rate (Fig. 4a); (ii) at $2 5 0 \mathrm { W }$ power, $0 . 3 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { m i n }$ scan speed, $0 . 3 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ layer thickness, $1 . 2 5 ~ \mathrm { g / m i n }$ powder feed rate (Fig. 4b); and (iii) at $3 2 5 \mathrm { W }$ power, $0 . 3 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { m i n }$ scan speed, $0 . 3 \mathrm { m m }$ layer thickness, $1 . 2 5 \ : \mathrm { g / m i n }$ powder feed rate (Fig. 4c) are depicted in Fig.4.It is clear from the figures that the defect was prolonged along the layer boundaries (see the inset ofFig. 4a-c),and unmelted powder particles were also observed. The density values of samples with respect to the process parameters are presented in Table 1,and the values are ranging from 4.21 to $4 . 4 ~ \mathrm { g / c m } ^ { 3 }$ for a given set of processing conditions.

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6-part-15
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6.pdf
content: The effect of laser power and scan speed on the microstructural changes of the DED processed Ti-6Al-4V alloy was noted here. It is observed that these two are the main parameters that can alter the columnar grain size as well as the phase constituents in the alloy.As illustrated in Fig.5,at a constant value of laser power $( 2 5 0 \mathrm { W } )$ upon increasing the scan speed from 0.3 to $1 . 2 ~ \mathrm { m / m i n }$ , the columnar grain size is decreased from $\sim 5 0 0$ to $\sim 1 8 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ resulting from the faster cooling rates attributed with high scan speeds.It has been reported that the high scan speed results in a low energy input (i.e., high cooling rate),which tends to decrease the width of the columnar grains [2]. Similar results have been observed in the case of laser powder bed fusion processed Ti-6Al-4V alloy [35] and 316L stain steel [36]. Besides, the effect of power on columnar grain size is quite contradictory to the scan speed. Increasing the power from 250 to $4 0 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ (at a constant scan speed of $1 . 2 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { m i n }$ ),the columnar grain size was considerably increased from $\sim 8 7$ to $\sim 2 3 2 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ as illustrated in Fig. 6. Kobryn et al.[2] studied the variation of prior $\beta$ grain width with respect to the power however the authors stated that the grain width was unaffected by power level. Recently, Kohnen et al.[37] reported the parameters which lead to favorable microstructure refinement during AM. The lower melt pool penetration depth, higher cooling rates,and minimum thermal gradient to solidification velocity ratio are highly recommended to attain the finer microstructure.In general, with increasing the laser power, the penetration depth of the melt pool gets deeper and wider [38] and the cooling rate of deposited material gets lowered. Thus,the higher power during additive manufacturing results in the coarser columnar grains.
summary: 3.2 Effect of power and scan speed on microstructural characteristics - Part 1/4

content: To investigate the effect of power and scan speed on the microstructure of the alloy, the samples deposited with low and high combinations of scan speed and laser power were taken into consideration and their respective EBSD (image quality (IQ) $^ +$ inverse pole figure (IPF)） micrographs are shown in Fig.7.From the figure, it is clear that irrespective of the laser power, the higher scan speed $( 1 . 2 \mathrm { m / m i n } )$ )results in martensitic transformation as illustrated in Fig.7 a and c. On the other hand, the samples deposited with the lower scan speed $( 0 . 3 \mathrm { \ m / m i n } )$ clearly show the $\alpha$ phase (see Fig. $^ \textrm { \scriptsize 7 b }$ and d) regardless of the laser power. The possible reason for the variation in microstructure is that it reduced laser-metal interaction time upon increasing the scan speed, which allows the formation of martensitic structure due to faster cooling rates,whereas the lower scan speed allows the growth of martensite utilizing longer interaction time which may lead to a significant reheating phenomenon on overlaying layers that resembles the annealing treatment results in the formation of $\alpha$ phase [3]. From Fig.7 b and d, it should be pointed out that the sample built with a higher power $( 4 0 0 \mathrm { W } )$ gives quite thick $\alpha$ laths (due to high level of heat) as compared to that of the sample built with lower power $( 2 5 0 \mathrm { W } )$ . The hardness values of the high scan speed specimens with the martensite phase were observed as $\sim 4 1 2 ~ \mathrm { H V }$ ，whereas the lower scan speed samples consist of $\alpha$ phase hardness decreased noticeably to $\sim$ $3 8 2 \mathrm { H V }$ ：

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6-part-18
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6.pdf
content: From the microstructural observation of all the samples, it is noticed that most of the samples consist of martensite (generally observed in DED processed Ti-6Al-4V), while the samples fabricated with lower scan speed levels $( < 1 ~ \mathrm { m / m i n } )$ exhibit the presence of the alpha phase revealing the importance of power and scan speed on microstructural features of the Ti6Al-4V alloy. On the other hand, the build height and the density of the samples were strongly influenced by all of the four processing parameters and the combination of process variables on the density and build height is not well known. Achieving the best quality products by means of relating the density and build height with process variables is quite complex with experimental results. Therefore, further investigation is focused on optimizing the density and build height of alloy through the ANN model.

ANN method is a mathematical invention inspired by biological systems that aim to map an input into the desired output [39, 40]. The ANN is a simple framework organized by layers named as input,output,and hidden layers.The input and output layers consist of independent and dependent variables, respectively. Thus, the inputs for the present model that were considered as laser power, scan speed,layer thickness,and the powder feed rate. The build height and the density of the Ti

6Al-4V alloy were considered as the outputs of the model. The optimal number of hidden layers and neurons is determined by tuning the model for minimum prediction error with trial and error.The schematic of the ANN model used in the present study is shown in Fig. 8.The model training focused on determining the optimal model parameters such as the hidden layers and neurons,momentum, learning rate,and the number of iterations.

content:
The model development primarily implicates the fitting of the neural network with experimental values; thus, the predicted outputs attain the experimental results with minimum error [41,42]. The backpropagation algorithm with a sigmoid activation function was adopted to train the present model. The model training was mainly focused on the minimization of the mean square error (MSE)and the average prediction error $( E _ { t r } )$ , which can be expressed as follows:

![](images/f344886834f49a9518ff896a0d3e427bd0489f627a204627e3728f36e716e10e.jpg)  
Fig.8 The basic architecture of the ANN model developed for the optimization of process parameters with respect to DEDprocessed Ti-6Al-4V alloy

$$
\mathrm { M S E } = \frac { 1 } { p } \sum _ { p } \sum _ { i } \left( T _ { i p } - O _ { i p } \right) ^ { 2 }
$$

$$
E _ { t r } ( y ) = \frac { 1 } { N } \sum _ { i = 1 } ^ { N } | ( T _ { i } ( y ) – O _ { i } ( y ) ) |
$$

where $E _ { t r } ( y )$ is the average error in the output predictions for parameter $y$ $N$ is the number of datasets, $T _ { i } ( y )$ is the targeted output, and $O _ { i } ( y )$ is the calculated output.

content: Initially, the model training was carried out by observing the error variation with respect to the number of hidden layers and neurons.Herein, we varied the 2-15 hidden neurons by considering the model with one and two hidden layers. Figure 9 a and b show the changes in the MSE and $E _ { t r }$ with respect to the hidden neurons in one and two hidden layers, respectively. It can be noticed that the MSE and $E _ { t r }$ values of the model decreased in accordance with an increase in the number of hidden neurons.Finally， the two hidden layered model structure consists of 15 neurons that give the lowest error values.

content: Further training focused on optimizing the number of iterations of the model. Figure $_ { 9 \mathrm { ~ c ~ } }$ presents the variation of the error values with respect to the number of iterations.In this study,the iterations were varied from 50oo to 25,000. However,when the model was trained with more than 18000 iterations, the error values were attained a minimum value (MSE 0.000001 and $E _ { t r }$ 0.001124) and remained constant upon further training, as shown in Fig. 9c. The remaining model parameters namely learning rate $( \eta )$ and momentum $( \alpha )$ were varied from O.1 to 0.9,and the respective $E _ { t r }$ values were plotted (see Fig. 9d). From the figure, it is clear that the minimum error was observed at the momentum value of 0.9 (indicated by the black arrow). Besides, the optimum value ofthe learning rate, which was O.7 (see Fig. 9d), resulted in the minimum training error. From Fig. 9d, it is noticed that the model trained with a O.6 momentum term exhibits the sudden rise in the error and then decreased with further increment in the momentum term $( > 0 . 6 )$ .This sudden rise in error indicates overfitting of the model, and one should avoid this phenomenon to attain high prediction accuracy with the model. Similarly, the learning rate value of O.9 also tends to increase the error drastically.Reddy et al. [43] reported that, in the case of the learning rate, the higher value resulted in an increase in $E _ { t r }$ due to the overfitting of the model. Therefore, the model that consisted of two hidden layers with 15 neurons with 18,ooo iterations, a momentum value of O.9,and a learning rate of O.7 was employed to optimize the DED process parameters, to realize high-quality Ti-6Al-4V alloy products. The prediction accuracy of the developed model was evaluated by comparing the measured and predicted density and build height values,as presented in Fig.1O.

content: To examine the process parameter influence on density and build height, 3D plots (process maps) were developed based on the ANN predictions.For easy observation, the maps were mainly highlighted with the red color,which indicates relatively lower densities and unsuitable build heights,and green color, which indicates the optimum values of the density and build height.Figure 11 a presents the variations in density with respect to the power and scan speed, whereas the other process parameters namely the layer thickness ( $\left. 0 . 3 \mathrm { m m } \right)$ and powder feed rate $( 2 ~ \mathrm { g / m i n } )$ were maintained as constant. As can be seen from the figure,with the exception of the low power levels $( 2 5 0 - 2 7 0 \ \mathrm { W } )$ and high scan speed (0.9-1.2 $\mathrm { { m } } / \mathrm { { m i n } } ,$ , the other combinations of the power and scan speed resulted in the sample densities higher than $4 . 3 ~ \mathrm { g } / \mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 }$ .The low density $( < 4 . 2 5 ~ \mathrm { g / c m } ^ { 3 } )$ ）at the low power and high scan speed combinations was mainly due to the lower energy input which is insufficient to effectively melt the alloy (more effective when the scan speed was too high)[5]. The lower energy input leads to the formation of a lack of fusion defects and thus significantly affects the alloy density [5]. Moreover, the densification of the alloy mainly depends on the material's melt flowability which can be increased by high power levels [44]. The dependence of the build height on the power level and scan speed is illustrated in Fig.11b.Based on the fabricated samples, the most suitable build height was considered as 5-6 mm.However,in the given set of process parameters (Table 1), the measured build height of the samples was varied from 3 to $1 1 \mathrm { m m }$ .Overall, an increase in the scan speed (from $0 .

On the other hand, the over build height $\mathrm { ( > 7 . 5 ~ m m ) }$ ）was observed with different combinations of power and scan speed as highlighted (red color) in Fig. 11b.In general, the laser power density,which is dependent on the temperature gradient and scan speed,determines the laser-metal interactions,which has a direct influence on the build height of the deposited material. The laser-metal interaction time is considerably at a minimum when laser power $( < 3 0 0 ~ \mathrm { W } )$ ）and higher scan speed (1.2 $\mathrm { { m } } / \mathrm { { m i n } } )$ ）combinations are lower which resulted in the lower build height in the specimen. With decreasing scan speed ( $\left( < \right.$ $0 . 7 ~ \mathrm { m / m i n }$ ), the interaction time was relatively high; furthermore,the reheating time of overlying layers rises and this overheating of layers leads to thermal expansion in the samples.Hence,to maintain the optimum sample height in Ti6Al-4V alloy, a proper combination of laser power and scan speed is important.From the results,the optimum build height of the samples (regions highlighted with green) can be obtained by simultaneously increasing the laser power and scan speed (from 0.75 to $1 . 2 \ \mathrm { m / m i n }$ )，as shown (green color） in the Fig.11b. Overall, the change in powder feed rate ( $\mathrm { ( 0 . 5 ~ g / m i n }$ to2 $\mathrm { { g / m i n ) } }$ and layer thickness( $0 . 2 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ to $0 . 3 \ \mathrm { m m }$ ）varies the density values to a maximum extent of $0 . 0 2 ~ \mathrm { g / c m } ^ { 3 }$ and 0.04 $\mathrm { g } / \mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 }$ ,respectively (see Fig. 12a). With respect to the build height of the sample, the regions with high feed rate-low layer thickness and low feed rate-low layer thickness results increase in build height. The higher amount of powder per unit area with a high feeding rate leads to an increase in the build height,whereas the combination of low layer thickness and feeding rate tends to reheat the overlaying layers during the printing of the subsequent layer cause thermal expansion. Besides, irrespective of the powder feed rate, the high layer thickness $\mathrm { 0 . 3 } \mathrm { m m } )$ lowers the build height due to insufficient energy density per layer which can affect the precision of the build samples. The green region reveals the conditions for the optimum build height as shown in Fig.12b. The significance of each process parameter with respect to the density and build height of the Ti-6Al-4V alloy was determined using a method referred to as the index of relative importance to determine the specific input impact (either positive or negative) on the outputs [42, 45]. Figure 13 presents the relative importance index values of each process parameter and its influence on the density and build height. It can be seen that the process parameters exhibited similar trends of influence on the outputs; however, the index values were noticeably different.Primarily, the power and feed rate have a positive influence on the density,whereas the increase in scan speed and layer thickness tend to minimize the density of the samples,as shown in Fig.13a. There was a noticeable rise in the build height of the samples in accordance with increasing the feed rate when compared with the power, whereas the scan speed resulted in a significant decrease in the build heights of the samples (Fig. 13b). The estimated index values are in accordance with the experimental observations, and the suggested method was able to give a basic idea regarding the qualitative relationship between input-output parameters.

content: From the selected regions of both the figures, four sets of process parameters were considered (denoted as S1, S2,PO-1, and PO-2, where PO represents the optimum parameters)and listed in Table 2.It should be noted for PO-1 the process parameters selected from the optimum region where the density and build height values were well maintained with respect to the scan speed and laser power (as indicated in Fig. 14a).As mentioned earlier, the density of the samples is not much varied with layer thickness and powder feed rate; thus, the sample PO-2,in the optimal build height region, is considered for validation of ANN predicted processing map (Fig. 14b). The other two sets of process parameters indicated as S1 and S2(see Fig. 14a) were then selected from the non-optimal parameter regions.The density and build height of the printed samples were measured and tabulated in Table 2.The macroscopic images of the four samples are depicted in Fig.14c. It can be seen that both PO-1 and PO-2 samples showed the optimal density and build height. According to the ANN results,sample S1 (selected from a low density region in Fig.14a) exhibits lower density due to severe lack of fusion defects. In the case of sample S2 (selected from quite high build height region） that shows reasonable density,however, the build height is increased to $\sim 9 \ \mathrm { m m }$ ； therefore,such a combination of process parameters should be avoided during printing. From the obtained results,the processing maps developed with the help of ANN predictions can guide the choice of desired process parameters and confirm that the model is a more suitable tool for the process parameter optimization，to allow for the realization of cost-effective and highquality product printing.

fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Narayana et al. - Optimization of process parameters for direct energy deposited Ti-6.pdf
content:
# 4 Conclusion
In this study,an artificial neural network model was developed for the optimization of the density and build height for the Ti-6Al-4V alloy fabricated by DED.The effect of the process parameters on the density and build height of the Ti6Al-4V samples was determined using the ANN model. The following conclusions were made:

1．The Box-Behnken method was used to design the experimental dataset for the ANN model development. The optimum architecture of the model was achieved by minimizing the training error which demonstrated an excellent prediction accuracy.   
2. The prior $\beta$ columnar grain size was decreased with increasing scan speed and increased with increasing the laser power.With respect to the phase constituents, the high scan speed tends to the formation of martensite $( \alpha ^ { \prime } )$ ， whereas the lower scan speed forms the $\alpha$ phase in the DED processed Ti-6Al-4V alloy.   
3. The developed process maps (based on ANN predictions) can provide clear knowledge regarding the process parameter influence on the density and build height of the samples.   
4. The suggested set of optimum process parameters yielded appropriate build height and density values.Hence, the ANN model helps to optimize the process parameters for the realization of fabricating high-quality products via the DED process.

Availability of data and material The authors confirm that the data supporting the findings of this study are available within the article.

Code availabilityThe software used during the current study is available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

Funding This study was supported by the Ministry of Trade,Industry, and Energy (Grant Nos.10077677,20013202,and 16-CM-MA-10).

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-1
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content:
# A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications: Directed Energy Deposition and Beyond Ti-6Al-4V
ZHIYING LIU,1 BEI HE,2,3,4 TIANYI LYU,1 and YU ZOU $\boldsymbol { \mathfrak { P } } ^ { 1 , 5 }$

1.-Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Toronto,Toronto,ON M5S 3E4,Canada.2.—Research Institute for Frontier Science,Beihang University,37 Xueyuan Road, Beijing，People'sRepublicof China.3.-NingboInstituteofTechnology，Beihang University，Ningbo31510o，People's Republic of China.4.—e-mail: hebei@buaa.edu.cn. 5.-e-mail: mse.zou@utoronto.ca

Titanium alloys are expensive and difficult to process into large complex components for aerospace applications.Directed energy deposition (DED), one of the additive manufacturing (AM) technologies, offers a high deposition rate, being suitable for fabricating large metallic components.So far,most review articles on the AM of titanium discuss the popular powder bed fusion method with the emphasis on the“workhorse” titanium alloy-Ti-6Al-4V. There have been few review articles on the DED process of a broad range of _titanium alloys-near- $\mathscr { X }$ $\beta$ ,and other $\alpha + \beta$ alloys beyond Ti-6Al-4V. This article focuses on the processing-microstructure-property relationships_ in the DED-processed titanium alloys (Ti-6Al-4V and beyond) with the following aspects: (1) microstructure evolution induced by solidification, thermal cycles,and postprocessing heat treatment; (2) tensile properties of as-deposited and heattreated titanium alloys; (3) defects, residual stresses, and fatigue properties; and (4） micro/nanomechanical properties. The article concludes with perspectives about future directions in this field.
summary: A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications: Directed Energy Deposition and Beyond Ti-6Al-4V

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-2
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content: Aerospace components need to withstand extreme operating conditions while being lightweight. Titanium alloys have been attractive in the aerospace industry, owing to their high specific strength (i.e., strength-to-weight ratio), fracture toughness, fatigue resistance,and excellent corrosion resistance.1,2 As the largest consumer of titanium, the aviation sector was projected to consume about $^ { 1 5 5 , 0 0 0 \mathrm { k g } }$ of titanium‘alonein2020.3 Therearetwo stable phases in elemental titanium at the standard atmospheric pressure-the hexagonal close-packed (hcp) $\mathscr { X }$ phase and the body-centered cubic (bcc) $\beta$ phase,4 as illustrated in Fig.1a. There are also a few metastable phases,including hexagonal $( \alpha ^ { \prime } )$ and orthorhombic $( \boldsymbol { \alpha } ^ { \prime } )$ martensite,metastable $\beta$ phase $( \beta ^ { \prime } )$ ，and omega $( \omega )$ phase,depending on compositions and processing histories.5,6 The transformation temperature from the $\beta$ phase to the $\mathscr { X }$ phase, also known as the $\beta$ -transus temperature $( T _ { \beta } )$ ,can be influenced by alloying elements on the stability of each phase (Fig. ia):(1) $\alpha \cdot$ -stabilizing elements include Al, O, N, and C；and (2) $\beta$ -stabilizing elements include Mo, V, $\mathrm { C r }$ ， Fe,Mn,Nb,and Ta (typically transition metals). Based on the chemical compositions and relative amounts of the $\mathscr { X }$ and $\beta$ phases at room temperature,titanium alloys are typically classified as $\mathscr { X }$ alloy，near $\mathscr { X }$ alloy， $\alpha + \beta$ alloy, near- $\cdot \beta$ alloy, and $\beta$ alloy. Although Ti-6Al-4V (also known as Ti64, TC4,or Grade 5 titanium） is the most used,about $50 \%$ of the total amount of all titanium alloys,a broad range of which have been used or under development for their specific applications.Typical titanium alloys used in the aviation industry are listed in Table I.

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-4
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content: Titanium is expensive: Raw titanium is about 5 and 5O times more expensive than raw aluminum and steel, respectively.10 Titanium alloys are also diffcult to process: their refining,ingot forming, and sheeting forming processes are 5, 10,and 18 times more expensive than their counterparts of aluminum， respectively.1 Conventional manufacturing processes, such as molding,casting, forging, and machining,generally lead to a large amount of material waste,a long manufacturing cycle,and, consequently，a very high cost.The “buy-to-fly" ratio,which is defined as the required input material weight divided by the finish machined part weight, can quantify the usage or wastage of the materials in each processing method.For wroughtbased methods in fabricating complex geometries of components, the buy-to-fly ratios could reach up tol0:1-2O:1 because most of the materials are machined down.12 Therefore,it is much more economical to decrease the “buy-to-fly” ratio by "building up” the components instead of“removing" expensive titanium alloys from forgings.

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-5
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content: Additive manufacturing (AM), sometimes also known as 3D printing, is a disruptive technique that builds up the components with desired complex geometries in a layer-by-layer fashion. AM optimizes the development and fabrication of new products by significantly reducing material wastes and the number of manufacturing steps.Metal AM has received significant attention in the aerospace industry,because of its high material utilization ratio (the buy-to-fly ratio is close to 1:1),short production cycles,and minimal subsequent machining.13,14 The most utilized techniques of metal AM are powder bed fusion (PBF) and directed energy deposition (DED) methods.In PBF,a heat source, either a laser or electron beam, fuses metal powder in a powder bed layer and subsequently consolidates them together. The technique using a laser source is also called laser powder bed fusion (LPBF） or selective laser melting.That based on an electron beam is called electron beam melting. In DED, by contrast, the coaxial heat source (laser or electron beam） moves along with the powder delivery route to melt and fuse powder at specific locations in an object (Fig. 2a). Laser-based DED,also known as laser metal deposition or laser-engineered net shaping,has drawn wider attention due to its higher production rate and more flexible working environment than electron beam-based DED， which requires a vacuum condition.1 The metal wire can also be used as feedstock,known as wire arc additive manufacturing,but our article will focus on the majority of the DED process with powder feedstock.

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-6
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content: Although PBF generally exhibits a better spatial resolution and surface quality of produced parts than DED,the latter possesses a few unique advantages over PBF for aerospace applications: (1) DED typically uses a much higher laser power (from $\sim 5 0 0$ W to a few $\mathbf { k W }$ ）thanLPBF( $\mathrm { ~ \stackrel { ~ } { ~ } { ~ } ~ } \sim 1 0 0 { - } 5 0 0 \mathrm { W } )$ and larger laser spots sizes $( \sim 1 { - } 1 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ )thanLPBF $( \sim 5 0 { - } \bar { 1 } 0 0 \ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ ；(2）DED exhibits a much higher (over one order of magnitude) deposition rate than PBF,which is essential for manufacturing large aerospace components; Fig. 2c compares the deposition rate and layer thickness of PBF and DED technologies6; (3)initially,from alaser cladding or coating technique,DED can also be used for repairing parts and coatings,with an example shown in Fig. 2b; and (4) DED can adjust real-time powder compositions and fabricate products with site-specific compositions and properties， providing a new opportunity for developing functionally_graded materials and multi-principal element alloys (or high-entropy alloys).

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-7
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content:
Over the last decade, several review articles have discussed the AM of titanium,but most of them emphasize the PBF process and the “workhorse” titaniumally Ti-6Al-4V.17-19 Thus,PBF-processed Ti-6Al-4V has been intensively reviewed for its microstructures,mechanical properties,and potential applications.In recent years,a large amount of research on the DED of titanium alloys,beyond Ti6Al-4V,have been reported.Up to date, there has been no review on the DED process for a broad range of titanium alloys, such as near $\mathscr { x }$ ， $\beta$ ，and other $\alpha + \beta$ alloys beyond Ti-6Al-4V. Our article reviews the recent progress on the laser-based DED of titanium alloys,while the electron beam-based DED is not the focus of this article.We discuss the processing-microstructure-propertyrelationships and focus on the following aspects:(1) how rapid solidification， thermal cycles, and post-processing heat treatment influence the microstructure evolution;(2) what the yield strength, tensile strength, and ductility of as-deposited and heat-treated titanium alloys are;(3) how defects and residual stresses affect the fatigue properties of the DEDprocessed titanium alloys,and (4) how the complex microstructure and phases influence mechanical properties at both the macroscopic and microscopic scales.

![](images/1b73d6a7a61de8ba252984aeb1dc8cff48b70518c096239cac0512db5fabf023.jpg)  
Fig.2.(a)Schematicftdiectdergdeposito(DED)proc.()itacompressaneepiedusigEDprocsepinte withpermissonfromRef..(cComparisonoftePBFandDEDtechologiesintrmsoflayerthicknessnddeposiorate(eprintedwith permission from Ref.16).

As new DED equipment, software,and advanced metallurgy are being developed,many new opportunities for fundamental research and technical development are to be exploited. Therefore，we briefly conclude with perspectives about future directions in this field,including in situ monitoring, functional gradient alloys,alloy design for AM, topology optimization,and machine learning.

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-9
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content: In the DED process,a laser beam melts metal powders to form a molten pool on the surface of a substrate.Due to the fast heat dissipation from the substrate, a molten pool experiences rapid cooling and solidification $( \mathrm { i } 0 ^ { 4 } { - } 1 0 ^ { 6 } ^ { \bullet } \mathrm { K } / \mathrm { s } ^ { 2 0 } )$ Unidirectional solidified prior- $\beta$ columnar grains are one of the most distinctive features in a DED-produced titanium alloy.Equiaxed grains at the top region of the deposition layer can also be observed.For example, Fig. 3a shows the microstructure of the DEDproduced $\Gamma \mathrm { i } – 6 . 5 \mathrm { A l } – 3 . 5 \mathrm { M o } 1 . 5 \mathrm { Z r } – 0 . 3 \mathrm { S i }$ alloy consisting of coarse columnar prior- $\beta$ grains at the bottom and equiaxed grains at the top of a deposition track.21 The $\mathscr { X }$ phase can be preferentially nucleated at the boundaries of the prior- $\beta$ grains, forming a grain boundary $\mathscr { X }$ phase $( \alpha _ { \mathbf { G B } } )$ (Fig. 3b).22 The columnar to equiaxed transition (CET） in prior- $\beta$ grains has been broadly investigated.23- 3-25 The columnar grains are formed by epitaxial growth from the substrate at the bottom of the molten pool. The equiaxed grains are attributed to the growth of newly nucleated grains due to the reduced thermal gradient and the existence of unmelted particles at the top of the molten pool (Fig. 3c).21
summary: Microstructure Induced by Rapid Solidification and Cooling - Part 1/2

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-10
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content: The prior- $\boldsymbol { \cdot } \beta$ morphology of mixed columnar and equiaxed grains varies in α, $\alpha + \beta$ ，and $\beta$ titanium alloys due to their distinct constitutional supercooling zone (CS) during the solidification process. The growth restriction factor $( Q )$ is defined as the development rate of the CS zone, indicating that a larger $Q$ value corresponds to a faster and larger development of the CS zone.Therefore,titanium alloys with larger $Q$ values exhibit a higher tendency of grain nucleation and growth, forming a higher volume fraction of equiaxed prior- $\beta$ grains. Zhu et al.26 found an increase of $Q$ from $\mathscr { X }$ to $\beta$ titanium alloys,and the volume fraction of equiaxed prior- $\beta$ grains increased from zero in Ti-6Al-2Zr-1V1Mo $Q = 3 . 7 )$ to $45 \%$ in $\mathrm { T i { - } 6 . 5 A l { - } 3 . 5 M o { - } 1 . 5 Z r { - } 0 . 3 S i }$ $Q = 1 5 . 2 )$ ，and finally to almost $100 \%$ in Ti-10V2Fe-3Al(Ti1023）( $Q = 2 6 . 3 )$ .Figure 3d shows the transformation of the prior- $\beta$ morphology from full columnar to full equiaxed in three types of DEDproduced titanium alloys with increasing $Q$ values. Figure 3d also illustrates the relationship between the $Q$ value,the size of the CS zone,and grain nucleation of the three types of titanium alloys. The columnar to equiaxed transition in prior- $\beta$ grains is also achievable in DED-produced common $\mathrm { T i } { - } 8 . 5 \mathrm { C u }$ alloys due to the high constitutional supercooling capacity (a high $Q$ value).27
summary: Microstructure Induced by Rapid Solidification and Cooling - Part 2/2

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-11
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content:
During the DED process, each layer experiences a large number of heating-cooling cycles,and the peaktemperature foreach deposited layer decreases continuously,as schematically shown in Fig. 4a. The cooling scheme of one deposited layer in Fig. 4a can be divided into three regions28,29: (1) when the peak temperature is above $T _ { \beta }$ (Region A), the original $\mathscr { X }$ phase can completely transform into $\beta$ phase and then transfer into the $\mathscr { X }$ phase again during the cooling process; (2) after a few layers of deposition, the peak temperature is below $T _ { \beta }$ (region B), the partial $\mathscr { X }$ phase lamella transfers into $\beta$ phase during heating and the new $\mathscr { X }$ phase precipitated from the $\beta$ phase during the cooling process,while the remaining $\mathscr { X }$ phase coarsens; and (3) when the peak temperature decreases to a temperature $( T _ { \alpha } )$ that no obvious phase transformation can take place (Region C), the as-deposited microstructures stabilize. The whole process demonstrates the effects of the cyclic thermal treatments on the $\mathscr { X }$ and $\beta$ microstructure evolutions. The $T _ { \beta }$ varies in different titanium alloys and can be calculated using the linear regression analysis proposed by Guo et al.30, given as follows:

$$
\begin{array} { r l } & { T _ { \beta } = 8 8 2 + 2 1 . 1 [ \mathrm { A l } ] - 9 . 5 [ \mathrm { M o } ] + 4 . 2 [ \mathrm { S n } ] - 6 . 9 [ \mathrm { Z r } ] } \\ & { \qquad - 1 1 . 8 [ \mathrm { V } ] - 1 2 . 1 [ \mathrm { C r } ] - 1 5 . 4 [ \mathrm { F e } ] + 2 3 . 3 [ \mathrm { S i } ] } \\ & { \qquad + 1 2 3 . 0 [ \mathrm { O } ] } \end{array}
$$
summary: Microstructure Induced by Thermal Cycles - Part 1/4

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-12
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content: where $[ M ]$ ，any element in the equation,represents_the weight percent of the element.Kelly et al.31 observed finer $\mathscr { X }$ laths at the top than that at the bottom in the Ti-6Al-4V bulk samples due to the distinct thermal history between the regions. Kenel et al.32 combined in situ $\mathbf { x }$ -ray diffraction and high-speed imaging to monitor the phase evolution upon cyclic rapid laser heating of Ti-6Al-4V in real time,showing the $\beta \to \alpha ^ { \prime } \to \beta$ phase transformation together with lattice strain evolution.The thermal cycles accompanied by phase transformation alsoinduce element partitioning，lattice defects， and thermal expansion， consequently leading to various microstructures.334 Li et al.34 observed anisotropic internal thermal expansion of as-deposited DED-produced Ti-6Al-2Zr-2Sn-3Mo1Cr-2Nb alloy. Such an anisotropic expansion results from $\mathscr { X }$ variant_ selection $( \{ 0 0 0 1 \} \alpha \mid \mid \{ 1 1 0 \} \beta ,$ $< 1 1 2 0 > \alpha \mid \mid < 1 1 1 > \beta )$ during the $\beta \  \ \alpha$ transformation.However,owing to the difference in chemical composition, the α, $\alpha + \beta$ ，and $\beta$ alloys exhibit distinct as-deposited microstructures (coarse Widmannstätten“ microstructurein Ti-4Al-1.5Mn alloy,finebasket-weave microstructure in Ti6Al-2Zr-1Mo-1V_alloy,36and Ti-6.5Al-3.5Mo-1.5Zr0.3Si alloy21). The effect of cyclic thermal treatments on the microstructures of a broad range of titanium alloys beyond Ti-6Al-4V needs further investigation.
summary: Microstructure Induced by Thermal Cycles - Part 2/4

content: The other microstructural feature, layer bands, can also be influenced by the cyclic thermal treatments. Figure 4b and c shows two kinds of layer bands_ in as-deposited Ti-6.5Al-3.5Mo-1.5Zr-0.3Si alloy,29ie.,heat-affected bands and interlayer bands.The heat-affected bands are present in the overlap of two layers,where re-melting or reheating takes place during the sequence deposition. The heat-affected bands are formed when the reheated temperature is increased in the upper part of the $\alpha + \beta$ region with ultra-fine $\mathscr { X }$ lamellae precipitated. The interlayer bands are spaced uniformly and located in a re-heated region rather than in a re-melted region. The interlayer bands can be only observed in titanium alloys with a high content of $\beta$ stabilizing elements.37 The diffusion of $\beta$ stabilizing elements promotes the formation of composition homogenization region， which are indispensable and favorable for $\mathscr { X }$ nucleation and growth from the $\beta$ phase,resulting in the interlayer bands with a width of about $1 0 { - } 1 5 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ ：
summary: Microstructure Induced by Thermal Cycles - Part 4/4

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-15

content: Post-DED heat treatment is an effective way to reduce high residual stress and optimize the microstructures, including the phases as well as their size,morphology,and volume fraction,thereby tuning the mechanical performance of the near-netshape components.The heat-treated microstructure is sensitive to thermal conditions, such as solution temperature and cooling rate. First,when the solution temperature is higher than $T _ { \beta , }$ the prior- $\beta$ grain boundary dissolves and the morphology of prior- $\beta$ grains varies. The precipitates from the $\beta$ phase depend greatly on the cooling rate.Water quenching allows the formation ofmetastable hexagonal $( \alpha ^ { \prime } )$ ororthorhombic $( \alpha ^ { \prime \prime } )$ martensite while furnace cooling produces stable hexagonal coarse $\mathscr { X }$ phase.An increase in $\beta$ stabilizer elements leads to a shift from $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ to $\alpha ^ { \prime \prime }$ martensite in rapidly cooled titanium alloys.38 Other metastable phases, $\beta ^ { \prime }$ and $\omega$ phases,also appear in titanium alloys with considerable $\beta$ -stabilizer elements during rapid cooling or low temperature_aging.39 e.g the $\omega$ phase in DED-produced Ti55511 alloy.37 Second, when the solution temperature is lower than $T _ { \beta , }$ the prior- $\beta$ grain remains stable but the $\mathscr { X }$ grains evolve. Figure 5a shows the as-deposited microstructure of the Ti-6Al- $2 \mathrm { Z r }$ -2Sn-3Mo-1Cr-2Nb alloy,40 presenting a fine basket-weave microstructure with O.1- to $0 . 4 \mathrm { - } \mu \mathrm { m }$ -wide $\mathscr { X }$ and $\beta$ laths.When the solution is treated under $9 5 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ $( T _ { \beta }$ of this alloy)，partial $\mathscr { X }$ phase transformed to the $\beta$ phase whereas the residual $\mathscr { X }$ phase (primary $\mathscr { X }$ or $\alpha _ { \mathbf { p } , }$ ）remains and becomes thicker and shorter (Fig. 5b).
summary: Microstructure Induced by Post-processing Heat Treatment - Part 1/2

content: The subsequent water quenching results in the precipitation of $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ in the $\beta$ matrix,which is less distinguishable in Fig. 5b. However, when followed by air cooling, instead of water quenching,a newly formed finer $\mathscr { X }$ phase (secondary $\mathscr { X }$ phase, $\alpha _ { \mathrm { s } } \mathrm { , }$ ）appears in the $\beta$ matrix (Fig. 5c). The $\alpha _ { \mathrm { s } }$ phases also decorate the edge of the ${ \mathfrak { X } } _ { \mathbf { p } }$ laths, forming a crab-like structure, as indicated by the circle in Fig. 5c. After further aging at $6 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $^ { 4 \mathrm { h } }$ ,the $\mathsf { \Omega } \mathsf { \Omega } \mathsf { \Omega } \mathsf { \Omega } \mathsf { \Omega }$ lath became thicker (Fig. 5d). The crab-like structure was also_observed in DEDproduced Ti-6.5Al-2Zr-1V-1M041 and Ti-6Al-4V alloys.42 Li et al.40 analyzed the crab-like structure through a dark-field TEM image (Fig. 5e), showing that $\mathsf { \Omega } \mathsf { \Omega } \mathsf { \Omega } \mathsf { \Omega } \mathsf { \Omega }$ phase nucleates at the edge of the ${ \mathfrak { X } } _ { \mathbf { p } }$ laths and grows to interact with other $\alpha _ { \mathrm { s } }$ phases, forming the crab-like structures with several $\alpha _ { \mathrm { s } } / \alpha _ { \mathrm { s } }$ interfaces (Fig. 5e).
summary: Microstructure Induced by Post-processing Heat Treatment - Part 2/2

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-17
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content: Defects and residual stresses are two essential factors that limit the application of DED-produced titanium alloys for aerospace components.There are ateDty formed when gas bubbles are unable to escape from molten pools timeously during the solidification process, while the lack of fusion is formed due to either a low temperature in the melt pool or an excessively high powder feed rate. Similar to laser welding, pores in the DED process can be categorized as keyhole,balling, and gas bubbles.44A keyhole is caused by a massive amount of high energy imposed on a small area, resulting in a melt pool with a narrow and deep shape.45 The resulted melt_pool shape makes it diffcult for the vapor bubbles inside to get out within a short period of cooling time before the materials are solidified, leaving a keyhole inclusion defect inside the produced part.46 Balling occurs at a relatively high laser energy density47: the melted liquid takes the cohesive powder particles and peels away from the surface in close to spherical shapes. The pores can also be formed from entrapped gas bubbles during the DED process. Figure 6c and d illustrates the formation of trapped gas pores in the melt pool.48 Such defects may not significantly affect the tensile strengths,but they play an essential role in the reduction of fatigue resistance of DED parts.

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-18
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content:
Residual stress is another major issue causing the failure of produced parts during and after the DED process. The thermal cycles with high heating and cooling rates in the DED process give rise to steep residual stress gradients, leading to the distortion or cracking of the parts and dramatically deteriorating their performance.A temperature gradient mechanism model is used to describe the residual stress during thermal cycles,50,51 as schematically shown in Fig. 6e and f. The temperature in the laser-powder interaction region quickly_ increases, but the hot material region expands and is restricted by the surrounding cooler regions. This restriction induces compressive stress in the hot material region.As the hot region cools and contracts， the contraction of this region is also restricted by the surrounded regions, resulting in permanent tensile residual stresses in the part and leading to a warped product.

content: The unique microstructures and internal defects associated with the titanium DED process significantly influence their mechanical performance. Tensile and fatigue properties are essential to evaluate the mechanical reliability of components under static and cyclic deformations. Previous reviews have mainly focused on the tensile properties of Ti-6Al-4V.52-54 Our article focuses on a broad range of titanium alloys produced by DED (Table I).

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-21
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content: The titanium components made by DED typically exhibit superior tensile strength, but lower ductility,compared to the components produced by conventional methods, such as casting and forging, owing to the high cooling rate and induced fine microstructure.Table I summarizes the tensile properties obtained from the as-deposited titanium alloys processed by DED in various laser or powder conditions.All data are obtained by low-strain-rate tensile tests at room temperature unless otherwise specified. The longitudinal and transverse orientations indicate that samples were extracted in parallel and perpendicular directions to the building direction,respectively. The longitudinal samples generally show 10-50 MPa lower in the tensile strength or yield strength than the transverse samples due to anisotropic microstructures (the columnar $\beta$ grains and the presence of grain boundary $\mathscr { X }$ phase, $\alpha _ { \mathbf { G B } }$ (Fig. 3).6,37
summary: Tensile Properties of As-Deposited Titanium Alloys - Part 1/3

content: Figure 7a_compares the tensile strength and elongation of the α, $\alpha + \beta$ ，and $\beta$ titanium alloys made by DED.The $\beta$ titanium alloys show the highest strength but the lowest ductility. The high strength can be attributed to the additional elements (e.g., Cu, Mo, Si, etc.） in $\beta$ titanium alloys, which dramatically refine the prior- $\beta$ grains during the solidification process and control the grain growth during thermal cycles.The other reason is the high content of the $\beta$ phase,which can be converted into a fine precipitated stable $\mathscr { X }$ phase or metastable phases (martensite and $\omega$ phase),contributing to the superior strength.The $\mathscr { X }$ and $\alpha + \beta$ titanium alloys also show high strength $( > ~ 1 0 0 0$ MPa) due to the fine $\mathscr { X }$ and martensite microstructure.The varied elongation could be due to the pores and $\alpha _ { \mathbf { G B } }$ in the as-deposited samples.Hot isostatic pressing (HIP) has been employed to close the pores and densify the microstructure,leading_ to higher ductility but lower strength.55-57 By eliminating pores and coarsening the $\mathscr { X }$ phase,the ductility of the as-deposited Ti1o23 alloy can be doubled, with a reduction of tensile strength by about $2 0 0 \ \mathrm { \dot { M P a } }$ .58 The presence of $\alpha _ { \mathbf { G B } }$ also plays an essential role in deteriorating the ductility of DED titanium. For example, Ti6242 alloy shows a low elongation $( < 3 \% )$ ,because a continuous film of $\alpha _ { \mathbf { G B } }$ acts as the weakness. Low elongation $( \sim 5 . 2 \% )$ in the DEDproducedTi-5Al-4Mo-2Zr-2Sn-4Cr alloy is also attributed to the continuous $\alpha _ { \mathbf { G B } }$ ， along which the cracks are easily_ propagated.60 Ren et al.61 also reported a lower elongation of Ti-6.5Al-3.5Mo-1.5Zr0.3Si alloy compared to that of the wrought sample $10 \%$ vs.
summary: Tensile Properties of As-Deposited Titanium Alloys - Part 2/3

content: $18 \%$ due to a large number of prior- $\beta$ grain boundaries perpendicular to the loading direction, although their tensile strengths are_comparable (1100 MPa vs. $1 1 2 0 ~ \mathrm { M P a } ,$ .Liu et al.22,62 observed a soft $\mathscr { X }$ phase precipitate-free zones (PFZ) accompanied by the continuous $\alpha _ { \mathbf { G B } }$ . The high yield strength difference between the soft PFZ and the hard aged $\beta$ matrix leads to intergranular fracture and poor elongation $( \sim 5 \% )$ of as-deposited Ti55511. Therefore，eliminating continuous $\alpha _ { \mathbf { G B } }$ is critical for enhancing the ductility of as-deposited titanium alloys.

content: The heat treatment for relieving residual stresses is conducted at relatively low temperatures $( <$ $7 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ ，which hardly alters the tensile properties because of the invariant microstructures.23,67 However, high-temperature annealing near the $\beta$ -transustemperaturemaysignificantlychange microstructures,leading to distinct mechanical properties. Table III summarizes the heat treatment parameters and corresponding tensile properties of the DED-produced titanium alloys.Figure 7b highlights the tensile strength and elongation of the heat-treated titanium alloys. The precipitation of fine α or metastable phases in both $\beta$ and $\alpha + \beta$ phase alloys decreases their strength difference in the annealed conditions.

content: Here, three specific effects induced by heat treatment are highlighted.First,the solution temperature and cooling rate can control the formation of phases as well as their size and content to achieve the strength-plasticity synergy. The strength-plasticity synergy of Ti6242 alloys can be achieved when the content and width of the $\mathscr { X }$ and $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ phases are optimized.73 The $\mathrm { T i } – 5 . 5 \mathrm { A l } – 3 . 3 8 \mathrm { S n } – 3 . 3 4 \mathrm { Z r } – 0 . 3 7 \mathrm { M o } –$ 0.46SiandTi-6.5Al-2Zr-1V-1Moalloysshow improved strength and ductility after two stages of heat treatment.41,75 The increased ductility is attributed to the high content of $\beta$ phase after the first high-temperature annealing $( \sim 1 0 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ ,while the high strength originates from the formation of crab-like $\mathscr { X }$ structure (shown in Fig. 5e), fine lamellar transformed $\beta$ ,and $\mathrm { T i } _ { 3 } \mathrm { A l }$ precipitates during the second modest-temperature annealing $( \sim 7 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ Second,annealing at a temperature higher than the $\beta$ -transus alters the morphology and size of the prior- $\beta$ grains,reducing the anisotropy of the tensile properties.64 Yang et al.79 found that increasing the size of prior- $\beta$ grains can strengthen the Ti-6.5Al$3 . 5 \mathrm { M o } { - } 1 . 5 \mathrm { Z r } { - } 0 . 3 \mathrm { S i }$ alloys, due to the strong constraints among the grains. And third, designing specific heat treatment paths can alter the discontinuity of the $\alpha _ { \mathbf { G B } }$ Liu et al.80 explored novel pure heat treatment paths and successfully increased the discontinuity of $\alpha _ { \mathbf { G B } }$ of the as-deposited Ti55511. The elongation of the heat-treated samples became 1.4-2 times more than that of the as-deposited samples without sacrificing their strength.
summary: Tensile Properties of Heat-Treated DED-Produced Titanium Alloys - Part 2/5

content: The fatigue resistance of titanium alloys is essential for aerospace applications.The fatigue life of DED-produced titanium alloys depends on the fatigue crack nucleation and early crack propagation,82 which is affected by residual stress, surface roughness,internal defects,and microstructural inhomogeneities. The residual stress and surface roughness can be reduced by stress-relieved heat treatment and post-machining,respectively. The effects of internal defects (i.e.， internal pores and unmelted particles8) and microstructural inhomogeneities on fatigue performance of DED-produced titanium alloys are discussed.
summary: Fatigue Properties of DED-Produced Titanium Alloys - Part 1/5

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-30
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content: The fatigue performance can be measured by the stress-life $( S { - } \bar { N } )$ approach using unnotched standard specimens. Figure 8a compares the $S { - } N$ curves of three types of DED-produced titanium alloys (data from Ref84-86).Under the same strength amplitude, Ti-6Al-4V shows the lowest fatigue life due to its high density of surface pores. The pores closer to the surface cause higher stress concentrations,increasing the propensity of fatigue crack initiation.85 The increased fatigue life in the Ti6.5Al-3.5Mo-1.5Zr-0.3Si and Ti-6Al-2Zr-1V-1Mo alloys is due to comparatively fewer surface pores, but their fatigue life decreases with increasing pore diameter.87 The three pore-related mechanisms of crack initiation can be summarized as (1） the element segregation at the surface of the pores makes the alloy brittle,for example,the segregation of Al at the surface of the pores in Ti-6Al-2Zr-1V1Mo alloys87; (2） the appearance of pores or unmelted particles breaks the continuity of grain boundaries around them,where cracks were initiated under cyclic stress; and (3） the sharpest topographies of irregularly shaped pores show the highest local stress, inevitably increasing the possibility of fatigue crack initiation.83 Figure 8b shows a representative fatigue fracture surface consisting of a crack initiation zone (Stage I),a crack propagation zone (Stage II), and a final fracture zone (Stage III). 87
summary: Fatigue Properties of DED-Produced Titanium Alloys - Part 2/5

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-31
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content: The presence of fine $\alpha , ~ \alpha ^ { \prime }$ ，and other nanoscale precipitates in DED-produced titanium alloys contributes to high fatigue strength but sacrifices ductility. The limited ductility associated with localized dislocation slip also promotes fatigue crack initiation.The microstructure-related crack initiation site is typically located in the prior- $\beta$ grain boundary and $\alpha / \beta$ phase boundary,due to the incompatible local deformation.72 The fatigue crack initiation also relates to the macro-texture or orientation of prior- $\beta$ grains,which impede dislocation motion and induce incompatible deformation.88 Compared to the fatigue crack initiation,the fatigue crackpropagation is moresensitive to the microstructure. Figure 8c systematically compared the fatigue crack growth behavior of as-forged, asdeposited,and heat-treated Ti-6.5Al-2Zr-1V-1Mo alloy using the $d a / d N { - } \Delta K$ curves.89 The as-deposited sample exhibits a comparable fatigue crack growth rate with the as-forged sample due to the presence of a high density of the" $\alpha / \beta$ interface. Moreover, the heat-treated sample shows a much lower fatigue crack growth rate,which can be attributed to the increased density of the $\alpha _ { \mathrm { { s } } } / \beta$ interfaces. Figure 8d shows a fatigue crack propagation path,demonstrating the role of phase boundaries in deflecting the fatigue cracks.90 Meanwhile, thespecial microstructural features, $\mathscr { X }$ colony boundaries,91 heat-affected bands,91 and discontinuous $\alpha _ { \mathrm { G B } } ^ { \mathrm { \ 9 2 } }$ also deflect or retard crack propagation. It should be noted unstable fatigue crack propagation occurs when the stress intensity factor $( K _ { V } )$ reaches the critical value, $K _ { \mathrm { I C } }$ (fracture toughness). However, studies on the fracture toughness of DEDproduced titanium alloys,especially beyond Ti-6Al4V alloys, are scarcely reported.
summary: Fatigue Properties of DED-Produced Titanium Alloys - Part 3/5
