name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-34
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content:
# Micromechanical Studies of Titanium Alloys by AM
The development of micro-/nano-mechanical characterization (e.g., nanoindentation and micro-pillar compression) provides powerful tools for probing the mechanical properties of constitutional phases of DED-produced titanium alloys (e.g.,hardness $H$ and modulus $E ^ { 9 4 }$ ).The micromechanical studies assist in understanding the deformation micromechanisms of_titanium alloys. For example, Formanoir et al.95 fabricated Ti-6Al-4V alloys and measured the $H$ of two heat-treated Ti-6Al-4V alloys by nanoindentation tests (Fig.9a, b). The $H$ difference between $\mathscr { X }$ and $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ is larger than that between $\mathscr { X }$ and $\alpha _ { d e c } ^ { \prime }$ (Fig. 9b),resulting in a more pronounced local strain partitioning and higher ductility in the $\alpha + \alpha ^ { \prime }$ titanium alloy (Fig. 9c,d). These results demonstrated the significance of the micromechanical properties of phases in controlling the local and global deformation of titanium alloys.More work should be carried out to establish the relationship between the microscale and macroscale mechanical properties of DED-produced titanium alloys.

# CHALLENGES AND FUTURE OPPORTUNITIES
The rapid development of the aerospace industry poses an urgent challenge to speed up the manufacturing rate and lower the cost of titanium components for many demanding applications. Despite the increasing popularity of AM of titanium alloys,there are still numerous challenges that restrict its potential. Meanwhile, a few emerging research directions have attracted significant attention to promoting the fundamental and technical development of the AM of metals.
summary: CHALLENGES AND FUTURE OPPORTUNITIES, Micromechanical Studies of Titanium Alloys by AM

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-35
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content:
# In Situ Characterization, Monitoring, and Mechanical Testing
First,in situ characterization: Recent studies have incorporated in situ X-ray characterizing techniques in synchrotron to directly observe melt pool dynamics,microstructural feature formation,and phase evolution during layer upon layer deposition.96 Such methodology offers_a new opportunity tofundamentally understand the underlying formation mechanism of defects and the solidification process in DED.Second, in situ monitoring: high-speed and infrared cameras can be used to detect melt pools, spatters, plumes,and temperatures.97 This monitoring method allows for exploring the optimized processing parameters to reduce the defects and residual stresses in the final components.And third,in situ mechanical testing: the effects of complex phases,microstructures, interfaces,defects,and anisotropy on the mechanical properties of the DED-produced parts are still not well understood. A better understanding of these effects can be benefited from using emerging in situ mechanical tests, such as tensile,compression, bending,fracture,and fatigue tests in SEM and TEM chambers.

![](images/bf8d5f45d9b9a9f20a803e066773bf614e47fb9d546273564afc5de95ee6290c.jpg)  
Fig. 9.. (a1) and (a2)the microstructures of two types of heat-treated AM-produced Ti-6Al-4V alloys. The $H$ and microscale strain in each phase areshowdspiely.spdofeedi from Ref.95

# Laser-Assisted Repair by DED
The repair of damaged components is a unique possibility of the laser-based DED method.98 Compared to conventional welding-based repair techniques (e.g., tungsten inert gas welding and plasma transferred arc welding), the DED process exhibits lower heat input, warpage and distortion,and dilution rate, and better metallurgical bonding between deposited layers.99 When dissimilar materials are used for the repair, the possible delamination cracks or pores due to thermal shrinkage near the interface should be addressed.
summary: In Situ Characterization, Monitoring, and Mechanical Testing, Laser-Assisted Repair by DED

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-36
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content: The capability of feeding dissimilar metal powders also allows the DED approach to fabricate functionally graded materials.10o So far, the structural graded titanium alloys (e.g., Ti/TiAll0l and TiAl/Ti2AlNb102), microstructural graded titanium alloys (e.g., Ti-6Al $\cdot 4 \mathrm { V } ^ { 1 0 3 } .$ , and compositional graded titanium alloys (e.g.，Ti-Cr alloyl04) have been successfully fabricated. There is growing research attempting to produce graded materials by delivering elemental powders from two (or more) nozzles. Direct in situ alloying can be a practical solution to increase manufacturing flexibility and save time and cost by eliminating the_production steps required for prealloyed powders.105 However, a few challenges must be circumvented, including(1) the local non-equilibrium thermal and chemical conditions raise the difficulty of predicting phase composition and microstructure,and (2) the generalized processing principle from one material to another is still lacking.Meanwhile,most of the titanium alloys for the AM are based on conventional compositions for casting or forging.Many of these alloys are not ideal for the AM process (rapid cooling and solidfication),and, consequently, they form pores,cracks, or brittle phases.Therefore, the design of new alloys specific for the DED process is also highly desiable. As an emerging feld of metallurgy,new multicomponent alloys or high-entropy_alloys are also interesting for producing by DED.65
summary: Design of Functionally Graded Materials and Multi-component Alloys, Topology Optimization for Large Metallic Components - Part 1/2

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-37
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content:
# Topology Optimization for Large Metallic Components
One of the distinct advantages of DED,compared to PBF，is its capability to manufacture large metallic components,from centimeters to meters. However，asthe building height increases,the geometrical integrity (distortion induced by large residual stress）and structural integrity (porosity) become sensitive,combined with a pronounced microstructure variation from the bottom to the top.106 Topology optimization can be used to optimize the structure and mechanics to reduce residual stress and weight of components,whose geometries are limited by conventional manufacturing techniques.107 By incorporating topology optimized structures into designs,designers can eliminate substantial weight, while maintaining the strength and integrity of parts.
summary: Design of Functionally Graded Materials and Multi-component Alloys, Topology Optimization for Large Metallic Components - Part 2/2

name: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an-part-38
fileName: 2021 - Jom - Liu et al. - A Review on Additive Manufacturing of Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Applications Directed Energy Deposition an.pdf
content:
# Machine Learning for Alloy Design and Process Optimization
Many metals and alloys that can be processed by conventional manufacturing techniques are not necessarily applicable to the DED process,and, meanwhile, emerging multi-component alloys or high-entropy alloys are attractive for producing by DED.65 Thus, alloy design_specific for the DED process is highly desirable.However, the identification of new alloys for DED out of a vast compositional space is still a daunting task, still requiring trial-and-error，especially when the composition needs to be optimized for a combination of properties.Similarly, the development of high mechanical performance DED products is limited by timeconsuming searching for optimized processing parameters,such as_ laser power,scanning speed, spot size,and layer thickness.Therefore,a fast and cost-efficient way to discover new alloys and optimized processes for fabricating high-performance components is desired. Machine learning_has been rapidly developed in the past decade.108 Highthroughput experiments together with machinelearning algorithms can be exploited to accelerate the discovery of new alloys for DED. Meanwhile, machine learning, morespecifically computer vision，can be used to predict the melting pool temperature,65 5 to enhance real-time image capturing,and to correlate the printing parameters for the geometrical attributes of the deposited metal trace. Such a machine-learning approach can be used to develop closed-loop control AM systems. Thus,the development of machine learning and more available datasets pave the way for the next-generation DED process of new titanium alloys.
summary: Machine Learning for Alloy Design and Process Optimization

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-1
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
Sheng Cao1\*， Yichao Zou', Chao Voon Samuel Lim²³ and Xinhua Wu23

# Abstract
Laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) is a timely important additive manufacturing technique that ofers many opportunities for fabricating three-dimensional complex shaped components at a high resolution with short lead times.This technique has been extensively employed in manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V parts for aerospace and biomedical applications.However，many chalenges，including poor surface quality，porosity，anisotropy in microstructureand propertyand dificultyintailoring microstructure,stillexist.Inthis paper,wereviewtherecent progress in post-process treatment and its influence on the microstructure evolution and material performance, including tensile,fatigue,fracture toughness,creep,and corosionproperties.The contradictionsinsimultaneously achieving high strength/ductility and strength/fracture toughness/creep resistance have been identified. Furthermore,research gaps in understanding the efects of the emerging bi-modal microstructure on fatigue properties and fracture toughness require further investigation.
summary: Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Ai-4V: process,post-process treatment, microstructure,and property

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-2
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
Ti-6Al-4V,also termed as TC4, titanium grade 5 and grade 23 (extra low interstitials), is the most commonly used Ti alloyl,². It combines excellent properties including good mechanical performance, outstanding corrosion resistance,and superior biocompatibility. Therefore,Ti6Al-4V is widely applied in aerospace, automotive, marine and chemical industries. Furthermore, it has been widely used in biomechanical applications such as implants and prostheses1-3. The details of the Ti-6Al-4V powders are available in the ASTM and AMS specifications4 .

Ti-6Al-4V is an $\alpha { + } \beta$ titanium alloy with a hexagonal close packed (HCP) $\mathfrak { a }$ phase stable at low temperatures, and a body centered cubic (BCC) $\beta$ phase stable at high temperatures'.The $\beta / { \alpha }$ allotropictransformation temperature ( $\beta$ transus） is approximately $9 9 5 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for Ti$6 \mathrm { A l } \mathrm { - } 4 \mathrm { V } ^ { 2 }$ ,and this temperature can be increased by adding $\mathfrak { a }$ stabilizers (Al, O, N,and C) and decreased by alloying with $\beta$ stabilizers (V,Mo, Fe, etc.)'². The crystal structures of $\mathfrak { a }$ and $\beta$ phases are shown in Fig.1. Similar to another HCP/BCC metal $Z \mathrm { r } ^ { 6 }$ ，the crystallographic orientation relationship between HCP Ti (α) and BCC Ti (β) obeys the Burgers_orientation relationship for which $\{ 0 0 0 1 \} _ { \alpha } / / \{ 1 1 0 \} _ { \beta }$ and $\mathrm { < 1 1 \overline { { 2 } } O > _ { d } / / \mathrm { < 1 1 1 > _ { \beta } } ^ { 1 } }$

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-3
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
In Al-containing Ti alloys,the precipitation of ordered and coherent $\mathrm { T i } _ { 3 } \mathrm { A l }$ $\left( \mathfrak { a } _ { 2 } \right)$ phase can occur in $\mathfrak { a }$ grains after ageing at low temperatures of approximately $5 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ when the Al content is at $6 ~ \mathrm { \ w t . } \% ^ { 7 - 9 }$ .Specifically, ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { 2 }$ has a hexagonal $\mathrm { D 0 } _ { 1 9 }$ superlattice structure',in which the lattice parameter on the basal plane is twice that of $\mathfrak { a }$ phase, whereas the lattice parameter remains the same on the $c \mathrm { . }$ axis. The ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { 2 }$ solvus temperature is approximately $5 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for Ti-6Al-4V1. Similar to the influence on $\beta$ transus, Al and $\mathrm { o }$ are ${ \bf { \delta } } \ a _ { 2 }$ stabilizers,which extend $\mathfrak { a } ^ { + } \mathfrak { a } _ { 2 }$ phase field to highertemperaturesandpromotetheordering transformation. Ordered ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { 2 }$ phase introduces precipitation hardening,and it is an extremely brittle intermetallic phasel². The presence of ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { 2 }$ results in non-homogeneous planar slip,and increases the effective slip length and strain localization10,11, whichhasdetrimentaleffectson microcrackpropagation， lowcyclefatigue(LCF) resistance,and stress corrosion cracking resistance' 1,12

![](images/d23bf7eb01a6e255cee4c973fc14b2a08d6803248a181ba6088c929ef125af7a.jpg)  
Fig.1 Crystal structures of HCP $\mathbf { a }$ and BCC $\beta$ phases in titanium'.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-4
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: Rapid cooling from temperatures above the martensitic starttemperature $\left( \mathrm { M } _ { \mathrm { s } } \right)$ leadstodiffusionless transformation. The martensite start temperature $( \mathrm { M } _ { \mathrm { s } } )$ in Ti-6Al-4V has been reported in a wide temperature range from $5 7 5 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ to $8 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } ^ { 1 3 - 1 5 }$ and a lower $\mathbf { M } _ { \mathrm { s } }$ has been observed at a higher cooling rate15. Similar to $\beta$ transus and ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { 2 }$ solvus temperatures, the martensitic start temperature is affected by the alloying elements. In general, the metastable martensite is hexagonal $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ in Ti-6Al-4V,and the Burgers orientation relationship is still valid between $\beta$ and $\mathbf { q } ^ { , 1 }$ . Given that the interstitial O atoms only introduce a small elastic distortion in $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite,the martensitic hardeningleadstoa slight increase instrength. Orthorhombic $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite is rarely observed in the low V containing Ti-6Al-4V. The martensite type can be determined by the temperatures from which Ti-6Al-4V is quenched and the concentration of $\beta$ stabilizers in the $\beta$ phase at that temperature?.In the $\alpha { + } \beta$ phase field, the V concentration in $\beta$ is dependent on the temperature.The formation of $\vec { \mathrm { \bf ~ a } } ^ { \prime \mathrm { \Delta } }$ is observed under conditions with a $\mathrm { v }$ concentration exceeding $9 \ \mathrm { { w t . } } \% ^ { 1 , 3 }$ .For example,the $\beta$ phase is enriched with $\mathrm { v }$ concentration of up to $1 0 \mathrm { \ w t . } \%$ at a temperature range of $8 0 0 { - } 8 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ ，and water quenching (WQ) from this temperature range leads to $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite transformation16.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-5
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
In contrast to the hardening effect of HCP $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite,the orthorhombic $\alpha ^ { \ast \ast }$ martensite is soft and can provide deformability²,3 Both metastable $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ and $\vec { \mathrm { \bf ~ a } } ^ { \prime \mathrm { \Delta } }$ martensite phases can decompose into equilibrium $\mathfrak { a }$ and $\beta$ phases at suitable heat treatment temperatures.

The high cost of conventionally processed Ti alloys limits their applications,and crucial contributors to the expense are the significant material wastage, high energy input,and long lead times in conventional processing techniques17. Laser powder bed fusion (LPBF)，asan advanced additive manufacturing (AM) technology,has attracted significant attention and has been implemented in research and industry over the last two decades.It has a wide range of advantages such as producing nearly fully dense and complex shaped components at a high resolution (which cannot be realized via conventional methods), high material utilization with limited machining,and reduced lead times18,19.

Specifically，LPBF is a complicated metallurgical process, which involves powder melting and extremely fast directional solidification,re-melting and re-solidification during the subsequent scan tracks and layers,and postsolidification thermal cycling. The understandingof microstructure evolution during the LPBF process and post-process treatment is essential to obtain Ti-6Al-4V components with high quality and satisfied properties. In thisreview，the LPBF technique and its processing parameters are briefly introduced. Then, the possible types of defects,residual stress,and LPBF built surface are reviewed.Subsequently，theuniqueas-fabricated microstructure and microstructure evolution during the post-process treatment are summarized,and its effects on tensile, fatigue, fracture toughness,and creep properties are discussed.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-6
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: LPBF,also known as selective laser melting (SLM) or direct metal laser melting (DMLM), was developed in the Fraunhofer Institute ILT in $1 9 9 5 ^ { 2 0 }$ It employs a focused laser beam to melt metallic powders within a selected area based on the cross-sectional slice of a 3-dimensional (3D) CAD model, and the melt pool is then solidified at a high cooling rate.After a layer has been scanned,the build platform is lowered by a depth,which is defined as the layer thickness.A new layer of powder is spread by the recoater and melted by the focused laser beam based on the next cross-sectional slice. The layer-by-layer deposition is repeated in a protective atmosphere until all the slices of the CAD profiles are complete.Fig.2 illustrates a typical LPBF system，which includes a processing laser，an automatic powder feed and overflow system,and an inert gasprotection system212. Afterfabrication, unused powders can be collected from the overflow and powder bed.These collected powders can then be recycled and reused23,24.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-7
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: The main in-process parameters include laser power, laser spot size，scanning speed，hatch distance,layer thickness，and build platform pre-heating temperature. Among them, the most widely manipulated parameters are laser power and scan speed. Fig. 3a presents a processing window between these two parameters.A high laser powder and a low scan speed can introduce an excessive energy input, which can lead to liquid melt overheating, evaporation within the melt pool, and keyhole defects²5. Conversely,a low laser power and a high scan speed can lead to insufficientenergydensity， which causes incomplete melting, inadequate penetration and lack-offusiondefects6Inadditiontolaserpowerandscan speed, inappropriate hatch distance and layer thickness can also result in lack-of-fusion defects. Furthermore, balling can occur at high laser power and scan speeds even for a suitable energy density as shown in the top right corner of Fig. $3 \mathrm { a } ^ { 2 8 , 2 9 }$ . Given that the increased laser power leads to a higher boosting effect on the maximum temperature achieved in the melt pool than the reverse effect from the increased scan speed3031，a higher peak melt pool temperature induces a more intense Marangoni flow, which can cause the Plateau-Rayleigh instability and balling0,32.36. An example of different types of defects in LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al-4V is illustrated in Fig. $3 \mathrm { b - d }$ Foran intermediate laser power of $1 7 5 \mathrm { ~ W ~ }$ ，gradually decreasing scan speeds are located in the three different regions of incomplete melting， processing window,and overheating as shown in Fig.3a. Additionally,another type of defect is gas porosity，which is typically small in size3.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-8
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
# In-situ thermal cycling
LPBF exhibits a unique thermal history including directional melting-solidifying against the heat transfer direction, subsequent re-melting/re-solidifying due to the following laser scan and deposited layer，and postsolidificationcyclicheating/cooling37-39 Fig.4isa simulated thermal history of a given location in a LPBF fabricated $\mathrm { T i { - } 6 A l { - } 4 V ^ { 4 0 } }$ ，and there are thermal cycles from different laser scan vectors within a layer and thermal cycles in the following layers.After solidification from the peak temperature in layer P1,the material undergoes a series of thermal cycles in the following laser scan tracks and layers. When the next track is scanned or the next layer is deposited, the previously fabricated material can be partially re-melted and re-solidified.The combined effect of high laser power,fast laser scan speed,and small laser spot size leads to an extremely high heating and cooling rate41-44. According to an in-situ synchrotron experiment on LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al-4V,the maximum heating and cooling rates can reach the orders of $1 0 ^ { 6 } ~ { } ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C / s }$ and $1 0 ^ { 5 } ~ { } ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } / \mathrm { s } .$ respectively45

![](images/89bc2c9d0b008a0a0a40c67f6c62dc5c09635ec64f62934ef88dac3e002a048b.jpg)  
Fig. 2 Schematic diagram of a typical LPBF system2.

![](images/51dcfb6b4dbf7f945ef9b4f74c7c9ae20226a322b310db23e38664e24e907123.jpg)  
Fig.3AprocesswindoandvroutypesofdefectsinBFfabricatedT-6-4V.AprocesingwindwforBfatedT64b The influence of scan speed on porosity types in LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al-4V with a fixed laser power of $1 7 5 \mathrm { ~ W ~ }$ and a hatch distance of $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m } ^ { 3 6 }$ b Lack-of-fusion due tostos at a low scan speed.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-9
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
During LPBF fabrication, the high cooling rate and large thermal gradients lead to high levels of residual stress46. This can cause distortion and delamination,which results in parts failure and unacceptable dimensional change4 e47,48 In general, residual stress varies with the build height.Fig.5 shows the residual stress distribution in Ti-6Al-4V cuboids fabricated on large and small substrates measured by the contour method. Specifically,the tensile residual stress presents at the bottom of the substrate and top surface of the built sample with a large compressive stress region located in between according to simulations49 and experimental contour method. In the horizontal crosssection，high tensile residual stress/strain is generally located at the part edge,while compressive residual stress is at the part center51.More specifically, the tensile residual stress can exceed $9 0 0 \mathrm { M P a }$ at the part edge,which is close to the yield strength of Ti-6Al-4V.

Tensile residual stressisdeleterioustofatigue properties，because it tends to facilitate fatigue crack propagation³.In addition to the influence on fatigue, the parts removal from substrate without stress-relieving heat treatmentwouldintroducedeformationthrough strain/stress relaxation46.49．Therefore，efforts have been made to reduce the residual stress, including substrate heating during the LPBF process and post-process stressrelieving heat treatment. Furthermore, residual stress can be influenced by the in-process laser scan strategy and scan rotation between neighboring layers.A lower residuals stress was observed in the bi-directional scan than that resulting from a chessboard scan.Additionally，a scan rotation of $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ led to a reduced residual stress when compared with that in a scan rotation of 67052.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-11
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
The surface roughness can be controlled by the powder particle morphology and size,layer thickness,processing parameters,scan strategies,and the orientation relationship betweentheinclinedsurfaceandlaserincident direction35.Inadition，the frequentlyused support structures adversely affect the surface finish of LPBF fabricated parts even after support removal9

The surface of LPBF fabricated parts is covered by partially melted powder particles57.Hence， the powder characteristics affect the surface roughness.Given that LPBF is a layer-wise manufacturing process, a larger layer thickness leads to a rougher inclined surface owing to the staircaseeffects45Moreimportantlylaserprocessing parameters can influence the melt pool morphology0, which in turn affects the surface quality.A few studies employed contour scans to improve the quality of the asfabricated surface56,58. Other factors, including the location of the part on the substrate,the orientation relationship between the inclined surface and the laser incident direction,have also been found to influence the surface roughness56.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-12
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: Surface treatments after LPBF fabrication are generally applied to improve surface quality. The most commonly used treatments include blasting7,shot peening@, vibratory particles on the surface of LPBF fabricated parts can be addressed by blasting and shot peening;however， the blasting and/or peening media can introduce deformations on the surface57； hence, they can only slightly reduce the surface roughness.In addition, shot peening results in work hardening and compressive residual stress in the surface layer,which prevent the fatigue crack initiation from the surface61. Vibratory grinding leads to a smoother surface, and it provides a better surface finish $\mathrm { ( R _ { a } ) }$ of a few $\mu \mathrm { m }$ when compared with blasting and shot peening. Machining and electropolishing are effective methods to remove the surface layer, which contributes to the lowest surface finish $\mathrm { ( R _ { a } ) }$ below $1 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } ^ { 5 7 , 6 0 }$

fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
The directional solidification, rapid cooling after melting,and subsequent thermal cycling result in a nonequilibrium hierarchical as-fabricated microstructure of epitaxial grown prior- $\cdot \beta$ grains aligned in the opposite direction of the cooling direction,and these columnar $\beta$ grains consist of a few sets of fine acicular $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite variants67heproceinpramesfee fabricated microstructure.A recent study showed that a higher laser energy density leads to a larger prior $\beta$ grain width and a smaller $\overrightarrow { \mathbfit { a } } ^ { \prime }$ martensite size.In addition to the columnar grains,the partial re-melting of the previously solidified layers leads to a strong $\beta$ solidification texture. As shown in Fig.6,a preferred $\{ 1 0 0 \} _ { \mathfrak { \beta } }$ texture along the grain growth direction has been found on the BCC orientation map reconstructed from electron back-scatter diffraction (EBSD) data of HCP Ti ( $\mathbf { \bar { a } }$ and/or $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ )based on the Burgersorientationrelationship6263It isimportant to note that the $\beta$ grain growth direction can be influenced by the thermal flux direction,which is affected by the laser scan speed and strategy38,62. As a result， the growth direction of $\beta$ grain can be either parallel or inclined at a certain angle to the macroscopic build direction $\left( Z \right) ^ { 3 1 , 6 2 }$ .The pole figure in Fig.6c is an example where the $\{ 1 0 0 \} _ { \beta }$ texture in thegraingrowth direction isinclined approximately $2 0 ^ { \circ }$ away from the build direction6.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-15
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: A few studies have shown that a small amount of $\beta$ can be detected by synchrotron $\mathrm { X R D } ^ { 6 9 }$ ， $\mathrm { E B S D } ^ { 7 0 }$ ,and $\mathrm { T E M } ^ { \mathrm { 7 1 } }$ in specimens fabricated at either high laser powers or short hatch distances. Fig. 7a shows an $\alpha { + } \beta$ microstructure at the middle height of a sample manufactured with a short hatch distance'.Both high laser power and short hatch distance can increase the in-process temperatures achieved and the time at high temperatures during the intrinsic thermal cycling45. These factors facilitate the depositionof metastable martensite into $\alpha { + } \beta$ phases.In addition to $\beta ,$ a few studies have reported ${ \bf { \delta } } \ a _ { 2 }$ precipitates in the asfabricated sample based on TEM and synchrotron XRD results3871 Fig.7b shows the superlattice reflection of ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { 2 }$ formed in $\mathfrak { a }$ lamella,and the formation of ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { 2 }$ is believed to be related to the thermal cycling at temperatures just below the ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { 2 }$ solvus. Carefully controlled Al and O compositions in the Ti-6Al-4V powders and the low O concentration in the printing atmosphere can suppress the ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { 2 }$ precipitation.
summary: As-fabricated microstructure Typical LPBF microstructure - Part 2/6

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-16
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: In general, the as-fabricated Ti-6Al-4V has a fully $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensitic microstructure.As a result of thermal cycles, $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite has a hierarchical structure with different width and length,which can be identified as primary,secondary, tertiary and quartic $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ ,and their formation mechanism has been described in detail in a recent study².Within the $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite,latice defects,including dislocations, stacking faults and twins，are present7374.A high density of dislocations has been identified in $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ plate via $\mathrm { T E M } ^ { 6 9 }$ and diffraction peak broadening phenomenon in high energy $\mathrm { X R D } ^ { 7 0 }$ The TEM dislocation analysis $( g \cdot b$ test） revealed the presence of both $< a >$ and $< c + a >$ dislocations within martensite， whichindicatesthatsignificantplastic deformation occurs during the LPBF process69

fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: In principle, $\{ 1 0 \overline { { { 1 } } } 1 \} \triangleleft { { 1 0 } } \overline { { { 1 2 } } } >$ and $\{ 1 1 \overline { { { 2 } } } 2 \} \mathrm { < l } 1 \overline { { { 2 3 } } } >$ twins can be activated when compression is applied along the $c$ axis，while $\{ 1 0 \overline { { { 1 } } } 2 \} \mathrm { < } 1 0 \overline { { { 1 1 } } } >$ and $\{ 1 1 { \overline { { 2 } } } 1 \} { < } 1 1 { \overline { { 2 } } } 6 { > }$ twins can occur when tension is applied along the $c$ -axis for HCP titanium75.In LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al-4V，compression $\{ 1 0 \overline { { 1 } } 1 \} ^ { 7 6 , 7 7 }$ and $\{ 1 1 \overline { { 2 } } 2 \}$ twins， and tension $\{ 1 0 \overline { { 1 } } 2 \} ^ { 6 9 , 7 2 , 7 8 , 7 9 }$ twins have been reported in hexagonal $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite as shown in Fig.8.A previous work has suggested that tension $\{ 1 0 \overline { { 1 } } 2 \}$ twins can accommodate the tensile residual stress at the top region of LPBF fabricated parts7,but this does not explain the co-existing compression and tension twins in the same TEM sample. Some studies have shown that twinning is related to the martensitic transformation of $\beta \to \mathbf { a } ^ { 7 6 , 8 0 }$ .However, this can only explain the activation of $\left\{ 1 0 \overline { { 1 } } 1 \right\}$ twins. A recent study has proposed that thermal cycles of fast heating to and rapid cooling from different peak temperatures and associated solid state phase transformation can lead tothe formation of both compression and tension twins in LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al$4 \mathrm { { V } ^ { 8 1 } }$

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-19
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
In addition to hexagonal $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite,orthorhombic martensite $\vec { \mathrm { \bf ~ a } } ^ { \prime \mathrm { \Delta } }$ has been reported in as-fabricated Ti-6Al-4V in a few studies6778 For samples fbricated at the same LPBF parameters, $\vec { \mathrm { \bf ~ a } } ^ { \prime \mathrm { \Delta } }$ was observed in one of the Ti-6Al4V cuboids with a larger horizontal (X-Y） cross section area. The results suggested that faster cooling related to the larger heat conduction area on the horizontal cross section could lead to $\vec { \mathrm { \bf ~ a } } ^ { \prime \mathrm { \Delta } }$ formation.However, the discussion is missing regarding the influence of horizontal crosssectional area on the temperature achieved during the postsolidification thermal cycling.During LPBF， thermal cycling can heat some previously deposited layers to intermediate temperatures in the $\alpha { + } \beta$ phase field. At these temperatures, element segregation occurs and $\beta$ phase is enriched in V.Thus,rapid cooling from such temperatures would result in the formation of $\vec { \mathrm { \bf ~ a } } ^ { \prime \mathrm { \Delta } }$ martensite78.

When compared to thermo-mechanically processed Ti6Al-4V，as-fabricated LPBF Ti-6Al-4V exhibits higher strength but lower ductility due to the non-equilibrium $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensitic microstructure64,65,72,82 and residual stress built up during the LPBF process83,84.As a result， in-process measures and post-process treatments have been explored to promote the metastable martensite decomposition to equilibrium $\alpha { + } \beta$ phases and to minimize residual stress.
summary: As-fabricated microstructure Typical LPBF microstructure - Part 6/6

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-20
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
During the LPBF process，a preheated substrate generally reduces the temperature gradients within the parts and decreases residual stress&5.Substrates preheated to $3 7 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ and $5 7 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ can effectively reduce the residue stress by $71 \%$ and almost $100 \%$ ,respectively, when compared to the sample built on a substrate heated to $1 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } ^ { 8 6 }$ For

LPBF fabricated $\overrightarrow { \mathbfit { a } } ^ { \prime }$ martensite,TEM and in-situ XRD investigations revealed that martensite decomposition commences at a low temperature at $4 0 0 \ { } ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } ^ { 8 7 }$ $\beta$ phase has been observed in the as-deposited Ti-6Al-4V fabricated on a preheated substrate at $2 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ and with a tight hatch distance of $4 0 \ \mu \mathrm { m } ^ { 7 1 }$ . A substrate preheated at $5 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ results in a partially decomposed $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite microstructure6, which improveselongation toapproximately $1 0 \% ^ { 8 6 }$ 、： However，high temperature preheating is not energy efficient, and can account for $40 \%$ of the total energy consumed in LPBF fabrication8.In addition, in a recent study,it was indicated that a preheated substrate at $5 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ leads to significant oxidation, because titanium suffers a high chemical affinity to oxygen at high temperatures. High oxygen content contributestwo consequences, namely increased brittleness and deteriorated powder recyclability 90,91
summary: Preheated substrate and in-process heat treatment - Part 1/2

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-21
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: Other in-process measures, including manipulation of laser beam focal offset distance (FOD) and interlayer time, were used to increase the temperature achieved during the intrinsic thermal cycling and to promote the $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensitic decomposition. Specifically， FOD can control the laser spot diameter and the local applied energy within the laser beam93 ， and an increased FOD generally leads to a decreased temperature and a shortened time window for insitu martensite decomposition during the intrinsic thermal cycling94.Given that LPBF is a layer-by-layer deposition process,a short interlayer time of less than 12 s have been found to be effective in promoting the in-process martensite decomposition，which leads to a coarser $\alpha { + } \beta$ lamellar microstructure95,%6. With a suitable FOD of $2 \mathrm { m m }$ an ultrafine fine $\alpha { + } \beta$ lamellar microstructure has been achieved in the as-deposited Ti-6Al-4V fabricated on support structures with a substrate preheated at $2 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } ^ { 6 4 }$ .In addition to the FOD manipulation,all the aforementioned investigationsincluded latticesupport structuresto decrease the amount of heat transferred to the substrate, thereby increasing the in-situ thermal cycling temperature. Support structuresare known to introduce surface roughness even after support removal，which affect the as-built surface quality and its application in the as-built condition.
summary: Preheated substrate and in-process heat treatment - Part 2/2

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-22
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
# Post-process treatment Stress-relieving
In general, stress-relieving treatments are carried out in the temperatures between $4 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ and $6 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ followed by air cool (AC) or furnace cool (FC) prior to the electrical discharge machining $\left( \mathrm { E D M } \right) ^ { 3 , 9 7 }$ .For instance,a $^ { 2 - 4 \ \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ stress-relieving treatment at $5 9 5 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ followed by AC is recommended for Ti-6Al-4V weldment. Such a heat treatment is generally performed in a protective argon atmosphere,which reduces oxidation and the formation of $\mathfrak { a }$ case.As shown in Fig.9, the time required for stress relief is dependent on temperature.A higher stressrelieving temperature decreases the required heat treatment time.For example,1h at $5 9 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ is equivalent to $^ { 5 \mathrm { h } }$ at $5 4 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ in terms of stress relief effectiveness．As the stressrelieving temperature is relatively low in the $\alpha { + } \beta$ field, the as-deposited microstructure will be slightly coarsened although the size and variants of primary and secondary ${ \mathfrak { a } } / { \mathfrak { a } } ^ { * }$ laths are maintained8.

It should be noted that the ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { 2 }$ solvus temperature is approximately $5 5 0 \mathrm { ~ ~ } ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for Ti-6Al $4 \mathrm { { V } ^ { 1 } }$ ，and it can be influenced by the Al and O content.A stress-relieving temperature below the ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { 2 }$ solvus can lead to the precipitation hardening of $\mathfrak { a }$ phase by ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { 2 }$ particles7³,which is dependent on the Al and O concentration in the $\mathfrak { a }$ phase. If the LPBF fabricated parts are used after stress relief, the stress-relievingtemperatureshouldbecautiously determined by whether ${ \bf { \delta } } \ a _ { 2 }$ formation is ideal for the application.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-23
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
# Annealing
It is widely accepted that the $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite formed in LPBF is brittle and responsible for the low elongation below $10 \%$ in the as-fabricated $\mathrm { T i } – 6 \mathrm { A l } – 4 \mathrm { V } ^ { 3 1 , 6 4 , 7 0 , 7 8 , 8 3 , 8 4 , 9 6 }$ . Such a low ductility does not satisfy the elongation requirement of $10 \%$ as per the specification of AM fabricated Ti-6Al4V in ASTM $2 9 2 4 - 1 4 ^ { 4 }$ .Therefore,investigations have been focused on promoting the non-equilibrium $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensitedecompositionintheas-fabricated microstructure to an equilibrium $\alpha { + } \beta$ microstructure through annealing. Previous studies have revealed that annealing in the range of $7 5 0 { - } 9 0 0 \ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ can effectively facilitate the $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite decomposition and improve the ductility7 ,76,99,100

![](images/639be23ede370dd526ed2ec4e28e632142bffea25a8b825ee9da1d1d158b1bf7.jpg)  
Fig.9Effect of stress-relieving temperatures on residual stress in Ti-6Al-4V.

Whencomparedwiththestress-relievingheat treatments,annealing is generally performed at relatively higher temperatures in the $\alpha { + } \beta$ phase field and followed by AC or $\mathrm { F C } ^ { 9 7 }$ . A direct annealing can promote martensite decomposition into $\mathfrak { a }$ and $\beta$ phases,and the lamellar microstructure will be significantly coarser than the asfabricated microstructure.A recent study has explicitly investigated the static coarsening behavior of lamellar structures in LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al-4V,which suggests that heat treatment temperatures at $9 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ orhigher significantly accelerate the coarsening kinetics101.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-24
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: Inthermomechanicallyprocessed titanium alloys, solution treating and aging (STA) treatments are generally used to improve strength. Such a heat treatment has also been employed as a post-process treatment for LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al-4V, which can be categorized into $\beta$ STA and $\alpha { + } \beta$ STA based on the solution temperature.As shown in Fig.10,the $\beta$ STA microstructure has significantly coarsened prior- $\boldsymbol { \cdot } \boldsymbol { \beta }$ grains when heat treated at temperatures above the $\beta$ transus,and $\beta$ grains lose the columnar morphology on vertical plane84,02. Because all the ${ \vec { \alpha } } ^ { \prime } { \vec { \alpha } }$ lamellae transform to $\beta$ phase solid solution at such temperatures, and $\beta$ grains begin to grow84. For example, a $\beta$ solution treatment at $1 0 1 5 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $^ { 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ led to an increase in $\beta$ grain width with unchanged length&4，and a heat treatment of $^ { 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ at $1 ~ 0 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ resulted in equiaxed prior $\beta$ grains in LPBF fabricated $\mathrm { T i } – 6 \mathbf { A l } – 4 \mathbf { V } ^ { 1 0 2 }$ . The width of $\mathfrak { a }$ lamellae is related to the cooling rate after $\beta$ solution treatment.After the $\beta$ STA, there are fewer $\mathfrak { a }$ variants left. This results in increased $\mathfrak { a }$ colony size,which leads to a longer effective slip length for dislocations.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-25
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: When compared to $\beta$ STA, $\alpha { + } \beta$ STA is versatile in terms of achieving different microstructures, in which the size, volume fraction,and morphology of various phases can be manipulated. A $2 \textrm { h } \alpha + \beta$ solution treatment followed by a slow cooling method, such as FC, generally leads to an $\alpha { + } \beta$ lamellar microstructure,and a small amount of equiaxed $\mathfrak { a }$ can form at solution temperatures close to $\beta$ transus1 s102.103. If fast cooling methods such as AC or WQ are used, some $\beta$ phases can transform to fine ${ \bf { \delta q } } _ { \mathrm { { s } } }$ (secondary $\alpha$ )or martensitic microstructure during cooling. Severalstudieshave indicated that a bi-modal microstructure can be obtained in LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al-4V through post-process $\alpha { + } \beta$ STA treatments102,04.105，InadditiontoLPBF，thebi-modal microstructure has been reported in similar post-process sub-transus STA treated Ti-6Al-4V fabricated by other AM techniques including electron beam melting $\left( \mathrm { E B M } \right) ^ { 1 0 6 }$ direct laser deposition $\mathrm { \left( D L D \right) ^ { 1 0 7 } }$ ，and wire arc additive manufacturing (WAAM) 108

content: As show in Fig.1la, the microstructure is still mainly $\alpha { + } \beta$ lamellae for low to intermediate solution temperatures of up to $9 2 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $^ { 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ followed by AC.This is due to the low equilibrium volume fraction of $\beta$ phase when the solution temperature is exceedingly below the $\beta$ transus, and the relatively slow AC used after solution treatment. Fig.l1b-d show that increases in solution temperatures lead to an increased $\beta _ { \mathrm { t } }$ (transformed $\beta$ ）region,in which fine ${ \bf { \delta q } } _ { \mathrm { { s } } }$ precipitates are formed. In the meantime, the volume fraction of ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { \mathfrak { p } }$ (primary α) decreases,and the aspect ratio of ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { \mathfrak { p } }$ decreases with the formation of some equiaxed ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { \mathfrak { p } }$ grains.Fig.11 also presents the influence of solution time,and a longer solution time results in a reduced number density of ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { \mathfrak { p } } ,$ a larger sized ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { \mathfrak { p } }$ and a more globular ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { \mathfrak { p } }$ morphology.

fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
In general, plastic deformation prior to heat treatment is essential for inducing globularization in thermomechanically processed Ti-6Al-4V. While in LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al4V,plastic deformationisnot requiredforthe globularization to occur. Because the high dislocation density inherited from the LPBF process can initiate the globularization. The globularization mechanism is similar for LPBF fabricated and thermomechanically processed Ti6Al-4V. Tangled dislocationsin $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensitecan rearrange into dislocation arrays and form sub-grain boundaries during the $\alpha { + } \beta$ solution treatment107. In the initial stage of globularization, dislocation arrays and subgrain boundaries are the feasible locations for the boundary splitting process, which includes the growth of $\beta$ phase into the sub-grain boundary (thermal grooving） and edge spheroidization at lamellae ends1.For a prolonged solution treatment, the globularization is driven by the second mechanism related to the $\mathfrak { a }$ lamellae coarsening by termination migration consisting of mass transfer from curved surface to flat surfaces.This results in shorter and thicker ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { \mathfrak { p } }$ lamellae,which gradually change the lamellar morphology to a more equiaxed morphology109

content: The globularization mechanism during cyclic heat treatment differs from that mentioned in the $\alpha { + } \beta$ STA.The cyclic heat treatment leads to variations in the volume fraction of $\mathfrak { a }$ and $\beta$ ，which promote $\mathfrak { a }$ lamellae to $\beta$ transformation in the heating cycle and facilitates $\beta$ to a more equiaxed $\mathfrak { a }$ transformation during the slow cooling cycle.

content:
Typically，LPBF fabricated metals and alloysoften contain defects such as gas pores, contour related pores, lack-of-fusion，keyholepores,andpartiallymelted powdersThesedefectsaredetrimentaltotheatiue properties and can affect the quality control of the LPBF process.As shown in Fig.l2, hot isostatic pressing (HIP) is an effective post-process method for tackling defects, including lack-of-fusion，keyhole,and gas pores,but it does not address pores connected to the surface as indicated by a few defects retained after HIP in Fig.12a. Similar evidence of pore closure in HIP have been reported in other studies1i2.13In addition,HIP can consolidate partially melted or unmelted powders11.A few studies have revealed that post-HIP annealing, including both subtransus and super-transus heat treatments,re-opens the HIP ‘closed’pores1,4,115.This indicates that these defects, containing Ar gas,are not eliminated by HIP and instead converted into small high-pressured pores,which are below the resolution of X-ray tomography.

The microstructure evolution during HIP is similar to that of heat-treated conditions.According to the ASTM standard for powder bed fusion fabricated $\mathrm { T i { - } 6 A l { - } 4 V ^ { 4 } }$ the recommended HIP scheme corresponds to $1 0 0 \ \mathrm { M P a }$ at 895 to $9 5 5 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for 3 to $^ { 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ .Several studies have performed HIP at 900-950 C/100-150 MPa/2-4 h31,2,113,116， ，the resultant microstructureismainlycoarse $\alpha { + } \beta$ lamellar microstructure containing a few equiaxed $\mathfrak { a }$ grains.For super-transus HIP, the prior- $\boldsymbol { \cdot } \boldsymbol { \beta }$ grain will grow and the lath thickness in the lamellar microstructure will be controlled by the cooling rate in the HIP cycle.

fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
The most influential microstructural parameter that affects mechanical properties ofLPBF fabricated lamellar structures is the $\alpha / \alpha ^ { \ast }$ width $^ { 3 5 , 6 4 , 7 6 , 9 6 , 1 1 7 }$ Under extremely fast cooled condition, the effective slip length for dislocation is limited to the individual martensite width rather than the $\mathfrak { a }$ colony size in thermomechanically processed Ti-6Al- $4 \mathrm { V } ^ { 1 }$ ： The relationship between the strength and $\alpha / \alpha ^ { \ast }$ width can be described by Hall-Petch relation as shown in Fig.13a, in which a linear relationship can be established between the yield strength and the inverse square root of $\alpha / \alpha ^ { \ast }$ width. Such a relationship is still valid after post-process annealing and HIP treatments in $\alpha { + } \beta$ phase field according to Fig.l3a. In general, the ductility exhibits an inverse relationship with the yield strength as shown in Fig.13b.

The as-fabricated LPBF Ti-6Al-4V has a fine $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensitic microstructurel18, which results in a high strength but low ductility as shown in Fig. 13b and Table 1. Post-process heat treatments and HIP can promote the martensite decomposition to $\alpha { + } \beta$ lamellae,which reduce the strength and increase the ductility.A recent study found that heat treated LPBF Ti-6Al-4V with an equilibrium microstructure possesses a superior ductility (elongation at fracture (El.) $1 > 1 8 \%$ ） similar to that of wrought Ti-6Al$4 \mathrm { V } ^ { 7 6 }$ .Details on the martensite decomposition in postprocess treatments have been summarized in the previous section of annealing. With respect to the lamellar microstructure,the overall trend is a higher heat/HIP treatment temperature (below the $\beta$ transus) and/or a longer heat/HIP treatment time lead to a lower strength but a higher ductility as shown in Table 1.

content: A further information that can be extracted from Fig.13 is the scattered tensile property in LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al4V，which can be attributed to the various specimen orientations,compositions,porositylevels,and microstructuresresultingfromdifferentpowder characteristics (size and composition)，LPBF systems, exposure parameters/strategies,and post-LPBF treatments.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-40
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: Despite the efforts on transforming a non-equilibrium $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensitic microstructure into the an equilibrium $\alpha { + } \beta$ lamellar microstructure, a few studies have reported similar ductility in a fully martensitic microstructure when compared to that in an $\alpha { + } \beta$ microstructure80,16-128。Inhot deformed Ti-6Al-4V,a rapid heating $\mathrm { ( > 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } C / s ) }$ to the $\beta$ phase field followed by water quenching lead to the formation of fine prior $\cdot \beta$ grains $( { \sim } 8 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ containing only $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite, which simultaneously improves strength and ductilityl26. The increase in strength is attributed to the refinement in both martensite width and prior- $\cdot \beta$ grain size, and the enhanced ductility is related to the reduced strain localization due to the shortened martensite,which is limited bythe prior $\beta$ grain size126 Twosimilar observations have been reported in LPBF fabricated Ti6Al-4V,inwhichafullymartensiticlamellar microstructure with a fine prior- $\boldsymbol { \cdot } \boldsymbol { \beta }$ grain width between 50- $1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ results in high strength and ductility127,128.For such an approach to achieve good tensile properties,the key is to have a small prior $\beta$ grain sizel26. It is known that the prior- $\beta$ grain width is related to the hatch distance in laser continuous scan strategy and the point distance in pulsed laser strategy. A small hatch distance can provide a narrow prior- $\beta$ width, but it sacrifices the productivity. In addition, cautiously controlled laser processing parametersare required to avoid the $\beta$ formation during the in-process thermal cycling, because the low volume of thin $\beta$ film causes stress concentration, which decreases ductility228.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-41
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
The mechanical properties of LPBF fabricated materials have been reported as anisotropic due to the columnar prior- $\beta$ grains inclined close to the build direction113,129,130 and the manufacturing defects631.In the former case, horizontally built samples generally have a higher strength but a lower ductility than those of vertically built samples, because the width of columnar $\beta$ grains is aligned in the tensile direction of horizontal samples' s13,129,130.Theaio is changed when lack-of-fusion defects present between deposited layers and scan vectors.Vilaro et al.have reported higher elongation in horizontally built samples than that in vertically built samples in as-fabricated and post-process heat treated LPBF Ti-6Al- $\cdot 4 \mathrm { V } ^ { 1 6 }$ .The reason is that tension in the vertical direction tends to open the lackof-fusion defects and results in a low ductility.Recently, a plasticity model has been developed to predict the stress state dependent anisotropic plasticity behavior of LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al- $4 \mathrm { V } ^ { 1 3 1 }$

A recent study has revealed that $\beta$ solution treatment can effectively mitigate the anisotropy in mechanical property due to the fact that $\beta$ grains lost the columnar morphology after such a treatmentl³².However，the strength and ductility significantly decrease after $\beta$ solution treatment, because excessive $\beta$ grain growth occurs at temperature above the $\beta$ transus84,132.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-42
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: For LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al-4V, the fatigue performance is influenced by the surface finish, manufacturing defects, residual stress and microstructurel33,134. The surface quality has been found to be the most crucial factor. Fig.14b shows a rough as-built surface covered by partially melted powders.Withoutsurfacetreatments, thefatigue performance of as-fabricated LPBF specimen is worse than that of the traditional cast productsAftersurface treatment, the fatigue strength is significantly increased in LPBF Ti-6Al-4Vwith57.8.603 and without post-process HIP treatments8.Fig.14a shows that various surface treatments can improve the fatigue performance,and a reduced surface roughness of $\mathrm { R _ { a } } = 0 . 3 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ (Fig. 14c), achieved by milling,improves the tension-tension( $( R = 0 . 1 )$ ）high cycle fatigue (HCF） strength to $7 7 5 \mathrm { \ : \ : M P a } ^ { 5 7 }$ ，which is superior than that of wrought Ti-6Al-4V at $4 5 0 – 6 5 0 ~ \mathrm { ~ M P a ^ { 1 3 5 } }$ Similarly, with respect to tension-compression fatigue ( $R =$ $- 1 \bigtriangledown$ ,Fig.14d shows a similar observation that an improved surface quality increases the HCF strength,and a reduced surface roughness $( \mathrm { R _ { a } } < 1 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ provides a HCF strength comparable to that of wrought Ti-6Al-4V. Thisis consistent with the fractographs shown in Fig.14e and f, which indicate that surface related defects are responsible for the inferior fatigue strength in the as-built sample,and fatigue crack initiation site is at the sample interior when the surface defects are removed by machining. The comparable or even higher HCF strength in improved surface conditions is because the LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al4V has a much finer microstructure than wrought and cast Ti-6Al-4V,which means a short effective dislocation slip length and a high resistance to fatigue crack initiation.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-43
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
If the defects are on the surface and/or at the sub-surface which are connected to the surface, then HIP cannot close such the surface related defects and does not improve the fatigue strength of samples with an as-built surface quality as shown in Fig.14d. In contrast, internal defects can be addressed bypost-processHIP， whichhasbeen summarised in the section of hot isostatic pressing.Fig. 14d shows that HIP improves the fatigue performance of machined samples $( \mathrm { R _ { a } } ~ < ~ 1 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ ，which is through eliminating the internal defects.In addition，HIP can effctively narrow down the fatigue data scatter. As described in the section of residual stress, tensile residual stress,which accelerates the fatigue crack propagation and is detrimental to the fatigue properties', presents at the top and side surfaces of the parto. Therefore, surface peening treatments have been used to tackle the tensile residual stress，which result in a compressive stress below the surface and improves the fatigue strength60,136

Fig.14EffectceefsHctsi an axial fatigue stress of $R = 0 . 1 ^ { 5 7 }$ b SEM micrograph of as-built surface $( \mathrm { R _ { a } } = 1 7 . 9 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } ) ^ { 5 7 }$ .c SEM image of milled surface $\left( \mathrm { R _ { a } } = 0 . 3 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } \right) ^ { 5 7 }$ .d Fatigue performance of post-process heat treated or HIP treated LPBF Ti-6Al-4V with an axial fatigue stress of $R = - 1 ^ { 1 , 5 8 }$ eFatigue fractograph of a sample with as-built surface $\left( \mathrm { R _ { a } } > 7 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } \right) ^ { 5 8 }$ fFatigue fractograph of a sample with machined surface $\left( \mathrm { R _ { a } } < 1 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } \right) ^ { 5 8 }$

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-44
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: Fortheinfluenceofmicrostructures,previous investigationsare mainly focused on the lamellar microstructure.In general,a finer microstructure has a higher fatigue strength.A sub-transus HIP treatment at $9 2 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ shows a better fatigue performance than the supertransus HIP treatment at $1 0 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } ^ { 1 1 6 }$ .Similar observations has been reported in the heat treated conditions116. Whereas, the situation is different for fatigue crack growth (FCG). In the hypo-transitional region, FCG is generally influenced by the microstructure.A coarse microstructure has a higher fatigue crack threshold stress intensity factor $( \Delta K _ { t h } )$ and a slowerFCGratel7At the threshold range,acoarser lamellar microstructure displays a stronger ability to deflect cracks along the lath boundaries137,138.Even at a higher $\Delta K ,$ crack deflection can be controlled by the colony/packet size138. On the contrary，the cyclic plastic zone is sufficiently large in the hyper-transitional region,which exceeds the colony size, thus FCG is insensitive to the microstructure138

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-45
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: As described in tensile and fatigue properties,a fine microstructure generally provides high yield and HCF strengths.In contrast,a fine microstructure leads to a low fracture toughness'．For LPBF Ti-6Al-4V，the fracture toughness has been reported at values below $3 0 \ \mathrm { M P a } { \cdot } \mathrm { m } ^ { - 1 / 2 }$ intheas-fabricatedconditionwith $\overrightarrow { \mathbfit { a } } ^ { \prime }$ martensitic microstructurel39.This is lower than that of the wrought Ti6Al-4V with a lamellar microstructure at $4 5 { - } 7 5 \ \mathrm { M P a { \cdot } m ^ { - 1 / 2 } }$ 1,3.This is dueto the extremely fine (sub-micro)and brittle $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ in the as-fabricated condition. It has been found that post-process stress-relieving and annealing can improve the fracture toughness to approximately $5 0 \ \mathrm { \ M P a { \cdot } m ^ { - 1 / 2 } }$ 139,140 which is comparable to that of wrought alloys. In addition, anisotropic fracture toughness has been observed in both as-fabricated and post-processstress-relieved/annealed conditions,which is related to porosity levels and columnar $\beta$ grains aligned along the build direction.A recent study has showed that a two-stage heat treatment of $\alpha { + } \beta$ STA effectivelyimprovesthefracturetoughnessto approximately $1 0 0 \ \mathrm { M P a { \cdot } m ^ { - 1 / 2 } \ ^ { 1 } \Sigma }$ 8. A short solution treatment at $9 2 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ followed by aging results in a coarse $\alpha { + } \beta$ Widmanstätten microstructure, and this microstructure can provide two benefits in terms of improving the fracture toughness. One is the $\alpha { + } \beta$ microstructure is more ductile than the $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensitic microstructure,and the other is a coarser lamellar microstructure means a rougher crack front profile and an increased crack tortuosityl,138
summary: Fracture toughness and creep property - Part 1/2

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-46
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: In the temperature range between $4 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ and $6 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ the as-fabricated Ti-6Al-4V has a comparable creep performance with that of the wrought Ti-6Al- $. 4 \mathrm { V } ^ { 1 4 1 }$ . After post-processheattreatments，aWidmanstatten microstructure showed a relatively lower creep strain and a lower steady-state creep rate than that in the as-fabricated condition.This indicates that the heat treated condition has a higher creep resistancel42. This is due to the fact that the as-fabricatedmartensiticmicrostructurecanbe decomposed at creep testing temperatures,and such a microstructure evolution reduces the creep resistancel42. The ${ \mathfrak { a } } / { \beta }$ interfaces in Widmanstatten microstructure act as obstacles to the dislocation glide during the creep deformation, which also improves the creep resistancel43,144
summary: Fracture toughness and creep property - Part 2/2

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-47
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: In titanium alloys, the corrosion resistance is attributed to the protective surface oxide $\mathrm { f i l m } ^ { 1 }$ . Therefore, the surface quality affects the corrosion performance of LPBF fabricatedTi-6Al-4V， andsurfacetreatmentscan effectively improve the corrosion resistance by surface machining145 and electropolishing146.For the influence of microstructure,metastable $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite is regarded as less corrosion resistant than the $\mathfrak { a }$ phase, and the $\mathrm { V }$ -containing $\beta$ phase is more corrosion resistant than $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite147. Therefore,as-fabricated LPBF Ti-6Al-4V has an inferior corrosion resistance (in $3 . 5 ~ \mathrm { w t . \% ~ N a C l }$ aqueous solution at room temperature） when compared with conventionally processed Ti-6Al-4V with an $\alpha { + } \beta$ lamellar microstructure duetothe non-equilibrium $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensitic microstructure147,148. The passive film thickness has been found to be thinner in laser fabricated Ti-6Al-4V than that in wrought counterpart,which also indicates a faster corosion ratel49In terms of anisotropy，there isa negligible difference in corrosion properties between vertical and horizontal planes in $3 . 5 \ \mathrm { w t } . \%$ NaCl aqueous solution,while anisotropic corrosion behavior has been observed in a harsher environment of $1 \mathrm { ~ M ~ H C l }$ aqueous solution,and the authors have related the anisotropy to different $\beta$ volume fractions on different orientations150

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-48
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: After post-process heat treatments,previous studies showed two distinctly different corrosion phenomena.A recent study has reported that both sub-transus and supertransus heat treatments deteriorated the corrosion resistance in $3 . 5 \ \mathrm { w t } . \%$ NaCl aqueous solution at room temperature due to the increased grain sizel51. While, other studies have suggested that post-process heat treatments improve the corrosion resistance in Ringer's solution at $3 7 ~ ^ { \circ } C ^ { 1 5 2 }$ and in $3 . 5 \ \mathrm { w t } . \%$ NaCl aqueous solution at room temperature147 This is attributed to the limited element segregation in the $\mu \mathrm { m }$ -sized $\alpha { + } \beta$ lamellar microstructure after the heat treatment, which mitigates the galvanic corrosion between $\mathfrak { a }$ and $\beta$ phases147. Nevertheless, further investigations on the corrosion performance of SLM-produced Ti-6Al-4V are required to understand the influence of post-process heat treatments.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-49
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: In this paper, the LPBF process, post-process treatments, microstructures,and properties of LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al4V have been briefly reviewed. At the beginning，the influences ofprocessing parameters on the defect formation, residual stress,and surface roughnessare presented.Thisisfollowedbytheas-fabricated microstructure and its evolution during the in-process and post-processtreatments.Lastly,theeffectsof microstructure, defects,and surface roughness on tensile, fatigue，fracture toughness，and creep propertiesare discussed.A summary of specific findings is provided

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-50
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
· The formation of defects and surface quality can be controlled by tuning the processing parameters and scan strategies.

$\bullet$ The residual stress and pores in the as-fabricated Ti6Al-4V can be addressed via post-process HIP treatments.

. The as-fabricated Ti-6Al-4Vgenerally hasa hierarchical microstructure containing textured prior- $\beta$ grains that are aligned close to the build direction and intragranular hexagonal $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensitic microstructure. In addition, a few studies have observed a small amount of $\beta _ { : }$ ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { 2 }$ ，and orthorhombic $\alpha ^ { \ast \ast }$ martensite in the as-fabricated condition.

· The microstructure evolution， including martensite decomposition and formation of lamellar and/or bi-modal $\alpha { + } \beta$ microstructures,can be realized via in-process thermal cycling and post-process treatments.

· For the lamellar microstructure,the yield strength follows a Hall-Petch relationship with the lamellar width in the as-fabricated and post-process treated samples.The typical trade-off between strength and ductility is observed within the sample with a lamellar microstructure.In contrast, the bi-modal microstructure can provide a simultaneous enhancement in strength and ductility.

· After surface treatments, the fine microstructure in asLPBF and post-process treated conditions leads to a high HCF strength. In contrast,a coarse $\alpha { + } \beta$ Widmanstätten microstructure is preferred for obtaining good fracture toughness and creep properties.

· In terms of corrosion resistance,the as-fabricated Ti6Al-4V has an inferior corrosion performance than that of wrought counterpart,which is related to the metastable $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensitic microstructure. A more detailed understanding of the influence of post-process heat treatments on the corrosion behavior is required.
summary: · The formation of defects and surface quality can be controlled by tuning the processing parameters and scan strategies. - Part 1/2

fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: Mostpost-processtreatments, includingheat treatments,HIP,and surface treatments,lead to comparable or even superior tensile, fatigue, fracture toughness,and creep properties than those of cast and/or wrought Ti-6Al4V.
summary: · The formation of defects and surface quality can be controlled by tuning the processing parameters and scan strategies. - Part 2/2

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-52
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content:
In principle,LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al-4V hasgreat advantages in preparing complex near-net shape parts and reducing lead times. However, there is still a gap between the current research and the aforementioned advantages. For example, surface roughness and internal defects require post-process surface treatmentsand HIP to address. Additionally， disadvantages of anisotropic microstructure and properties must be considered, and the mitigation of anisotropy requires further investigation.

Interms of microstructure and properties,LPBF fabricated Ti-6Al-4V possesses a fine microstructure, which offers great advantages,including superior tensile and HCF strengths.However,a fine microstructure is not favorable for fracture toughness and creep resistance.A careful microstructuredesignthroughpost-process treatments is required for specific applications.

name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-53
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: In contrast to the inverse relationship between tensile strength and ductility in the lamellar microstructure, the bimodal microstructure shows a great potential in terms of achieving satisfied strength and ductility. In addition, the bi-modal microstructure shows a higher HCF strength,a slower fatigue crack propagation rate of microcracks,and a higher LCF strength in wrought and cast alloys. As a twostep $\alpha { + } \beta$ STA treatment is generally used to obtain a bimodal microstructure, the alloy element partitioning effect inevitably occurs.
