name: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc-part-56
fileName: 2021 - Light AM - Cao et al. - Review of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V process, post-process treatment, microstruc.pdf
content: In contrast to the inverse relationship between tensile strength and ductility in the lamellar microstructure, the bimodal microstructure shows a great potential in terms of achieving satisfied strength and ductility. In addition, the bi-modal microstructure shows a higher HCF strength,a slower fatigue crack propagation rate of microcracks,and a higher LCF strength in wrought and cast alloys. As a twostep $\alpha { + } \beta$ STA treatment is generally used to obtain a bimodal microstructure, the alloy element partitioning effect inevitably occurs.

# ARTICLEINFO
summary: A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti-6Al-4V alloy processed by additive manufacturing vs. traditional processing

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-2
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
# ABSTRACT
Keywords: Elective laser melting Electron beam melting Mill-annealing Titanium alloy Mechanical property

The unique thermal history of different metal additive manufacturing processes would have profound impacts on theresulting microstructure and material properties.However,few have conducted benchmark research on the impacts.This work provides a comprehensive benchmark comparison on microstructure, mechanical properties, and their underlying mechanisms in selective laser melting (SLM),electron beam melting (EBM),and millannealing of Ti-6Al-4Valoys.The results have shown that the SLMedand EBMed samples possess very fine acicular $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ martensite while the conventional mill-annealed ones have granular $\alpha$ phase.The SLMed samples exhibit the highest tensile and yield strength resulted from the combined effects of refined $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite and high microscale residual stres.The lowest tensileand yield strength and intermediate elongation of the EBMed samplesare atributed to the relatively high numberof type-I pores and in-situ annealing for residual stres relief during the printing processThe mill-nnealed samples have the highest elongation due to the fully dense structure,the negligible microscale residual stress,and favorable grain orientation.Itis expected to improve the ductility of SLMed samples via appropriate post-annealing and enhance the strength of EBMed samples by reducing the number of type-II pores through process optimization.The fundamental diffrences in microstructure and properties are attributed to the unique thermal histories of the concerned processes.

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-3
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content: The mechanical properties of high specific strength and excellent corrosion resistance make titanium alloys such as Ti-6Al-4V attractive for a variety of applications of biomedical devices,aircraft,and aeroengines [1-3].Most titanium alloy components are conventionally shaped from the various mill products,of which plate and sheet comprise beyond $4 0 \%$ 、The Ti-6Al-4V alloy plate with good performance is typically prepared by multiple thermal-mechanical processing. The procedure involves forging into alloy bloom from ingot first and then hot rolling into a slab,which further receives hot reductions when the desired thickness fora plate was obtained.Finally,the final plate is subjected to an annealing treatment and surface conditioning by grinding and/or pickling. So,the procedure involves high costs and a long production cycle time [4]．In addition，surface oxidation, non-metallic inclusions,and even delamination during hot working will deteriorate the titanium alloy properties [5].

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-4
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content: The emerging high energy beam-based additive manufacturing (AM has received more attention nowadays because it possesses many attractive advantages such as great design freedom,flexibility,high material utilization,short product development time compared with the conventional manufacturing methods [6-9]. The selective laser melting (SLM)and electron beam melting (EBM),as two representative members of the AM family,has developed rapidly in recent years.The main difference between SLMand EBM lies in the higher production efficiency of EBM $( 5 5 - 8 0 c m ^ { 3 } / h )$ than that of SLM $( 1 0 { - } 3 0 c m ^ { 3 } / h )$ because there is no reflection beam energy loss when the electron beam melts the metal powders.The typical 3D printing defects such as porosity,residual stress,and microstructure such as unstable $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite,are found for both SLMed and EBMed titanium alloys [1O-14] although their characteristic features are somewhat different.From the viewpoint of social and technological interests, the main differences among traditional mill annealing,SLM,and EBM were summarized in Table1.

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-5
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
Nowadays,many studies are devoted to the understanding of the relationship of processing-microstructure-properties in titanium alloy produced by given processing of SLM, EBM,or mill annealing [15-18] separately.However, the systematic comparative study especially on mechanical properties in terms of their dependence on printing defects, residual stress,and microstructure in the Ti-6Al-4V alloy processed by AMand traditional processing were not fully investigated and seldomly reported yet to the current authors'knowledge [19-22].Compared to the existing work regarding mechanical properties,the focus of this work is well beyond the measured data by revealing the underlying mechanisms of different thermal histories experienced in EBM, SLM,and annealing on microstructure,pores,and residual stress under equivalent energy density.This highlights the different thermal nature or mechanisms of the concerned processes from a new perspective of energy density. Specifically,the contributions are manifested in the following two aspects. Table 1 The processing comparison among SLM, EBM,and hot working.

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-6
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content: It provides the first apple-to-apple benchmark process comparison, in particular identical powder materials and equivalent energy density for the concerned processes.It is well known that a slight variation of powder materials,even different batches from the same suppliers,has a significant impact on the resulting microstructure and material properties.However, the keypoints were largely ignored in the bulk literature.For example,Zhao etal.[19] investigated the influence of pores and microstructure on the mechanical properties of SLM and EBM Ti-6Al-4V alloy and found that the tensile strength of SLM samples is significantly greater than that of EBM samples whereas the ductility is quite lower due to the fine $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ martensite.But the initial powders used for EBM and SLM are quite different.The residual stress and grain orientation (texture) were also not considered.

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-7
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
This work also conducted a more comprehensive study than the literature.The fundamental differences of the three processes are elucidated in terms of the microstructural features including grain morphology,grain size,phase constituents,and texture,the mechanism correlating the mechanical properties with the process-induced porosity,internal residual stress,and microstructure of Ti-6Al-4V alloy.According to the literature,few made such a systematic work.For instance,residual stress and grain orientation (texture) were also not considered by Zhao et al.[19].Gong et al. [2O] investigated the relationship between the process-pores-mechanical properties for SLM and EBM alloys and the finding is that the large defects produced in EBM are more sensitive to process parameter variation. The same aspects are missing in reference [21],which compared the microstructural details and tensile strength for the EBMed and wrought Ti-6Al-4Valloy and the main finding is that elongations achieved by EBM is greater for the high-strength forgings but also varied in a large variation range.Rafi etal.[22] investigated and found that the difference in microstructures and mechanical properties of Ti-6Al-4V parts fabricated by SLM and EBM is related to the different cooling rates.However,the two studies provide litte information on the influence of process-induced pores, residual stress,and texture on the resulting mechanical properties.

The paper has two major objectives.The first one is to compare the main microstructural features with regards to grain morphology, grain size,phase constituents,and texture induced during different AM and traditional hot working.The second one is to clarify the mechanisms governing the process-induced porosity,residual stress,microstructure, and the mechanical properties of Ti-6Al-4V alloy.

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-8
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
# 2.1．Materials
Table 2 gives the chemical compositions of the Gas atomized Ti-6Al-4V powders (supplier Arcam ELI) used in SLM and EBM. Spherical metal powders w.o.satellites were observed as shown in Fig.1. The average particle size is approximately $5 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ,which is suggested by the measurements $( d _ { 1 0 } = 4 6 . 3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $d _ { 5 0 } = 5 4 . 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $d _ { 9 0 } = 6 4 . 2 $ $\mu \mathrm { m } )$ by the particle analyzer (Mastersizer 3000).

# 2.2.Processing method


# 2.2.1． Electron beam melting
Table 3 shows the detailed processing parameters,which are selected for optimization by using the Arcam Q1O EBM machine (vacuum $( 3 ~ \times$ $1 0 ^ { - 2 }$ mBar). The processing chamber was kept at $7 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ during the building process,which decreases the residual stresses.The fabrication process was controlled by regulating gas helium to avoid powder charging.

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-9
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
# 2.2.2. Selective laser melting (SLM)
SLM samples were produced on the TRUMPF TruPrint $1 0 0 0 \ \mathrm { \ m a } \cdot$ chine.The SLM processing parameters were selected based on the equivalent linear energy density (the ratio of energy beam power to scanning speed in the unit of $\scriptstyle { J / \mathrm { m m } }$ [23] to that employed for EBM for a given laser beam power (125 W).The previous study [24] suggests that the relationship between the porosity (based on OM examinations) and corresponding linear energy density under different laser scanning speed is shown in Fig.2.The linear energy density employed in EBM is $0 . 2 0 7 \mathrm { J / m m }$ .The corresponding scanning speed for SLM is $6 0 5 \mathrm { m m } / s$ in terms of the equivalent linear energy density $( 0 . 2 0 7 \mathrm { ~ J / m m } )$ ,but the induced porosity is too high (Fig.2).Therefore the scanning speed of $7 0 5 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ was selected due to the least induced porosity for the SLM process in this study.The detailed processing parameters were also shown in Table 3.The process was done on substrate preheated at $2 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } .$ The high-purity argon with an oxygen content of less than $0 . 1 \%$ was employed to prevent from detrimental oxidation and lessen severe evaporation during the entire building process.

# 2.2.3. Traditional processing
Ti-6Al-4V plate with a thickness of $1 0 ~ \mathrm { \ m m }$ was commercially available under mill-annealed condition.The last processing steps involve hot-rolling and subsequently annealed at $7 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $^ \textrm { \scriptsize 1 h }$ The actual chemical compositions of the testing samples were examined using XRF (ZSX-10Oe) at the condition in Table 2.

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-10
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
The SLMed and EBMed bars were vertically fabricated based on the tensile testing design.The dog bone-shaped dimensions were shown in Fig.3a and b for the SLMed and EBMed tensile samples,respectively. Three tensile bars for each additive manufactured alloy were used to determine the mechanical properties.Two tensile testing samples with the dimensions as given in Fig.3c were cut from the mill-annealed Ti-6Al-4V alloy plate by electrical discharge machining (EDM).All the samples are machined to improve surface finish before the tensile test. The tensile loading direction is parallel to the build direction (BD) for the additive manufactured samples and the rolling direction (RD) for the mill-annealed Ti-6Al-4V alloy samples,respectively. The yield strength,ultimate strength,and elongation percentage were measured by the tensile tests,which were carried out on a universal testing machine (Instron 5969) with a cross-head velocity of $8 . 3 3 \times 1 0 ^ { - 3 } \mathrm { m m } \bar { s } ^ { - 1 }$ at room temperature in quasi-static conditions.The fractured surface of the examined tensile samples was observed by SEM (Quanta 250). name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-12
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
X-ray source-based Micro-CT scan (ZEISS Xradia 52O Versa) with a high resolution of O.7 was used for porosity examination for the SLMed and EBMed samples.A $5 \ \mathrm { m m }$ diameter cylindrical sub-volume was sectioned from SLMed and EBMed samples.The 3D model can be reconstructed based on the micro-CT data using the software ORS Visual (Montreal, Canada).The internal pores features including geometric size,shape,and distribution were studied by analyzing the 3D model. The porosity was then determined based on the volume fraction by dividing the volume of entire detectable pores with the bounding volume of the part.

Metallographic specimens cut from the as-processed samples were prepared according to the standard technique.The examined surfaces were mechanically ground and electropolished.X-ray diffraction (Bruker D8 Advance) for phase identification and EBSD (HKL) measurements were directly performed on the electropolished surfaces. EBSD orientation mapping was reconstructed based on the collected and indexed Kikuchi patterns.Then the grain orientation and phase distributions were analyzed using Channel 5 software.The microstructure was further examined on the electropolished and etched surface by an optical microscope (OM) and a field emission SEM(Quanta 25O).For the etching procedure, the electropolished surface was etched in Kroll reagent $\mathbf { \hat { 9 } 2 \ m l }$ distilled water,5 ml HNO3,and 3 ml HF) for $_ { 1 5 s . }$

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-13
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
# 2.5.Residual stress evaluation
Williamson-Hall method was used to evaluate the residual stresses based on the X-Ray diffraction data,which was collected in the $2 0 / \theta$ geometry using Cu Kα radiation $( \lambda = 1 . 5 4 0 6 \mathrm { ~ \AA } )$ at $4 0 \ \mathrm { k V }$ and $4 0 \ \mathrm { m A } ,$ Scans were run for ${ \sim } 6 0 \ \mathrm { m i n }$ in the 20 range of $3 0 { - } 1 5 0 ^ { \circ }$ .Here,the diffraction peaks including (10-10),(0002),(10-11),(10-12),(11-20), (10-13),and (20-21）were used for stress analysis for $\alpha$ -phase of Ti-6Al-4V alloy.

# 3. Results


# 3.1.Porosity characteristics
The porosity measured by micro CT was $0 . 1 6 6 \%$ and $0 . 4 5 0 \%$ for the SLMed and EBMed samples,respectively.The typical 2D images sectioned from the 3D pore structures are presented in Fig.4,from which the pores with varied shapes and sizes can be clearly observed. The number of detectable pores per $\mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ was 27 and 57 regardless of the size for SLMed and EBMed sample,respectively.The distributions of pore volume in the logarithmic form are also given in Fig.5.Three main phenomena were indicated from Figs.4and 5.First, the observed Type-I porosity is nearly spherical pores with relatively small size;type-I pores appear like elongated band-shape along with the build layers [25]. Second, the total number and volume of pores per volume in EBMed samples are higher than those in SLMed ones.Third,the average size of type-I pores in EBMed samples is larger,which is nearly twice that in SLMed ones.

# 3.2.Microstructure

content:
The characteristic microstructure on three perpendicular planes for the samples produced by three different processing are shown in Fig.6. The morphology of prior columnar $\beta$ grain delineated by grain boundary $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ martensite along BD has remained,and the acicular $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ martensite was formed within the prior $\beta$ grains in both SLMed and EBMed samples upon rapid cooling，which is consistent with the previous studies [26-28].However,the layer thickness of $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ martensite is a little larger in

EBMed samples than in SLMed ones,which are approximately $2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $1 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,respectively.By comparison,the typically elongated microstructure along the rolling direction was observed in the hot rolled and annealed sample as presented in Fig. 6c.

content:
# 3.2.2.EBSD results
EBSD-reconstructed orientation image microscope (OIM) maps for the fabricated Ti-6Al-4V samples are shown in Fig.7.The layer width of acicular $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ martensite was approximately $1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ for the SLMed and EBMed samples,respectively.It is consistent with the SEMand OM observations (Fig.6).No obvious texture for $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ martensite is found in the SLMed and EBMed samples while strong (4-2-23) $\perp \mathrm { R D }$ texture was present in the mill-annealed sample.Also,phase constituents based on EBSD measurements are listed in Table 4.Very limited $\beta$ phase was found in the three samples except for a little higher amount of $\beta$ phase $( \sim 2 \% )$ in the mill-annealed sample.It should be noted that it is very hard to index the Kikuchi patterns due to severe crystal lattice distortion and ultra-fined $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite in the SLMed sample.The indexed rate of Kikuchi patterns was around $7 0 \%$ $8 3 \%$ ,and $9 5 \%$ for the SLMed,EBMed, and mill-annealed samples, respectively.

content:
The XRD analysis shows few bcc $\beta$ phase and hcp $\alpha ( \alpha ^ { \prime } )$ phase in the samples (Fig.8).Although the positions of the diffraction peaks for $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ martensite are nearly the same,further scrutinization reveals that minor peak shift and broadening occur to a different extent for the three samples,for example,at the diffraction peaks of $2 0 { \sim } 3 5 ^ { \circ }$ as enlarged in the inset map in Fig.8.There are two main aspects of stress analysis by XRD,one is peak displacement and the other is peak broadening.The former indicates the type of stresses (tensile or compressive) and the latter is indicative of the microstrain.When the compressive stress is induced,a shift of the peaks to higher 20 should appear. Considering that the diffraction peaks measured under the three conditions are invariably shifted to the higher 20 values compared with the standard diffraction peaks of $\alpha$ phase free of stress in Ti-6Al-4V sample,which can be assumed that the samples prepared by the three processes possess compressive stresses within $\alpha ( \alpha ^ { \prime } )$ phase. content: Full Width atHalf Maximum (FWHM) was determined based on the X-ray diffraction results and the microstrain was estimated according to the Scherer formula and Williamson-hall method [29,30]. The Young moduli used in the calculation of the micro-stresses was 11O GPa [31]. The estimated micro stresses are given in Table 5.The SLMed samples possess the highest stress and the value reaches $1 4 5 . 2 \mathrm { M P a }$ .The lowest stress was found in the mill-annealed sample and intermediate stress in the EBMed one.It should be noted that the magnitude of micro stress is also indicative of the amount of residual stress at the macroscopic level. The higher the residual micro stress is,the larger the residual macro stress value is.

fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
# 3.3.1．Tensile results
Fig.9 shows the stress-strain curves for the tested samples.The yield strength $( \sigma _ { \mathrm { y } } )$ ,tensile strength $( \sigma _ { \mathrm { u t s } } )$ ,and fracture strain (ε)are summarized in Table 6.The SLMed samples exhibit the highest yield strength and ultimate tensile strength (UTS) while relatively low elongation. By comparison,the EBMed samples possess the lowest $\sigma _ { \mathrm { y } }$ and $\sigma _ { \mathrm { u t s } }$ values on average.The mill-annealed ones have the $\sigma _ { \mathrm { y } }$ and $\sigma _ { \mathrm { u t s } }$ values in-between but the highest elongation among the three sets of samples.It should be noted that more scattered mechanical properties were present in the EBMed samples. On average, the $\sigma _ { \mathrm { y } }$ and $\sigma _ { \mathrm { { u t s } } }$ in the SLMed samples are comparable or even superior to those in traditional mill-annealed ones; the elongation in the EBMed samples is comparable to that in millannealed ones.

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-19
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
# 3.3.2. Fractography Figs.10-12 show the fracture surface morphology of the typical tensile samples fabricated by SLM, EBM,and mill-annealing,respectively.From the low magnification SEM maps (Figs.1Oa-l2a),the appearance of the fracture surfaces has quite different features in the three samples.First,more type-I pores were observed on the fractured surface of the SLMed sample.They have nearly the same size as those measured by Micro-CT.It is suggested that these sphere pores did not develop or coalescence upon tensile loading. Second, some cleavage planes were clearly found in the EBMed sample.These smooth cleavage planes are typically attributed to the break of pre-existing porosity zone, where the large-sized type-II pores are torn open or a high density of type- I pores are coalesced and propagated upon tensile loading. Third, the homogeneous ductile fracture was observed in mill-annealed one. The high magnification maps show that a typical ductile fracture appearance with fine dimples emerges except for the pre-existing porosity region (Fig.11b).The main differences between the dimples lie in the size and shape of the three tensile samples.Much shallower and larger dimples with the averaged size of $5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ in the mill-annealed sample.By comparison,the dimples in the ductile fracture zones for the SLMed and EBMed samples were around $1 { - } 2 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ，which is at the same level as the $\alpha ( \alpha ^ { \prime } )$ layer thickness. name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-20
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content: The distinct properties of the samples fabricated by SLM,EBM,and traditional annealing have resulted from the inherent structural differences at macro-and micro-levels,which are attributed to the compound effect of surface roughness,internal defects (pores),residual stress,and microstructure (grain morphology,grain orientation, phase distribution, etc.).Considering that surface polishing was conducted and nearly a single $\alpha ( \alpha ^ { \prime } )$ phase without precipitation was found in the current study, we will explain the differences in mechanical properties in terms of porosity,residual stress,and microstructure (grain size,shape,and orientation).In the realm of additive manufacture based on selective melting by high energy beam (laser or electron),it has been wellrecognized that various pores [32-34],high residual stress [35,36], and hierarchical microstructure [37,38] are inherent consequence due to rapid cooling of the local molten metal powders on a relatively cold substrate or a previous deposition.
summary: 4.1.Explanations for the diference in mechanical property

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-21
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
Two main types of pores,spherical (type-I) and elongated pores (type- II),are often observed [25,39]. The type-I pores are caused by entrapped gas associated with the powders produced with a gas atomization process or trapping gas in the environment during SLM and EBM. Alloy vaporization might occur due to extremely high local temperature for the powder or deposited layers when exposed to the laser or electron beams during SLMand EBM.The alloy vapor might become trapped and contracted as nearly or less spherical pores upon cooling.The equivalent diameter is typically smaller and the aspect ratio (AR) is greater than 0.5 for type type-I pores.The elongated pores [39-41] are induced by insufficient melting in subsequent layer deposition.They are typically larger in equivalent diameter [40,42] and characterized by sharp corners and elongated appearance with AR less than or equal to O.5.The number and cumulative size distribution for the two types of pores distinguished by aspect ratio with the threshold of 0.5 were shown in Fig.l3. There are more type-II pores than type-I ones for both samples while the total pore number is quite lower in the SLMed sample than in EBMed one (Fig.l3a). Also,type-I pores with AR larger than 0.5 possess the equivalent diameter of less than $4 0 \ { \mu \mathrm { m } } .$ ,and most of them (around $8 0 \%$ lessthan $2 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in the SLMed sample.By comparison,type-I pores possess the equivalent diameter of less than $7 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } ,$ ，and most of them (around $8 0 \%$ ）less than $4 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ in the EBMed counterpart. For type-II pores,the equivalent diameter is larger,which is less than $1 2 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and $1 8 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ for SLMed and EBMed sample (Fig.13b), respectively.

Table 6 Tensile mechanical properties for fabricated samples.

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-23
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
The higher energy input per unit length (linear energy density) can effectively reduce the number of type-II pores by increasing the pool depth [40,43,44]. The linear energy density was calculated as 0.207 $\scriptstyle { J / \mathrm { m m } }$ and $0 . 1 7 7 \mathrm { ~ J / m m }$ for the EBMed and SLMed samples.Although linear energy density imposed on the EBMed sample was approximately $1 5 \%$ higher than on the SLMed one,the layer thickness of alloypowder employed during EBM is 2.5 times that during SLM,which may lead to insuficient melting penetration between the adjacent layers,and therefore the number of type-I pores per unit volume is larger in EBMed sample.It is assumed that the sharp corners of type-II pores would cause stress concentration in tensile testing and exhibited lower-yielding strength and ultimate tensile strength in the EBMed sample compared to the SLMed and mill-annealed one.That is,type-I pores acted as the origins of crack nucleation and were readily torn open upon tensile loading,leaving the cleavage fracture as shown in Fig. 11b.

At the same time,the melting pool formed during EBM is relatively deep due to a little higher linear energy densityand is more liable to entrapping the alloy vapor or gas.It is why much more type-I pore is also found in the EBMed sample.Such small-sized pores typically have a less detrimental effect on the mechanical properties due to no sharp corners. In addition, the presence of a relatively large number of pores also leads to more scattered data or the uncertainty in the mechanical properties of EBMed samples as shown in Fig.8 and Table 6.

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-24
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
# 4.1.2.Effect of residual micro stress
The micro stress is balanced at intergranular and intragranular length scales and typically present in the form of the high density of dislocations and lattice distortion.Although this type of stress,also indicative of residual stress at the macro level indirectly,does not lead to the part distortion, dislocation strengthening tends to occur.The flow stress $\left( \tau \right)$ in the slip systems that causes dislocation motion is related to the dislocation density $( \rho )$ by Refs. [45,46].

$$
\tau { } = \tau _ { 0 } + a G b \sqrt { \rho }
$$

where $G$ is the modulus, $^ { b }$ is the Burgers vector of dislocation,and $\tau _ { O }$ and $a$ are constants associated with a given material.

The magnitude of the residual micro stress is the highest in SLMed samples,which contributes a lot to the high yielding strength and ultimate tensile strength.The significant micro stress-induced in the SLMed sample compared to the other two samples is caused by two main reasons.Firstly,no annealing is employed in the SLMed sample.By comparison, the EBMed samples were in-situ annealed with the chamber temperature of $7 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ during building and the mill-annealed ones are post annealed at $7 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } .$ So,the residual stress is alleviated in EBMed and mill-annealed samples. Secondly, the melting pool is more locally during SLM because of the smaller laser spot than that of the electron beam.The steeper temperature may lead to high residual stress.

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-25
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
# 4.1.3. Microstructure effect
The grain morphology，size,and orientation of the $\alpha ( \alpha ^ { \prime } )$ may contribute to the difference in the properties of the fabricated materials. Acicular $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ martensite (layer thickness $1 { - } 2 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ (Fig.5) was found in the SLMed and EBMed samples while nearly equiaxed grain (avg. grain size $4 \ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ was present in the mill-annealed samples.The thickness of the martensite layer is finer and may contribute to the strength based on the Hall-Petch relationship in the SLMed sample.There is weak texture because multiple $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ martensite variants were introduced in the SLMed and EBMed sample [47,48]. By comparison, there is a relatively strong (4-2-23) $\perp$ RD texture evidenced by the prevalence of green-colored grains in the OIM of the cross-section perpendicular to RD (Fig.7).

For HCP $\alpha$ crystal with an axis ratio $c / a < 1 . 6 3$ in Ti-6Al-4V alloy, slip may occur on prismatic,basal,and first-type pyramidal planes with the slip directions belonging to the ${ < } 1 1 { - } 2 0 >$ family. In the case of deformation along the c-axis,the slip systems $\{ 1 0 { - } 1 1 \} { < } 1 1 { - } 2 3 >$ and $\{ 1 1 { - } 2 { - } 2 \} { < } 1 1 { - } 2 3 >$ can also be activated [49,5O].The Taylor factor may tell how difficult to deform the grains during tensile loading.The typical Taylor factor distributions on the cross-section perpendicular to the tensile axis in the mill-annealed sample are shown in Fig.14.Most grains have a low Taylor factor (2.0-2.5),which may contribute to the large elongation to a certain extent for the mill-annealed samples.

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-26
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
# 4.2.Fracture mechanism
Many pores can be seen on the fractured surface of the SLMed samples and their size is nearly the same as those measured by Micro-CT before tensile testing.It is suggested that these pores did not develop or coalescence upon tensile loading.In addition,although the ductile dimples were prevalent throughout the fracture surface of the SLMed sample,they are not so homogenous in size compared with those in the mill-annealed sample and EBMed samples (see Figs.1Od-12d).It should beascribed to high residual stress present in the SLMed samples.When the severe stress concentration in many local areas occurs upon tensile loading, necking due to inhomogeneous tensile deformation will emerge and finally lead to fracture. During the entire process,more pores or other defects may also act as stress concentration origins and therefore lead to relatively low ductility.By comparison,the pores coalescence or development remarkably occurs and leaves some cleavage planes in the fracture surface in the EBMed sample (Fig.11),where a mixture of the ductile dimples and smooth cleavage plane coexist.Furthermore, the ductile dimples are relatively deep in addition to homogenous size compared with those in SLMed samples.It can be assumed that the mechanical properties would be enhanced significantly if pores, especially type-II pores,be reduced during building for the EBMed samples. The shallow but homogeneous ductile dimples were observed in the fracture surface of the mill-annealed sample.The size is at the same level as the grain size of around $4 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ .It can be postulated that the millannealed samples were uniformlyplastically deformed with relatively high elongation before fracture due to a fully dense structure compared to the other two AMed samples.

name: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by-part-27
fileName: 2021 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Ren et al. - A comparative study on mechanical properties of Ti¿C6Al¿C4V alloy processed by.pdf
content:
# 5．Conclusions
The mechanical properties were compared among three Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by SLM,EBM,and traditional hot rolling and annealing.The main differences in mechanical properties and the underlying mechanisms in terms of porosity,residual stress,and microstructure were comprehensively benchmarked.Key findingsare summarized as follows:

![](images/56fcb7f58a1d188e79eaa57d32a8863a9f2a9d8f8922d5af68a2482e7fd9d5e0.jpg)  
Fig.14.The distributions of Taylor factor for the grains on the cross-sections (// to the loading axis of the annealed samples).

(1)The SLMed samples exhibited the highest tensile and yield strength as a result of the combined effects of refined $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ martensite and high microscale residual stress.   
(2) The EBMed samples possess the lowest tensile and yield strength, which are attributed to the relatively high number of type-II pores and in-situ annealing to release residual stress in the printing.   
(3) The mill-annealed samples have the highest ductility due to the fully dense structure,the negligible microscale residual stress, and favorable grain orientation.   
(4) The yield and tensile strength in the SLMed Ti-6Al-4V alloy are superior and the ductility of the EBMed alloy is at the same level as those of the mill-annealed ones.The ductility of SLMed samples may be improved through appropriate post-annealing,and the strength of EBMed samples may be enhanced by reducing the number of type-II pores via further optimizing the processing parameters.
