name: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b-part-37
fileName: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b.pdf
content:
Besides build orientation, the way parts are positioned and manufactured inside the build chamber can also affect the roughness generation in EB-PBF processes.The arrangement inside the build chamber can determine the total number of parts that can be fitted,ultimately impacting batch production times and unit cost.The position of parts in L-PBF processes has been proven to affect their final roughness due to the laser incidence spot deformation [154,155],the direction of inert gas flow,and recoater movement [156-158].

Although these factors are not applicable to EB-PBF processes, there is evidence that the position of parts can influence the surface finish of Ti-6Al-4V parts.Borrelli et al.[1O1] noticed that parts produced at the four corners of the build platform consistently displayed slightly higher Ravalues than other parts,even more so in the surfaces facing the outward directions.These corner parts were built very close to the limits of the build platform,and the authors attribute this adverse behavior towards roughness to the less efficient heat dissipation of these regions. Their hypothesis was that heat was trapped in the narrow space between the solid part and the boundaries of the build chamber,inducing more powder particles to attach to the outward-facing surfaces [1O1].Galati et al.[77] and Kotzem et al.[159],also observed a similar tendency, especially in parts positioned closer to the EB-PBF equipment door.It is worth noting that the position of parts along the Z direction had no significant influence on surface roughness [101].

Yet, the relative position between Ti-6Al-4V parts inside the EB-PBF build chamber has been proven to afect their surface quality. Jamshidinia and Kovacevic [l6O] verified an inverse relationship between the spacing distance of thin-walled parts and their surface roughness:

name: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b-part-38
fileName: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b.pdf
content: the closer two distinct surfaces were positioned,the higher their Sa roughness values were.Similar to Borrelli et al.[lOl],the authors explain this behavior as being due to the increased accumulation of thermal energy in the regions between parts with shorter spacing distance,which ultimately favors the adhesion of partially melted particles.

name: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b-part-39
fileName: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b.pdf
content:
The size and shape of the melt pool are determined,among other aspects [161],by the total amount of energy supplied by the energy source and absorbed by the powder bed,which in turn depends on interdependent and mutually interacting process parameters of the PBF process [1O2,146].For EB-PBF,in particular,the process parameters are dynamically controlled by a proprietary algorithm,making the study of individual parameters very challenging.For this reason, researchers rely on theoretical variables for calculating the total energy input levels. Among the most usual variables are the linear energy density [l26,162] and the volumetric energy density,the latter of which is defined as:

$$
\ E _ { \nu } = \underbrace { \begin{array} { l l l } { \begin{array} { r l r } { P } & { { } } & { P } \\ { V _ { s } } & { { } \times } & { H _ { s } \times } \end{array} } _ { t } } \end{array}
$$

For EB-PBF specifically, $P$ (W) is the power of the electron beam, $V _ { s }$ $\mathrm { ( m m / s ) }$ the scanning speed of the electron beam, $H _ { s }$ (mm) the hatching space between scan lines,and t (mm) the layer thickness of the build. The electron beam power (P) is a function of both the accelerating voltage and the current, though it is controlled by the current (in mA) alone since the accelerating voltage is kept constant in EB-PBF equipment [162,l63].The hatching space is the physical distance between two adjacent tracks,and for EB-PBF processes,it is determined by the line offset parameter [9,l34].The scanning speed is the actual translational velocity of the electron beam and can be either dynamically controlled by the speed function parameter or be assigned a fixed value in manual control operation [l24].The layer thickness was already discussed in 5.2,and all these parameters are illustrated in Fig.11.

name: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b-part-40
fileName: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b.pdf
content:
Another parameter closely related to the energy density input is the focus of the electron beam.The focus is controlled by a process parameter called focus offset,which is the current (in mA) that defocuses the electron beam from the sharpest calibrated position [162,164]. Defocusing the electron beam can sometimes enlarge the EB spot size up to a point but at the expense of producing shallower melt pools [165].It is worth noting that the EB spot size is ultimately controlled by a combination of the beam current and focus offset parameters through a non-linear relationship that is not disclosed by the EB-PBF equipment manufacturer [166].The energy density affects many aspects of EB-PBF parts since the size and temperature of the melt pool is known to influence the microstructure [127,l67], the chemical composition [168], and the porosity of Ti-6Al-4V parts [24,163].

![](images/88e69df39dfd221ecf6cdd4cb0cec980e33d1344d6933f0dee5b49f706899213.jpg)  
Fig.11.Schematic of the electron beam and scanning strategy process variables.

The energy density also significantly affects the surface quality of top surfaces in EB-PBF with Ti-6Al-4V.Guo etal.[163] observed that lower energy density levels,achieved by reduced beam current and higher scanning speeds,lead to top surfaces dominated by cavities and lack-of-fusion pores.The authors claim that there was not enough energy to melt the whole powder region properly,and a gradual increase of the energy density with higher beam current values and slower scanning speeds produced much denser and smoother surfaces.Similar results were observed by Shrestha and Chou [1O9],in which the higher energy density levels obtained by only reducing the scan speed produced denser and flatter surfaces.

name: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b-part-41
fileName: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b.pdf
content:
As mentioned in Section 4.3,the topology of top surfaces is dominated by wavy structures located at the edges of each melted track. Employing larger melt pools can re-melt some of these structures from adjacent scan tracks and improve these surfaces.Higher energy density levels elevate the melt pool's temperature and reduce its surface tension, increasing the width of the melt track [124] and benefiting the surface quality,but only up to a point.Excessive energy density can cause intense hydrodynamic instabilities in the melt pool, producing highly distorted structures on top surfaces [163] or,in extreme cases,leading to material vaporization that produces highly damaged top surfaces [8, 169].

Still,using higher energy density levels can be a suitable strategy for roughness control on top surfaces,as verified by Prisco et al.[126] with Ti-6Al-4V specimens.According to the authors,besides reducing the scanning speed, increasing the focus offset values created a defocused beam spot large enough to re-melt the ridges of adjacent scan tracks. Another way of achieving these results is by reducing the distance between adjacent melting tracks through the line offset parameter [126, 134,168].This strategy induces scan tracks to overlap more while increasing the energy density as per Eq 1.

It is also worth mentioning the individual influence of parameters when the energy density is kept constant during the top surface melting. Silvestri etal.[l24] verified that using higher levels of beam current and or scanning speeds while maintaining the total energy density constant produced top surfaces with lower Sa roughness in Ti-6Al-4V specimens by EB-PBF.According to the authors,although the total amount of energy input is maintained,the thermal diffusion times are lower at higher scanning speeds,resulting in higher temperatures in the melt pool that are beneficial to surface roughness.

name: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b-part-42
fileName: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b.pdf
content:
As for the lateral surfaces,the energy density also plays a central role in the surface quality EB-PBF with Ti-6Al-4V,but mostly due to partially melted particles.Increased energy density levels lead to thermal accumulation in parts and high-temperature gradients towards the surrounding powder bed region, thus enabling more particles to partially melt and adhere to surfaces [1O5,l66].This seems to be the case as either increasing the beam current and reducing the scan speeds [105, 125] or reducing the scanning speeds only [l26] resulted in rougher lateral surfaces in Ti-6Al-4V.On the other hand, the influence of the focus offset in the roughness of lateral surfaces showed mixed results with EB-PBF with Ti-6Al-4V.For Safdar et al.[1O5],decreasing the focus offset from $2 5 \mathrm { m A }$ to $1 0 \mathrm { m A }$ produced lateral surfaces with much higher roughness,which according to the authors is due to the concentrated electron beam that leads to higher energy densities.Prisco et al. [126], on the other hand,tested three differentlevels of focus offset-4,10,and $2 0 \mathrm { m A }$ - that showed no influence on the surface roughness of lateral surfaces.

Itis also important to highlight the impact of energy density in the process deviation roughness by anomalies like balling. Yan et al.[170] verified through multi-physics modeling that the energy density from the electron beam must be sufficient enough to melt the solid substrate below the powder bed. Suppose the energy provided is only enough for the powder particles to melt or the melt pool is not as deep as to reach the layer below.The melted material would cluster into isolated agglomerates (balls) to reduce the surface energy,but according to the authors,a properly melted substrate should avoid the balling effect as the melted particles can spread to reduce the surface energy [170].

name: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b-part-43
fileName: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b.pdf
content: The scanning strategy in EB-PBF comprehends both the powder bed heating stages and the melting process [166].The powder bed heating is done by a defocused electron beam and consists of 3 separate stages: (1) preheating of the entire build platform,(2) preheating regions closer to the where melting process will take place,and (3) a post-heating stage performed after the melting process to either heat up or cool down the layer[1O,171].However,a sintered powder bed favors the thermal conductivity between the solid part and surrounding powder [172], which in turn contribute to the melting and adhesion of particles to the surfaces [l73],even more so considering the already elevated temperature of the surrounding powder in EB-PBF processes [8].As such,it would be expected that the role of the preheating stages in the roughness generation had been investigated,but no experimental studies were found in the reviewed literature.

name: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b-part-44
fileName: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b.pdf
content: The scanning strategy of the melting process relates to the individual paths that the electron beam follows to purposely melt the powder and create solid layers.Fig.l2 exemplifies the melting of a single layer. This process is divided into two separate stages: the first involves melting the perimeters,which can be up to 5 concentric contour lines [1O].This stage is also known as contouring,and for EB-PBF processes,the default themes perform it with a spot melting strategy called Multibeam [3,127, 174,175]. This function is specific to EB-PBF processes since the translational speeds of electron beams are much higher when compared to lasers,allowing several melt pools to be simultaneously active.Unlike typical continuous fusion,in the Multibeam strategy the electron beam rapidly shifts between several points along a scanned track, promoting faster scanning and increasing productivity [176].It is also claimed that the smaller melt pools created by this strategy reduce the thermal gradient toward the surrounding powder and leads to better surface finishes [127,l76].However,a comparison between Multibeam and a continuous melting strategy for the contours performed by Wang et al. [125] showed that the non-multispot strategy was able to produce surfaces with lower Ra values for Ti-6Al-4V,though with the worst dimensional accuracy.The authors also verified that the parameters of the Multibeam function had some impact on the surface roughness on lateral surfaces of Ti-6Al-4V by EB-PBF,among them the number of beam spots,the spot time,and the distance between two consecutive spots.The number of spots determines the total number of active melt pools [56],and was the dominating factor in affecting roughness according to the authors,with a higher number of spots producing better-finished surfaces.

name: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b-part-45
fileName: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b.pdf
content:
Acombination of shorter spot time,which is the total amount of time that the electron beam melts each spot,and reduced distances between spots also produced better results in terms of Ra roughness [125].

![](images/bfc59dba51dcd28ca2a2c2b214103d9413c67c553ecd935ac74b9c3fce4247ed.jpg)  
Fig.12.Diagram of the scanning strategy for the contour and hatching patterns.

The second melting stage involves melting the bulk of the part, as illustrated in Fig.12. This is known as rastering or hatching since continuous parallel tracks are melted in varying patterns to produce the inner regions of the parts.The direction and the pattern of the hatching are altered between consecutive layers to avoid anisotropy [l66].It is worth mentioning that EB-PBF parts can be produced by hatching strategies only -without contours -yielding faster build times although producing extremely rough surfaces as verified by Mallipeddi et al. [177] with Ti-6Al-4V.

The scanning speeds and line offset parameters are also linked to the scanning strategy,although their influences on surface roughness were already discussed in the context of energy density (Section 5.5).Still, the effects of the line offset for the contours (contour offset),along with the number of perimeters,have also showed some influence on the lateral surface roughness of EB-PBF with Ti-6Al-4V,although practical results were not obtained by Klingvall et al.[127].

name: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b-part-46
fileName: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b.pdf
content: Another factor contributing to surface roughness in EB-PBF processes is the geometry of parts.The effect of geometrical features and attributes,such as wall-thickness of parts,have also been investigated in terms of surface roughness,although not extensively. Safdar et al. [105] state that thicker walls produced higher levels of Ra roughness in Ti-6Al-4V by EB-PBF.The authors claim that the increased energy required to melt these bulkier structures promoted more particles to partially melt and adhere to lateral surfaces partially.The results later observed by Razavi et al.[4O] and Karlsson et al.[l2O] contradict these findings,with the thin-walled specimens displaying the worst Ra roughness levels compared to the thicker ones,though with different thickness levels.Yet,more recent studies by Segersall et al.[178] showed that the part's thickness did not influence the roughness of Ti-6Al-4V specimens.More research on the matter is required to investigate further the role of geometry and wall-thickness in the surface roughness of EB-PBF parts.The influence of the powder size distribution and the layer thickness,although claimed by many authors as the main drivers of surface roughness generation in EB-PBF,still demand additional experimental evidence for the actual influence of these parameters to be established.The effects of the preheating stages should also be explored due to their role in surface roughness as explored in this review.With that said,the high costs associated with the EB-PBF equipment operation and the feedstock material can hinder experimental studies in the field.Numerical simulations have gained much traction over the past decade,including those to predict surface roughness [9].

name: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b-part-47
fileName: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b.pdf
content: Itis also worth mentioning some guidelines for future research in the area.A deep understanding of the subject is often made impractical by how experiments are conducted and the results are published.Though properly established procedures for the surface measurement of metallic PBF parts are still to be conceived, ISO/ASTM 52902 [75] provides a good starting point，and its guidelines should be followed when designing an experiment.As a general recommendation,all the evaluated surfaces must be duly identified when publishing results,along with all the methods and parameters used for measurement and characterization.In addition,the feedstock material information,the EB-PBF equipment model, the final orientation and disposition of parts inside the build chamber,along with the relevant process parameters described in Section 5 should also be clearly stated.

name: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b-part-48
fileName: 2022 - AM - C. B. Carolo, Cooper O. - A review on the influence of process variables on the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V by electron b.pdf
content:
# 7．Conclusion
This study reveals the growing effort by the academic community to better understand and correlate EB-PBF process variables with the surface roughness of Ti-6Al-4V parts,which also indicates the relevancy of this field of study.EB-PBF has already shown a great potential for industrial applications,and its inherent rough surface quality plays a central role,both positively and negatively.Yet,surface metrology for metallic PBF parts remains a very challenging task with the present measurement and characterization methods and techniques.

Practical and experimental correlations are very challenging to establish in EB-PBF processes due to the highly interrelated process parameters and different measurement and characterization methods. Still, the main mechanisms behind surface roughness generation in EBPBF were reviewed,as well as the process variables and experimental correlations obtained for Ti-6Al-4V specifically.The opportunities for future research in the area were also covered,along with recommendations and guidelines that would allow the community to better interpret the results.

Overall,the relationship between process variables and surface roughness of EB-PBF can better serve the purpose of comprehending the process rather than controlling the roughness entirely.To that end, surface finishing processes still present the best solution for fine roughness control, despite their many limitations regarding AM parts.

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-1
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
Research paper

# Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by laser powder bed fusion
Qixiang Luoä, Lu Yina, Timothy W. Simpsonb,C, Allson M. Beesea a,c,\*

DepartmentofMaterials ScienceandEngineering,Pennsylvania State UniversityUniversityPark,PA682,UA bDepartmentfdstraldctungigsytateUesityesityark Departmentof Mechanical Engineering,Pennsylvania State University,University Park,PA16802,USA

# ARTICLEINFO


# ABSTRACT
Keywords: Additive manufacturing Laser powder bed fusion Processing parameters Correlation analysis X-ray computed tomography

In this study,the process-structure-property linkages in laser powder bed fusion of Ti-6Al-4V were investigated experimentaly and quantified via correlation analysis.Forty-two different combinations of laser power and scan speed were examined to probe lack-of-fusion,keyholing,and beading-up defect regions in addition to dense regions of the procesing space.The resultant structures of the fabricated components were characterized through X-ray computed tomography for visualization and characterization of internal poresand optical metallography to examine prior $\cdot \beta$ grain features.Mechanical properties were assessed via uniaxial tension tests and Vickers microhardness measurements.Correlation analyses,used to quantify the statistical bivariate relations between feature pairs describing procesing conditions, microstructural features,and mechanical properties,revealed the relationship between processng parameters and defect pore morphology，which in turn corelated with mechanical properties.Additionaly,the work expands on process maps for avoiding porosity by defining correlations between processing conditions and resultant properties,providing a means for tailoring properties and structures via processing in laser powder bed fusion additive manufactured materials.
summary: Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by laser powder bed fusion 前言

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-2
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
Ti-6Al-4V is widely studied in additive manufacturing (AM),as it has broad applicability to aerospace [1,2]，biomedical [3,4]，marine, chemical and energy,and defense industries,due to its high mechanical strength,low density,corrosion resistance,and biocompatibility [1-6]. Ti-6Al-4V processed via AM is often reported to have higher strength but lower ductility than in traditionally processed conditions due to differences in microstructural features including $\alpha$ -lath size,prior $\cdot \beta$ grain size/morphology，and defects [7,8]．The present study focuses on identifying relationships among different processing conditions,microstructures and defects,and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V fabricated via laser power bed fusion (L-PBF) AM.

L-PBF AMis a layer-by-layer process to fabricate three-dimensional components,where for each layer,the laser scans and melts powder in the pattern of the current 2D slice of the 3D component [5,6].Numerous parameters can have an impact on the structure,over several length scales,of the final component,including hatch spacing (the distance between parallel laser passes), $h$ ，powder layer thickness, $t ,$ laser power, P,and laser scanning velocity,v,[9],as well as other variables (e.g., parameters describing the beam source) that are closely related to the laser energyabsorptivity [1O,11].These parameters of $P , \nu , h ,$ and tare typically reported in L-PBF studies that aim to correlate processing with structural features,such as defect morphology and grain/sub-grain features,as the variation of these parameters influences cooling rate and thermal history within components [6,9,l2,13].

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-3
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
Process maps can be used to identify combinations of parameters that result in certain features of interest.For example,Gockel and Beuth [14] introduced a process map of electron-beam power versus scan speed for electron beam wire feed AM process Ti-6Al-4V in which they defined boundaries separating different prior $\cdot \beta$ grain size and shapes based on estimated solidification modes,supporting the use of P-v process maps for microstructural control.Gordon etal.[9] extended the use of processing maps to delineate boundaries for different processing defects in L-PBF,and used synchrotron-based micro-tomography to characterize morphology of pores under a range of processing regimes, defining boundaries to differentiate lack of fusion (LOF) and keyholing defects [15].

The present study aimed to determine the four processing regimes that result in dense builds,and builds that contain defects due to LOF, keyholing,and beading-up.These regimes are accessed by different combinations of processing parameters that affect melt pool size and shape during processing [13]. The formation of both LOF and keyholing pores is directly related to the laser energy used,where irregularly shaped LOF defects appear with insufficient laser energy density and/or insufficient overlap between adjacent melt pools [l3].In contrast, keyhole pores appear when the energy density is high,resulting in a deep melt pool in which the molten metal may vaporize and leave behind trapped gas pores of a relatively round shape [12].While LOF and keyholing pores are typically discussed in terms of melt pool sizes, beading-up or balling is attributed to melt pool shape: if the melt pool is sufficiently elongated along the direction of laser scanning,then a Rayleigh-Plateau instability of the metallic fluid occurs due to surface tension,such that the long melt pool separates into multiple melt pools, resulting in bumps in the solidified material [16-18].

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-4
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
A total of 42 processing parameter sets,guided by various studies in literature [13,15,19],were designed to probe dense,keyholing,lack of fusion,and beading-up regimes in fabricated tensile specimens,to generate samples with varying defect structures,microstructures,and mechanical properties.To delineate different regions,boundaries can be defined based on two metrics:(1) laser energy density,which corresponds to melt pool size,and (2) laser power multiplied by scanning velocity,which corresponds to melt pool shape.Mathematical details on the process map design are given in Section 2.1.

The present study focuses on developing process maps for L-PBF Ti6Al-4V by experimentally identifying the impact of processing parameters on:(a） microstructure,in terms of prior $\cdot \beta$ grain size and morphology; (b) processing-related defects,in terms of frequency,volume fraction,and morphology;and (c） mechanical properties.The specimens were characterized using non-destructive X-ray computed tomography to obtain size,distribution,and morphological information on internal pores. Uniaxial tensile tests assessed ultimate tensile strength (UTS) and elongation to failure of all samples.The microstructures of samples were imaged to characterize prior $\cdot \beta$ grain sizes and morphologies,and their Vickers microhardness values were measured.These data were used to construct processing-structure-property maps,and correlation analyses were performed to determine which processing descriptors,microstructural features,and mechanical properties were most strongly correlated in both dense samples and those with pores. Thus,in addition to providing comprehensive maps that show the effect of varying processing parameters on microstructure,including porosity, and mechanical properties,the statistical analyses presented in this study uncover the linear and nonlinear correlations among processing features,microstructural features,and mechanical properties.

fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-6
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
To probe a range of processing regimes intended to produce a range of microstructures as well as dense samples and those with keyholing, lack of fusion,and beading-up defects,a process map was designed in which laser power and laser scan speed were varied for a constant layer thickness and hatch spacing. These four parameters are important to consider in processing maps because they each influence the total energyimparted by the laser to the powder bed.Specifically,the volumetric energy density(VED) is often used as metric for comparing L-PBF processing conditions [15,19,2O],and is expressed as:

$$
V E D = { \frac { P } { h \nu t } }
$$

where $\mathrm { \bf P }$ is laser power, $\mathbf { h }$ is hatch spacing, $\mathbf { v }$ is laser scan speed,and t is layer thickness.

In addition to the volumetric energy density (VED),which approximates the laser penetration depth to be constant,and depends on a constant layer thickness,a modified energy density (MED) was also computed to consider the effect of laser power distribution and penetration depth.Ferro et al.[21] defined the MED by replacing the layer thickness with a variable penetration depth of the heat source penetration,with the MED given as:

$$
M E D = \frac { \beta } { h \sqrt { 4 \alpha \phi } } \bullet \frac { P } { \sqrt { \nu } } = C \bigg ( \frac { P } { \sqrt { \nu } } \bigg )
$$

where $\alpha$ is laser absorptivity, $\beta$ is thermal diffusivity of the powder, $\phi$ is the laser spot diameter,and C is a constant. These laser-powder interaction variables were approximated to be constant in the present study; thus,MED was taken to be proportional to laser power divided by square root of scanning speed.

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-7
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
Based on these energy density metrics,processing parameters (P,v,h and t) contribute to melt pool size,which can dictate the formation of processing defects. High power and low scan speed provide high energy densities,which may result in excess heat beyond the critical value for full melting and solidification of the powders,which in turn may cause overheating or the transition of the melt pool into a penetration keyhole regime.Lower energy density,in the case of low power and high speed, can easily give rise to the incomplete fusion,seen as LOF defect pores.

The Rosenthal equation [22] and its extend analytical solutions [23-25] are often used to describe the melt pool size and shape in terms of the heat source parameters and the powder properties.There are two main criteria to determine the transition between different processing regimes via variation in melt pool size and shape based ona combination of processing parameters.The details of each follow.

Poirier and Geiger [23] and Adams [24] developed an equation for melt pool size by first solving for the temperature distribution as a function of distance from a moving heat source.By seting the temperature of interest, $T _ { i }$ ，to the melting temperature in the following expression,the melt pool size (described by the radial distance away from the heat source,r) as a function of linear energy density is given as:

$$
r ^ { 2 } = { \frac { 2 \epsilon } { e \rho C _ { p } ( T - T _ { 0 } ) } } \left( { \frac { P } { \nu } } \right) \quad { \mathrm { a n d } } \quad L E D \quad = { \frac { P } { \nu } }
$$

where $\epsilon$ is absorptivity, $e$ is Euler's number, $T _ { 0 }$ is room temperature, $T$ is set to the melting temperature to define melt pool size, $\rho$ is material density, and $C _ { p }$ is thermal capacity. The linear energy density (LED) is defined as the energy provided per distance along the scanning path, which is the ratio of laser power to scan speed.

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-8
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
Based on Eq.(3), the size of the melt pool is proportional to the square root of linear energy density,which supports the usage of LED as a suitable metric to control the melt pool size.Several studies have used LED as the main processing feature with which to link density and mechanical properties of L-PBF Titanium alloys,through both experimental results [26,27] and statistical analyses [28].

The second criteria to describe the melt pool geometry and processing defect regime stems from examining the top surface of the melt pool during heat source motion. Researchers have shown that the square of the aspect ratio of the melt pool (length, $L$ ,over width, $w$ ）on the top surface of the powder bed is proportional to the product of heat source power and scan speed [23]:

$$
\left( \frac { L } { w } \right) ^ { 2 } = \frac { \epsilon e } { 3 2 \pi k \alpha ( T - T _ { 0 } ) } ( P \nu )
$$

where $k$ is conductivity,and $\alpha$ is thermal diffusivity.As the aspect ratio increases,the melt pool approaches or enters the beading-up regime. Gratzke et al.[25] attributed the beading-up regime in welding to the competition between surface tension and gravity that leads to the Rayleigh-Plateau instability,responsible for the breaking up of liquid jets.More recent research confirmed the prediction of the beading-up regime for metal L-PBF via both in situ process monitoring [29] and heat transfer simulations supplemented by experimental observations in

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-9
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
In summary,the boundaries in the process map can be estimated considering two metrics: (1) linear or volumetric energy density for melt pool size,and (2) the product of $P$ and $\nu$ for melt pool shape,originating from the Rosenthal equation [22] and its analytical solutions [12, 23-25].

As the melt pool size is determined by energy density,critical values were assumed to describe the boundaries between LOF,dense,and keyholing regimes. LED also describes the cooling rate, $\begin{array} { r } { \frac { { \partial T } } { { \partial t } } , } \end{array}$ during melt pool solidification [12]:

$$
\begin{array} { c } { { \displaystyle \left( \frac { \partial T } { \partial t } \right) _ { x } = \left( \frac { \partial T } { \partial x } \right) _ { t } \left( \frac { \partial x } { \partial t } \right) _ { T } = - 2 \pi k \epsilon ( T - T _ { 0 } ) ^ { 2 } \left( \frac { \nu } { P } \right) } } \\ { { = - 2 \pi k \epsilon ( T - T _ { 0 } ) ^ { 2 } ( L E D ) ^ { - 1 } } } \end{array}
$$

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-10
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
which is equal to the product of temperature gradient, $	extstyle {  rac { \partial T } { \partial x } }$ ,and, solidification rate, $\scriptstyle {  rac { \partial x } { \partial t } } .$ Thus,the cooling rate is inversely proportional to the LED,and the size of the solidification structure,which is correlated with cooling rate,is also correlated to LED [12]. In terms of melt pool shape,a critical value of $P 	imes 
u$ was assumed to describe the transition to beading-up at high power and high scan velocity.Based on published experimental processing data,we estimated the following thresholds: (a) lack of fusion was anticipated with VED below $6 0 \mathrm { J } / \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ [13,15,19], (b) keyholing was anticipated with $\mathrm { V E D } > 8 0 \mathrm { J } / \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ [15],and (c) samples fabricated with VED between 6O and $8 0 \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ would be dense.Finally, beading-up was estimated to occur for $P 	imes 
u > 4 2 0 ~ \mathrm { W }  ullet \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }$ ,based on the experimental porosity inspection over different $P 	imes 
u$ regimes to estimate the upper limitation for dense built to beading-up region transition [15].

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-11
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
For all samples,a constant hatch spacing $( 8 2 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ ，layer height $( 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ ,hatch rotation (245' between subsequent layers),and outer contour parameters (275 W, $8 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ )wereused to isolate the effects of bulk processing parameters on microstructure,defined herein as prior- $\beta$ grain characteristics (size and morphology) and defect structure (pore size distribution,pore morphologies,and overall porosity） and mechanical properties.A total of 42 processing parameter combinations were selected,as given in Table 1 and shown schematically in Fig.1 to highlight anticipated processing regimes.Multiple samples were built for each processing parameter combination.

All the samples were fabricated using a 3D Systems,Inc.ProX DMP 320 L-PBF system,using LaserForm?Ti Gr23(A) Ti-6Al-4V powder (3D Systems,Inc.) with a composition $( \mathrm { i n } \mathrm { w t } \% )$ of 5.5-6.5Al,3.5-4.5V,0.25 Fe, $_ { 0 . 1 3 0 }$ ,0.08 C,0.03 N,and $0 . 0 1 2 \mathrm { H }$ .After the samples were fabricated,they were subjected to a stress-relief at $6 7 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $^ { 5 \mathrm { h } }$ followed by furnace cooling for $^ { 1 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ in an Argon environment. Wire electrical discharge machining was used to remove specimens from the build plate,and no additional heat treatment was done prior to testing.

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-12
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
The specimens were designed to have flat or round geometries for uniaxial tension testing[31],as shown in Fig.2.Two samples of flat and two samples of cylindrical geometries for each of the 42 process parameter sets were tested.Specimens were fabricated such that the tensile axis of each sample was in the vertical build direction.Both flat and cylindrical specimens were evaluated to determine if sample geometry impacted the measured mechanical properties;and it was confirmed that,for each parameter set, these two geometries of samples resulted in the same measured mechanical properties.The surface roughness of the fabricated samples was measured using X-ray computed tomography scans,and the mean surface roughness was found to be $1 2 . 3 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,with a standard deviation of $2 . 1 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ among all samples, and a root mean squared (RMS) average roughness of $1 5 . 0 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ witha standard deviation of $2 . 0 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ among all samples.Thus,the use of constant contour parameters for all variations in bulk processing parameters resulted in similar surface roughness for all samples,eliminating surface roughness as a factor in property variation in the present study.

Table 1 Processing parameter variations used to fabricate samples in the present study.

content: Uniaxial tensile tests were conducted for both flat and cylindrical specimens using an electromechanical load frame (MTS Criterion Model 45) with a $1 5 0 \mathrm { k N }$ load cell. The gauge region for each specimen was spray painted with a white basecoat and random black speckle pattern for analysis with digital image correlation (DIC).Samples were deformed under an applied strain rate of $3 { \times } 1 0 ^ { - 4 } / s$ .For DIC,one (for flat specimen) or two (for cylindrical specimen) digital cameras (Point Grey GRAS-50S5M-C) were used to capture images of the specimen gauge regionsata frame rate of $_ { 1 \textrm { H z } }$ during loading using software to capture data (VIC-Gauge 2D/3D, Correlated Solutions).After testing,analysis software (VIC-2D/3D,Correlated Solutions）was used to compute evolving surface deformation and strain fields within the gauge region for each sample.A vertical $2 4 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ vertical extensometer was used for axial strain measurements.For each processing parameter combination, yield strength,ultimate tensile strength,elongation at necking,and elongation to failure were measured under uniaxial tension

fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
# 2.4.Microstructure characterization
Microstructural features initially considered in the present analysis included width of $\alpha$ laths and size and morphology of pores and prior $\cdot \beta$ grains. Limited variations in $\alpha$ -lath width were observed with respect to extreme changes in processing parameters; thus,this feature was not pursued in the full analysis of all samples. Knowing that prior $\beta$ grain size and morphology play an important role in determining ductility [32,33],we characterized the prior $\cdot \beta$ grains in samples from all 42 parameter combinations.For these studies,fractured flat specimens were sectioned,with the undeformed grip regions used for metallurgical examination.Grip regions were mounted and polished using standard metallurgical procedures with a final polishing step using $0 . 0 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ colloidal silica suspension.All polished samples were etched using Kroll'sreagent $( 1 ~ \mathrm { w t } \%$ hydrofluoric acid and $2 \mathrm { w t } \%$ nitric acid in water) for $3 0 \ : s$ of immersion. Samples were imaged using a digital optical microscope (Keyence VHX-2ooo). The images were analyzed using image analysis software (MIPAR ${ \tt v 3 . 3 . 4 }$ [34]),with pre-processing filters to sharpen the contrast to differentiate features (prior- $\cdot \beta$ grains and pores). An automatic segmentation procedure was designed for batch processing sample images to output grain measurements,i.e., equivalent grain diameter and aspect ratio,for all grains in each processing parameter combination.

After imaging,the samples were re-polished and Vickers microhardness measurements were taken (LECO LM110AT).For each sample, 10 indents were made with a load of 1oo gf and load time of $_ { 1 0 s }$

content:
To study internal defects，samples were examined using X-ray computed tomography (XCT, General Electric v丨tome $\lvert \textbf { x L 3 0 } 0$ nano/ microCT),using a voltage of $1 7 0 \mathrm { k V }$ and current of $5 5 \mathrm { m A }$ Each specimen was positioned $3 5 \mathrm { m m }$ away from the X-ray source and $7 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ away from the detector,yieldinga pixel pitch of $0 . 2 \mathrm { m m }$ .These conditions resulted ina voxel size of $1 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .Samples were imaged through a rotation of 36o for a total of 9oo images,each with an exposure time of $9 0 0 \mathrm { m } s$ .The images were reconstructed into 3D formats via phoenix datos $\mid \textbf { x } 2 . 0$ CT software.

Pore segmentation and analyses were performed using Amira-Avizo 2020.2 software [35] (Thermo Fisher Scientific),ImageJ1.8.0 [36],and MATLAB [37].Based on the $1 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ voxel size,features with diameters over $3 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ were determined to be reliably detected [38],while features below this threshold were filtered out.For each processing parameter set，porosity,number of pores,average pore equivalent diameter, average pore sphericity,and the projected area of all pores,within a sample,onto the cross-sectional plane orthogonal to the loading axis

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-19
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
To identify the relationships between processing features (e.g.,laser power and scan speed),microstructure (e.g.,prior- $\beta$ grain and pore characteristics) and mechanical properties (e.g.,UTS,elongation,and Vickers microhardness),statistical bivariate correlation values were calculated forall pairs of the 16 features listed in Table 2,and correlation plots were generated to visualize these connections.

Four statistical correlation parameters were used to describe both linear and nonlinear relationships between features:(1) Pearson's correlation coefficient (Pearson's $r )$ ,(2) Spearman's rank correlation coefficient (Spearman's $\rho )$ ，(3）Kendall's rank correlation coefficient (Kendall's $\tau )$ ,and (4) $\mathfrak { p }$ -value for hypothesis significance testing.The numerical association of feature variable pairs was evaluated using Pearson's $r ,$ and the ordinal association using both Spearman's $\rho$ and Kendall's $\tau$ was measured via the ranks of the feature variables instead of numerical values.Compared to Pearson's $r$ linear regression fit,the rank correlation methods integrate ordinal sequences that can reveal monotonic relationships between bivariate pairs [39-41] and can also better capture nonlinear trends.

Pearson's $r$ was calculated by applying a correlation function to binary feature variable sets $x$ and $y _ { : }$ defined as [42]:

$$
r = { \frac { \sum _ { i = 1 } ^ { n } ( y _ { i } - { \overline { { y } } } ) ( x _ { i } - { \overline { { x } } } ) } { { \sqrt { \sum _ { i = 1 } ^ { n } ( y _ { i } - { \overline { { y } } } ) ^ { 2 } } } { \sqrt { \sum _ { i = 1 } ^ { n } ( x _ { i } - { \overline { { x } } } ) ^ { 2 } } } } }
$$

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-20
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
where the dataset $\left\{ ( x _ { 1 } , y _ { 1 } ) \right.$ ， $( x _ { 2 } , y _ { 2 } )$ ，， $\left( x _ { n } , y _ { n } \right) \bigg \}$ has a sample size of $n$ and mean values of $\textstyle { \overline { { x } } }$ and $\bar { y }$ .Pearson's $r$ values range from $- \textrm { 1 } \mathrm { t } \mathbf { 0 } + \textrm { 1 }$ ， representing negative and positive linear proportional trends,respectively,and the bivariate correlation between the two variable sets increases with increasing absolute values of $r$ 、For all the correlation coefficients (i.e.,Pearson's $r ,$ Spearman's $\rho$ ，and Kendall's $\tau _ { \cdot }$ and significance testing (p-value) discussed here,the absolute values of the coefficients were used; thus,all correlation values range from O to 1.

Spearman's $\rho$ calculates the correlation coefficient between the rank value sets $a$ and $^ { b }$ corresponding to the binary feature sets $x$ and $y$ instead of the variable values.It is defined as [41,43]:

$$
\rho = 1 - { \frac { 6 \sum _ { i = 1 } ^ { n } ( a _ { i } - b _ { i } ) ^ { 2 } } { n ( n ^ { 2 } - 1 ) } }
$$

where the input bivariate pairs are the feature ordinal datasets $\{ ( a _ { 1 } , b _ { 1 } ) , ( a _ { 2 } , b _ { 2 } ) , . . . , ( a _ { n } , b _ { n } ) \}$

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-21
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
Kendall's $\tau$ also measures the ordinal association between the variable pairs.However,instead of directly using the rank values to find correlations as in Spearman's $\rho$ ，Kendall's $\tau$ considers three separate cases for the rank set data: (1) concordant,(2) discordant,and (3) tying pairs.Concordant and discordant pairs are determined by whether the differences between a pair of bivariate observations, $\left( x _ { \mathrm { i } } , y _ { \mathrm { i } } \right)$ and $\left( x _ { \mathrm { j } } , y _ { \mathrm { j } } \right)$ ,have the same or opposite sign,respectively.In addition, to differentiate the signs of the monotonic relationships between bivariate sets,Kendall's $\tau$ also considers a tying condition within each individual variable set, which occurs when two sample observations are equal (i.e., $x _ { \mathrm { i } } = x _ { \mathrm { j } } \ \mathrm { o r } y _ { \mathrm { i } } = y _ { \mathrm { j } } )$ .Note that the Kendall's $\tau$ used in this study is the t-b type and accounts for the tying condition in the calculations,as opposed to $\tau$ -aor $\pmb { \tau } - \mathbf { C }$ types,which do not [43]. The Kendall's $\tau$ is defined as [40]:

$$
\tau = \frac { n _ { c } - n _ { d } } { \sqrt { ( n _ { c } + n _ { d } + n _ { t } ^ { x } ) ( ( n _ { c } + n _ { d } + n _ { t } ^ { y } ) } }
$$

where $n _ { c }$ and $n _ { c }$ are the number of concordant and discordant pairs among the full bivariate dataset,respectively,and $n _ { t } ^ { x }$ and $n _ { t } ^ { y }$ are the number of tying pairs within each individual variable set $x$ and $y _ { : }$ respectively.

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-22
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content: The null hypothesis significance testing parameter, the p-value, was also used to quantify the bivariate correlations between processstructure-property feature pairs,with the alternative hypothesis being that the variable sets are statistically significant. Unlike the Pearson's r value,the p-value is not limited to linear regression and provides a broader treatment of nonlinear data structures [42]. The $\mathfrak { p }$ -value measures the degree of significance for statistical correlations between data pairs.P-values range from O to 1,in which a lower p-value suggests lower probability of the null hypothesis being true,and a greater correlation significance for the bivariate feature combination.P-values that are less than O.O5 typically indicate strong evidence against the null hypothesis [42,44],meaning there is a statistically significant correlation for that data pair,whereas p-values larger than O.O5 indicate low confidence in the existence of a correlation.

content:
To characterize the observed processing defects,the average pore equivalent diameter, total projected area of pores within the gauge region, total pore quantities,and average pores sphericity were computed from the XCT scans for each processing condition studied. Characteristic defect structures,as visualized via X-ray computed tomography,are shown in Fig.3.The pore sphericity was measured via Hakon Wadell sphericity, $\psi _ { p }$ [45],defined as:

$$
\psi _ { p } = { \frac { A _ { s } } { A _ { p } } } = { \frac { \pi ^ { \frac { 1 } { 3 } } { \left( 6 V _ { p } \right) } ^ { \frac { 2 } { 3 } } } { A _ { p } } }
$$

where $A _ { p }$ and $V _ { p }$ are the measured pore surface area and volume, and $A _ { s }$ is the pore equivalent surface area under the assumption that the pore is perfectly spherical.

fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content: The internal pore size distributions for the samples are shown in Fig.4a and c. Small and spherical gaseous pores with equivalent diameters below $5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ were present in all samples,and these had no preferred locations.While there were a large quantity of these small pores in each studied processing condition, these pores had a negligible contribution to the overall porosity value due to their small size [46]; these gaseous pores corresponded to,on average, $6 0 \%$ of the total number of pores,but only contributed approximately $5 { - } 1 5 \%$ of the total pore volume for a sample.Defects smaller than $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ were found to not impact ductility，with samples having pores this size retaining elongation to failure of $1 2 \%$ .Intermediate-sized pores,with diameters from 50 to $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,were largely observed at high energy density conditions.These defect pores,identified as keyhole pores,were the main contributors to porosity in the high energy density regime,and have been shown to result in reduced elongation and strength of material compared to material processed in dense regimes [9,46].Larger defects, with diameters from $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to over $5 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,were found in two processing regimes:(1） those with extremely low laser power and scan speed,resulting in insufficient energy input for producing dense samples,and (2) those with high powers and high scan speeds where beading-up leads to irregular defects.

content: A comparison between the processing defect regimes based on literature [13,15,19] (see Fig.1),and the XCT-measured porosity in the present study,is given in Fig.5. Differences between the present study, which used a 3D Systems ProX DMP 32O,and studies in the literature that used an EOS M 29o L-PBF machine [13,15] may arise due to variations in other processing parameters that are not typically prescribed by users (e.g.，scan pattern,laser spot size),while here we also emphasize the fact that boundaries between defect and dense regions are approximate.The nonlinearity of the defect regime boundaries can be partially explained by the variation of laser penetration depth [21] and laser-powder interactions [47].Considering the MED criterion,the LOF-dense boundary was smoothed as the laser power P is proportional to the square root of scan speed v. However,for the dense-keyholing boundary, contours of constant modified energy density did not capture this transition. This can be partially explained by the fact that a significant increase in laser absorptivity has been observed in L-PBF when transitioning from dense to keyholing regimes [47].To identify processing-structure-property feature correlations for dense and porous samples in Section 3.4,we definea threshold of $^ { 1 \% }$ porosity to delineate dense versus porous samples.

content:
The relationships between processing parameters and defect morphologies are summarized in Fig. 6. Large irregular pores,coinciding with increasing porosity (see Fig.6a),were present at high LEDs corresponding to the upper left corner of the P-v map.This agrees with the energy density criterion discussed in the previous section,where high energy density leads to deep penetration of the melt pool and keyholing defects.In contrast,LOF was accessed only for the lowest power and scan speed probed in this study.Instead,large irregular voids indicative of lack of fusion defects appeared at combinations of low laser powers and low scan speeds (see Fig. 6c-f).Additionally,large pores resulting from beading-up processing conditions were found at combinations of high laser power and high scan speed,indicated by sharp increased pore size and total pore projected area at upper right corner of the process map (see Fig.6e and f).The presence of large pores from both lack of fusion and beading-up resulted in significantly increased pore irregularity (see Fig.4c-d),leading to a significant drop in ductility as discussed (see Fig. 4b and d).

content:
3.1.3.Relationship between defect morphology and mechanical properties The relationships between defect characteristics and mechanical properties were also investigated as shown in Fig.4,as it was anticipated that the morphology of the internal defects would play a critical role in the material ductility (elongation to fracture).The pore size distributions,for pores up to $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in diameter,are logarithmic for all of the parameter sets (see Fig.4a)；however,on a logarithmic scale,the distribution plot highlights some abnormal sample parameter sets (see Fig.4c),where the existence of large pores (over $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ , fromlack-offusion or beading-up,was identified in four parameter sets.The average ductility decreased with increasing pore size (see Fig.4b). Similar to the effect of size,pore irregularity contributes to decreased elongation,as shown in Fig. 4b and d. Among all of the $0 { - } 2 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ sized pores,the lackof-fusion and keyhole pores (i.e., those at low or high $\mathrm { P / v }$ ,respectively, according to the $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ size threshold defined in Section 3.1.1), have higher irregularity than the small and round gas pores.As a result, specimens with large pore size and low sphericity exhibited a lower ductility $( 3 - 1 0 \% )$ compared to those with gas pores,which showed a relatively high ductility $( 1 0 \mathrm { - } 1 5 \% )$ . Large pores due to beading-up or extreme cases of lack-of-fusion voids $( 2 0 0 - 5 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ reduced tensile ductility catastrophically,resulting in ductility less than ${ 3 \% }$

content:
# 3.2.Process dependent prior $\boldsymbol { \cdot } \beta$ grain structures
Variations in L-PBF AM processing conditions influences the microstructure of materials due to variations in the temperature gradient, $G _ { i }$ and solidification rate, $R$ [12],along with overall thermal history. Correlations between processing conditions and grain sizes/morphologies of the samples were studied by characterizing prior- $\cdot \beta$ grain size and shape distributions from the optical micrographs in Fig.7,and visualizing the average quantities on the process map shown in Fig.8.Analysis of each of these results follows.

# 3.2.1. Prior $\boldsymbol { \beta }$ grain morphology analysis
With varying laser power and scan speeds,the prior $\cdot \beta$ grain size increased with increasing energy density,where higher input power results in slower cooling and coarser microstructures compared to samples with decreased LED or VED.The prior $\cdot \beta$ grain morphology varied from columnar to equiaxed with increased $P \times \nu ,$ which results in a transition from columnar to equiaxed solidification modes.This transition in solidification mode in L-PBF Ti-6Al-4V has been shown experimentally [48],and explained using the constitutional supercooling theory by Chalmers et al.[49].Specifically,increasing laser power and scan speed result in an increased solidification rate and decreased temperature gradient at the trailing edge of the melt pool, increasing the degree of constitutional supercooling and resulting in a higher driving force for equiaxed grains over columnar [12].
summary: 3.2.1. Prior $\boldsymbol { \beta }$ grain morphology analysis, 3.2.Process dependent prior $\boldsymbol { \cdot } \beta$ grain structures

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-31

content:
Prior- $\cdot \beta$ grain sizes and morphologies were characterized based on the segmented images shown in Fig.7.For each processing condition,the grain size (in terms of equivalent diameter) and shape (in terms of aspect ratio) were measured from the corresponding optical image.The aspect ratio was defined as the maximum length of the prior- $\cdot \beta$ grain divided by the perpendicular width,based on an elliptical fit for each prior- $\beta$ grain feature [5O].Grain measurements were correlated to the processing parameters for each sample to construct power vs.velocity vs.prior $\cdot \beta$ grain feature process maps.

In the P-v-prior $\cdot \beta$ grain morphology process map shown in Fig. 8, there are two key correlations.For the grain size versus processing parameters shown in Fig.8a, the dense region at the center of the process map,where pores played a minimal role,showed increasing grain sizes with the increase of LED.This is due to the low cooling rate of the melt pool under high energy density conditions,which leads to the growth of coarse grains during the solidification process.

![](images/81641b75274d73df2d973f796534c1db18141d28b69be4a4d0437db1c37f90b7.jpg)  
Fig.8.Process-dependent prior- $\cdot \beta$ grain characteristics of (a) average equivalent diameter,and (b) average grain aspect ratio.

content: For the prior $\cdot \beta$ grain morphology versus processing parameters shown in Fig.8b,itis hard to find quantified trends for the grain aspect ratio due to the limitation of image segmentation.However,through qualitative examination of the micrographs in Fig.7,along the diagonal line from lower left to theupper right corner of P-v space,the prior $\cdot \beta$ grains had a decreasing aspect ratio as the grain morphologies changed from columnar to mixed columnar/equiaxed and finally equiaxed with increasing $P \times \nu _ { \mathrm { { } ; } }$ ，which has also been observed in literature [14]. Overall， the prior $\beta$ grain size and shape values were not strongly correlated to the processing parameters,especially compared to the processing-defect relationships discussed in Section 3.1.2.The low correlation between prior $\cdot \beta$ grain features and processing parameters was due to the high variation of prior $\boldsymbol { \cdot } \boldsymbol { \beta }$ grain size and morphology measurements,as the growth of prior- $\boldsymbol { \cdot } \boldsymbol { \beta }$ grains was disrupted by the presence of large and frequent pores,resulting in scattered prior $\beta$ grain features.

# 3.3.Process dependent mechanical properties
The measured mechanical properties as a function of processing conditions are summarized in Fig.9.Fig.9a and b show the effects of processing parameters on (a) UTS and (b) elongation to failure.There are three main regions of interest,defined by different $P 	imes 
u$ values. For intermediate $P 	imes 
u$ values $( 1 0 0 < P 	imes 
u < 4 2 0 ~ \mathrm { W }  ullet \mathrm { m / s } )$ at the center of the plots,samples were ductile,with both UTS and ductility decreasing with increasing LED due to the increasing importance of small $( < 2 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ internal pores with increasing LED.For the low and high $P 	imes$ $
u$ regions $( P 	imes 
u ~ > ~ 4 2 0$ ，or $< ~ 1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { { W }  ullet \mathrm { { m } / \mathrm { { s } } } ) }$ ，ductility drastically decreased with the introduction of large $( > 2 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ and highly irregular pores due to beading-up at high $P 	imes 
u$ values and lack of fusion at low $P 	imes 
u$ values.This relationship between mechanical properties and defect size/morphology is supported by the similar trends observed in the ductility map (see Fig. 9b) and porosity and sphericity maps (see Fig. 6a,c-d and also Fig.5).The impact of variation in prior $ eta$ grain features on mechanical strength and ductility was not as significant as the impact of pores.The ductility had a higher sensitivity to the existence of internal defects than UTS did,shownas higher variation in high porosity regions within the P-v space.A summary of strength and ductility grouped by processing regimes is listed in Table 3.The Vickers microhardness as a function of processing conditions, shown in Fig. 9c, did not exhibit strong or clear trends.

# 3.4.Quantification of correlation among process, structure, and property features

content: A total of 16 features were selected to describe the processing conditions,microstructure and defect structures,and mechanical properties,as listed in Table 2.As multiple mechanical tests were performed for each processing parameter set, the average values for mechanical properties are presented here.One sample from each processing parameter set was examined for prior $\cdot \beta$ grain structure and pore characteristics.Multiple images of each sample were used for prior $\cdot \beta$ grain analysis,and XCT was used to analyze all the pores within the gauge region.Microstructural features were averaged from the images and XCT reconstruction for correlation analysis.

content: Bivariate feature correlation analysis was conducted using the four statistical parameters discussed in Section 2.6 for all pairs of the 16 features.Correlation matrices were constructed to visualize the liear correlation and statistical significance results,as shown in Fig.1O,and the nonlinear correlation results,as shown in Fig.11.In the correlation matrices,each column or row represents one feature,and matrix cell values correspond to the correlation intensities for intersecting feature pairs.The matrix is symmetric,and the diagonal cells have no significance,as features are self-correlated by definition.The color scales present in the correlation maps range from red (strong correlation) to blue (weak or no correlation). Correlation matrices for the four correlation parameters are presented for the following datasets:(i) dense samples ( ${ < } 1 \%$ porosity),(ii) porous samples $( \geq 1 \%$ porosity),and (iii) the differences in correlation coeficients between the dense and porous samples. Separate analyses were performed for dense and porous samples as pore volume fraction，pore size,and pore morphology are strongly linked to ductile fracture [5l-53].Thus,the separation of sample types allows for the identification of process-structure-property links in different processing regimes where pores are either absent or present.

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-36
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
To further analyze the correlation results that are shown in Fig.10 and Fig.1l,thresholds were defined for strong and weak correlations for the four statistical metrics.Two features were considered to be strongly correlated if (a) the correlation coefficients (Pearson's $r ,$ Spearman's $\rho$ and Kendall's $\check { \tau _ { \mathrm { + } } }$ ）were greater than O.8 and (b) the $\mathbf { p }$ -valueswere less than O.oo5.A threshold delineating strong versus weak correlation is difficult to define as it depends on a number of factors,including data set size,data distribution,and confidence interval [39]；however,it is generally accepted that a correlation coeficient (Pearson's r,Spearman's $\rho$ ,and Kendall's $\tau$ )of 0.8 or higher can be interpreted as indicating a strong correlation [44]．A p-value of 0.o5 is generally considered to be an appropriate cutoff for the null hypothesis of variate correlation with a $9 5 \%$ confidence interval [42].However, this cutoff depends on the sample size and assumes a normal distribution of values [54,55]. Since the present dataset is relatively small (42 parameter sets) with non-normal distributions,a tighter threshold p-value of O.oo5 was used instead [55],corresponding to a $9 9 . 5 \%$ confidence interval.

![](images/d895089d167fa8f868a1ff247d80dea2b4c0b61417461e180d06434a9dbc6294.jpg)

content: Comparison matrices between the dense and porous correlation data were generated,as shown in Figs.1Oe-f and 1le-f.A non-zero difference in Pearson's $r$ value represents a change in magnitude of linear correlation, while a non-zero difference in p-value suggests a potential change in certainty of the null hypothesis being accepted or rejected.However, caution must be taken in the interpretation of the differences in p-values. For instance,there may be a large difference between two p-values,but both p-values are above the threshold set for statistical significance (in this case, O.0o5).Despite the large p-value difference,the null hypothesis would be accepted in both cases,and no linear relationship for either case should be inferred.

content: For the correlation matrices based on Pearson's correlation coefficient (Pearson's r) and p-value,there were no significant differences for the linear bivariate correlations (see Fig.1O) between VED and MED with structure or properties features,of nonlinear correlation metrics (see Fig.11) indicating these are similar metrics.According to the correlation matrices for the Pearson's $r$ coefficients,both the dense and porous sample sets showed strong correlations among the mechanical strength and elongation features; the ultimate tensile strength (UTS) and yield strength (YS),and the elongation at necking (EN) and elongation to failure (EF) were strongly correlated with each other regardless of porosity level,with anaverage $r = 0 . 9 2$ .However, compared to dense samples,the porous samples showed a $1 7 \%$ increase in Pearson's $r$ for the elongation at neck-elongation to failure feature pair (EN-EF),which can be atributed to the defect structures limiting the elongation to failure of the samples,resulting in closer or equivalent values of elongations to failure and necking.For both dense and porous samples, the prior- $\cdot \beta$ grain features (GD and GAR) showed weak correlations with other processing and mechanical property features (average $r < 0 . 3$ when correlating GD and GAR to LED,MED,PV, UTS,YS,EN,and EF). Similarly，weak correlations were also found between the Vickers microhardness (HD) and all other features,as the hardness values did not vary significantly over the range of processing parameters studied.

content:
The main differences between the dense and porous sample types were in the correlations within defect morphology features (NSP,VSP, FRQ,DIA,PPA,and POR) and between processing and strength features (LED,MED,UTS,and YS).Dense samples had strong correlations (average $r = 0 . 9 6 $ between pore size (DIA) and average pore sphericity, both of which were based on number of pore (NSP) and weighted by pore volumes (VSP),and between cumulative pore statistical features, including porosity (POR), total pore projected area (PPA),and pore quantity (FRQ).This confirms that the gaseous pores in the dense regime samples were small and spherical.Moreover,the small pores in the dense samples were also relatively constant in size and morphology despite the variations in processing parameters,as indicated by the high Pearson's $r$ (average $r = 0 . 9 5$ )between pore frequency (FRQ) and cumulative porosity characteristics (POR and PPA).In contrast, for the porous samples,only the pore size-porosity (DIA-POR） feature pair resulted in a strong correlation $( r = 0 . 8 4 )$ ,which corresponded to a $^ { 1 3 \% }$ decrease in Pearson'srcompared to dense samples.These differences in linear coefficients confirm that the pores in the porous samples had different sizes and morphology characteristics than the relatively small and spherical gaseous pores in the dense samples,as large $( 5 0 - 5 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ and irregular (sphericity lower than 0.95) defect pores (LOF,keyholing, or beading-up,see in Fig.4b) dominate the overall porosity in porous samples.The nonlinear trends in the correlations were also detected via the rank correlation coeficients as discussed in Section 3.4.3.

Fig.11.Proce-stucureproertytistialorelaioalysisasusiglarelaeets (a)as $\rho$ and $( \boldsymbol { \mathrm { b } } , \boldsymbol { \mathrm { d } } , \boldsymbol { \mathrm { f } } )$ Kendall's $\tau$ Input variables are the 16 features listed in Table 2.Samples are split into (a-b) dense samples (average porosity les than $1 \%$ )and (c-d) porous samples (average porosity greater than $1 \%$ ),with their correlation differences shown in (e-f).

The other main difference between the two sample types was in the correlation coefficients between processing features (LED and MED) and mechanical strength features (UTS and YS). The average r value for these bivariate pairs in dense samples was O.73 higher than the average $r$ value for their porous counterparts,as shown in Fig.1Oe.This indicates that the mechanical properties in dense samples were more strongly linearly dependent on LED and MED,while the mechanical properties in porous samples were dominated by processing dependent defects and exhibited nonlinear relationships with processing parameters.

The contrast between porous and dense samples highlights the tradeoff between pores and grain structure.For dense samples, the internal defects were small and round and had limited impact; thus, the prior- $\beta$ grain features played a role in the mechanical properties.However,the properties of the porous samples were dominated by large, irregular defects,resulting in strong correlations between energy density and pore size and sphericity,which correlated with elongation to failure.
summary: 3.4.2. Linear correlation analyses and significancy analyses - Part 4/5

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-42
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content: For the correlation matrices based on p-values,similar trends to those seen in the linear regression $r$ analyses were found. Other than these relationships,an additional difference between the dense and porous samples using p-value classification was found in the processing feature,defined as $\mathbf { P } \times \mathbf { v }$ (Pv),and mechanical property (UTS,YS,EN, and EF) pairs.Dense samples showed high correlations between Pv and all mechanical properties,including strength metrics and elongation metrics,with an average $\mathfrak { p }$ -value of less than O.oo2.In contrast,the porous samples showed no correlation (average p-value of 0.78) for any of these pairs.This difference arises because bivariate correlation can only consider the impact of one feature on one outcome,and not the combined effects of features (e.g.,variations in microstructural features and defect features) on an outcome (e.g.,elongation to failure).Thus,in dense samples,the mechanical properties may be dominated by a combination of microstructural features,while in porous samples,the mechanical properties were dominated by large defects.
summary: 3.4.2. Linear correlation analyses and significancy analyses - Part 5/5

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-43
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
Unlike the Pearson's correlation method,which directly correlates the feature bivariate sets via linear regression,rank correlation methods interpret the ordinal sequences as input variables; hence,there are no limitations on the description of nonlinear trends,unlike linear regression.To address the ordinal association,two different correlation coefficients, Spearman's $\rho$ and Kendall's $\tau _ { \cdot }$ ,were used in this study.The use of rank correlation methods alongside linear correlation methods provides complementary nonlinear descriptions for the process-structureproperty relationships,which is important to consider because catastrophic failure dominated by the presence of significant defects at porous regimes is nonlinear. This means that in dense samples, ductility may scale with porosity,while in samples with large pores,there is a sharp decrease in ductility with the introduction of irregular or large pores,leading to nonlinear behavior.

The correlation and difference matrices for Spearman's $\rho$ and Kendall's $\tau$ for dense and porous samples are shown in Fig.11.Few differences can be found between the two rank correlation methods.The Spearman's $\rho$ resulted in slightly higheraverage correlation values $( \rho =$ 0.45 and O.29 for dense and porous samples,respectively) than the Kendall's $\tau$ $( \tau = 0 . 3 4$ and 0.22 for dense and porous samples,respectively)when averagingall bivariate pairs,with an average increase of $3 1 \%$ in the coefficients.This suggests that the Spearman's $\rho$ may be more sensitive than Kendall's $\tau$ to evaluate the nonlinear feature correlation relationships found in this work.Thus,further discussions in this section focuses solely on Spearman's $\rho$ as the primary nonlinear correlation parameter.
