fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
When comparing the correlation matrices for Pearson's $r$ to the correlation matrices for Spearman's $\rho$ and Kendall's $\tau _ { \cdot }$ ,it is evident that bivariate pairs that did not correlate under the limitations of linear regression were uncovered with nonlinear rank correlation.In general, these bivariate pairs were more strongly correlated in the porous samples than the dense samples,which was expected as the nonlinear transitions between defect-dominated properties to dense properties were all identified in porous samples.

The correlation scores significantly improved between the numerical and volumetric weighted pore sphericity metrics (VSP and NSP) and mechanical properties metrics (UTS,YS,EN,and EF) when Spearman's $\rho$ was used instead of Pearson's r. Specifically,an increase in the average correlation value of 0.11 $( + 1 7 \% )$ and 0.29 $( + 1 4 1 \% )$ was found for dense and porous samples,respectively.The increase in average correlation value for porous samples confirms that nonlinear correlation coefficients better describe the detrimental effects of large and irregular pores (LOF and beading-up) on mechanical properties due to early failure.The volumetric weighted sphericity (VSP) was identified to be more correlated to mechanical ductility (EN and EF) than the numerical weighted sphericity (NSP) in dense samples,as it showed $3 5 \%$ higher correlation values in the case of nonlinear correlation.

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-45
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
Additionally,among the mechanical property features (UTs,YS, EN, and EF),the elongation properties (EN and EF) were more sensitive to pore irregularity than the strength properties (UTS and YS). This was concluded by comparing the differences in Pearson's $r$ and Spearman's $\rho$ values for pore sphericity and elongation properties pairs and pore sphericity and strength properties pairs.When Spearman's $\rho$ was used instead of Pearson's $r ,$ the average correlation value between pore sphericity (VSP) and elongation properties (EN and EF) increased by 0.37 $( + 1 2 2 \% )$ ，while the average correlation value between pore sphericity (VSP)and strength properties (UTS and YS) only increased by 0.19 $( + 5 7 \% )$ .The smaller increase in average correlation value suggests that elongation is more sensitive to pore sphericity than strength.

Finally,the difference in correlation coefficients for the processing feature and porosity (Pv-POR) bivariate feature pair between dense and porous samples increased significantly when using nonlinear descriptions instead of linear regression.As shown in the difference matrix between Spearman's $\rho$ for dense and porous samples (see Fig.1l), the $\mathbf { P v }$ -PORpairhadacorrelationvalue difference of O.76,where this pair was not related in dense samples $( \rho = 0 . 0 5 )$ ,but strongly correlated in porous samples $( \rho = 0 . 8 1 $ ).This result,along with the experimental observations from XCT,confirms the formation of beading-up pores at high Pv regimes.

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-46
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content: To summarize,nonlinear correlation methods via the interpretation of rank correlation coefficients (Spearman's $\rho$ and Kendall's $\dot { \tau _ { \scriptscriptstyle + } }$ provide complementary information on the relationships between binary process-structure-property variable sets that linear correlation methods cannot accurately describe.Compared to the linear correlation method (Pearson's $r )$ ,the rank correlation coeficients resulted in better descriptions of the nonlinear turning points,which are due to the early fractures observed in porous samples (average elongation to fracture lower than $3 \%$ ）and the existence of extremely large $( > 2 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ and irregular (sphericity lower than 0.6) pores (see Fig.4).This turning point was observed in the statistical analyses from the increase in correlation values when nonlinear correlation methods were used instead of linear correlation methods to determine the relationships between processing features (LED,MED,and Pv),defect morphology (NSP,VSP, and POR),and mechanical properties (UTS,YS,EN,and EF).This is because linear correlation methods only consider the numerical values of bivariate pairs while nonlinear correlation methods consider the ordinal association,and as a result,nonlinear correlation methods can more accurately detect turning points between dense and porous regimes.By comparing the differences in correlation coefficients calculated from the linear and nonlinear correlation methods,new information can be obtained regarding the bivariate feature correlation relationships.Additionally,the analysis of rank correlation coefficients can enable the tailoring of the processing regime bounds via a detectable transition point found using bivariate feature pairs such as processdefect morphology and defect morphology-mechanical properties.

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-47
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content: The efect of a wide range of processing parameters on microstructure,defect structure,and mechanical properties for L-PBF Ti-6Al-4V were studied experimentally via optical microscopy,XCT,and mechanical testing.Two sample types were classified-dense (samples with less than $^ { 1 \% }$ porosity) and porous (samples with more than $1 \%$ porosity) -and statistical correlation analyses were performed on each sample type to quantitatively investigate both linear and nonlinear relationships among processing,structure,and mechanical properties.This study combines experimental results and statistical investigation to uncover process-structure-property relationships in dense and porous samples, which can provide a path to determine the processing parameter bounds for defect-dominated regimes and the optimal design of L-PBF Ti-6Al4V.The primary conclusions for this work include:

name: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l-part-48
fileName: 2022 - AM - Luo et al. - Effect of processing parameters on pore structures, grain features, and mechanical properties in Ti-6Al-4V by l.pdf
content:
·The process maps investigated in this study provide insight on the dependence of defect structure,prior $\cdot \beta$ grain structure, and mechanical properties on laser power and scan speed velocity, providing a means for identifying appropriate processing conditions for desired mechanical properties.   
In the absence of pores (i.e.,porosity ${ < } 1 \%$ ,yield strength (YS),ultimate tensile strength (UTS),uniform elongation to necking (EN), and elongation to failure (EF),were strongly linearly correlated with the linear energy density (LED) and modified energy density (MED), indicating that microstructural changes as a result of varying cooling rates during processing impacted these properties.   
·Increasing size and irregularity of pores,measured in this study via volume weighted lack of sphericity,strongly correlated with reductions in ductility and strength.   
·Pearson's $r$ was applied to quantify the strength of linear bivariate correlations among the experimental collected process-structuralproperty features.Rank coeficients of Spearman's $\rho$ and Kendall's $\tau$ were introduced asa complementarymethod to identify nonlinear correlation relationships that conventional Pearson's $r$ is unable to detect,due to its limitation of linear regression.Critical nonlinear relationships among processing feature of $( P \times \nu )$ ,defect pore features (pore size,shape and volume fraction),and pore-dominated mechanical properties,were also revealed.

In addition to providing processing maps that visually link processing to microstructure/defect structure and mechanical properties,this study provides an understanding of the linear and nonlinear correlations among processing,structure,and properties,providing a means for tailoring microstructure and properties in AM.

name: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys-part-2
fileName: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys.pdf
content:
Abstract: Additive manufacturing is a rapidly developing manufacturing technology of great potential for applications. One of the merits of AM is that the microstructure of manufactured materials can be actively controlled to meet engineering requirements. In this work, three types of Ti-6Al-4V (TC4) materials with different porosities are manufactured using selective laser melting using different printing parameters. Their dynamic behaviors are then studied by planar impact experiments based on the fre-surface velocity measurements and shock-recovery characterizations. Experimental results indicate that the porosity significantly affects their dynamic response,including not only the yield, but also spall behaviors. With the increasing porosity, the Hugoniot elastic limit and spall strength decrease monotonically. In the case of TC4 of a large porosity, itbehaves similar to energy-absorbing materials, in which the voids collpse under shock compression and then the spallation takes place.

Keywords: additive manufacturing; Ti-6Al-4V; dynamic behaviors; porosity; spall
summary: Article Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys - Part 2/2

name: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys-part-3
fileName: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys.pdf
content:
Additive manufacturing (AM) technology has a series of technical advantages such as rapid prototyping, free manufacturing, and high material utilization, thus showing great development potentials and broad application prospects in automation industry [1,2], aerospace [3,4], shipbuilding, biotechnology [5], automobile [6], parts processing [7], and other fields [8,9]. Several critical reviews regarding AM technological innovation processes have been published [10-13]. Recently, AM technology has shown one advantage which is even more attractive-that is, it can actively manipulate the microstructure of materials by adjusting printing parameters and strategies, such that some unique and excellent mechanical properties could be designed for specific applications. For example,AM components with special microstructures such as honeycomb and gradient can significantly improve heat transfer and anti-collision performance [9,14].

In many engineering cases, the mechanical properties of materials under dynamic loading are of importance and have been approved to be sensitive to the internal microstructure [15-17]. Therefore, there is an urgent demand to employ AM technology to control the microstructures, and then to manipulate the macroscopic dynamic properties of materials. By far, only a few works are available to study the dynamic response of AM materials, especially on the effect of porosity produced during printing. For instance, Valdez et al. induced various levels of porosity in Super Alloy 718 by modifying the powder bed fusion process including laser power, scan velocity, and hatch spacing,and then investigated their dynamic behaviors [18,19]. Their results show that, in the presence of high porosity, porous materials perform much like open-cell foams and are highly sensitive to densification.

name: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys-part-4
fileName: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys.pdf
content:
Branch et al. demonstrated shock wave modulation or "spatially graded-flow" in shock wave experiments via controlling AM techniques at the micron scale by using time-resolved X-ray imaging [20]. Gangireddy et al. discovered that porous sandwich Ti-6Al-4V (TC4) AM samples exhibited greater energy absorption per unit volume than fully dense samples using split-Hopkinson Pressure Bar (SHPB) testing [21]. However, there is still a lack of systematic understanding of the effect of porosity on the dynamic mechanical properties of AM materials.

In order to better understand the effect of porosity on the dynamic response, in this work, we prepare three TC4 specimens of different porosities by using different printing parameters in the Selective Laser Melting (SLM) process and then carry out a series of planar impact experiments to investigate their dynamic behaviors. Results demonstrate that dynamic mechanical properties, including the Hugoniot elastic limit and spall strength, are significantly affected by the porosity. A small difference in porosity could remarkably reduce the dynamic properties. Depending on the porosity, the materials may present a good energy absorption capability.

The particle size of the used powder is $1 5 { \sim } 4 5 \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ which was measured by scanning electron microscope (SEM) as shown in Figure 1. The chemical composition of TC4 powder and workpiece is listed in Table 1. The porosity is controlled by adjusting the printing parameters, including scan velocity, laser power, and hatch spacing,as given in Table 2. The printing parameters are chosen based on the Refs. [22-25]. The stack of layers is along the Z-axis with the layer thickness of $3 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and the scanning strategy of $4 5 ^ { \circ }$ rotation between layers. ![](images/dc218ddf4da7b1394f3b1535cb5fda66ad77d92eb6340b8886a071eb67738a29.jpg) Figure 1. To quantify the porosity of the samples, the micro-morphology of three samples is analyzed by optical microscopy (OM),as shown in the left column of Figure 2. It is obvious that the porosity of the three samples increases from $\mathrm { T 1 }$ to T3. The average pore sizes of T1, T2, and T3 samples are $1 . 8 \ \mu \mathrm { m } , 3 . 2 \ \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ and $8 1 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ respectively. Using the drainage method,we determine the density $( \rho _ { 0 } )$ of each sample and then calculate the porosity according to $( 1 \mathrm { - } \rho _ { 0 } / \rho _ { d } )$ ,where $\rho _ { d }$ is the density of dense wrought TC4. As given in Table 2, the samples T1-T3 have the porosity of $0 . 2 9 \%$ $0 . 8 8 \%$ ,and $5 . 4 1 \%$ ,respectively. ![](images/f04514fdcc76f8f6fe58664d51556908670a569087c9dede265e1bebabe42e2a.jpg) Figure 2. Optical microscopy (left),EBSD (middle),and band-contrast images (right) of the SLM Ti-6Al-4V materials studied. name: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys-part-7
fileName: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys.pdf
content:
The inverse pole-figure obtained via electron backscatter detection (EBSD),shown in the middle column of Figure 2, presents needle-shaped textures, indicating the existence of acicular $\propto$ martensite [26,27]. The size of acicular $\propto$ martensite for all three samples is almost the same, with an average grain width of $1 . 9 \mathrm { - } 2 . 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ and a length of $1 0 { - } 1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ Further, acicular $\propto$ martensite forms complex $\beta$ columnar grains which appear along the building direction with the size of $1 0 0 \mathrm { s } ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ . Continuous grain boundaries are observed in three band-contrast images,as marked by the red dotted line shown in the right column of Figure 2 [28,29].

The acoustic velocities (longitudinal wave velocity, $C _ { L } ,$ and shear wave velocity, $C _ { s }$ of each sample are determined by using the pulse-echo method, respectively. Then, the bulk sound velocity, $C _ { 0 } ,$ is calculated by

$$
C _ { 0 } = \sqrt { C _ { L } ^ { 2 } - \frac { 4 } { 3 } C _ { s } ^ { 2 } }
$$

All these results are listed in Table 2.

Figure 3 presents the sample textures. It shows that the samples represent a stronger texture in the {100} orientation than that of {110} and {111} orientations. The maximum texture intensities of T1, T2,and T3 samples observed in the {100} orientation are 42.85, 32.13,and 59.18, respectively, indicating that T3 has the most concentrated texture. This is because the change in printing parameters leads to different cooling rates and grain growth mechanisms, resulting in different grain orientations and texture intensities [30].

![](images/865a93c8665fd1d303a4e53ab6e19f68a94eaf8aebecf656692aa7ba13f02c97.jpg)  
Figure 3.Pole figure maps of SLM Ti-6Al-4V materials studied.

name: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys-part-8
fileName: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys.pdf
content:
# 3. Shock-Wave Experiments and Results


# 3.1.Planar Impact Experiments
Planar impact experiments were performed on a single-stage gas gun with a caliber of $1 4 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ . Figure 4a schematically shows the experiment configuration for measuring the free-surface particle velocity history. SLM TC4 samples were wire-cut to $1 . 8 \mathrm { m m }$ in thickness and $1 2 \mathrm { m m }$ in diameter for experiments to make sure that the shock compression was along the z-axis. The oxygen-free copper flyer plate was $0 . 9 \mathrm { m m }$ in thickness to drive tensile damage in the center of the TC4 sample. The impact speeds of the flyer impact are

$5 0 0 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }$ and $6 2 0 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }$ , respectively. A Doppler Pin System (DPS) was used to probe the free-surface particle velocity [31-33]. Figure 4b shows the configuration for shock-recovery experiments. To prevent possible secondary damage during shock recovery, a stainless-steel recovery cabin filled with low-density vacuum-sealing putty was used to capture the target samples after dynamic tensile.

![](images/b07f01496ceb50d029d4498db74f53fec7c78696d5e44e8f4ff8c0aad2fb27bc.jpg)  
Figure 4. Experimental configurations for (a) free-surface particle velocity measurements and (b) shock-recovery characterizations. A Cu flyer is launched by a single-stage gas gun to produce spall damage in TC4 samples. DPS is used to monitor the free-surface velocity profile. A recovery cabin is used to capture the target sample for shock-recovery characterizations.
summary: 3. Shock-Wave Experiments and Results, 3.1.Planar Impact Experiments

name: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys-part-9
fileName: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys.pdf
content:
Figure 5 presents the free-surface particle velocity profiles for all the samples and at two different impact speeds. For samples T1 and T2, the velocity profiles show an obvious elastic-plastic transition during loading. The Hugoniot elastic limit $( \sigma _ { H E L } )$ is, thus, calculated by

$$
\sigma _ { H E L } = \frac { 1 } { 2 } \rho _ { 0 } C _ { L } u _ { H E L } ,
$$

where $\sigma _ { H E L }$ is the velocity at the transition point. It is clear in Figure 6a that $\sigma _ { H E L } ,$ for the sample T1, is bigger than that of T2, suggesting that an increase in porosity leads to a decrease in $\sigma _ { H E L }$ . The difference in $\sigma _ { H E L }$ between the two samples is about $0 . 3 8 \mathrm { { \sim } } 0 . 8 3 \mathrm { { G P a } }$ (that is, $1 3 \% { \sim } 2 7 \%$ ), depending on the impact velocity.

![](images/43d3ecd453cf2c608726541530e9264bd40fa99c0d6ee1dcb1ed161a76a236b1.jpg)  
Figure 5. Free-surface particle velocity profiles of three SLM TC4 samples obtained in planar plate experiments at the impact velocity of (a) $5 0 0 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }$ and (b) $6 2 0 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }$ ：

![](images/47dcf6d7e1077ad940d374db5c714d7ffc62622b537bf2b14eee3ce3ba1f557d.jpg)  
Figure 6.Hugoniot elastic limit (a) and spall strength (b) of three different TC4 materials produced by SLM. Sample number and loading velocities are indicated on each bar.

We can also calculate the spall strength $( \sigma _ { s p a l l } )$ based on the observed 'pullback' signal in the free-surface velocity profiles, which is caused by the spallation damage when two rarefaction waves originated from the flyer's rear free surface and the sample's free surface, by

$$
\sigma _ { s p a l l } = \rho _ { 0 } C _ { L } \Delta u _ { f s } \frac { 1 } { 1 + \frac { C _ { L } } { C _ { 0 } } } ,
$$

name: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys-part-10
fileName: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys.pdf
content:
where $\Delta u _ { f s }$ is the difference of the free surface velocity from the peak value to the first minima,as indicated in Figure 5. The calculated results are shown in Figure 6b. This demonstrates that, although the porosity difference between the two samples is only $0 . 5 9 \%$ the difference in the spall strength is more than $2 5 \%$ . Therefore, the porosity produced during printing significantly affects the dynamic response, including both the yield and spall behaviors. Compared with wrought TC4 $( 5 . 2 8 \mathrm { G P a } )$ [22], the spall strength of SLM TC4 is much smaller. The degradation in the spall strength might be due to the combined contrition of the pores and microstructure. It is well known that the microstructures of SLM and wrought materials could be remarkably different. In this work, however, it is impossible to identify which is playing the dominant role.

For sample T3, the free-surface velocity profile is extremely different from that of samples T1 and T2. The free-surface velocity increases gradually and no shock wave is formed. This is due to the compaction of numerous voids under dynamic compression. Note that, at the impact velocity of $5 0 0 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }$ , the peak free-surface velocity is remarkably lower than that of the samples T1 and T2, while at $6 2 0 \mathrm { m } / s$ the peak velocity is almost the same as the ones in samples T1 and T2. It thus suggests that the voids in the sample T3 are completely compacted and the sample becomes dense at higher shock pressure.

name: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys-part-11
fileName: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys.pdf
content:
The Hugoniot elastic limit and spal strength of the sample T3, as shown in Figure 6, are calculated by using Equations (2) and (3), respectively. Results demonstrate that, as expected,both $\sigma _ { H E L }$ and $\sigma _ { s p a l l }$ of the sample T3 are further lowered due to the large porosity. Based on the above comparison, it is concluded that the increase in porosity markedly reduces the Hugoniot elastic limit and spal strength of SLM TC4 materials, thus degrading their mechanical performance.

Jones et al. have also investigated the spall strength of SLM TC4 [22]. In the case of the loading direction parallel to the printing one which is the same as us, SLM TC4 samples had the spall strengths of $3 . 0 3 \mathrm { G P a }$ and $3 . 3 4 \mathrm { G P a }$ at the impact velocities of $3 1 0 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }$ and $4 1 5 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s } ,$ , respectively. In comparison with our result, we speculate that SLM TC4 materials used in Ref. [22] may have a porosity of more than $0 . 5 \%$

name: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys-part-12
fileName: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys.pdf
content:
To further understand the dynamic behaviors of shocked materials, shock-recovered samples were characterized by using OM, as shown in Figure 7. At the impact velocity of $5 0 0 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }$ , no cracks are visible in sample T1, while in the samples T2 and T3 there exist obvious isolated cracks. Some cracks have rounded tips, suggesting the coalescence of voids [34,35]. Such an observation is somehow inconsistent with the observed velocity profiles in which the spallation occurs in the samples T1 and T2. We atribute this inconsistency to the incomplete spallation in sample $\mathrm { T 1 }$ because it has a higher resistance to dynamic tension than the samples T2 and T3 as indexed by the spall strength. In the sample T3 recovered, the collapse of voids is clearly observed, providing direct evidence for the shock-driven compaction. At the impact velocity of $6 2 0 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }$ complete spallation takes place in all three samples, thus obvious spallation damages are visible. In the sample T1, a large number of small cracks with a length of less than $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ locate at the zone with a width of $2 7 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . While in the samples T2 and T3, the damage region expands significantly, suggesting that cracks originate from widely distributed voids.

![](images/f3e342ad5296b5e969a7b22e6a5e81f0acf6e9dda195a91cbc248763d05d537f.jpg)  
Figure 7. Optical metallography of three SLM TC4 samples shock-recovered at the impact velocity of (a-c) $5 0 0 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }$ and (d-f) $6 2 0 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }$

name: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys-part-13
fileName: 2022 - Micromachines - Cui et al. - Effect of Porosity on Dynamic Response of Additive Manufacturing Ti-6Al-4V Alloys.pdf
content:
# 4. Conclusions
We have printed TC4 materials with diferent porosities by designing the printer parameters and experimentally investigated the effect of porosity on the dynamic response of SLM TC4 materials. Experimental results indicate that:

SLM TC4 with different porosities show observably different dynamic characteristics in the free-surface particle velocity profiles. The increase in porosity significantly degrades the dynamic mechanical properties, including the Hugoniot elastic limit and the spall strength. . Dense samples show better tensile-resistant properties than porous samples, while porous samples show a good energy absorption capability than dense samples. Shock-recovery characterizations indicate that, in porous samples, void collapse and energy absorption occur in the impact stage and cracks mainly originate from widely distributed voids.

Therefore, materials with various dynamic properties can be produced by selecting certain printing parameters. This work may guide AM technology to design materials for certain applications under extreme conditions.

All authors have read and agreed to the published version of the manuscript.

# ABSTRACT
Keywords:   
Ball milling

Microstructure   
Mechanical properties

In this study,influences of the processing parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti parts fabricated by selective laser melting (SLM) using ballmilled powders were investigated systematically.Singletracks experiment indicated that when significant depth $\operatorname { \rho d } _ { \operatorname { i n t } } )$ of the molten pool overlap area was greater than $6 8 . 4 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and a high-quality morphology of the molten pool was formed,fully dense SLM-ed samples can be obtained.The tensile strength and elongation of SLM-ed samples fabricated at different process parameters were in the range of 940-985 MPa and $9 . 5 \mathrm { - } 1 7 . 3 \%$ ,respectively.When the laser beam power,scan speed and hatch spacing were $1 7 5 \ \mathrm { W }$ $6 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ，and $0 . 0 9 \ \mathrm { m m }$ ,respectively,the samples exhibited the highest mechanical properties with a tensile strength of $9 8 5 . 4 \mathrm { M P a }$ and an elongation of $1 7 . 3 \%$ ,which exceeded the ASTM B265-15 Ti-6Al-4V alloy level.The outcomes of this work have facilitated in developing titanium parts using low-cost modified HDH-Ti powder,and have also opened many dimensions for future investigations.
summary: The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabricated by selective laser melting using ball milled powders 前言

name: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr-part-2
fileName: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr.pdf
content: Due to rapid production,high materials utilization rate and flexibility in forming complex shapes,additive manufacturing (AM) has gained considerable attention compared with the other fabrication technologies such as casting,forging,powdermetallurgy,spark plasma sintering,and hot press [1-5].In several AM technologies,selective laser melting (SLM) is regarded as the most promising method for fabricating parts with intricate structures due to its high manufacturing precision.In addition,rapid solidification processing also makes the microstructure of SLM-ed samples finer and more homogeneous,which results in excellent mechanical properties [6-9].Due to their characteristics of high specific strength,remarkable thermal stability,and excellent biocompatibility,titanium(Ti) and its alloys are widely used in the fields of aerospace,defense,marine,and biomedical.[10-15]. Considering the advantages of SLM technology,lots of Ti-based alloys, such as pure Ti, Ti-6Al-4V, Ti-Ta, Ti-Nb-Zr, Ti-Nb-Zr-Sn,are fabricated and studied recently [16-26].

name: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr-part-3
fileName: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr.pdf
content:
In general, spherical powder is recommended as the raw material for the SLM process due to its high flowability,which is usually produced by either gas atomization (GA) or electrode induction melting-gas atomization (EIGA)[1].Nevertheless,the fine spherical powders used for SLM are not cost-effective.Compared with atomized spherical powders, irregular hydrogenated dehydrogenated (HDH) powders are finegrained and cost-effective.However,low flowability inhibits their extensive applications for SLM.In order to meet the SLM process requirements，ball milling technology was used to improve the morphology of irregular HDH powder by our group previously [27].Ball milling is a technology that usually was used to modify the morphology of powders [28-32].After ball milling of $4 \mathrm { h }$ ,the particles become nearspherical with no obvious angularity,and the powders have optimal flowability with the tap density of $2 . { \dot { 1 0 } } { \mathrm { g } } / { \mathrm { c m } } ^ { 3 }$ and Carr's index of 77.74, which meet the SLM process requirements [32]. The modified powders were then used to fabricate the samples,and fully dense sample could be obtained using this kind of powder.In addition,compared with the samples using spherical powder,the samples fabricated using the modified powder exhibited higher strength and elongation,which were $8 7 6 . 1 \pm 2 0 . 5$ MPa and $1 4 . 7 \% \pm 0 . 5 \%$ ,respectively [4,19,27].

As iswell known,microstructure and mechanical properties of SLMed parts are highly affected by the process parameters [4,5,33,34]. For instance,Wysocki [34] fabricated the high-performance commercially pure Ti (CP-Ti) through adjusting the process parameters,and the fracture strength of fabricated samples was nearly1.7 times of ASTM B265-15 Grade 3 CP-Ti while the elongation was basically the same.As mentioned fore,the modified low-cost near-spherical Ti powders could meet the requirements of SLM,but the powder characteristics,such as morphology，apparent density are different from spherical powders. This can lead to different laser absorption rates and refractive rates of powder bed.Thus,a different set of SLM process parameters may be required to obtain optimized mechanical properties.Consequently,it is worth investigating the effects of SLM process parameters on the microstructure and mechanical properties of SLM-ed Ti parts using modified HDH-Ti powders. In this paper, the influences of process parameters on the singletracks,microstructure,mechanical properties of Ti parts fabricated by SLM using modified HDH-Ti powder were investigated systematically. The aim is to obtain the optimized SLM process parameters for fabricating high-performance CP-Ti using low-cost modified HDH-Ti powder. This will also help in promoting applications of low-cost SLM-ed CP-Ti parts in the different engineering fields.

name: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr-part-5
fileName: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr.pdf
content:
# 2.1．Raw materials
Hydride-dehydride titanium (HDH-Ti) powder supplied by a commercial company (Tian Tai Long Tech. Co., Ltd. China) were used in this study (Fig.1(a)). The raw Ti powders exhibited highly irregularity with sharp edges and corners.To improve the flowability,the powders were modified by ball milling,and SEM of modified powder was shown in Fig.l(b).After ball milling,the powders became near-spherical without sharp angularity,and the median particle size $( \mathrm { D } _ { 5 0 } )$ was $3 2 . 2 1 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ (Fig.1(c)).The details of the ball milling process are as follows: the raw powders were milled lasting $^ { 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ in ultra-high purity argon atmosphere within a planetary ball mill,involving ball milling tanks made of bearing steel GCrl5 and stainless balls with the diameter of $6 \mathrm { m m }$ ,with a ball-tomaterial ratio of 5:1 and a rotation speed of $2 0 0 ~ \mathrm { r / m i n }$ [27,35]. Also, properties of the modified powder, the impurity element content in the powder and SLM-ed component were listed in Table 1.After milling, the flow rate reached $4 5 . 8 \ \pm \ 1 . 3 \ s / 5 0 \ g ,$ and can satisfy the SLM requirement.

name: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr-part-6
fileName: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr.pdf
content:
# 2.2.SLM process
A commercial selective laser melting machine (SLM Solution $1 2 5 ^ { \mathrm { H L } }$ Germany) equipped with a modulated 4oo W fiber laser and a maximum forming volume of $1 2 5 \times 1 2 5 \times 1 2 5 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ (length $\times$ width $\times$ thickness) was employed to fabricate samples.The beam spot and thickness of the metal powder layer were selected at $7 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $3 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,respectively.The ultra-high purity argon gas was filled in the build chamber and the oxygen concentration was kept less than $0 . 0 5 \%$ $\left( \mathrm { w t \% } \right)$ throughout the printing process.The platform was preheated to $2 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ to reduce warpage in the produced samples due to a sharp temperature gradient. In the single-tracks experiment,different values of laser power (P) of 75,125,175 and 225 W and scan speeds $\mathbf { \rho } ( \mathbf { v } )$ of 300,600,900,and 1200 $\mathrm { { \ m m } } / s$ were selected to obtain single-tracks with the length of $5 \ \mathrm { m m }$ Samples of $6 0 \times 1 0 \times 1 0 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ ，which used the same with P and v of single-tracks experiment and hatch distances of 0.o9,O.12,O.15,and $0 . 1 8 \mathrm { \ m m }$ ，were manufactured by a layer-by-layer method with the mutual angle of $6 7 ^ { \circ }$

# 2.3.Microstructure characterizations
The morphologies of the single-tracks were observed by LEO 1450 scanning electron microscope (SEM) and a metallrgical microscope, respectively. The pool width was measured by the software of FZRS2018 at different locations and an average value was taken. JSM6480LV scanning electron microscope was used to observe the microstructure.The samples were prepared by grinding,mechanically polishing，and etching with the Krol's etchant.A SmartLab X-ray diffractometer with a scanning rate of $2 ^ { \circ } / \mathrm { m i n }$ and a scanning angle of $3 0 { \cdot } 9 0 ^ { \circ }$ was used for phase identification.

name: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr-part-8
fileName: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr.pdf
content:
SLM is a layer-by-layer processing technology,and the quality of products is affected by each single track and each single layer. In every layer,the quality of the single-tracks melts pool influences the layer directly and hence,is evaluated firstly in this study.Laser power and scanning speed,as two major processing parameters of SLM,significantly affect the quality of the single-tracks melt pool.Hence,a $4 \times 4$ orthogonal experiment, as presented in Table 2,was designed to study the influence of these two parameters on the molten pool.

Fig.2 presents SEM micrographs of single-tracks with different laser beam powers and scan speeds.As can be seen, the pool width increased gradually with the decrease of scan speed from $1 2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ to $3 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ and increase of laser power from 75 W to 225 W.When the scan speed and laser power were $3 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ and 225 W,respectively, the width of the pool reached the value highest of $3 7 4 . 1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (Fig.2(b)). The increase in the width of the pool was mainly related to the linear energy density (LED).At a constant scanning speed,the LED increases with laser power. On the contrary,ata constant laser powder,the LED decreases with scan speed.The higher LED leads to a higher temperature of the molten pool, which leads to melting of more powder and hence,increases the width of the molten pool.
summary: 3.1．Morphology and width of the single-tracks melt pool - Part 1/3

name: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr-part-9
fileName: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr.pdf
content:
Additionally,a continuous single-tracks molten pool with fish-scale characteristics can be formed at low laser power or high laser power with low scan speed (Fig. 2(a). It is worth noting that balling caused by Plateau-Rayleigh instability was not formed with a low laser power of 75 W.This is mainly caused by powder laser absorptivity.By testing, the laserabsorptivity of modified powderis O.71,which is higher significantly than that of spherical powder (O.6) [38].The higher laser absorptivity can inhibit balling formed as even at low energy input.When the laser power is $2 2 5 ~ \mathrm { W }$ and scan speed is in the range of 6oo-1200 $\mathbf { m m } / s _ { \mathrm { i } }$ ,the surfaces of the single-tracks showed arc-shaped protrusions and balling,as marked by the yellow circle and red arrow in Fig.2(a). This was related to the viscosity $( \mu )$ ,flow and thermocapillary force of the melt in the molten pool. The $\mu$ of melt can be calculated using the following equation [5]:

$$
\mu = \frac { 1 6 } { 1 5 } \sqrt { \frac { m } { k _ { B } T } } \sigma
$$
summary: 3.1．Morphology and width of the single-tracks melt pool - Part 2/3

name: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr-part-10
fileName: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr.pdf
content: where m, kB,T and $\sigma$ are the atomic mass,Boltzmann constant (J/K), molten pool temperature (K),and surface tension of the liquid $\mathrm { ( N / m ) }$ respectively.At a constant scanning speed, the energy received by the molten pool increased with laser power increasing,leading to an increase in the temperature of the molten pool. From the formula (l),it can be seen that any increase in temperature of the molten pool leads to reduced $\mu$ [39,40].In addition,as the constant of laser power, the increase in scanning speed gives rise to the increase of temperature gradient in the molten pool [39].This induces a high gradient of surface tension in the molten pool with a high scanning speed,and resultant Marangoni convection [5,39]. The formation of such convection increases the thermocapillary force and resulting in the instability of molten pool [5]．Consequently,the higher scanning speed means stronger Marangoni convection and greater thermocapillary force within molten pool,which reduces the stability of the molten pool significantly [41-45].Taken together,the combined influence of the decrease in $\mu ,$ the strengthen Marangoni convection and the enhancement thermocapillary force increased the instability of the molten pool and hence,formed arc-shaped protrusions and balling.Thus,when the laser power reaches 225 W and scan speed is in the range of 6oo-1200 $\mathrm { m m } / s$ ，an instable molten pool forms,resulting in arc-shaped protrusions and balling.
summary: 3.1．Morphology and width of the single-tracks melt pool - Part 3/3

name: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr-part-12
fileName: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr.pdf
content:
Fig.3(a) shows the relative densities of block parts with different SLM process parameters.The low relative density of these three samples was mainly due to narrow pool width and relatively wide hatch distance, resulting in fewer overlaps between adjacent tracks.In general,the high line energy density can cause the formation of keyhole.In order to verify if the keyhole affects the density of SLM-ed parts in this study.The keyhole threshold was calculated based on the keyhole mode threshold criteria $\begin{array} { r } { ( \frac { P } { \sqrt { V } } \geq \frac { \sqrt { \left( \pi d \right) ^ { 3 } } } { \sqrt { D } A } T _ { b } K ) } \end{array}$ ， and it is determined to be $4 8 2 . 8 ~ \mathrm { W \cdot ( m / s ) ^ { - } }$ 0.5[7]. In this study,the keyhole valueis lower than the_keyhole threshold even with a parameter of 225 W and $3 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ .Thus,the keyhole was not formed in this study,and did not affect the density of component.

In order to further investigate the influence of process parameters on the relative density of SLM-processed parts comprehensively,an evaluation parameter, significant depth $\mathrm { ( d _ { i n t } ) }$ of molten pool overlap area was introduced. The $\mathbf { d } _ { \mathrm { { i n t } } }$ can be calculated by hatch distance and width of the molten pool,as the following equation shows [46]:

$$
d _ { i n t } = \sqrt { R _ { m } ^ { 2 } - \frac { d _ { s } ^ { 2 } } { 4 } }
$$

where $\mathrm { R } _ { \mathrm { m } }$ is the radius of the molten pool, $\mu \mathrm { m }$ ,which is equal to half of the molten pool width in value; ${ \bf d } _ { s }$ is the distance between the centers of two adjacent molten pools, $\mu \mathrm { m }$ ,which is equal to the hatch distance in value.
summary: 3.2.SLM processing window of modified HDH-Ti powder - Part 2/3

name: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr-part-13
fileName: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr.pdf
content: As shown in Fig.3(b), the minimum $\mathbf { d } _ { \mathrm { { i n t } } }$ at which the relative density of fabricated parts reaches more than $9 9 \%$ was $6 8 . 4 9 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ In theory, when the $\mathtt { d } _ { \mathrm { i n t } }$ is greater than the layer thickness ( $3 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in this study), the SLM-ed parts can be dense [44].However, the minimum $\mathtt { d } _ { \mathrm { i n t } }$ should be greater than $6 8 . 4 9 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ in this study.This is due to the raw material of modified HDH-Ti powders with near-spherical shapes being used in the present study,which makes the molten pool not an ideal hemisphere [47].The change in the shape of the molten pool increased the ${ \mathrm { { d } } _ { \mathrm { { i n t } } } } .$ Additionally,it is worth noting that the relative density of three points as marked by the circle in Fig.3(b) was less than $9 9 \%$ although the $\mathtt { d } _ { \mathrm { i n t } }$ was greater than $6 8 . 4 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .This is mainly related to the morphology of the molten pool.Arc-shaped protrusions and balling phenomenon appeared atthese three points,which lowers the density of fabricated products.It is worth concluding here that,to obtain high-density SLM-ed parts (relative density greater than $9 9 \%$ )using modified HDH Ti powders two conditions must be met: 1） high-quality single-tracks without protrusions and balling; 2) the $\mathbf { d } _ { \mathrm { { i n t } } }$ greater than $6 8 . 4 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .According to the above results,4 sets of parameters meet the requirements,as shown in Table 4,and microstructure and mechanical properties were focused on the samples fabricated under these parameters.
summary: 3.2.SLM processing window of modified HDH-Ti powder - Part 3/3

Fig. 4(a) shows XRD patterns of raw powder and samples A, B, C, D, respectively. It can be seen that the XRD patterns of all samples were similar and only peaks of hexagonal-closed pack titanium (hcp-Ti) exist. Nevertheless,as shown in Fig.4(b),compared with that of the raw powders,XRD patterns in the small 20 angles range exhibited that the exact 20 locations of the diffraction peaks of all samples had a slight deviation.Lattice parameters of a and c of four samples calculated by XRD were $0 . 2 9 3 4 2 \mathrm { n m }$ and $0 . 4 6 7 9 6 \mathrm { n m }$ ,respectively.Thisagreedwith the values in previous study given for $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ phase $\mathtt { \Omega } = 0 . 2 9 3 1 3 \mathrm { { n m } }$ and ${ \mathfrak { c } } =$ $0 . 4 6 8 1 3 \mathrm { n m }$ [27,33,48]. Thus, the phase formed in samples A,B, C,and D was the $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ phase.This was mainly related to the SLM process.In the SLM process,there is a very high heating/cooling rate $( 1 0 ^ { 3 } – 1 0 ^ { 8 } ~ \mathrm { K } / \ s )$ which leads to the non-equilibrium $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ phase formation. name: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr-part-16
fileName: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr.pdf
content: Fig.5 shows the microstructure of samples A,B,C,and D as observed by SEM. It can be seen that all samples were close to full density.The microstructure of all samples can be characterized by the acicular $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ phase,and there was no significant difference except for grain size.The grain size of samples A,B,C,D was compared in Fig.6.It should be noted that the width and length of the grain size of four samples were in the range of $2 . 1 1 - 5 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $1 3 . 5 \mathrm { - } 3 0 . 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,respectively.Among them, the grain size of sample A was the finest with a width of $2 . 1 1 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ and length of $1 3 . 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ 、This was mainly related to the LED.The LED of samples A, B, C,and D was $2 9 1 . 7 \mathrm { J / m }$ $4 1 6 . 6 \mathrm { J / m }$ $5 8 3 . 3 \mathrm { J / m }$ $7 5 0 \mathrm { J / m } ,$ respectively.Decreasing LED reduces the accumulation of heat inside the molten pool.This enhances the thermal gradient,which in turn increases the thermodynamic and kinetic undercooling of the molten pool, resulting in an increase of the solidification rate [5,39].The increased solidification rate results in forming finer $\beta$ grain (the initial grain of the $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ phase transformation),and hence can form finer $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ phase. In addition, the grain growth was inhibited due to the increase in cooling rate during the process of the $\beta$ phase transforms to martensitic $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ phase [5].Taken together,compared with other samples,sample A with higher solidification rate exhibits the finest grain.

name: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr-part-17
fileName: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr.pdf
content: The hardness and typical tensile stress-strain curves of four samples are shown in Fig.7.As Fig.7(a) shows, the hardness of the four samples was in the range of 275-3oo HV,which was higher than the as-casted CP-Ti $[ - 1 8 0 \ \mathrm { H V } )$ and SLM-ed CP-Ti with spherical powders ( ${ \sim } 2 4 0$ HV)[19,49].The tensile strength of four samples increased from 940 MPa to 985 MPa while the elongation was in the range of $9 . 5 \mathrm { - } 1 7 . 3 \%$ (Fig.7(b)).Among them,sample A exhibited the highest mechanical properties with a tensile strength of $9 8 5 . 4 \mathrm { M P a }$ and elongation of $1 7 . 3 \%$ which is higher thanas-casted CP-Ti and SLM-ed CP-Ti with spherical powders (a width of $\sim 6 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and length of \~ $4 5 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ [19,49]. In general, the difference on the mechanical properties of fully dense Ti component mainly relate to grain size,interstitial element content,dislocation density and phase composition [9].In this study,four samples showed similar interstitial element content as the same level.In addition,based on the Williamson-Hall theory, the dislocation density of SLM-ed parts with different LED ranged from 2.41 to $2 . 6 1 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 5 } \mathrm { m } ^ { - 2 }$ ,and has no significant difference [8,9].Hence, the excellent mechanical property mainly attributed to the phase and grain size.The microstructure of four samples consisted of martensitic $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ phase,which had higher hardness than the $\alpha$ phase.In addition, the finer grain size of CP-Ti also improved the properties.As mentioned before,the lower the LED,the finer grain size.Compared with spherical powders,the modified powders had a higher laser absorptivity,which results in lower energy input to obtain the densified Ti parts and hence exhibited a finer grain size [50].

name: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr-part-18
fileName: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr.pdf
content:
Fig.8 compares the optimized mechanical properties of CP-Ti samples in this study and other Ti and its alloys fabricated by SLM using near and spherical powders,and conventional manufacturing technologies, such as casting and forging.It can be seen that the fabricated Ti part in this study provides outstanding strength-ductility synergy as compared to the literature.The strength of optimized CP-Ti parts is nearly 2 times compared to ASTM B265-15 Grade 3 CP-Ti for the same elongation. Noticeably,the mechanical properties of CP-Ti parts fabricated in this study even exceed the ASTMB265-15 Ti-6Al-4Valloy level.The reason for the excellent performance of the SLM-ed part using modified HDH powders in this study is mainly due to the process optimization,which resulted in full acicular $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ phase microstructure with fine grain size in the fabricated parts.As a result, this study further improved the mechanical properties of CP-Ti fabricated by SLMusing low-cost modified HDH-Ti powder through process optimization.This outcome not only establishes optimized process windows for SLM-ed parts using modified low-cost HDH powders but also can facilitate in developing of CP-Ti parts in different engineering fields.

![](images/48d6affde6f20a765344bcc591ade14ff9d9f91cd5f3ba6adeeaad5489844d43.jpg)  
Fig.8. Comparison of the mechanical properties among typical Ti materials [16,19,27,39,49-58].

![](images/47481ff7b2adb065ea6277f1e658b1bbc8c258e7197aba261370c7c6e981261b.jpg)  
Fig.7.Hardness (a) and engineering stress-strain curves (b) of samples A,B, C, D.

name: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr-part-19
fileName: 2022 - Optics and Laser Technology - Chen et al. - The effect of process parameters on the physical and mechanical properties of Ti fabr.pdf
content:
# 4.Conclusion
In the present study,the effects of laser power,scan speed,and hatch distance on the width and morphology of single-tracks,densification, microstructure，and mechanical properties of SLM-ed CP-Ti using modified HDH-Ti powders were investigated.The main conclusions are as follows:

(1) 5.Width of single-tracks increased with an increase in laser power and a decrease in scan speed. A fish-scale shape continuous molten pool formed when laser power of 75-225 W and scan speed of $3 0 0 { - } 1 2 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ were applied were applied.   
(2) 6.SLM-ed parts with relative density higher than $9 9 \%$ using modified HDH-Ti powders can be obtained when when highquality single-tracks without protrusions or balling formed and the $\mathtt { d } _ { \mathrm { i n t } }$ was greater than $6 8 . 4 9 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$   
(3) 7.The SLM-ed parts all consisted of a full fine martensite $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ phase. The obtained optimized mechanical properties of CP-Ti parts with a tensile strength of $9 8 5 . 4 \ \mathrm { M P a }$ and elongation of $1 7 . 3 \%$ exceeded the ASTMB265-15 Ti-6Al-4Valloy level.

# ARTICLEINFO
summary: In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer single-track laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-2
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content:
# ABSTRACT
Keywords:   
Additive manufacturing Surface roughness   
Laser powder bed fusion Rayleigh Taylor instability Lack of fusion

Surface roughness controls the mechanical performance and durability (e.g.,wear and corrosion resistance) of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF)components.The evolution mechanisms of surface roughness during LPBF are not well understood due to a lack of in situ characterisation methods.Here,we quantified key processes and defect dynamics using synchrotron X-ray imaging and ex situ optical imaging and explained the evolution mechanisms of side-skin and top-skin roughness during multi-layer LPBF of Ti-6Al-4V (where down-skin roughness was out of the project scope).We found that the average surface roughness alone is not an accurate representation of surface topology of an LPBF component and that the surface topology is multimodal (e.g., containing both roughness and waviness) and multiscale (e.g., from $2 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ sintered powder features to $2 5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ molten pool wavelength).Both roughness and topologyare significantly affcted bythe formation of pre-layer humping,spatter,and rippling defects.We developed a surface topology matrix that accurately describes surface features by combining 8 diferent metrics: average roughness,root mean square roughness,maximum profile peak height,maximum profile valley height,mean height,mean width,skewness,and melt pool size ratio.This matrix provides a guide to determine the appropriate linear energy density to achieve the optimum surface finish of Ti-6Al-4V thin-wall builds.This work lays a foundation for surface texture control which is critical for build design,metrology,and performance in LPBF.

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-3
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content:
Laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) additive manufacturing (AM is a digital manufacturing process that produces complex metallic components with excellent mechanical properties owing to the grain structure and reduction in phase segregation under rapid solidification [1-3]. The “as-built”LPBF parts often exhibit rough surfaces [4],requiring additional post-processing steps to achieve a desired surface finish [5]:this increases lead time and development cost. Many post-processing methods,including heat treatment [6],hot isotropic pressing [7],ultrasonic nanocrystal surface modification [6]，advanced finishing machining [8] and laser polishing [9],have been used to improve the surface finish and eliminate residual stresses in “as-built”components [10].Roughness control on AM parts is vital as surface roughness has its advantages and disadvantages depending on the end-user applications, e.g.controlled roughness can promote bond formation between implants and the human body[11,l2],whereas surface irregularities can lead to wear or reduction in fatigue life and consequently lower the part performance [13].

The surface finish of the AM part is governed by process parameters (e.g.laser power,scan speed,hatch distance,and layer thickness,etc.) and materials parameters (e.g. optical and thermophysical properties)

[14,15].In general, the surface roughness decreases with increasing laser power $( P )$ and reducing scan speed (v) [14,16,17]. Conversely, lower heat input or linear energy density $( \mathrm { L E D } = P / \nu )$ applied to the powder bed leads to a colder and more viscous melt pool, promotes poor wetting behaviour [14]，and results in balling-like features and increased surface roughness [18].These prior studies predominantly studied LED ranges from 0.1 to $1 . 5 \ : \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ [14,18,19].

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-4
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content:
Several characterisation techniques have been used to quantify the surface roughness of AM components, including optical microscopy [20],scanning electron microscopy (SEM) [19],atomic force microscopy [21],coherence scanning interferometry (CSI) [14],and hyperspectral imaging [22].None of these techniques can study the built topology on a layer-by-layer basis;therefore,the underlying mechanisms in which both geometrical properties and individual powder layer thickness contribute to the final build part remain unclear.Analysing the interlayer roughness and quantifying the underlying mechanisms would provide further insight to achieve optimum as-built surface quality.

Engineering surface textures are split into three key profiles: roughness,waviness,and nominal profile [23].Roughness refers to micro-scaled asperities of the build surface,also known as fine textures [24].Fine textures are usually generated by the laser beam melting or sintering of powder particles [25].Roughness parameters are measured commonly ina two-dimensional form (2D) and they are typically used to dictate the overall surface roughness topology [26].Amplitude parameters are commonly used to describe the surface topology by quantifying the vertical surface deviation with respect to a centre line [27]. $R _ { a } ,$ the average surface roughness,is also known as the arithmetic average of the profile height deviation from the centre line,i.e.,the mean height which indicates the overall surface texture [28]. Surface waviness describes the periodic oscillations induced by the melt pool behaviour [29]: it usually increases with a decrease in surface roughness. Lastly, the nominal profile is described as a combination of the roughness and waviness profile.

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-5
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content:
To produce high-quality AM parts,in situ monitoring can help achieve the desired surface texture [2O,3O].In situ optical and thermographic imaging studies focus on surface roughness at the final build layer which does not reveal the interlayer mechanisms thatlead to some types of surface roughness [31,32].New analysis methods are required to understand both final build layer and interlayer relationships.To characterise surface roughness fora multilayer build, various statistical parameters should be used such as average roughness $\left( R _ { a } \right)$ ,root mean square (RMS),and skewness (Sk) [24,26],which in return provides a feedback system for monitoring surface roughness through parameter control as demonstrated by ref.[26].

Synchrotron radiation enables X-ray imaging to offer unparalleled spatial and temporal resolution [33]. Several research groups have used in situ X-ray imaging to study process dynamics during multilayer LPBF [30,34,35] but have not discussed the underlying mechanisms involved in surface roughness variations under multilayer conditions.The first multilayer X-ray imaging study of LPBF [34] revealed that a thick powder layer could increase spatter,whereas a thin powder layer could lead to laser remelting,forming a smoother track surface.

Recent work shows that increasing the imparted specific energy, SE (esed beam diameter, reduces surface roughness and increases waviness [37]. The resultant surface topology of an AM track is linked to the hump formation owing to the combination of Plateau-Rayleigh and Kelvin-Helmholtz instabilities.The variations in $\nu$ and $P$ under overhang conditions also impact the laser energy transferred to the powder particles, thus having a direct influence on the melt pool size and wetting mechanisms which lead to balling phenomena by reducing laser power and scan speed.

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-6
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content: Although X-ray imaging has been used to analyse multilayer LPBF of Ti-6Al-4V where the surface texture and overall topology of the thinwall builds are linked to the powder layer thickness,the underlying evolution mechanisms that lead to different degrees of surface roughness are not yet known [38].Here,we characterise and quantify multilayer LPBF builds using in situ high-speed synchrotron X-ray radiography coupled with an in situ and in operando process replicator (ISOPR) [39].We successfully captured the evolution of processing defects (e.g.porosity and spatter) and surface texture in thin-wall builds composed of 1O layers under eight different linear energy densities LEDs.Post-mortem analysis was carried out to further examine the overall internal defects using X-ray computed tomography (XCT) and high-resolution surface profiling to validate in situ measurements.We also investigate the relationship between surface roughness and LED, quantifying the interlayer underpinning mechanisms that result in the final surface roughness of the build and delivering a roughness selection matrix to optimise the topology of the built part.The impact of this work can improve surface texture control in LPBF and could be further extended to welding and other laser processing technologies.

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-7
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content:
# 2．Materials and methods
Ti-6Al-4V powder (TLS Technik GmbH & Co.Spezialpulver KG, Germany) with a nominal size range of $2 4 \mathrm { - 6 8 \ : \mu m } , D _ { \mathrm { V ( 1 0 ) } } = 2 6 \mathrm { \ : \mu m } , D _ { \mathrm { V ( 5 0 ) } }$ $= 3 8 { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and $D _ { \mathrm { V ( 9 0 ) } } = 5 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (shown in Supplementary Fig. 1 and Supplementary Table. 1) and 1-mm-thick Ti-6Al-4V alloy substrates were used for the in situ multilayer build during the LPBF experiments.

# 2.1． In situ X-ray imaging of LPBF
Here,the LPBF experiments were conducted using an in situ and in operando process replicator (IsOPR)[39],which was designed to mimic the major features of an LPBF system which consists of a $2 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ $1 0 3 0 { \mathrm { - } } 1 0 7 0 \ \mathrm { n m }$ ,continuous wave fibre laser with a spot size of $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ The powder bed was filled with gas-atomised Ti-6Al-4V powder,which was fused in the environmental chamber which consists of an automated powder hopper,sample holder,and argon gas pressure sensor. The environmental chamber was sealed and backfilled with argon at a flow rate of $4 \mathrm { { l m i n } ^ { - 1 } }$ and then evacuated. The system chamber has two X-ray windows which are made of glassy carbon.This device can operate as a standalone unit and is also integrable into different synchrotron beamlines [4O]. The process parameters are given in Supplementary Table 2 with LED ranging from 0.5 to $4 \ : \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ . Each build is $5 \mathrm { m m }$ long with a total of 10 fused powder layers (Supplementary Fig. 2) with a nominal $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ thickness [41] under a bi-directional scanning strategy [30]. X-ray imaging was performed at the beamline Il2: Joint Engineering, Environmental,and Processing (JEEP),Diamond Light Source,UK [33, 37].
summary: 2.1． In situ X-ray imaging of LPBF, 2．Materials and methods

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-8
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content: Fiji version 1.52i [42],Python 3.7 [43,44] and MATLAB 2019a [45] were used to analyse the radiographs.A flat-field correction (FFC) was applied to the radiographs before analysis to reduce noise introduced by the detector and distortions in the optical beam path,improving the overall image quality [46,47].FFC is used to renormalise intensities across the image and correct the intensity pattern (Fig.la).A standard FFC equation is deployed using a Python script,and image denoising was run using the VBM3D method depicted in ref.[39,48]. Denoising allowed a clearer segmentation between the melt track,background (argon),and powder.After that, Otsu thresholding was applied to the denoised image to segment the background and melt track [49] (Fig.lb-c).We used the binarised image to calculate the built height by adding all the pixels in the build direction along the track length forming a track profile using a MATLAB script [5O] (Fig.1di). Using the Gaussian filtering process,a high-pass filter is applied to separate the roughness profile using a MATLAB script ref.[51], $\begin{array} { r } { \mathrm { G a } ( { x } ) = \frac { 1 } { \alpha \lambda c } \mathrm { e x p } \Big [ - \pi \big ( \frac { 1 } { \alpha \lambda c } \big ) ^ { 2 } \Big ] } \end{array}$ [52] where $\alpha = \sqrt { \ln { 2 } } / \pi ,$ $x$ is the position from the origin of the weighted function, and $\lambda _ { c }$ is the long-wavelength also known as the roughness cut-off.The cut-off frequency for the filter is denoted by the nominal size range of the Ti-6Al-4V powder (Supplementary Table 1). The Gaussian filter is commonly used and recommended by the ISO 11562-1996 and ASME B46-1995 standards for the roughness analysis [53].The surface roughness and waviness were then extracted (see inset Fig.1dii) [54]. All initial in situ data analysis was conducted using Image J(Fiji version 1.52i) before deploying any Python or MATLAB script for validation purposes.

Most defects imaged by optical microscopy were greater than $6 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ therefore sub-micron imaging,such as SEM was not required for this study.The autofocus [55] setting for the optical microscope is used to focus on the defect imaged solely,which results in blurring of other (not relevant) features due to the sample not being completely flat.

content:
To quantify the trapped powder between melt tracks,we performed XCT scans on the thin walls produced from the in situ experiments using a Nikon XTH 225 X-ray microfocus tomography system.Each scan consisted of 3175 projections with 1 s exposure time [30,37]. The data were reconstructed (with a voxel size of $2 . 7 \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ and analysed using the method presented in ref [3O]．XCT was used alongside optical microscopy and in situ X-ray radiographs for further validation of lapping defects.

D) $\mathrm { L E D } = 2 ~ \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ thin wall structure with.e-i) humping and e-ii) lapping defects. All scale bars are $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$

# 3．Results and discussion

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-11
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content:
High-resolution optical images of the thin-wall builds are shown in Fig.2.The results highlight the presence of various surface defects after multilayer LPBF for 8 different LEDs.Fig.2a shows that the size of the waviness () increases with LED.Atan LED of $0 . 5 { - } 0 . 6 \mathrm { J m m ^ { - 1 } }$ and under a scan speed of $3 0 0 { - } 4 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m s ^ { - 1 } }$ ,we observe track interruption with low ,and balling defects owing to insufficient melting [56] and poor wetting resulting in an increased solidification rate and thus the formation ellipsoidal balling.

As the scan speed further decreases,while keeping a constant laser power, the LED increases (up to $1 \ \mathrm { J m m ^ { - 1 } } .$ ),the top profile of the thin walls is flattened,and the surface humps are drastically reduced.With a further increase of LED from 1.5 to $4 \ : \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ ,the top profile of the thin wall becomes wavier.At an LED of $4 \ \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ ,more prominent lamellar rippling is found on the melt track,which is similar to the defect reported in welding [57].

We have identified three types of defects in these thin walls:(1) lapping defects (Fig.2b and further discussed in Fig.4c) are found at both ends of all builds between built layers (as shown by the inset in Fig.2-i and Fig.2e-ii) under the conditions studied; (2) lack-of-fusion defects are found with unsintered powder, indicating insufficient energy was applied at the powder bed at an LED of $0 . 5 { - } 0 . 6 \mathrm { J m m ^ { - 1 } }$ (Fig.2cii);and (3) humps,swell-like defects (Fig.2d),mainly formas λ increases with non-optimal LED, $e . g . < 0 . 7 5 ~ \mathrm { a n d } > 1 ~ \mathrm { J } \mathrm { m m } ^ { - 1 }$ (Fig. 2e-i) [38].
summary: 3.1.Top surface defects revealed by the surface profile/morphology - Part 1/2

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-12
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content:
In LPBF,the print quality of each layer has a direct effect on subsequent layers,and hence the overall build morphology.To further understand the impact of lapping,hump formation and lack-of-fusion defects on the side-skin roughness of the thin wall,we studied the evolution of these defects during LPBF over 1O build layers using in situ synchrotron X-ray imaging, see details in Sections 3.2-3.4,respectively.

Three LED conditions were selected that show track interruption (Fig.3a),rippling (Fig. 3b) and necking effect (Fig.3c) at the top surface of the thin-wall build (see other thin-wall profiles at different LEDs in Supplementary Fig 3).

At an LED of $0 . 5 \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ ,track interruption and balling are prevalent due to the higher surface tension at a lower melt temperature,leading to incomplete melting (Fig.3a).Additionally,the sintered powder is observed between humps due to spattering during LPBF.

At an LED of $2 \ : \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ the surface tension gradient from the centre to the edge of the melt pool will be higher,and this may also lower the melt viscosity,creating a higher Marangoni-driven flow towards the pool edge [58],which freezes in as ripples at the rear of the pool, resulting in higher top-skin roughness but a continuous track (Fig. 3b).

With a further increase of LED from 2 to $4 \ \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ , necking is more prevalent (Fig.3c),reaching a threshold linear energy density which deteriorates the build quality. Supplementary Table 2 confirms that the stable rippling and necking under an LED of $4 ~ \mathrm { J m m s ^ { - 1 } }$ and our observations are consistent with prior studies [59] where neck formation was due to the Plateau-Rayleigh instability.
summary: 3.1.Top surface defects revealed by the surface profile/morphology - Part 2/2

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-13
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content:
# 3.2.Lapping formation revealed byin situ synchrotron X-ray imaging
Lapping affects both geometrical properties and mechanical properties of the build [6O],which is observed at both ends of the final multilayer builds under all the conditions studied,shown in Fig.2d-i and Fig. 2f-ii. Using synchrotron X-ray imaging,we captured the lapping evolution mechanism during LPBF.Fig. 4a shows a radiograph of a thin-wall build after the lOth layer,wherein the light grey lines at the ends of the track are labelled as lapping.The grey scale values indicate how much energy has been attenuated along the X-ray beam path: the lighter the pixel,the less energy is being attenuated by the object and darker pixels indicate higher attenuation.

The radiograph (Fig. 4a-i), optical (Fig.4b),and XCT 3D rendering images (Fig.4c) confirm the presence of sintered powder between the overlapping tracks.The in situ X-ray images (Fig.4d-g) have allowed us to capture,for the first time,how a lapping defect is formed under a multilayerLPBF process.Firstly,the layer thickness increases by powder accumulation at the edge of the previously solidified structure: this alters the build condition from remelting to an overhang build condition (Fig.4d).At the onset of the melting process,the effective thermal conductivity of the Ti-6Al-4V reduces up to $9 0 \%$ [61]: this promotes the formation of balling or melt pool curl-up on the accumulated powder [39] (see Fig.4e).The liquid metal may overflow,wet onto the solidified structure below,and subsequently trap powder particles whilst merging with the solidified part.In other words,the powder particles are sandwiched by two scan tracks above and below,forming the lapping defect (Fig.4f).As the laser beam continues to move from right to left,the layer thickness is reduced from $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to none,indicating significant remelting and promoting a large volume of melt flowing towards the end of the track, such that the added material warps or budges upwards as it cools. (Fig. $_ { 4 g ) }$ ：
summary: 3.2.Lapping formation revealed byin situ synchrotron X-ray imaging

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-14

content:
Lack-of-fusion porosities are only observed during LPBF ata low LED of $0 . 5 \mathrm { ~ - ~ } 0 . 6 ~ \mathrm { J m m ^ { - 1 } }$ . We selected an LED of $0 . 5 \ \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ to explore the underlying defect evolution mechanisms,see Fig.5a.Fig.5b and c show two types of lack of fusion: (Type I) between two humps and (Type II) within the build,respectively.To analyse how lack-of-fusion porosities arise,we quantified the grey colour variation at the region of interest from layer 5 (Fig.5d) and subsequent build layers (Fig. 5e). By measuring the 2D projected build area from the radiographs,there are up to $6 \%$ more light grey pixels in the thin wall structure as the build layer increases from 5 to 10,i.e., showing more unmelted powder,or lack-of-fusion porosity,which correlates with Fig.5a.From our observations,the warping/bulging effect (depicted in Section 3.2) becomes more prominent,forming peaks (where materials build) and troughs (filled with sintered powder).The powder particles at the trough region are being ejected by the metal vapour as the laser beam remelts the peak material, leaving a gap between two humps,ie., type I lack-of-fusion porosity.On some occasions,not all powder particles are ejected: instead, they undergo partial melting and form weak interconnects between humps,i.e., type I lack-of-fusion porosity.
