content:
# 3.4. Spatter defects revealed by in situ synchrotron X-rayimaging
At an LED of $0 . 5 \ \mathrm { J \ m m ^ { - 1 } }$ ,the melt pool is expected to have a low average temperature and thermal gradient, resulting in a higher surface tension compared to the melt pool processed at a higher LED.The melt pool size is also expected to have a smaller depth $( d )$ and width $( w )$ at this LED.This high surface tension and low melt pool $( d / w )$ aspect ratio causes the melt pool to undergo Plateau-Rayleigh instability,forming melt beads rather than continuous melt track (at 66 ms).The ejection of a melt bead is seen at $2 4 6 ~ \mathrm { m s }$ ,which subsequently lands on the powder bed (at $8 1 2 \mathrm { m } s \mathrm { \ i n }$ ),see Fig.6a.This solidified bead could potentially create

![](images/77f6771f7570bd96143007a649fd4b70c7b609dc96c56386cd794983559a6cc7.jpg)  
Fig. 6. Synchrotron X-ray radiographs acquired during laser powder bed fusion with laser power $P = 2 0 0 \ : \mathrm { W }$ , scan speed $\nu = 4 0 0$ $\mathrm { m m s ^ { - 1 } }$ and linear energy density $\mathrm { L E D } { = } 0 . 5 \ \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ (Suplemntaryvideos3and4).Spaterandbalingevolutionwererevealedfra)layerandb)layerOresultinginlackoffusionwihite build as presented in the final morphology in Fig.5. All scale bars are $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$

a defect in subsequent tracks.

Fig.6b shows that the formation of powder spatter is due to hot particles or solidified beads (Fig.6a) being ejected from metal vaporisation at the melt pool surface (at $5 0 ~ \mathrm { m } s \mathrm { _ ) }$ [39,62]. Unlike what has been reported,we observed the formation of large droplet spatter could also be caused by the agglomeration of powder $( 1 1 2 \mathrm { m } s )$ and droplet spatter $( 1 2 1 ~ \mathrm { m } s )$ .These droplet spatters (Fig. 6a-b) may land and solidify on the melt track and result in a high side-skin roughness.

content: Under all conditions studied,we observe hump formation at the end of the track,which could be due to a combination of the lapping defect (depicted in Section 3.2)and deceleration of the scanning mirror in the LPBF system [63]. On the other hand, we periodically observed humping defects in the middle of the build under non-optimal conditions (Fig.5).

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-18
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content: Here,we selected the thin-wall sample made with LED of $1 . 5 \ : \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ for the following discussion.Fig.7a shows the side view of the thin wall aftera 1O-layer build.The zoom-in images show that there are regular large humps (Fig 7bi) and irregular small humps (Fig 7ci).Fig.7a shows a qualitative increase in powder denudation on the side-skin (front surface in Fig.7) of the track in comparison toa lower LED build in Fig.5a.Although not quantified,this result qualitatively matches the results of ref.[64],shows a transition from significant balling and spatter causing significant rough powder attachment at the side surface of the build (front of Fig. 5a) as compared to the large pool with a smoother track side surface with little powder attachment,albeit with greater waviness on the top surface.To understand how these humps formed during LPBF,we looked into the time-series radiographs.As the moving laser beam melts the powder and substrate, the liquid metal is moving backwards,adding material at the end of the track,and forming a hump (Fig 7bii).We hypothesise that the humps (seen at $1 2 3 \mathrm { m s }$ were created by the tidal-wave-like topology at the front of the melt pool.This wave travels to the back of the pool where undulations are observed due to theRayleigh-Taylor(orPlateau-Rayleigh) instability[65],inaddition to the lapping defect; note these undulation effects are amplified on subsequent build layers.The Rayleigh-Taylor instability describes an infinite column that is subjected to periodic instabilities (due to pressure differences) over a period of $2 \pi R$ where $R$ is the column radius [66].
summary: 3.5. Humping defect revealed byin situ synchrotron X-ray imaging - Part 2/3

content:
Fig.7a shows a decrease in the average $R _ { a }$ when the LED increases from 0.5 to $1 \ \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ (low range) due to two possible mechanisms: (i) when the melt pool size ratio $( d / w )$ is large,this promotes RayleighTaylor (or Plateau-Rayleigh) instability and balling formation (quantified later as shown by Fig.8c). (2) Combined balling with a lack of fusion porosity and spatter (Fig.6) generates a discontinuous track with a high side-skin roughness. [18,19,22] A minimum average $R _ { a }$ of $1 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ was achieved at an LED of ${ \sim } 1 ~ \mathrm { J m m ^ { - 1 } }$ . As the LED continues to increase from 1 to $4 ~ \mathrm { { J m m ^ { - 1 } ( h i g h } }$ range)，severe metal vaporisation takes place, resulting in unstable keyhole-mode melting (quantified later as shown by Fig.8c).Prior work hypothesised that for the mixing of hot and high-velocity vapour/argon (reaching up to $3 0 ~ \mathrm { m / s }$ ）flowingabovea fast-flowing melt pool $( \sim 4 ~ \mathrm { m / s } )$ ,the differences in flow velocities lead to the Kelvin-Helmholtz instability and hence hump formation [37],i.e. generating more ripple features at the track surface and increasing $R _ { a }$ of the track. The minimum $R _ { a }$ values calculated from the X-ray images are similar to those of the optical image at layer 1O.The mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) between these two measurements is $0 . 0 4 \%$ possibly owing to the filtering step during data processing.

content:
Parameters such as P,v and LED are shown to have an impact on the overall surface roughness of thin-wall build, though other parameters such as hatch distance have not been explored in this study. Several reports have observed that increasing hatch distance increases the overall roughness [3,67,68],which would affect the overall defect dynamics observed that are an onset of roughness,i.e.,lack of fusion and spatter (Section 3.3.- 3.4).

Fig.8b shows the λ increases in the low-range LED and decreases in the high-range LED,an opposite trend to the $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ analysis;however, the highest λ is also achieved at an optimum LED of ${ \sim } 1 ~ \mathrm { J m m ^ { - 1 } }$ ：

![](images/04cb60fff2c7840fa9c7253e8279a7700c71f4948917c68ae16b5dec56efbffb.jpg)  
Fig.8.Roughnessquantificationacross diferent linear energydensities.a).Plotoftheaverage arithmetical mean deviation $\mathrm { ( R _ { a } ) }$ which includes maximum, minidial waviss(sisdl plementary Fig. 6b.c). A scatter plot of the melt pool size ratio $=$ depth $( d )$ /width $( w )$ versus the LED for (1) Ti-6Al-4V alloy and SS 316 L (after 66]).The black line dividesthablablgdelspeieldlisoaoe average roughness $\left( R _ { a } \right)$ ;root mean square average (RMs); maximum profile peak height $( R _ { p } ) _ { : }$ maximum profile valley height $( R _ { V } )$ ；mean height $( R _ { c } )$ meanwidth $( R _ { s m } )$ skewness (Sk); and melt pool size ratio $( d / w )$ for different LEDs.The values are normalised by maximum value of each row as shown in Supplementary Table 3 and Supplementary Table 4 $\begin{array} { r } { \cdot \ ( X _ { n o r m a l i s a t i o n } = \frac { ( X _ { i } - X _ { m i n i m u m } ) } { ( X _ { m a x i m u m } - X _ { m i n i m u m } ) } ) \ } \end{array}$ where $X _ { i }$ :the acta value, $X _ { m i n i m u m }$ : minimum value onthe row and $X _ { m a x i m u m }$ : maximum value in the row).

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-22
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content: Fig.8c compares two sets of results: (1) Ti-6Al-4V alloy (present study);and (2) stainless steel $3 1 6 \mathrm { L }$ [66] under similar processing conditions.Ref [66] identified a threshold $d / w$ ratio of $2 \pi$ 、Above the threshold,an unstable melt pool is formed with periodic humping, otherwise a stable melt pool is formed with a shallow amplitude and longer.Our results identify similar stable and unstable melt tracks, corroborating the results reported in ref [66].

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-23
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content: Here,we propose a novel roughness selection matrix (Fig.8d) to combine eight roughness parameters used in AM: (1) average roughness $\left( R _ { a } \right)$ [69];(2) root mean square average (RMs) [7O]; (3) maximum profile peak height $( R _ { p } )$ [26];(4) maximum profile valley height $( R _ { \nu } )$ [71]; (5) mean height $( R _ { c } )$ [71]; (6) mean width $( R _ { s m } )$ [72]; (7) skewness (Sk)[71];and (8) melt pool size ratio $( d / w )$ ref.[66].Each parameter has been normalised with a weighting between O and 1 representing low to high roughness (Supplementary Table 3 and Supplementary Table 4). The selected parameters represent roughness for a singular line as they are extracted from the in situ X-ray radiographs;however,the matrix presented has potential for additional singular valued aerial roughness measurements to be included.The $R _ { a }$ and $\lambda$ have already been discussed extensively In Fig.8a-b.RMS and $R _ { a }$ are both representations of surface roughness and the overall surface finish [73],and Fig.8d shows the RMS follows a similar pattern to $R _ { a }$ (as demonstrated by Fig.8a). There is a small difference in the RMS values in comparison to $R _ { a }$ ，where RMS values are more sensitive to larger peaks/flaws within the surface and could be used as a comparison indicator to the $R _ { a }$ The $R _ { p }$ and $R _ { V }$ values measure periodic undulation,and both values are used to calculate $\lambda$ of the humps. The $R _ { c }$ and $R _ { s m }$ increase with LED indicating that $\lambda$ increases and track height decreases,correlating to the finding in Fig.8b and Fig.2a.When the modulus of $^ { s k }$ is $> 0$ ，both peaks and valleys are prominent on the track surface,indicating a rough build surface.A higher $^ { s k }$ value means a lower number of asperities/peaks and valleys in the build,i.e.,a smoother build surface.A similar pattern arises for $^ { s k }$ and $R _ { a } ,$ where LEDs of 0.

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-24
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content: 75 and $1 \ \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ has the most symmetrical distribution of peaks and valleys,indicating low surface roughness.For each roughness parameter,we normalise all values using methods described in Supplementary Information (section G). The colour map denotes the average-built layer is flat as 1 and rough as O.In the present study,the optimum printing parameter range to produce a flat surface is between LEDs of 0.75 and $1 \ : \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ .Based on our findings,the end-users can tailor surface finish of a thin-wall build using the proposed roughness selection matrix as it considers both $R _ { a }$ and $\lambda$ across the length scale of the LPBF process.

name: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin-part-25
fileName: 2023 - AM - Bhatt et al. - In situ characterisation of surface roughness and its amplification during multilayer sin.pdf
content:
# 4. Conclusions
This study used in situ synchrotron X-ray imaging to investigate the evolution of the interlayer side-skin roughness and waviness and associated defect formation mechanisms during LPBF of TI-6Al-4V multilayer builds.The findings were supported by ex situ optical imaging and XCT results.A novel surface topology matrix was developed to describe surface features and defect formation mechanisms while effectively representing the overall geometrical build morphology and texture.The matrix can be used to find the desired surface finish and achieve better surface control under a layer-by-layer processing during LPBF.The following conclusions have been drawn:

1.Two key mechanisms were observed that affected the side-skin roughness and amplitude: (1) $R _ { a }$ decreased between an LED range of $0 . 5 { - } 1 ~ \mathrm { J m m ^ { - 1 } }$ ,due to a decreasing melt pool size ratio where the surface became smoother due to Plateau-Rayleigh and KevinHelmholtz instabilities and (2) $R _ { a }$ increased between a LED range of $1 { - } 4 \ \mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ as metal vaporisation was more severe due to an unstable keyhole melting mode. An optimal $R _ { a }$ of $1 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ was found to be at an LED of ${ \sim } 1 ~ \mathrm { J m m ^ { - 1 } }$ ：

2.Using synchrotron X-ray imaging we observed the defect dynamics during LPBF and quantified their effects on each of the printed track quality.We found that defects that occur at: (1) LED range of 0.5-0.6 $\mathrm { J m m } ^ { - 1 }$ include lack of fusion, spatter, balling and track interruption, which increase $R _ { a ; }$ and (2) that regardless of the process parameter for LPBF printing,the single bi-directional multilayer printing lead to the formation of,lapping and humping defects, which also increasing $R _ { a }$

# Author contribution
PDL,CLAL,MKT and AB conceived the research/project. CLAL and GS designed the experiments.All authors performed the beamtime, except MKT.AB performed data analysis and results in interpretation with the assistance of YH.AB,YH,CLAL,and PDL led the results interpretation and paper writing.GS performed powder size distribution analysis.SS performed $\mu \mathrm { C T }$ and AB analysed the results.AB,YH,GS performed surface roughness ex situ roughness results via Keyence.

# CRediT authorship contribution statement
Alisha Bhatt: Conceptualisation，Methodology，Formal analysis, Investigation，Writing - original draft, Visualisation. Yuze Huang: Conceptualisation，Methodology，Investigation，Writing- review & editing. Chu Lun Alex Leung: Conceptualisation,Methodology, Investigation,Writing-review & editing,Funding acquisition.Gowtham Soundarapandiyan: Methodology, Investigation. Sebastian Marussi: Methodology, Investigation. Saurabh Shah:Methodology, Investigation.Robert C.Atwood: Resources, Supervision.Michael E.Fitzpatrick:Supervision, Conceptualisation,Resources,Writing -review & editing,Funding acquisition. Manish K. Tiwari: Supervision, Conceptualisation,Writing-review & editing,Funding acquisition. Peter D.Lee: Supervision, Conceptualisation, Investigation,Writing-review & editing,Funding acquisition.

# Declaration of Competing Interest
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

# Data availability
Representative sample data is summarised in the figures (and supplementary data).Additional datasets generated and analysed during the study are available upon reasonable request through the corresponding authors due to the large size and volume of data acquired.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-1
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
# Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-meltig of layers in selective laser melting
Snehashis Pala\*, Matjaz Finsgarb, Radovan Hudak, Viktória Rajtukovac, Tomaz Brajliha, Nenad Gubeljakä, Igor Drstvensek a

aFacultyof MechanicalEngineering, Universityof Maribor,Maribor,Slovenia bUniversityofarboracultyofeistyndeicalngeeingriboe Departmentof Biomedical Engineeringand Measurement, Technical University ofKosice,Kosice,Slovakia

# ARTICLEINFO


# ABSTRACT
Keywords:   
Re-melting   
Pore properties   
Defects   
Surface morphology   
Ti-6Al-4V   
Selective laser melting

Knowledge of defect formation mechanisms in the manufacturing proces helps improve product quality.In this study,defect formationdue to re-melting of each layer in selective laser meltingof Ti-6Al-4V demonstrated the physical behavior in the manufacture of metallic parts.The re-melting strategy was based on scanning with low energy density (ED)and increased ED with various combinations of laser processing parameters.The increased EDsand their parameters,namely laser power,scanning speed,and hatch distance,were selected based on the previous research experience by the authors.The concept of selecting a low ED followed by a high ED was to reduce the spattering of the powder material during the proces.The low ED caused partial sintering of the powder,while the high EDcaused the melting of the material,resulting in different metallurgical properties of the manufactured parts.Densities,pore properties,porosity in the initial layers,surface morphologies,and microstructures in the defective areas of the samples were studied to determine the effects of re-melting.Advantages and disadvantages were found with respect to the range of applications of the products.
summary: ABSTRACT, ARTICLEINFO, Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-meltig of layers in selective laser melting

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-2
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
Additive manufacturing (AM) of metal is one of the most desirable but also stochastic manufacturing processes [1,2].Due to the high flexibility of AM processes and intricately designed,mass customized or even individualized components can be manufactured ina shorter time compared to traditional manufacturing processes [3,4].Liu et al.[5] mentioned that since the development of selective laser melting (SLM),a special powder bed AM process for the production of metal parts, extensive research was conducted to develop high quality products considering the manufacturing parameters.The manufacturing parameters mainly include the environmental conditions of the processing chamber,the laser processing parameters,and their combination strategy [6,7]. Several researchers found that the combination of laser processing parameters is not arbitrary in terms of the required energy input and significantly affects quality [8].

The laser processing parameters are the laser power, the scanning speed and the hatch spacing.But the diameter of the laser focus also plays a decisive role in melting the material. The energy density (ED) of the impact area mainly depends on these laser processing parameters, while some researchers also consider layer thickness as a parameter of the ED [9].In addition, the laser scanning strategies,such as scan patterns and repeated scanning of the same layer (re-melting) have also been addressed to observe their influences.These manufacturing conditions can be used to manipulate the properties of the SLM product, such as density，porosity，and microstructure,which ultimately contribute to the mechanical and chemical properties [10].

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-3
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content: There are a large number of research articles and patents on the effects of laser power,scan speed, hatch spacing,scan patterns,and ED [8].Nevertheless,there are only a few research papers so far dealing with re-melting strategy, especially for Ti-6Al-4V alloy.Wei et al. [11] reported that the surface quality and strain can be improved by remelting strategy for Ti-5Al-2.5Sn alloy.Yu etal.[12] studied the remelting effects on $1 7 { - } 4 ~ \mathrm { P H }$ stainless steel during laser metal deposition.They observed that the strain is limited due to the interlayer defects,which can be reduced with increased ED during re-melting. Vaithilingam et al.[13] observed that the chemical composition of the surface of Ti-6Al-4V products changed with the second scanning,where the concentration of Al and V increased.Lv et al.[14] worked on the elimination of pores of Ti-6Al-4V by in situ re-melting and found that the scanning speed can control the porosity.However,the above articles are based on the re-melting strategies,which show that it is possible to regulate the metallurgical properties of Ti-6Al-4V in the SLM process in ways other than the single scanning.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-4
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
Titanium alloys such as Ti-6Al-4V are attractive alloy systems in terms of the favorable combination of high strength-to-mass ratio and biocompatibility,including corrosion resistance [15,l6].Due to these advantageous properties,a wide application of Ti-6Al-4V can be observed in the automotive,aerospace,marine,and chemical industries [17].It is also used extensively in biomedical implants such as orthopaedic (knee,hip,shoulder),maxillofacial (skull,mandible),dental and other implants [1,l8].However, there are numerous disadvantages to manufacturing titanium alloy products using conventional methods due to the high hardness,chemical affinity,melting point, volumetric specific heat,and low thermal conductivity of titanium. These disadvantages in conventional manufacturing of Ti-6Al-4V alloy products can be overcome by AM technologies,such as SLM[19].

Much research was done to achieve the desired quality of Ti-6Al-4V alloy products fabricated by SLM,considering the different laser processing parameters and their different scanning strategies.Ultimately, achieving the desired product quality is still challenging considering all the mechanical and chemical properties.Even though re-melting layers require additional time and energy，researchers are investigating possible re-melting strategies given the process to improve product quality.Therefore,in this work,the influences of repeated scanning of the same layer, consisting of pre-melting with an effective lower ED and subsequent re-melting with several higher EDs,on the quality of Ti-6Al4Valloy products in the SLM process were investigated.

content:
# 2.1． Material
Commercially available titanium grade-23 powder from Dentaurum, Germany,was used to manufacture the samples by the SLMmethod.The powder particles were fully dense so that no gas escaped from the powder during the melting process in the SLM process.Fig.1 shows the image of the powder taken with the scanning electron microscope (SEM) of FEI Quanta 2Oo 3D.The diameter of the particles is mainly in the range of $1 0 { - } 4 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,butthere are also some tiny particles with a diameter of a few micrometers.The density of the titanium alloy supplied is 4.429 $\mathrm { { g } / \mathrm { { c m } 3 } }$

![](images/8122539c5919ce62deffc15b209fce9dfab7e61abdb0efdfc53009f2e5cc681e.jpg)  
Fig.1. SEM image of the Ti-6Al-4V powder.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-6
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
An mLAB SLM machine with the Yb:glass fiber laser from Concept Laser LLC,Lichtenfels,Germany,and IPG Photonics,Germany,respectively,was used to fabricate the samples.The machining chamber was filled with argon to maintain ${ < } 0 . 4 \%$ oxygen and a temperature of ${ 2 0 } ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ The laser beam had a diameter of $0 . 1 1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ and was focussed perpendicularly on the scanning surface using a telecentric f-theta lens.A checkerboard scanning strategy with $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ rotation for each successive layer was used,and the same layer was scanned a second time (remelting) with the same pattern.The first time,a layer was scanned with a low ED $\left( 3 6 \mathrm { \ J / m m ^ { 3 } } \right)$ ）where the laser power,scanning speed, hatch distance,track overlap,and layer thickness were 55 W, $8 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ $0 . 0 7 7 \mathrm { m m }$ $3 0 \%$ ,and $0 . 0 2 5 \mathrm { m m }$ ,respectively.The second time,the same layer was re-melted using a higher ED.Five combinations of laser parameters were used (see Table 1） for the second scanning,using knowledge from the authors'previous research to manufacture different samples.ED was calculated using eq.(1)[7],where $P , \nu , h ,$ and $H$ denote laser power，scanning speed,hatch spacing，and layer thickness, respectively.

$$
E D = { \frac { P } { \nu \bullet h \bullet H } }
$$

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-7
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content: The laser power of 55 W was used for the first scanning,as this gave the best product density,while the highest permissible scanning speed was $8 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ to keep the ED ata low level,as in an earlier study by the authors [2,2O] The other fabrication parameters also provided one of the best values considering the metallurgical properties [2O,21].In order to remelt the same layer,different combinations of laser parameters were chosen for different sets of samples.The selection of the fabrication parameters was based on previous experiments performed by the authors.There,the best ED was $6 5 \mathrm { ~ J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ along with a laser power of 75 W,a scan speed of $6 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,and a track overlap of $3 0 ~ \%$ [22]. They also state that the best range for scan speed is $4 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s \cdot 8 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ The highest possible scanning speed of the machine was $1 0 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ . It was found that the decrease in laser power resulted in a decrease in porosity and an increase in tensile properties [2O].Thus,the best laser power was observed at 55 W and 65 W was the second best laser power.Considering these parameters, $3 5 ~ \%$ of the track overlapprovided a nearly $1 0 0 ~ \%$ dense product [2O].Therefore,these parameter combinations were chosen to investigate their effects on the remelting strategy.Contour scanning was performed on the periphery of the samples using the same strategy associated with each sample.

# 2.3.Sample and support structure The cubic samples having a side length of $8 \mathrm { m m }$ were built up on the $2 \ \mathrm { m m }$ high support,as shown in Fig.2.The supportive bars had a cruciform cross-section with a length and width of the cross of $0 . 3 \mathrm { m m }$ and $0 . 0 5 \mathrm { m m }$ ,respectively at the point of contact with the sample.The lateral and diagonal distances between the supportive bars were 0.63 mm and $0 . 8 0 \mathrm { m m }$ ,respectively.Three test samples were considered for each test condition. # 2.4.Density measurement Archimedes’principle was used to measure the density of the prepared samples.An electronic balance with a measurement sensitivity error of $\pm 0 . 0 0 0 1 \ g$ was used to obtain the weight of a sample in air and the weight after immersion in ethanol. fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
# 2.5. Surface morphology analysis
The surface morphologies of the specimens were evaluated using SEMimages of the surface as well as the cross-sectional plane.The crosssectional planes were exposed by grinding and then polished.The depths of the transverse sections were $1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and $1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ from the vertical surfaces,respectively.

# 2.6. Porosity and defect analysis
The surface porosity and defects of the samples were examined with both SEM and a light microscope.Additionally,the samples were abraded about $1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ from the vertical surface and then polished to examine the porosity in the contour areas.To study the porosity inside, the samples were grinded ${ > } 1 \mathrm { m m }$ from the vertical as well as horizontal plane.The adrading process was carried out in four steps to grind out the materials using silicon carbide abrasive papers with 32o,5oo,800, 1000,25oO and 4ooo meshes,one after the other and under constant exposure to water.Afterwards,the ultrasonic bath was run through with subsequent water cleaning to remove residual particles from the ground surface.Then the first polishing operation was carried out by moistening the cloth with a lubricant propylene glycol and a diamond pest with a diamond grain size of $3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ In the second polishing operation, $0 . 0 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ of aluminium oxide were used for $2 0 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ to obtain the final surface for observation.The samples were then cleaned with water and ethanol and dried with a hair dryer.
summary: 2.5. Surface morphology analysis, 2.6. Porosity and defect analysis

# 3．Results and discussion

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-11
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content: The findings demonstrate that the samples made using various remelting techniques have significantly varying densities,as shown in Fig. 3. Thus, $4 . 3 0 ~ \mathrm { g / c m ^ { 3 } }$ $4 . 3 1 ~ \mathrm { g / c m ^ { 3 } }$ and $4 . 3 6 ~ \mathrm { g / c m ^ { 3 } }$ density products were produced with ED $3 9 \mathrm { \ J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ $4 9 \ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ,and $6 5 \ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ,respectivelywhere their relative densities are $9 7 . 0 9 \%$ $9 7 . 3 1 \ \%$ ,and $9 8 . 4 4 \%$ Therefore, the density improved successively from samples 1 to 3 with the increase of ED in the second scan.The scanning speed was reduced while the other fabrication parameters were kept constant to produce these three samples sequentially.Then,the laser power was reduced along with the scan speed to $5 5 \mathrm { W }$ and $4 4 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,respectively, to keep ED constant at $6 5 \ : \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ .As a result, the density of sample 4 decreased to $4 . 3 2 g / \mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 } ( 9 7 . 5 4 \% )$ This means that the density decreased by about $0 . 9 ~ \%$ ,although ED was the same between samples 3 and 4.With constant ED,increased track overlap from $3 0 ~ \%$ to $3 5 ~ \%$ ,increased laser power to 65W,and increased scan speed to $5 6 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,the density of the sample decreased further to $4 . 2 6 ~ \mathrm { g / c m ^ { 3 } }$ $( 9 6 . 1 8 \% )$ .This means that the density decreased by another $1 . 3 5 ~ \%$ even though the ED remained the same.Therefore,the maximum and minimum product densities were obtained in sample 3 and sample 5,respectively,although they were obtained with the same ED $( 6 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } } )$

content:
![](images/726f770b2552e1c42d0f79f270db39642ea613b47fd2d1657373534d6db17256.jpg)  
Fig.3.Densities of samples.The first bar for each sample represents the density produced by single scanning (without re-melting) while the second bar represents the density produced by re-melting strategy.

The densities of the corresponding samples were $4 . 3 7 \ : \mathrm { g / c m ^ { 3 } }$ $4 . 0 2 g /$ $\mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 }$ $4 . 0 5 ~ \mathrm { g / c m } ^ { 3 }$ $4 . 4 2 ~ \mathrm { g / c m } ^ { 3 }$ ， $4 . 3 ~ \mathrm { \bar { g } } / \mathrm { c m } ^ { \bar { 3 } }$ ，while they were produced using the same manufacturing parameters with single scanning. Therefore,the density deteriorated significantly due to the employment of remelting strategy.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-13
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
Notable porosity features were observed in the samples, which may help to investigate the reason for the density differences.Similarly,insights can be gained into the phenomena that occurred during the interaction between the laser and the metal powder,including their effects on the melting process and the properties of the melt pool. The porosity differed between the contour and core regions of a sample. Fig.4 shows the SEM images of the contour regions ( $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ inside from the vertical surface) of the cubic samples,where an exposed region followed the scanned layers successively along the build-up direction. The contour region contains a small number of tiny pores,while the core region consists of many pores.Although the overall porosity of the samples ranges from $1 . 6 1 ~ \%$ to $3 . 7 6 ~ \%$ ，the number of pores in the contour region is very small, with some regions containing no pores. Moreover, these pores are tiny compared to the pores that usually occur in the SLM process for Ti-6Al-4V[14,2O],and the defective regions are also small.Therefore,re-melting in the contour region resulted in significantly lower porosity and other defects forall samples manufactured by different parameters.

Fig.5 shows that the pores are very small and irregularly shaped. Their size ranges from a few micrometers to $3 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ in length/width/ diameter. The tiny pores are formed by the keyhole effect,as shown in Fig.5(b),or by the entrapment of gas bubbles,as shown in 5(h). Insuficient melting or bonding between layers/tracks,on the other hand,has resulted in large pores with small widths,as shown in Fig. 5 (d).Some almost spherical pores with high irregularity were observed, possibly due to small spattering of material or insufficient melting,as shown in Fig.5(f).However, Figs. 4 and 5 together show the melting characteristics of the surface,where good melting and bonding also occurred.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-14
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
The pores in Fig.5 also represent the highest possible phenomena of pore formation in the production of a sample with the corresponding manufacturing parameters. Sample 1,which was manufactured at the highest scanning speed,was most likely to collapse the keyhole and form a keyhole pore [23],as shown in Fig.5(a). Samples 1 and 2 were highly likely to leave pores with unmelted region as they were manufactured with low ED.They also had a high scanning speed,which meant lower thermal stability and a high cooling rate.Therefore,the melt was not able to occupy all the required sites,especially in the lower region between two melt pools belonging to two consecutive tracks [24],as shown in Fig.5(c).Increased ED in sample 3 causing the onset of spattering of the melt [1O],as shown in Fig.5(e).As the laser power was very low in sample 4,the viscosity of the melt pool was low.Therefore, there was a high probability that the gaseous bubbles were trapped [4]. The gaseous bubbles normally enter the melt pool from the spaces between the particles.However,they flow with the vortex,as shown in Fig.5(g), and as the melt pool solidifies from bottom to top,the vortex becomes correspondingly smaller.The gaseous bubbles also flow with the vortex and move upwards.Then they move away from the melt pool or remain on the upper region and mix into the next uppwer layer during scanning.

![](images/dc6a7578c287c6a192207cb7043a18472edc6765c88966efcbac5494ae4c8011.jpg)  
Fig.4.Contour areas of (a) sample 1,(b) sample 2,(c) sample 3,(d) sample 4,and (e) sample 5.

fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
Entering the interior of the contoured area in the cubes revealed a different porosity pattern,as shown in Fig.6.A large number of pores can be observed in samples 1,2,4,and 5,while sample 3 contains a small number of pores.On close inspection of the pores,it can be observed that they have a neat arrangement.The pores are aligned vertically across the layers,and the aligned lines are parallel with constant spacing.These parallel pore line spacings vary between samples, and the actual spacings may differ.This is due to the depth of grinding, angle of visualization,and interference from successive layers from the cross-scan.The pores become gradually smaller with increasing ED between samples1 to 3.Among them,the pore alignment is clearly visible in sample 1 and poorly visible in sample 2. Similarly,no alignment of pores is observed in sample 3.Only some small spherical pores are seen in sample 3.Subsequently,a significant decrease in laser power and scanning speed while keeping ED the same as in sample 3 resulted in a higher porosity with a vertical pore alignment,as shown in Fig.6(d). However,in sample 4,some additional pores are out of alignment.

Further increase in laser power and scanning speed with the higher overlap of tracks while keeping ED the same resulted in a higher number of pores in sample 5.A larger number of out-of-alignment pores can be observed in sample 5 than in sample 4. Some out-of-alignment pores in sample 5 are significantly larger,drastically reducing the sample's

density.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-16
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content: The light micrographs in Fig.7 show a slightly different pore orientation on a horizontal plane inside the specimens.The pores are oriented in two directions,and they are orthogonal.Similar to the observation of porosity in the vertical plane,the porosity between samples 1,2,and 3 gradually decreased with increasing ED and decreasing scanning speed.Moreover, the alignment of pores in sample 3 disappeared,and few pores could be observed in this sample.Significantly decreased laser power and scanning speed increased the porosity in sample 4,although the ED was the same.Again,the pore arrangement was similar to that in samples 2 and 3.Similar to the vertical pores, the size of the pores in sample 5 increased significantly,as shown in Fig.7 (e).Along with this,the pore orientations can also be seen,but the larger pore formation destroys them.Ultimately,these large pores caused the lowest density in sample 5.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-17
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
The vertically aligned pores on the vertical planes (XZ and YZ) result from the absence of melting.The absence of melting occurred between two underlying parts of two melt pools,as shown in Fig.8(a) labeled “unmelted zone".Here,the melt pools belong to two successive scanning tracks.Therefore,these pores had the potential to extend continuously parallel to the scanning tracks in a layer.However,they were interrupted by the peak regions of the melt pools in the previous layer that were re-melted.Fig.8(b) depicts this phenomenon,where the unmelted height is lower than the peak regions of the melt pools of the previous layer.A valley section between two successive melt pools remained an unmelted area. Thus,the unmelted zone remained at the junctions of the melt pools of two successive layers rotated by $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ ,leaving these horizontally extended pores,as shown in Fig.8(d),a top view of one layer.If the peak of a melt pool of the previous layer was not high enough, the unmelted zone continued and remained as a longer extended pore,as two of them marked in Fig.7(a).

Since the scanning tracks change by $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ in each successive layer, the unmelted track is not visible in the same plane in the next layer. Therefore,these pores can be visible after about two layers,as shown in Fig.8(c),since the unmelted zone remained in the lower part of one layer.One of these two layers belongs to the same layer of the unmelted zone,and the other belongs to the next layer.Similarly,the pores in each of the two successive layers appeared in the same position and produced a vertical alignment of the pores.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-18
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf

![](images/a79de050bd19f4a8be7d10643c1490a96df6900e65b600551ca34e96c3fbe4bc.jpg)  
Figts Zattesd of a cubic specimen.

Understanding the laser melting of Ti-6Al-4V powder is crucial to comprehend the phenomena occurring when a layer is re-melted.When the laser beam hits the powder layer, part of the rays are reflected by the surfaces of the powder particles on top of the layer [25]，as schematically shown in Fig.9(a). Other rays penetrate the powder layer and are reflected several times by several particles and finally scattered. The powder particles eventually absorb these laser rays as thermal energy [8]. Since the laser power was low and the scanning speed was high during the initial scanning of a layer, only a small amount of laser energy was induced, resulting in a small ED that allowed partial melting of the particles.Therefore,these materials formed some spheres that clumped some adjacent particles by the balling mechanism,as schematically shown in Fig. 9(b),or the particles sintered,as shown in Fig.9(c),or a mixture of both.

![](images/9592953645cc8d3d4cd4c14e4ac13c03cf2265d696c12b0385a1356f18135be0.jpg)  
Fig.9.Reelaoeia laeaedl withig fspereflop microstructure,(h) the sphere is not molten at all and contains only cellular microstructure.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-19
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content: The initial scanning and fusing process formed a roof on the top of the layer,as shown in Fig.9(c).The successive large spheres allowed less area between them for the laser beams during the second scanning. On the other hand, the sintered particles formed a roof with higher number of pores where the large spheres were less.This roof also allowed a small number of laser rays to penetrate the layer during the second scanning. Most of the rays were reflected from the top of the layer in both conditions,as shown in Fig.9(d).The amount of laser penetration depended on the laser power,scanning speed,and the presence of holes in the roof. The extent of laser penetration increased while the laser power increased and the scanning speed decreases.However,less ray penetration was not able to melt the large sphere.Finally,it remained as a sphere with little connection to the surrounding metal, as schematically shown in Fig.9(e).An example of this type of unmelted sphere in the sample is shown in Fig.9(f).This balling effect with a diameter of about $2 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ was observed on samples 1,2,4,and 5.This balling effect was also observed on the vertical surface of sample 3,which means that the balls in this sample were well melted due to the high ED with high laser power.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-20
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content: Although sample 1 was manufactured using high laser power (75 W), the scanning speed was very high $( 1 0 0 0 \mathrm { { m m } / \mathrm { { s } ) } }$ ,which allowed less laser penetration and less time for absorption by the top surface.Therefore, the melt pool was not formed properly,and the material was not melted well.The viscosity of the molten metal was high so that it could not flow and fill the required interstices [14].Moreover,due to the low ED, the melt pool was not large enough to melt all the required materials.Hence the bottom part of the layer remained untouched by the melt pool. Eventually,this unmelted area extended parallel and adjacent to a track. The adjacent next track also left the unmelted zone connected to the previous unmelted zone,which together formed a larger pore with intertwined shapes.This unmelted track is sometimes interrupted by the peak areas of the melt pool of the preceding layer.The peak area varies slightly in a sample due to the physical properties of the melt pool formation.It should be noted that the peak area does not vary significantly with the variation of the process parameters and ED due to the fixed layer thickness.Therefore,the pores (belonging to the defined alignment) varied by the size laterally of the melt pool and by the melting properties,including the viscosity.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-21
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
The layer was more thoroughly penetrated when the scanning speed was dropped to $8 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ (sample 2).This createda largermelt pool and decreased the viscosity of the melt,resulting in a reduction of the unmelted areas.Consequently,the pore sizes and their number in sample 2 were reduced.A further reduction of the scanning speed to 600 $\mathrm { { \ m m } } / s$ made it possible for even more laser rays to penetrate the layer and absorption by the top surface.As a result,a larger melt pool was created,and the viscosity decreased significantly,allowing the melt to reach all necessary areas in a shorter time.In eventuality, fewer pores remained in sample 3; therefore,the highest density was achieved in this sample.

Although the calculated ED to produce sample 4 was the same,the reduction in laser power resulted in a lower intensity of laser energy. This resulted in fewer rays penetrating the layer, forming smaller melt pools with high viscosity and keeping the unmelted zones.To produce sample 5,the scanning speed was higher than sample 4,but more moderate and lower than sample 3.Therefore,amoderatelyincreased laser power provided higher intensity,and simultaneously the overlap of the tracks was also higher.These three parameters were sufficient to allow penetration of a significant amount of rays,resulting in explosions of trapped gases and metal vapour within the layer [26].These explosions caused material to be ejected from the action zone,causing it to lose material and heat.The melt pool belonging to the next layer could not reach those unmelted zones.Therefore,the spattering of materials created large pores in sample 5,which can be seen in Fig.6(e) in the vertical plane and Fig.7(e) in the horizontal plane.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-22
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content: However,the difference in porosity between the samples may be greater than is reflected in their difference in density.This is due to the presence of the powder particles in the pores.The particles may remain unchanged or may be partially melted.They contribute to the apparent density of the specimens but would not significantly change the mechanical loading capacity [2]. These particles were removed during the grinding and polishing of the cross-sectional surfaces.However, sample 5 lost material due to spattering,significantly reducing its density.Moreover,the metal spheres formed by the balling effect have the cellular microstructure near the circumferential regions and the planar/ cellular microstructure in the core regions,as shown in Fig.9(f)-(h). Where a similar effect in Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated by SLMhas been observed by the authors [27].This microstructural formation is normal in the welding process,where cellular growth can be observed against the direction of heat transfer [28].Therefore,these deteriorate the mechanical properties and corrosion resistance as well.However,while the metal spheres melt partilly,as shown in Fig.9(f),the acicular $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ -martensite formed at the well mixed area due to rapid cooling [22].

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-23
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-24
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
Significant differences were noted between the specimens in surface morphology.They also significantly differ from the parts produced by the regular single scanning method in SLM[29].However, three sides of the surface morphologies were studied, namely the bottom,the vertical, and the top surface.The bottom surfaces of the samples are afected by the problem of starting layers because the starting layers are built on the support bars.The gaps between the support bars were filled with powder particles. Some of these particles became associated with the melt pool, and some of them stuck to the bottom of the melt pool.This phenomenon occurred twice,once during the first scan and the other during the second,with increased ED.The bottom surface,comprising the first few layers from the beginning of layering of the cubic samples,was represented in Fig.1O by SEM images of the vertical cross-sectional plane.

It is known that a remarkable problem occurs in the production of some layers above the supporting bars and the hanging areas [29]. The melt pools of the first layer were unstable due to the lack of solid support underneath,and they accumulated excessive powder particles.This circumstance ensured the melt pool could move downwards at the gap between the supporting beams.The powder accumulations were caused by the penetration of the laser rays into the previous layer and the adhesion of the powder particles to the bottom of the melt pool.In addition, the powder particles were blown out from the front and side areas during the laser progression due to the high heat generation.This resulted in a lack of material,eventually leading to pores,as shown in Fig.1l(a). On the other hand,a large amount of material was obtained in some areas and a large volume melt pool was formed,as shown in Fig.1l(b).The large pores at the starting layers occurred mainly at the beginning of the experiment, such as sample 1, followed by sample 2 at an increasing rate.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-25
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
These circumstances occurred during the scanning of the first layer, while a few next layers were affected by these circumstances.The low ED in sample 1 could not melt well enough to contribute to molten metal flowing and covering the pore areas.In addition,the high scan speed did not provide enough time for the material to flow into the pores.However,the pore areas lacked material,so they suffered from the excess heat energy that led to the melting of the particles under the layer.These events occurred at the sample site up to several layers due to the high heat generation,bowl creation,gas explosion,powder spattering,and spattering of molten metal. This event caused an extension of melting below the first layer,as shown in Fig.11(a),with the “extended melting" marker.The depth of this extended melting corresponded to some layer thicknesses.The elevated ED covered these pores in sample 3, but these occurrences resulted in several large expansions below the first layer,as shown in Fig.11(b).These expansions ranged from tens of micrometers to $3 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$

Nevertheless, scanning speed significantly influenced surface morphologies in the present study.A slower scan speed resulted in higher timing of melt pool stabilization,which caused neighboring particles to partially melt and attach to the bottom surfaces of the melt pools. Consequently,a lower number of powder particles adhered to sample 1, which was produced at a high scanning speed during the second scanning.Therefore,the bottom of sample 1 has a small amplitude deviation, as shown in Fig.1O(a).This effect was also influenced by the applied ED, whereby it was lowest in sample1of all samples.The low ED generated the smallest melt pools and affected the surrounding powders the least, as the heat transfer to the neighboring particles was low.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-26
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
Subsequently, a reduced scanning speed allowed comparatively more time for the neighboring particles to melt and adhere to the bottoms of the melt pools in sample 2.Additionally,the increased ED delivered more heat to the neighboring particles,allowing them to melt partially and adhere strongly to the melt pool.These phenomena also led to several extensions of melting.Therefore,the bottom of sample 2 contained more powder particles and expanded melting compared to sample 1 shown in Fig.1O(b).Fig.1O(f) illustrates by an etched vertical surface that half of the infiltrated particles did not strongly bond with the bottom layer.The microstructure of these particles is not entirely $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ -martensite,and they have a cellular microstructure in the peripheral regions which is similar to the balling effect as shown in Fig.9(f).These adherent particles form a strong layer on the bottom surface of the sample.These particles cannot be easily removed,and they also increased the size of the sample.These particles also decrease the corrosion resistance in the corrosive environment,especially in the human body fluid when the scaffold structure in metal implants is used, where removing these particles is difficult.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-27
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
Further reduced scanning speed enabled a higher extension of the layer downward. The surface extended up to $3 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ in sample 3 as shown in Fig.1O(c).This surface consisted of a high amplitude waveform with average deviations of about $2 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ .Due to the longtime of heat exchange and the high application ED,the adhering powder particles gradually give off the heat to the neighbor particles.Afterwards, the neighbor particles partially melted and adhered to each other or are affected by the balling formation and finally adhered firmly to the surface.Therefore,two phenomena assisted to extend the surface at the bottom of sample 3 which are extension of melting and enormous particle adhesion in the form of balling or gathering.Though the density of sample 3 is the highest, the bottom surface produced a highly complex structure containing high surface area due to the high volume of melt pool creation.

Interestingly,this surface structure formation (as sample 3) is both advantageous and disadvantageous.The advantages are the improvement of osseointegration and the increase of current density for metalair batteries.The disadvantages are decreased defined pores volume in the scaffolded and deteriorated corrosion resistance.Nevertheless, the fortunate is martensitic formation in these extended areas,as shown in Fig.lO(f).Another drawback of this sample is the possible formation of cracks,as can be seen in Fig.1O(c).Eventually,a microcrack was noticed in this sample,as presented in Fig.1O(f),which occurred due to the uneven thermal stresses accumulation among the extended melting zones.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-28
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
In comparing the samples,the first layer of sample 4 was not fused well in several places and was greatly expanded in some places,as shown in Fig.1O(d).This was due to the strong impact of the laser beams with the low laser power and scanning speed. Several locations were not well fused due to the low laser power and roof formation. These roofs were also broken in some places due to the explosion during the second scanning,and therefore large flaws occurred in these places.Since the scanning speed was the slowest,a large portion of the laser beam penetrated the roof hole areas.The penetrated rays were reflected several times and reached deeperunder the first layer due to the lack of absorption.Therefore,these rays melted the powder under the layer and bonded them together.Finally, they formed the extended melting areas up to $4 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ,containinga high amount of adherent powder particles. Therefore,they would be difficult to remove from the inner regions of the scaffold product.

Comparatively shorter expansion occurred at the bottom of sample 5, as shown in Fig.1O(e).Although the laser power was increased slightly, the scanning speed increased comparatively more in sample 5,as the ED remained the same as in sample 4 with the help of a larger track overlapping.The higher track overlap did not contribute to higher penetration of the laser ray.Therefore,the bottom of sample 5 did not extend significantly,resulting in the least fluctuation and fewer particles adhering to the bottom surface compared to the other samples in this study.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-29
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content: Substantial differences can be observed between the vertical surfaces of the samples,as Fig.l2 shows.The main differences are caused by the adhesion features of the powdered particles and the balling effects.The smaller differences belong to the volumes of the melt pools and their shapes.The adhered powder particles formed the main architecture on the surfaces.These structures varied due to the different stability times of the melt pools and the heat transfer mechanism to the external particles.These mechanisms were dependent on the scanning speed and the amount of heat affected by the ED [6]. The surface texture properties were affected by the volume of the melt pool,which was clearly influenced by the active ED.The shape of the melt pool was varied by viscosity and the involvement of infiltrated and adherent particles [30,31].

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-30
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
Surface particles can be classified into three categories:‘mostly melted particles',‘partially melted particles'and ‘adherent particles'.A mostly molten particle has almost entered a melt pool,and a small part of ithas remained outside the surface.Consequently,a large portion of it was melted and is adherent to the melt pool.A partially melted particle, on the other hand,has neither properly entered the melt pool nor melted well.About half of this particle has remained in the melt pool.An adhered particle is almost not melted,and a small portion of it adhered to the surface of the melt pool and melted partially.Therefore,it can be considered thata major part of a mostly melted particle has changed the microstructure and has a high potential to transform the microstructure into acicular $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ -martensite completely. On the other hand, the microstructure of a partially melted particle consists of a cellular microstructure in the circumferential region,as shown in Fig.1O(f). These grains grew in the opposite direction to the direction of heat transfer, as the heat was transferred radially outward during cooling [32,33].The otherregion of this particle consists of martensitic or planar microstructure.An adhered particle has undergone a different thermal process resulting in a structure that is not completely martensitic.Therefore, these particles may exhibit different corrosion properties in the

Fig.12.The vertical surface morphologies of (a) sample1,(b) sample 2,(c) sample 3,(d) sample 4, (e) sample 5.

simulated body fluid [34].

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-31
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
Examination of several images of the surface SEM reveals that sample1 contains less mostly and partially melted powder particles.The amount of these particles increased in sample 2and further increased in sample 3.Although the architectures and placement of adherent particles are remarkably different between samples 3 and 4,their number is almost the same.The amount of these particles decreased in sample 5 again.The mostly melted particles are barely visible on the surface of sample 1.A few partially melted powder particles are seen in sample 1 and the restof the surface particles belong to adherent particles.The highest number of adherent particles adheres on the surface of sample 1 followed by sample 5.A few mostly melted particles and numerous partially melted particles were observed on the surface of sample 2. Compared to sample1,fewer adherent particles are seen here.

The surface of sample 3 consists of numerous mostly and partially melted particles,and these,in turn,have some adherent particles on the surface.This has resulted in a complex surface morphology consisting of interior spaces.The surface particles are clearly visible as the complexity is reduced in sample 4.Here,numerous mostly and partially melted particles can be seen.Sample 4 contains the least number of adherent particles present on the surface.Similarly,the surface of sample 4 has the lowest vertical surface roughness when considering the quality and quantity of surface particles.Since the surface of this sample has the highest number of mostly and partially melted particles and the lowest number of adherent particles,this sample would have the highest corrosion resistance due to the $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ -martensite compared to the $\texttt { \alpha + }$ $\beta$ -microstructure [18,34]．By studying these surface morphologies, especially the surface particles,new knowledge can be gained in the field of the melt pool's physical properties and the involvement of the neighboring powder particles.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-32
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content: A low ED,such as samples 1 and 2,made a highly viscous melt pool that enabled to stick the neighboring particles but could not pull them inside.On the other hand,the scanning speed was high,and thus the available heat transfer time from the melt pool to the particle was lower [5].Therefore,most of the particles remained as adhered particles on the surface.At increased ED,some of the adherent particles could be partially melted,and some of them entered the melt pool when the viscosity decreased. In addition,a significantly slower scanning speed allowed a longer time for heat conduction to the adherent particles, eventually leading to a higher melting ability.The significantly increased ED melted many adjacent powder particles,drawing them into the melt pool with the help of sufficient surface tension and viscosity. These particles also contributed the collected heat to the neighboring particles with the help of high heat as well as higher timing.Thus, these neighboring particles adhered to mostly and partially melted particles.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-33
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
Two stages of powder particle adhesion caused complex surface morphology in sample 3.The same ED implication in sample 4 caused good melting of surface particles.Although the scanning speed was slower than in sample 3,the laser intensity was also lower,gently melting the adherent particles and drawing many of them into the melt pool.The low intensity of the laser induced less thermal energy into the material,so the heat was not transferred sufficiently to cause more particles to adhere or only partially melt.Since the surfaces of the samples were processed with contour scanning,a larger overlap of the tracks did not affect the surface melting behavior.Therefore,although the calculated ED was the same,the apparent ED was lower for sample 5. On the other hand,the laser power was lower than that of sample 3, so e sample 5 could not melt the particles.Therefore, these fabrication parameters caused a higher number of adhered particles with a low number of partially melted particles on the surface of sample 5.

The balling effect is observed in all samples,increasing successively from sample 1 to 3.After that,a slightly lower balling effectis observed in samples 4 and 5 compared to sample 3,although they were prepared with the same ED.The balling effect depends on the viscosity of the melt pool [6].The lower the viscosity, the higher the potential for metal balling to occur. The samples in this study were well within the manufacturing range of balling on the second scan.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-34
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
As can be seen in Fig.13,different smoothness and surface profiles were obtained on the tops of the samples.The smoothness has increased from sample 1 to sample 3.Sample 4 has an almost similar texture to sample 1,while sample 5 hasa smoothness that is intermediate between samples 2and 3.The surfaces consisted of powder particles,spheres due to balling effects，pores,uneven zones，micro-cracks,and ripples. Nevertheless,sample 3 has a significantly smooth surface considering the SLM fabrication process for the Ti-6Al-4V alloy.

Two main types of powder particles can be observed, which belong to the mostly molten and adherent particles.The number of these particles substantially decreased from sample 1 to sample 3.Their number increased in sample 4 and decreased again significantly in sample 5.The mostly melted particles remained from the first scanning, and in the second scanning,the particles were not completely melted. These particles are only observed in sample 1, so this happened due to the low ED.These particles’sizes，which may be determined by observing their chords,fall between 10 and $4 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ：

Fig.14.A typical top surface morphology belongs to sample 1.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-35
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
On the other hand,there is a possibility that it is a balling effect, which remains as mostly melted particles due to rapid cooling. Observing the sequence of tracks in detail as shown in Fig.14,it can be seen that “particle A" should be melted when scanning the $\mathbf { n } ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ track,with the particle adhering to the $( { \bf n } + 1 ) ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ track.It can also be seen that the surface of the melt pool that belonged to the $\mathtt { n } ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ track was below the particle,and the surface was clearly smooth.This proves that the particle belongs to the $( \mathbf { n } + 1 ) ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ track,and it is dificult for this particle to move so far away from the $( { \bf n } + 1 ) ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ track when the particle belongs to the powder particles.Therefore,there is a high probability that the balling effect created this particle.

A similar particle,“particle $\mathbf { B } "$ ,can be seen in the next track as shown in Fig.14.The low applied ED produced high viscosity and high surface tension in the melt pool,which increased the cohesive force in the melt. Due to the high cohesive force and rapid solidification,the particles remained stationary after the onset of balling.In this state of the particles,there is also a probability that the particles got there during the (n $+ ~ 1 ) ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ track scanning and mostly or partially melted. The particles originate from either the powder spattering phenomenon or the balling phenomenon.“Particle C"in Fig.14, however, may be a mostly melted powder particle and is less likely to have originated from the balling effect.“Particle D"in Fig.14 has both equally likely causes of formation, namely the balling effect and the mostly melted powder particle.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-36
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content: Increased ED and decreased scanning speed helped to decrease viscosity and surface tension [6]. This resulted in some tiny spheres spattered on the scanned surface,as shown in Fig.13(c)and Fig.14.The tiny particles with a diameter of a few micrometers are mainly observed on the samples prepared with high ED,i.e.,samples 3,4,and 5.Most of the tinyparticles are located in the pores.This indicates that these particles were formed by spattering or balling effects and rolled on the smooth surface to find a stable place.Finally,they settled in the pores asadhered particles,as shown in Fig.14.The medium-sized particles have a diameter of $1 0 \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ and their quantity decreases from sample1 to sample 3 and then remains the same until sample 5.The balling phenomenon may be the primary cause of their formation,while the phenomenon of powder scattering may be the secondary cause.These particles also reached their stabilized location on the pore areas or on previously adhered particles,as marked in Fig.14.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-37
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content: The balls are large on the tops of samples 3 to 5,which are manufactured by high and same ED.Their diameter ranges from $8 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to 140 $\mu \mathrm { m }$ ,as shown in Fig.15.Since the balls are large,they did not spatter and did not migrate far.An example can be seen in Fig.15(b) and (c), which are about to be ejected from the surface and got stuck by pulling the molten metal with the help of cohesive force. Since they are large, they were cracked during the rapid cooling rate in the SLM process. The crack occurred due to the inhomogeneous heat transformation.There is a big difference in heat transfer by convection and conduction in this manufacturing process.Therefore,the particle from the core to the contacted area with the main body of the sample cooled faster than the surface areas of the ball belonging to the opposite side of the core of the sample. These thermal challenges resulted in a difference in shrinkage between the core and surface regions.The core region shrank faster than its surface,which is on the opposite side of the sample surface.This stress eventually caused several cracks on the ball's surface.Some balls were not melted during the next layer scanning inside the sample due to their high volume,as shown in Fig.9(f).However,if the ball,especially the cracks,are not well melted, the ball and its cracks will remain in the sample,which will deteriorate the product's mechanical properties.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-38
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
Two remarkable types of pores are observed on the tops of the remelted specimens,belonging to the pores between the tracks and the pores on the tracks,as shown in Fig.13.The number of pores between tracks gradually decreases from sample1 to 3,while it increases again in sample 4and decreases again in sample 5.Numerous pores are observed in sample1,while fewer pores are present in sample2,and finally,no or only a small number of pores were observed in sample 3.A similar mechanism of pore formation (between the tracks) can be observed in samples 1 and 4. The pores are very pronounced in sample 1,while they have become smaller or disappeared in sample 4. Therefore,the porous area between the tracks cannot be called pore,and it remains as a valley. Eventually,a few of them are observed in sample 5.

![](images/6fc205913e3a8fcc853974bac11bffba4fca28d266cba60da65885e245dc64db.jpg)
