name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-39
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content: The volume and shape of the melt pool and the contraction properties are responsible for forming the pores between the tracks.The volume of the melt pool in sample 1 was the smallest due to the lowest applied ED.During the first layer scan,the particles formed spheres of adjacent powder particles,as describedabove and shown in Fig.9(b). Similarly,during the first scan,discrete material tracks formed through the corresponding tracks of the laser beam,as shown in Fig.16(a). During the second scan in sample 1,the ED was not high enough to form the large volume melt pools.Therefore,the widths of the tracks were thinner and thus could not connect with the adjacent track.The shape of the melt pool was conical,and during cooling,contraction helped to create a larger distance between the tracks,as illustrated in Fig.l6(b).A higher potential prevailed in the balling region,creatinga larger distance between the tracks.SEMimage in Fig.16(c) shows two examples of the pores between the tracks, through which the previous layer can also be seen.At the bottom of these pores,the melt pool ripples belonging to the previous layer can be seen,forming orthogonally to the top layer'sripple direction.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-40
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
As the ED was low in sample 1,the pores between the tracks are large.When the ED was increased in sample 2,the melt pools conjugated better across the tracks,resulting in fewer gaps between tracks. Similarly,the melt pools were well connected for sample 3,which was made with the highest ED.Although the ED was high for sample 4,the laser power was much lower,resulting in insufficient penetration of the laser to produce large melt pools.Therefore,gaps remained between the tracks in several places,although the adjacent track could be connected in some places,and the size of the pores between the tracks was significantly reduced.For example,in sample 4,several pores disappeared between the tracks as shown in Fig.13(d).In sample 5,more pores disappeared between the tracks due to the higher laser power and larger overlap of the tracks.Finally,sample 3 was irradiated with the highest laser power among the samples prepared with the same ED, resulting in the smoothest surface with almost no pores.

The pores on the tracks are clearly presented in Fig.17.Several mechanisms are involved in the formation of these pores,namely the absence of material due to stacking and spattering of materials [35].As shown in Fig.17(a), the absence of material on the track is also possible during the first scan due to aggregation and balling effect.During the second scan,the surface tension in the melt pool and the contraction force during cooling are the reasons for the appearance of these pores as shown in Fig.17(c) and (d). The large pore,as shown in Fig.17(a),was formed due to lack of material as well as a small stacking of material forming a mounded zone.The lower part of the pore area melted well with a smaller volume of material and with the same ED.The stacked or mounded zone was scanned after the pore area, resulting in a larger pore space with high cohesive force and clumping.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-41
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
Asthe temperature rises,the coefficient of viscosity of a liquid decreases because the internal coefficient of friction between the molecules decreases.At a higher temperature,the molecules move apart and lose cohesive force,causing the coeficient of friction to decrease.At a higher ED,the temperature increased,and as a result, the viscosity of the molten pool decreases.Thererfore,the low ED resulted in high viscosity in the melt pools of sample 1[17].The high viscosity together with the high surface tension,hindered the driving forces against the viscous drag forces [36]. Therefore, the molten material could not spread and flatten efficiently in the available time.This phenomenon shaped the track as bumpy and small stacked zones of sample 1.

Increased ED in sample 2 moderated the viscosity of the melt pool, allowing the material to stack behind the pool. This resulted in several large material stacking zones,next to which a pore can be observed,as one of them is shown in Fig.17(b).There is also a possibility that a ball exists in the same location marked as a stacking zone,which was created during the first scanning.In the second scanning,the laser could not focus well on the pore area that existed along the scanning direction behind the ball.Therefore,a small area did not melt well, while after this area,the material melted and pulled a little material from the shadow zone[3].The same effects are observed in sample 5,as presented in Fig.17(f).The effective ED was almost the same as the laser power in sample 5 and was lower than that in sample 2.As for the previously seen spattered pores inside sample 5,there was a high probability of the occurrence of pores due to material spattering on the top surface and one of them is presented in Fig.17(e).Therefore,no stacking zones were observed adjacent to these pores.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-43
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content: The effects and mechanisms of melting,bonding and solidification of Ti-6Al-4V alloy were investigated using a re-melting strategy focused on lower energy density scanning (ED) followed by higher ED in selective laser melting (SLM).The concept of this study was sintering the powder particles with a low ED and complete re-melting with several high EDs. Based on the authors'previous experience,different combinations of the manufacturing parameters were selected.However,the following conclusions can be drawn from the results of this study:

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-44
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
i.Density may not be improved and may even deteriorate when the re-scan strategy is used.The laser may not penetrate sufficiently into the target layer during the second scan because the laser is reflected from the top of the layer.Therefore,the calculated volumetric energy density would not be applicable in the second scan.   
ii.The results show that melting during the second scanning is possible if the ED is high enough to completely melt the layer. Furthermore,high laser power is required to achieve sufficient penetration of the laser rays.So while the laser power decreased while the ED remained high,the porosity increased.   
iii.Although a high ED melted the layer well when re-melted,the surface acquired a complicated morphology as the powder particles were induced a second time and partially melted.In addition,reducing the laser power resulted in less adhesion of the powder particles and thus a less complicated morphology.   
iv.Massive spattering of molten metal occurred while the hatch spacing decreased due to overheating in the overlap zone, although the ED was the same. Although the same hatch spacing resulted in higher product density ( $1 0 0 \%$ relative density) when used for single scanning.   
v. The in-depth study and analysis of the top surface morphology of the re-melted samples provided a diverse knowledge of the properties of laser metal melting and the phenomena of the occurrence ofporosity and otherdefectsand surface

morphologies.With this knowledge,the porosity and surface architecture in Ti-6Al-4V alloy products can be regulated.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele-part-45
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Pal et al. - Mechanisms of defect formation in Ti-6Al-4V product during re-melting of layers in sele.pdf
content:
vi.With a suitable remelting strategy,different surface textures can becreated,ranging froma remarkably smooth or bumpy surface to ahighly porous surface.A combination of laser parameters resulted ina very smooth top surface,but also a very intricate surface with high roughness in the contour and bottom areas.   
vii. Re-melting with high energy density and high laser power provided the complicated surface structures with internal spaces on the bottom and vertical surfaces that allow good osseointegration for implant fabrication and increase the current density for metal electrode batteries.   
viii. Due to the sintering of the powder particles and the subsequent melting,a high number of balling effects occurred.The spheres were larger than $2 0 \ \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ ，while the layer thickness was $2 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ They did not mix with the other molten metal and remained with cellular and planar microstructures without $\alpha ^ { \ast }$ -martensite. Therefore,they deteriorated the yield strength and possibly increased the ductility.

This study has helped to reveal the pores and other mechanisms of defect formation especially in Ti-6Al-4V alloys.The implications of this study have created an awareness of the problems that will occur in most cases when using the re-melting strategy in SLM.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-1
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
# Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by calibrated melt pool simulation
Peter S. Cook\*, David J. Ritchie

CSIRO Manufacturing,Private Bag 10,Clayton,VIC 3169,Australia

# ARTICLEINFO


# ABSTRACT
Keywords:   
Additive manufacturing (AM) process   
Multiphysics model   
Ti-6Al-4V laser absorptivity   
Laser powder bed fusion   
Simulation

Additive manufacturing proceses such as laser powder bed fusion (LPBF)are now routinely used for advanced medical and aerospace components. However, moving from these bespoke applications to high-volume commercial manufacturing requires higher levels of predictability and control of part properties.Detailed simulations of the LPBF processcan assist this transition by providing understanding of defect mechanisms and guiding paths to improvement.An accurate value of laser absorptivity for the material is critical for LPBF simulation but the published literature contains surprisingly little absorptivity data applicable to actual LPBF operating conditions. Here we determine the in-situ laser absorptivity of the alloy Ti-6Al-4V during LPBF to be $0 . 2 7 + / \mathrm { - } \ 0 . 0 3$ fora laser wavelength of $1 . 0 7 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ . Our technique involves calibrating melt pool CFD simulations against single-track experiments conducted over arange of energy densities and can be extended to other materials.The simulations incorporate multiple laser reflections and cover the transition from conduction to keyhole mode.We also discuss physical mechanisms that may be responsible for changes in the absorption behaviour at high laser energy density which are observed in this and other work.
summary: ABSTRACT, ARTICLEINFO, Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by calibrated melt pool simulation

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-2
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: Metal additive manufacturing (AM) refers to the creation of parts by adding material ina layer-wise and selective fashion to build the desired 3D geometry.Within each layer,an intense energy source (laser,electron beam or electric arc) moves along a CAD-derived path to melt metal powder or wire,which then solidifies before the next layer is deposited. The advantages of AM for the production of metal parts are well known. Geometries with a complexity impossible by subtractive methods can be achieved and AMoffers the design flexibility foradvanced applications like functionally graded compositions and meta-materials.Tooling,part post-processing and material wastage are all reduced.However, although AM is used extensively for aerospace applications and for medical implants,the broader rate of adoption by high-volume commercial manufacturers has been slow.The main concerns have been variable part quality and a low level of predictability of the part microstructure and mechanical properties.These problems stem from the relatively poor understanding and control of the complex physical processes involved.Simulation of the various AM production methods can greatly assist in this regard.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-3
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: The methodology and applications of AM simulations are described in many reviews,for example [l-4].Most work has focused on three areas:the behaviour of the melt pool which forms where the laser or electron beam strikes the workpiece,the microstructure which develops during solidification and cooling,and the overall part distortion and stress distribution.Modelling studies linked to experiments have provided valuable insights into the fundamental factors controlling melt pool dynamics,keyhole instabilities,dendrite growth and grain development. Simulations have also helped clarify thecausesof manufacturing defects like baling, lack of fusion between build layers, pore formation, spatter, surface roughness and excessive part distortion. The majority of these simulation investigations,though,have been of a qualitative nature,examining mechanisms and trends with limited experimental validation.More quantitative predictions can enable selection of the best production settings [5],assist part quality certification[6] and,eventually,directly improve part quality by linking machine process control to concurrent simulation [1].

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-4
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: The ultimate simulation goal is an all-encompassing ‘digital twin' of the AM process [7] which operates at multiple scales from microstructure to whole part distortion,with integrated material properties and bidirectional coupling between sub-models [2]. Since the pool of molten metal which forms during AM is key to the whole process,an accurate description of this region is essential if such digital twins are to produce reliable predictions.The sophistication of the underlying physics in melt pool simulation has advanced considerably in recent years to encompass the effects of powder particle size distribution,melt circulation and free surface dynamics,metal vaporisation,surface tension variation and vapour recoil.Nevertheless, simulation accuracy remains fundamentally reliant on knowledge of the dozens of material and process parameters which influence the final part properties and quality to varying degrees. Arguably, the most important process variable is the rate of heat transfer to the part from the energy source,usually a laser or electron beam. This heating rate directly affects the melt volume,track dimensions and local temperature histories,and therefore the subsequent microstructure, residual stress and distortion.For laser powder bed fusion (LPBF),as considered in the current work,heat transfer to the part depends on the fraction of the incident laser power that is absorbed by the metal, rather than reflected.The fraction absorbed at a particular location is a material parameter known as the‘absorptivity'.The material absorptivity is a critical parameter in LPBF which exerts a first order effect on most aspects of part production.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-5
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
Here we determine the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during LPBF. We employ a novel method which involves combining single track LPBF experimental data with detailed simulations.Crucially,our approach yields the values during actual LPBF operating conditions.Absorptivity values are normally measured in laboratory conditions,requiring specially designed apparatus.The advantages of obtaining absorptivity data in-situ become clearer after some background concerning absorptivity behaviour and measurement methods.

In LPBF,the apparent absorptivity (fraction of laser power transferred to the part) can be increased by extraneous contributions from multiple laser reflections and vapour plume absorption,as discussed later.We refer to this quantity as the ‘effective'absorptivity to distinguish it from the ‘intrinsic'absorptivity which is determined just by the intrinsic (bulk) properties of the material. (Note absorptivity is not truly an intrinsic quantity as it also depends on the external radiant flux.) The intrinsic absorptivity of metals depends strongly on many factors such as the light's wavelength,angle of incidence and polarisation,and the material's temperature,roughness,oxidation and other contamination [8].

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-6
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
·Absorptivity tends to reduce with increasing wavelength,by an order of magnitude in the case of titanium from $1 . 0 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (Yb:YAG laser) to $1 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ 0 $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ laser) [9].   
·Absorptivity varies with both the polarisation of the incoming light and the angle of incidence with the surface.The Fresnel equations describe how absorptivity varies differently with angle for polarisation in a plane parallel or perpendicular to the plane formed by the incident and reflected rays.The absorptivity of polarised light typically varies by $5 0 ~ \%$ or more with both angle and orientation. For randomly polarised light, the angular dependence follows an intermediate ‘average'curve which typically exhibits a maximum at the Brewster angle,this angle varying with wavelength but in the range from 60 to $8 0 ^ { \circ }$ for most metals at room temperature [8,9].   
· The composition (e.g.,contamination) of the material surface also strongly affects the absorptivity.For Ti-6Al-4V,a surface oxide layer forms rapidly from any oxygen or water vapour in the atmosphere [10] and can change (generally increase) absorptivity by $5 0 ~ \%$ or more [11,12] with continued exposure.   
·Surface roughness is yet another important factor.The intrinsic absorptivity is defined for (and normally measured on) highly polished surfaces.However,if the surface roughness increases to a scale similar to or larger than the laser wavelength,reflections between protrusions significantly increase the apparent absorptivity [13]. Strictly speaking,roughness is a geometric rather than intrinsic property.However, in practice it is virtually impossible to separate its influence so poorly characterised surface roughness affects many

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-7
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: published‘intrinsic’absorptivity values，especially in hightemperature measurements subject to surface oxidation. ·As described by Boley [14],the absorption coefficients of metals generally increase significantly with temperature while still solid but then drop markedly upon melting due to the surface transition from optically rough to smooth.Temperature also indirectly influences absorptivity by controlling the rates of the chemical reactions which produce surface oxidation and roughness changes. ·Finally,we note that absorptivity and emissivity are equal in conditions of thermodynamic equilibrium.For LPBF,absorptivity also equals (1-reflectivity) because laser light transmission through the particles is negligible,the metals used having penetration distances of about one $\mu \mathrm { m }$ at most [8].

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-8
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: Considering all the above complexities,absorptivity values obtained in conditions which reflect the actual process are essential for accurate simulation.For Ti-6Al-4V, the subject of the current work,very little of the considerable body of published absorptivity data meets this requirement for LPBF.For the LPBF process,the laser beam is unpolarised with an angle of incidence generally close to $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ ,except when approaching keyhole mode as discussed later in this work.The wavelength of the predominant LPBF laser types (Yb-fiber at $1 . 0 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and Nd: YAG at $1 . 0 6 4 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ is significantly different to the $1 0 . 6 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ of the $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ lasers often used in other processes like welding.Even more importantly,it is now well-established (for example[1,l5]) that in LPBF the laser beam primarily strikes molten rather than solid material,apart from at the start of laser tracks.However, the high-temperature absorptivity data published for Ti-6Al-4V[11,12,16-27] are mostly restricted to the solid state which has limited relevance to LPBF since a decrease in absorptivity of $\sim 3 0 \%$ occurs from the solid to liquid state [20]. The data vary over a wide range,from about O.2 to O.8,due to the various factors described earlier such as wavelength,temperature and oxidation level. They are also restricted to angles (specific values $6 5 ^ { \circ }$ [24], $7 8 ^ { \circ }$ [23], $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ [11,12,16,17,19-22,26], hemispherical averages [18]) and wavelengths (specified [11,12,16,17,20-22,26], band averages [18,19,23,24]) which are mostly ill-matched to the typical LPBF conditions noted earlier.In summary,therefore,we are not aware of any measurements of Ti-6Al-4V laser absorptivity which are adequate for accurate LPBF melt pool simulation.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-9
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: The most obvious route to such data is to enhance and extend existing methods so we now briefly review some attempts,grouped broadly into approaches based on emission, absorption and reflection.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-10
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: 1.The absorptivity of metal surfaces can be obtained from emission data since emissivity and absorptivity are equal in practice.The most common technique to obtain directional emissivity from a solid Ti6Al-4V surface has been to combine the radiance value from narrow-band pyrometry with thermocouple measurements to obtain emissivity viaPlanck's Law[12,19,22,24].Other techniques tested include an emissivity reference paint (found to be unsuitable [24]) and a InGaAs photodiode detector,used ina study of the effects of oxidation on the emissivity of solid Ti-6Al-4V surfaces [11].Reports of emissivity measurements from molten Ti-6Al-4V surfaces are scarce.Lisiecki [26] investigated the effect of nitriding on melt emissivity by pyrometry,with only relative results possible due to the experimental difficulties. Just two groups have obtained absolute emissivity data for molten Ti-6Al-4V,both by applying rapid electrical pulse heating to wire and measuring during the brief period before the wire collapses.The first group,Cezairliyan et al.[17], measured radiance by pyrometry and calculated emissivity by assuming that a radiance plateau immediately before wire failure corresponded to melt at the liquidus temperature.Boivineau et al. [20] employed the most sophisticated technique;measuring the phase change of a polarised laser beam after reflection to directly calculate emissivity via the Fresnel equations,and then combining this emissivity with pyrometer measurements to determine surface temperature. All of these laboratory approaches are subject to significant error from various factors such as extrapolating temperatures in a dynamic environment, thermocouple inaccuracy, changing surface oxidation and unwanted background radiation sources [11,19,24]. Uncertainties of $2 0 ~ \%$ or more remain in even the most carefully controlled experiments [24].

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-11
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
Additionally,none of the above emission techniques are readily transferable to LPBF conditions as the higher temperatures can be expected to further increase measurement error and also create new problems such as vapour coating of delicate optics and thermocouple breakdown [24].

An alternative to measuring emission is to directly calculate absorptivity from the fraction of laser power absorbed by a sample.This approach has the attraction of being more robust in LPBF conditions, although still requiring a purpose-built laboratory rig. For Ti-6Al-4V, the technique was first attempted by Keller et al.[21] and subsequently refined by others [25].Laser tracks are run across an insulated sample which contains two thermocouples located at different distances from the top surface.The laser stops at time $\mathbf { t } _ { 1 }$ and the sample starts to cool.After around $^ { 1 0 \ s , }$ ，the two thermocouple readings converge,and it is inferred that the entire sample has equilibrated to a uniform temperature.The subsequent rate of sample heat loss,as measured by the thermocouples,is used to extrapolate backwards to the initial enthalpy at time $\mathbf { t } _ { 1 }$ .Knowing the laser power and duration,the fraction of laser energy absorbed can be calculated.However, this fraction may be under-estimated as there is an implicit assumption that heat losses by long-term convective cooling dominate those from the immediate melt pool region (radiation,enhanced convection,energy lost with vapour).The fraction only constitutes an effective absorptivity rather than the intrinsic material property since it is increased by melt pool reflections,for example,and is also an average over the whole period of laser heating rather than instantaneous.This calorimetric method therefore does not yield absolute values,although providing very useful trend information concerning absorptivity behaviour.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-12
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: 3.A third technique is to measure the total backscattered light with an integrating sphere radiometer,yielding the nett sample absorption by subtraction from the laser power.The corresponding absorptivity is again an effective rather than intrinsic quantity as it includes energy transferred by multiple laser reflections and vapour plume absorption[28]． Side-by-side experimental comparisonswith calorimetry [29,3O] and co-axial monitoring of melt pool emission [31] indicate that the backscattering approach can be more accurate. However,this requires painstaking processes to calibrate radiometer sensitivity (by prior measurements with a gold target),account for ambient light and determine various backscattering losses (to the laser beam head and through openings such as the entrance port). Spatter from the melt pool also necessitates occasional recoating of the $\mathrm { B a S O _ { 4 } }$ lining of the radiometer to maintain full reflectivity. Despite these difficulties,backscattering systems offer the considerable benefit of providing the effective absorptivity in real-time,as exemplified by fascinating comparisons with simultaneous highspeed X-ray imaging [27].

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-13
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: In summary,the prospects to obtain melt absorptivity data from laboratory measurements which are both accurate and applicable to LPBF appear poor,and in-situ measurements during LPBF require complex equipment and analysis.Here,we determine the melt absorptivity bya different approach based on simulations calibrated by LPBF experiments.Laboratory methods all replace the actual LPBF conditions with some simplified arrangement in which analytic equations (particularly Planck's law and 1D heat conduction) become reasonable approximations. Such experiments are very difficult to construct and control,as explained above,and can miss important influences on the desired property.In contrast,by calibrating simulations against LPBF data obtained during actual operating conditions,any effects on absorptivity like surface roughness,oxidation and elevated temperatures are automatically encompassed.A hurdle for LPBF simulation has always been the complexity of the underlying physical equations but this is no longer a barrier with the latest CFD codes [3].As we demonstrate, providing the model is accurate and other contributing parameters are well-known, the material absorptivity can be obtained by calibration of the model against experimental data.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-14
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: In this work the absorptivity is calibrated by simulating single-track LPBF experiments run on a Ti-6Al-4V plate at a range of laser powers and speeds.The absorptivity value used in the simulations is adjusted to produce the best match of the simulation results with the measured dimensions of the fusion zone and the heat-affected zone (HAZ). Some other groups have used simulation to obtain a laser absorptivity during LPBF but their methods (applied to Inconel) relied on a single track [32,33] or omitted melt flow influences [34,35]．By contrast, the approach reported here involves calibration over a range of experimental conditions with a full CFD calculation,and is further strengthened by including HAZ as well as fusion data.The next section describes the LPBF experiments and the calibration data obtained. Sections 3 and 4 provide details of the simulation methodology and the absorptivity calibration process.Finally, Section 5 discusses the implications of the laser absorptivity results,including interesting trends observed at higher laser energy densities.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-15
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
The LPBF experiments were run in a Concept Laser M2 Cusing machine under an inert argon atmosphere.A plate of wrought Ti-6Al-4V metal, $6 \ \mathrm { m m \ h i g h } \times 1 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ wide $\times ~ 4 0 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ long,was ground with 120 grit paper and then sand blasted to dull the surface.Eleven tracks were run across the plate at a variety of laser powers and speeds,each track being $9 \ \mathrm { m m }$ long and sufficiently far apart to ensure thermal isolation.Laser power was calibrated with a PRIMES Cube device with an accuracy of $3 \%$ .The tracks were subsequently sectioned and examined under a microscope (Olympus PMG3,with Olympus DP71 digital camera) to measure the dimensions of the fusion zone and the heat-affected zone (HAZ),with uncertainties of $0 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .After etching the sections with Kroll's Reagent,images were obtained in polarised light and also by Nomarski interference contrast.

The tracks were deliberately laid on a bare plate,rather than powdercoated,to reduce variation along each track for more precise experimental and simulation results.The intrinsic material absorptivity determined from bare plate experiments is also applicable to LPBF because previous work [25] has shown that the melt pool conditions and laserinteraction are very similar once the track has reached a steady state.In both cases,the laser beamis predominantly incident on the melt pool surface,and there is a similar depression of the melt surface in each case.We discuss this further and show an example later.

Fig.1 gives two examples of the track section images,with the extents of the fusion zones and HAZ indicated.These examples illustrate the enlargement of the fusion zone as the laser power increases (note the different length scale bars) and the accompanying increase in the depthto-width aspect ratio.Table 1 contains all the experimental results.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-16
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
Fig.2 presents the fusion zone dimensions graphically. Often such data are plotted against the laser ‘line energy',namely the ratio of laser power/speed.However,it has been shown experimentally and theoretically [36,37] that the fusion dimensions are more directly related to the ratio of laser power divided by the square root of speed.We also observed a better correlation with that measure of laser intensity and so have plotted the dimensions on that basis in Fig.2.

The dependence of the shape of the fusion zone on the laser conditions is visualised in terms of aspect ratios (depth/width) in Fig.3.The ratios vary from O.2 to more than 1.It is instructive to compare these experimental aspect ratios with analytic solutions.The simplest approximation of a point source of heat moving over an infinite plate with no melt flow and constant properties yields a fusion zone which is semi-circular with an aspect ratio of O.5 [38].More sophisticated analyses including a Gaussian heat source [39] predict a fusion zone which is generally wider than semi-circular,i.e.aspect ratio less than 0.5.Aspect ratios up to about O.5 indicate the system is behaving in a ‘conduction'mode.As the energy density increases further,effects like multiple laser reflections and evaporative recoil become important and larger aspect ratios are observed, such as the upper four data points in Fig.3.Ultimately,at power levels greater than normal production settings,the melt pool enters a ‘keyhole'mode accompanied by aspect

![](images/7a57d6c6ff53548d4b90146095615acf18dcf0c6e8ddbd23479c51846c36b2e4.jpg)  
Fig.1.Track cross-sections for (a) Experiment 3 (laser power $6 0 \mathrm { W }$ ,speed $6 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s \mathrm { \hbar }$ and (b) Experiment11 (laser power 360 W,speed $6 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s )$ . Arrows indicate the depths (D)and widths (W)of the fusion zone and the HAZ, with the dimensions being supplied in Table 1.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-18
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: The CFD simulations of the experiments were performed with the commercial CFD software FLOW-3D? WELD(Version 2.3.6,Flow Science,Inc.).The models incorporated melt pool formation,free surface movement,melt flow,evaporative heat loss and recoil pressure,Marangoni stirring,a tapered Gaussian laser profile and multiple laser reflections.Each simulation was continued until the melt pool dimensions reached a steady state fromwhich the fusion and HAZ dimensions were extracted for comparison with experimental data.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-19
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
# 3.1.Computational domain
Block-shaped portions of the Ti-6Al-4V plate were modelled. Due to symmetry across the laser track,only one side of each track needed to be included.The models were made sufficiently long in the direction of laser movement that the fusion zone was essentially constant (less than $1 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ variation) from the half-way point onward.The necessary model lengths ranged up to $3 . 6 \mathrm { m m }$ ,depending on the laser speed and power of the particular experiment being simulated.Model heights and (half) widths were set to $3 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ and $0 . 3 \mathrm { m m }$ ,respectively,after testing that greater values had no effect on the melt zone temperatures.A void space of $0 . 2 \ \mathrm { m m }$ above the plate surface was added to enable inclusion of vaporisation effects and to accommodate free surface movement.

![](images/d5a82e8de57b2fd52d04ade41280cfdec0134f6e133576101625ad4b1d1c7c08.jpg)  
FigExp power divided by speed1/2.

![](images/2b0e651d415ce0c9a2d91799f6fea676162fbfc9fe4914bae88bcc21cdb8ac2b.jpg)  
Fig.3.Dependence of the aspect ratio of the fusion zone (depth/width) on laser intensity,measured as laser power/speed1/2.

Fig.4 shows both the overall geometry and a zoomed-in view of the mesh for one of the models.Based on a preliminary mesh sensitivity study,a cell size of $4 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ in the melt region was found to provide adequate accuracy.Graded multi-grid meshes were employed for computational efficiency,with model sizes ranging from $_ { 0 . 6 \mathrm { M } }$ to $3 . 9 \mathrm { M }$ cells depending on the experiment conditions.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-20
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
The physical equations underlying the coupled solution of fluid flow and heat transfer are summarised below.In common with virtually all previous simulations of the melt pool region during LPBF [3],they start by approximating that the melt is incompressible with laminar flow and Newtonian viscosity. Then the Navier-Stokes equations for mass and momentum conservation simplify to:

$$
\begin{array} { r l } & { \nabla \bullet \boldsymbol { \nu } = 0 } \\ & { \rho \frac { \partial \boldsymbol { \nu } } { \partial t } + \rho ( \boldsymbol { \nu } \bullet \nabla ) \boldsymbol { \nu } = - \nabla P + \mu \nabla ^ { 2 } \boldsymbol { \nu } + \rho \boldsymbol { g } - \rho \boldsymbol { g } \beta \big ( T - T _ { \mathrm { r e f } } \big ) + \boldsymbol { S _ { m } } } \end{array}
$$

Here Pis pressure, $\nu$ is the velocity vector and $\pmb { g }$ is the acceleration vector due to gravity.The temperature dependence of the viscosity $\mu$ is included. The melt density $\rho$ is taken to be constant except that a buoyancy force corresponding to a constant volume expansivity $\beta$ is applied,represented by the second-last term in eq. (2).Tis the local temperature and $\mathrm { T _ { r e f } }$ is a reference temperature, set in this work to the liquidus $\mathrm { { T } _ { L } }$ 、The final vector term $s _ { m }$ represents the remaining momentum source terms which are described shortly.

Since the metal pool region has a free surface,an additional equation is needed to track the vapour interface.Flow-3D uses a conventional volume-of-fluid approach in which the fluid volume fraction at a given point,F,obeys the following conservation equation:

$$
\frac { \partial F } { \partial t } { + } { \boldsymbol { v } } \bullet \nabla F = 0
$$

The energy conservation equation can be expressed in terms of enthalpy h as:

$$
\rho \frac { \partial h } { \partial t } + \rho ( \nu \bullet \nabla ) h = \nabla \bullet ( k \nabla T ) + S _ { h }
$$

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-21
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
Here $\mathbf { k }$ is the thermal conductivity and the final term $s _ { h }$ represents remaining enthalpy source terms as described shortly.

For the phase change calculation,a linear variation of liquid fraction $\alpha$ is assumed between liquidus and solidus temperatures $\mathrm { T _ { L } }$ and Ts:

$$
\alpha ( T ) = \begin{array} { l } { 0 i f T < T _ { S } } \\ { T - T _ { S } } \\ { T _ { L } - T _ { S } } \\ { 1 i f T > T _ { L } } \end{array} { } i f T _ { S } \leq T \leq T _ { L }
$$

![](images/16e8144e5242505809bda908db918ff735b295afa84a490f5c40ce05a3f2d756.jpg)  
Fig.4.Overallgeotryfodeladesetailateooftheate.Eaplesoisforxpermet11withessm.

The temperature dependence of the enthalpy $\mathbf { h }$ is expressed as the sum of the integral of specific heat $\mathsf { c } ( \mathrm { T } )$ and the latent heat of fusion $\mathrm { L } _ { \mathrm { f } } ,$ linearly scaled by liquid fraction:

$$
h ( T ) = \int _ { 0 } ^ { T } c ( T ) d T + \alpha ( T ) L _ { f }
$$

Returning to the additional terms $s _ { m }$ in the momentum eq. (2),the effect of partial solidification on the metal flow is treated by a mushy zone approach (Carman-Kozeny) in which a drag force proportional to the local velocity is applied to the flow:

$$
S _ { m } ( \mathrm { m u s h y z o n e } ) = - C \big [ ( 1 - \alpha ) ^ { 2 } / \big ( \alpha ^ { 3 } + \varepsilon \big ) \big ] \nu
$$

The constant C in eq.(7) is a value made sufficiently large,looo in the current work,to ensure that velocity drops to zero as a region freezes.

The surface tension $\sigma$ is approximated to vary linearly with temperature according to:

$$
\sigma ( T ) = \sigma _ { \mathrm { r e f } } + \frac { \partial \sigma } { \partial T } \left( T - T _ { \mathrm { r e f } } \right)
$$

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-22
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
where $\sigma _ { \mathrm { r e f } }$ is the surface tension at a reference temperature $T _ { \mathrm { r e f } }$ (liquidus $\mathrm { T _ { L } }$ here) and $\partial \sigma / \partial T$ is the temperature derivative,which is taken to be a constant.The contribution of surface tension to the momentum equation can be expressed as:

$$
S _ { m } \mathrm { ( s u r f a c e t e n s i o n ) } = \sigma \kappa \pmb { n } + \frac { \partial \sigma } { \partial T } [ \nabla T - ( \pmb { n } \bullet \nabla T ) \pmb { n } ]
$$

Here $\kappa$ is the surface curvature and $\pmb { n }$ is the (vector) outward normal to the melt surface.The first term in eq.(9) is the effect of surface tension which acts normal to the surface and is incorporated in the pressure boundary condition.The second term represents the Marangoni effect, one of the main fluid flow drivers,and is applied in eq.(2)as a traction force parallel to the surface.

The flux of atoms escaping as vapour from the liquid metal surface exerts a recoil pressure.The vaporising alloy can be approximated [40,41] as if a pure material with effective physical properties and a molar mass $\mathbf { M } _ { \mathrm { A } }$ If the latent heat of vaporisation (at O K) is $\mathrm { L } _ { \mathrm { v } } ( 0 )$ and the boiling temperature is $\mathrm { { T _ { b } } . }$ ，then the recoil pressure at temperature $\mathrm { T }$ is:

$$
P _ { r e c } ( T ) \cong 0 . 5 6 P _ { a t m } e x p \left[ \frac { L _ { \nu } ( 0 ) M _ { A } ( T - T _ { b } ) } { R T T _ { b } } \right]
$$

where $\mathrm { R } = 8 . 3 1 4 \mathrm { J } / \mathrm { m o l } / \mathrm { K }$ is the universal gas constant and $\mathrm { P _ { a t m } }$ is atmospheric pressure.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-23
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
Evaporation of material from the liquid surface can remove significant heat from the metal pool.The rate of enthalpy removal equals the mass flux multiplied by the total enthalpy per unit mass at the liquid surface.However,in the metal pool simulation,mass is not explicitly removed from the liquid domain so for correct temperature calculation only the latent heat of vaporisation $\mathrm { L } _ { \mathrm { v } } ( \mathrm { T } )$ is applied [3].Then the evaporative heat flux Q becomes [40]:

$$
Q ( e \nu a p o r a t i v e c o o l i n g ) = \phi L _ { \nu } ( T ) \sqrt { \frac { M _ { A } } { 2 \pi R T } } P _ { a t m } \mathrm { e x p } \biggl [ \frac { L _ { \nu } ( 0 ) M _ { A } ( T - T _ { b } ) } { R T T _ { b } } \biggr ]
$$

Here $\Phi$ is the evaporation coefficient which is the fraction of the evaporating mass flux which never returns to the liquid surface.The value of 0.82 employed in other published LPBF simulations,really an upper limit [3],was adopted here as well.The latent heat of vaporisation is estimated from the critical temperature $\mathrm { T _ { c } }$ as:

$$
L _ { \nu } ( T ) = L _ { \nu } ( 0 ) \sqrt { 1 - \frac { T ^ { 2 } } { { T _ { c } } ^ { 2 } } }
$$

The radiative contribution to cooling of the top surface is:

$$
\varrho ( r a d i a t i \nu e c o o l i n g ) = \sigma _ { S B } \varepsilon ( T ^ { 4 } - T _ { a } ^ { 4 } )
$$

where $\sigma _ { S \mathrm { B } }$ is the Stefan-Boltzmann constant,ε is the surface emissivity and $\mathrm { T _ { a } }$ is the ambient temperature. Convective cooling was also added to the top surface:

$$
Q ( c o n \nu e c t i \nu e c o o l i n g ) = h _ { c } ( T - T _ { a } )
$$

fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: Here $\mathtt { h _ { c } }$ is a convective heat transfer coefficient which was set in this work to $4 0 \mathrm { { W / m ^ { 2 } K } }$ The value chosen has negligible efect on the results, as confirmed by sensitivity tests, because convective cooling in the hot zone is negligible compared to conductive,radiative and evaporative cooling.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-25
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
To properly model the laser-material interaction,the treatment incorporated multiple laser reflections.The incident beam was divided into a large number of rays,and each ray tracked through successive reflections until less than $1 \%$ of the initial ray energy remained,or the ray left the model domain.Each reflection was assumed to be specular with a fraction $\eta$ of the current energy absorbed and $( 1 \cdot \eta )$ reflected.

The laser power was applied as a Gaussian profile

$$
I ( r , z ) = \frac { 2 Q } { \pi R ^ { 2 } ( z ) } \exp \left[ - \frac { 2 r ^ { 2 } } { R ^ { 2 } ( z ) } \right]
$$

where $_ { \mathrm { I } ( r , z ) }$ represents the beam intensity ata radial distance $r$ from the beam axis and a vertical location $\mathfrak { z }$ relative to the top of the plate.The quantity $\operatorname { R } ( z )$ is the radius at which beam intensity has fallen to $1 / { \mathrm e } ^ { 2 }$ of its maximum value. $\operatorname { R } ( z )$ was set to vary linearly with $\mathbf { z }$ to represent a beam tapering,based on manufacturer parameters,from $7 1 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ at the top of the plate to a minimum of $3 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ at the focus plane $2 . 5 \mathrm { m m }$ below. The quantity Q was set individually for each experiment such that the integral over the Gaussian profile matched the total laser power listed in Table 1.The laser beam travelled at the speeds given in Table 1 with the centre of the beam $( r = 0$ ）on the symmetry plane.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-26
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
The material properties required for the flow and thermal equations are generally temperature-dependent.As noted by others [25],obtaining accurate values over the complete range from room temperature to boiling temperatures is challenging despite Ti-6Al-4V being an important alloy.Table 2 sets out the values adopted as the most reliable in the available literature.Temperature-dependent properties are listed as multiple valuesat the indicated temperatures,with linear interpolation applied in between.Since material properties are critical,both to the simulation results and part production in general, some further explanation is warranted:

· Critical temperature is approximated as a weighted average over the individual elements [41].   
· The latent heat of vaporisation at $_ { 0 \mathrm { ~ K ~ } }$ was calculated from eq. (12) using the measured value of $9 . 8 3 \times 1 0 ^ { 6 } \ \mathrm { J / k g }$ at the boiling point [42].   
·In the case of density, the data of Li etal.[43] were preferred as the most accurate up to the solidus and those of Schmon et al.[44] beyond,where the gradient controls the buoyancy term in eq.(2). The sudden $3 \%$ drop in density at the solidus was spread over the interval from $1 4 0 0 ~ \mathrm { K }$ to $1 8 7 8 \ \mathrm { K }$ to assist model convergence,after confirming with sensitivity tests that this modification had negligible effect on the results.   
· Thermal conductivities in the solid state were obtained from the extensive table provided by Milosevic and Aleksic [22].However, their measurements ended at $1 5 8 2 \mathrm { K } .$ Earlier measurements by Boivineau et al. [2O] extend to the melt, but are thought to systematically under-estimate the true conductivity [22]. Therefore,in the

Table 2 Material properties of Ti-6Al-4V employed in simulations.Values are constants or linearly interpolated between the indicated temperatures.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-28
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
·Specific heat values reported in the literature are more consistent than for thermal conductivity.The data of Milosevic and Aleksic are used here up to $1 4 0 0 ~ \mathrm { K }$ and those of Kaschnitz et al.[45] at higher temperatures.The temperature dependence of specific heat is far from linear,especially the spike due to the $( \alpha + \beta )$ to $\beta$ phase transition in the vicinity of 1200 to $1 3 0 0 \mathrm { K } ,$ so required more data points to capture adequately.

·Wunderlich [46] measured the viscosity and surface tension of Ti6Al-4V melts up to about $2 0 0 0 ~ \mathrm { K } ,$ and found that the properties vary quite strongly with oxygen content.Their data for $0 . 0 9 7 \mathrm { \ w t \% }$ oxygen were chosen since this was closest to the oxygen level in the plate used in the experiments.The viscosity values in Table 2 are extrapolated beyond $2 0 0 0 \mathrm { K }$ on a linear assumption. Surface tension was extrapolated at constant slope to $2 3 5 0 \mathrm { K }$ ,and thereafter assumed to fall to a negligible value at the boiling point.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-29
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: Each analysis began with the laser at the left-hand end of the model and a uniform temperature of 293 K (room temperature) throughout and continued until the laser reached the right-hand end of the model. Timesteps were restricted to a maximum of 2E-8 s for accuracy.A user function was added to the Flow-3D code to record the greatest temperature reached in each model cell during the analysis.This result was termed‘Maximum Temperature'and facilitated measurement of the Fusion Zone and HAZ,as described shortly.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-30
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
Fig.5(a) illustrates the temperature distribution near the end of a representative analysis,chosen to show results when the laser power and speed lie within the normal operating window for building Ti-6Al-4V parts.The laser beam is centred on the hot zone at right where the substrate is still molten and a marked depression of the melt pool surface is evident. This melt concavity is typical behaviour during LPBF and caused by the Marangoni-driven surface flow,plus recoil from surface evaporation when laser conditions are more intense.Presentation of the melt circulation pattern seen in the results is omitted here for brevity, being somewhat peripheral to laser absorptivity measurement and similar to those described in great detail by many authors,for example [48].

Fig.5(b) plots the Maximum Temperature results for the same analysis.The key point to note is that the Maximum Temperature contours become constant within a short distance of laser travel, reflecting the fact that the melt pool itself quickly reaches a steady state condition. The distance required for this to occur increases with laser power.As mentioned earlier,the model for each experiment was made sufficiently long that this asymptotic region of Maximum Temperature was attained by at most half-way along the block.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-31
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
Fusion and HAZ dimensions were extracted from cross-sections of the Maximum Temperature result across the block in the asymptotic region. The fusion zone boundary is represented by the contour at the liquidus temperature (1928 K). The HAZ is delineated by the $( \alpha + \beta )$ to $\beta$ phase transition for which we adopted the value of $1 2 8 0 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ recommended by Milosevic and Aleksic in their recent thermophysical measurements [22].They note a range of variation fromabout 1250 to 1300 K.Previous simulations of the HAZ dimensions formed during LPBF of Ti-6Al-4V employed lower phase transition temperatures $( 1 2 5 3 \mathrm { K }$ [12] and 1255 K [49]) which were obtained from older data sources.Fortunately,the sensitivity of the HAZ dimensions to this transition temperature uncertainty is minimal; changing the value to $1 2 5 0 \ \mathrm { K }$ moves the HAZ boundary by less than $1 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$

Fig. 6 compares the Fusion and HAZ profiles extracted in this way with the experimental cross-sections for the same case that was shown in Fig.5.Measurement of the zone dimensions was potentially ambiguous due to the variety of track surface profiles observed, some with a central hump and some also with a slight depression(undercut')on each side.It was therefore crucial to use consistent conventions when extracting the experimental and simulation dimensions.Vertical dimensions were measured at the mid-point of the track cross-section from the final surface location (not the original plate level) down to the zone boundary. Horizontal dimensions were measured between the two points at which the Fusion or HAZ boundary reached the final surface.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-32
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
Having established the simulation method,the next step was to run a series of analyses to calibrate the absorptivity value.After some iteration,an absorptivity of O.32 was found to give a reasonable match of the simulated fusion and HAZ dimensions with the experimental data,as plotted in Figs.7 and 8.As a guide, the dashed lines show where the data points would lie in the hypothetical case of a perfect match.That ideal is, of course,not realised due to both simulation error and experimental variability.However,considering that all material properties are fixed and only one global parameter is varied to fit four different experimental measures, the overall agreement is considered very good. The final step was to refine this initial estimate of O.32 for absorptivity,as described later in this section,but some further explanation of the results is first required.

The largest discrepancies occur in the fusion zone predictions at high laser line energies.The simulations under-estimate the fusion width and, to a lesser extent, depth for the uppermost four data points in Fig.7 (a) and 7 (b).These data points correspond to the four highest values of power/sqrt(speed),which were Experiments 5,6,10 and 11 in Table 1. Previous comparisons of LPBF track simulations with experiment, for both Ti-6Al-4V [50,51] and steels [52-54],have also all under-predicted the track dimensionsat high laser energies.We believe that this trend is related to the onset of a transition to keyhole mode.Such a transition can be seen in both the measured track aspect ratios (refer discussion concerning Fig.3) and in the melt pool simulation results described shortly. An association with keyhole development is also consistent with the observation that fusion zone dimensions are under-predicted but HAZ dimensions are not.

Fig.5.Simulations of Experiment 4 (120 W, $6 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ） showing (a) temperatures near the end of analysis and (b) the Maximum Temperature reached up to th same time.

![](images/3c9ef235f21e64bbc3a3c735287244c56e968602c47958c63d05570d85cc9f72.jpg)

Theexperimental HAZ and fusion zone boundaries are indicated for comparison with the simulation contours at $1 2 8 0 \ \mathrm { K }$ (HAZ transition temperature) and 1928 K (liquidus).

![](images/53ca1486acb68de96dabd79fbe7822b4a7a4c29a9501566b70008122d3e7de2a.jpg)  
Fig.7.Compaoofuadessielulssioiltdepthsgtfrngeacet.

To illustrate the onset of keyhole mode,Fig.9 plots temperatures for the three cases of increasing laser power. The same contour scale from the solidus $( 1 8 7 8 \ \mathrm { K } )$ to the boiling point (3315 K) is employed so that colours other than deep blue indicate partial or full melting.At 300 W laser power,the melt surface is just beginning to reach the boiling point inafew places.Noting the length scale,a significant enlargement of the melt pool with laser power is evident,which of course leads to greater fusion zone dimensions.The melt pool transforms from a shallow depression to an increasingly steep cavity and the melt surface also gets bumpier.These waves on the melt surface are a real effect, not numerical error,and seen in many prior simulation and experimental studies as discussed later.Instability of the melt pool is a major contributor to porosity in LPBF,especially at high energy density.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-34
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
It is now well-established, particularly by the group at LLNL [1,15], that the laser flux during LPBF is primarily incident on the melt for all regimes other than at very low energy densities.Fig.1O illustrates this observation by plotting the laser flux,as a percentage of maximum, for the same three cases as in Fig. 9.At $6 0 \mathrm { W }$ ,the heating extends over the whole melt pool and there is also a small amount ahead of the melt pool, on solid material.At $1 2 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ ，themelt pool is larger and less than 2 percent of the heating occurs ahead of the melt.At 3oo W,laser heating is applied solely to the melt surface,and concentrated on the leading face of the melt depression.The spots of heating on the rear face stem from reflections off the front face.

The LLNL group also found that the effective laser absorptivities of plates with and without a powder layer become similar once melting begins [25,55].With all other conditions the same,the steady melt pool behaviour in a powder layer closely resembles that of a bare plate,and the fusion zone dimensions of solidified tracks are also similar [31].To illustrate this point, we modelled a case with a layer of $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ diameter spheres spread in a regular array acrossa plate (Fig.11).There are differences in detail,of course.The melt surface lies somewhat deeper in a powder bed which tends to promote multiple laser reflections, increasing the total heat transfer to the metal and therefore the melt volume.Also,variabilityabout the steady state averageis increased bya powder.However,the fundamental heat transfer mechanisms are the same so that laser absorptivity values determined from bare plate experiments are equallyapplicable to powder beds.

![](images/cf9cc6183523e03d77c2aa544143d28e10dab167fb9c0579fce51e07777f09aa.jpg)  
Fig.8Copaofuaedssipladhtthte

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-35
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
![](images/762d91ebe43ac4067e680c46fef924530db0b688a0b10cb333930d5b374a1051.jpg)  
Fig.9.Temperatures on the symmetry plane during steady conditions for a laser moving at $6 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ with a power of (a) 60,(b) 120 and (c) 300 W.Note th difering length scales of the plots.

Returning to the calibration of absorptivity,we wish to improve the initial estimate of O.32 for which the simulation results were plotted in Figs.7 and 8.We define the fitting error as the RMS difference between the simulated and experimental dimensions. One route to an optimum absorptivity fit would be to runa large number of additional simulations and adjust absorptivity by ever-smaller amounts to minimise this error. However,a much more efficient method is possible because the dimensions are proportional to laser power,especially in the conduction mode regime,and therefore to absorptivity aswell (refer Fig.2).This means that modifying absorptivity by a factor‘f'which is close to 1 changes each simulated dimension D (fusion or HAZ) by the same factor. Therefore,to calibrate absorptivity we simply find the value of f (call it $\mathbf { f } _ { \mathrm { m i n } } )$ which minimises the fitting error:

$$
E r r o r = \sum _ { i } { ( f D _ { S i } - D _ { E i } ) } ^ { 2 }
$$

Here $\mathrm { D } _ { \mathrm { S i } }$ is a dimension simulated with an absorptivity of 0.32 in Experiment $\mathbf { \vec { i } } ^ { \prime }$ ，and $\mathrm { D _ { E i } }$ is the corresponding experimental dimension. The error minimisation is done in a simple spreadsheet calculation and the final fited absorptivity equals $0 . 3 2 \mathrm { f _ { m i n } }$

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-36
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
In Table 3,we show the absorptivity values calculated in this manner based upon various subsets of the experimental data.This approach of fitting data subsets gives a better idea of the uncertainty in the overall calibration.The first column gives the values obtained just from the 7 experiments conducted in the conduction mode,for which the assumed linearity of dimensions with laser power (and absorptivity) is an excellent approximation.The values range from 0.252 to 0.295 and we determine the fitted absorptivity to be 0.27 with a precision of $+ / - 0 . 0 2$

![](images/e2726f38fb26210f410be6ab1b7ceb76e7ede328b9fcd6f6335e3f2d88decfcc.jpg)  
Fig.10.2D section plots of laser flux for laser moving at $6 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ with power 60,120 and 30o W.Note differing length scale bars.

![](images/e069055fdbec0fdb1a9fdc1c070f17da095fd6083fc78ee00d7c3fa21b16ed56.jpg)  
Fig.11.Steady temperatures for 120 W laser moving at $6 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ with (top) no powder and (bottom) $5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ diameter particles.Plotted in 3D view at sam size scale.

If all experiments are fitted (last column in Table 3), significantly larger absorptivity values are obtained which average to O.33;we discuss this behaviour in the next section.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-37
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
We next evaluated the total uncertainty in thecalibrated absorptivity values as a sum of random and systematic contributions. Random errors, which arise here chiefly from experimental sources such as fluctuations in the dimensions along each track,are responsible for the deviations in Figs.7 and 8 from the ideal 1:1 match.These random errors,which create the range in the values reported in Table 3 and the corresponding uncertainty in their averages,could be reduced by measuring more tracks and more cross-sections along each track.By contrast,errors in the laser power calibration and the high-temperature material properties used in the simulations (refer Section 3.4) create systematic shifts in all the fitted absorptivity values.The absorptivity error arising from a given material property depends on both the degree of uncertainty and the sensitivity of the simulated fusion and HAZ dimensions to that property.Sensitivity analyses of the properties listed in Table 2 established that thermal conductivity and specific heat are the predominant error sources due to their relatively large uncertainties and thermal diffusivity being a key determinant of melt pool dimensions.The estimated uncertainty in each property at high temperatures is up to $5 \%$ [22].To gauge the resultant error,simulations were run with a $5 \ \%$ change in thermal conductivity or specific heat,applied across all temperatures to be conservative.These produced $3 \%$ changes in average fusion and HAZ dimensions for each property,and therefore in absorptivity as well.In summary,the main sources of error are $3 \%$ from laser energy, $3 \%$ from specific heat, $3 \%$ from thermal conductivity and $+ / - 0 . 0 2$ from experimental precision.As these errors are independent, theyare combined in quadrature and our measured value of Ti-6Al-4V absorptivity in conduction mode is $0 . 2 7 + / \mathrm { - } \ 0 . 0 3$

Table 3 Absorptivity values fitted to various subsets of experimental data.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-39
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
In discussing the absorptivity data,we must distinguish between two regimes identified in the results.These are the conduction mode normally used for LPBF and the higher power keyhole mode. Our absorptivity measurement in the conduction mode regime represents the intrinsic material property of the Ti-6Al-4V melt surface.The higher value obtained when all experiments were considered suggests that the model is missing some physical mechanism which increases heat transfer to the substrate when the keyhole forms.First,though,we discuss the conduction mode results.

The melt absorptivity value of $0 . 2 7 + / \cdot 0 . 0 3$ we find during LPBF in normal operating conditions is consistent with Ti-6Al-4V data published for other melt processes (Table 4).In an investigation of laser milling with a $1 . 0 7 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ Yb:YAG laser, Zamani et al. [56] mention determining an absorptivity of $0 . 2 7 ~ + / - ~ 0 . 0 3$ based on‘metallographic studies accompanied by numerical simulation'.No further detail of their method is given but it is presumed to be analogous to that employed here.Rai etal.[57] employedan absorptivity of O.30 to model keyhole welds formed in Ti-6Al-4V plates by a $1 . 0 6 4 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ Nd:YAG laser. This value is not referenced but their prior work [58] describes how to measure absorptivity by matching simulation results to weld geometry. Laboratory measurements of molten Ti-6Al-4V absorptivity are scarce, as outlined earlier.Ye etal.[25] used a $1 . 0 8 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ laser to heat various powders and,with some heat loss assumptions,applied a calorimetric method to obtain the effective melt absorptivity.Most values were increased by reflection and keyhole effects but their minimum of 0.26, obtained fora bare plate at low laser power,should approximate the intrinsic absorptivity.By measuring backscattering with a stationary
