$1 . 0 7 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ laser, Simonds et al.[27] observed an absorptivity of $0 . 3 3 + / \mathrm { - }$ 0.03 for molten Ti-6Al-4V during a $2 \ m s$ period before a keyhole developed.Emissivity data for molten Ti-6Al-4V have also been recorded (0.395 by Cezairliyan etal.[17] and O.35-0.40 by Boivineau et al. [20]) but at wavelengths of O.65 and $0 . 6 8 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,respectively,so significantly lower values would be expected at LPBF wavelengths.We conclude that our value of $0 . 2 7 + / - \ : 0 . 0 3$ falls within the range of the relevant melt data and turn now to a discussion of the behaviour at high laser power.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-41
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
The apparent increase in effective absorptivity which we observe at higher laser powers is a commonly observed phenomenon in LPBF. Virtually all melt pool CFD simulations which include validation against experimental track dimensions report discrepancies very reminiscent of those found in the current work, namely that the fusion width and depth are under-predicted when the energy density is increased. Such underprediction is seen for a range of build materials (Ti-6Al-4V [50,51], steels [52-54],Mo [54],Ni alloy [59]) with the maximum error ranging from about 20 to $5 0 ~ \%$ 、All these studies employed a constant absorptivity which produced a good match of the simulated dimensions with experiment at lower laser powers.Omission of multiple laser reflections from some of these simulations contributed to under-prediction but it still occurred even when reflected rays were included,like in the current work.

There are two characteristics of the data at high laser power that need to be reconciled.The most obvious is that the fusion zone width is underestimated,and to a lesser extent the depth.The other is that the HAZ dimensions remain well-predicted.This finding about the HAZ is significant as,to the authors'knowledge,no previous simulations of LPBF have investigated this aspect. (Karayagiz etal.[49] did compare simulated HAZ dimensions to experiment but only in conduction mode with a single combination of laser power and speed.) The HAZ finding adds an important constraint on explanations for the high-power behaviour.We now explore a variety of possible causes,including those put forward in the literature.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-42
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
The assumption of a constant intrinsic absorptivity,as applied in the current simulations,must first be examined.For example,a melt absorptivity that increased with temperature might improve the calibration.However,such a temperature dependence appears unlikely since laboratory emissivity data for molten Ti6Al4V[2O] and Ti [6O] display, if anything,a slight tendency towards the opposite trend.Perhaps the increasing fraction of laser power incident on molten rather than solid surfaces might somehow be responsible.This explanation can also be discounted as the fraction is already close to 1.O (refer Fig.1O) and,in any case,melt absorptivity is markedly lower than the solid absorptivity so that a larger fraction would reduce the laser heating.

Another possibility is that the laser beam width increases at high power for some reason.We tested this idea with a sensitivity test based on Experiment 6,which at 30o W and $6 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ exemplifies the keyhole regime.The simulated fusion zone width and depth were l68 and 180 $\mu \mathrm { m }$ ,respectively,both under-predicting the experimental values of 247 and $2 0 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ as we have noted.When the analysis was repeated with the beam width increased by $1 0 ~ \%$ (at constant total power),the simulated width increased to $1 8 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ but the depth decreases, to $1 6 3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .From this and other tests,we found that broadening the beam to better match the experimental width enlarges the contact area of the melt pool with the underlying substrate so that the depth drops,and faster than the width increases.The overall agreement is not improved so it is concluded that the calibration mismatch is not simply due to error in the beam width.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-43
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: The remaining explanation for under-prediction in the keyhole regime is that energy transfer from the laser beam to the substrate is enhanced by some mechanism which is missing from current LPBF models.It appears more complex than just invoking an effective absorptivity greater than the intrinsic material value.We simulated that case with a sensitivity test based on Experiment 6; increasing the absorptivity by $2 0 \%$ increased the fusion width and depth by $1 3 \%$ and 26 $\%$ ,respectively.Although these movements are in the desired direction, we require the width to increase faster than depth for an improved experimental match.Furthermore,the associated increases in HAZ width anddepth ( $1 6 ~ \%$ and $2 4 ~ \%$ respectively) move both dimensions away from the experimental results.In general terms,we conclude that improving the model agreement with keyhole mode results requires slightly more heat deposition and,more importantly,a partial redistribution from the beam centre out toward larger radii. There are several mechanisms operating in the keyhole regime which might create such behaviour,and we start by examining vapour effects.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-44
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: The vapour produced by melt evaporation has several influences to consider.First,it exerts a drag force on the melt surface.In laser welding,this can broaden the keyhole by pushing the liquid outward around the keyhole rim [61,62] and thereby increase the fusion zone width.It is an open question whether vapour drag can similarly broaden the melt pool in LPBF,but it seems likely.We know that vapour release creates a recoil pressure which can depress the melt surface.(For example, removing the recoil pressure term from the simulation of Experiment 6 reduces the fusion zone depth from 180 to $8 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .) The vapour jet is also sufficiently powerful to entrain powder particles adjacent to the track and then eject them,along with spattered melt droplets [63,64].Second, the vapour plume can attenuate the incident laser beam.This is wellestablished in welding and also seen in LPBF where fine metal particles in the vapour, smaller than $1 0 0 \ \mathrm { n m }$ ,reduce laser intensity by Rayleigh scattering [65-67].For Ti6Al4V in LPBF conditions,Ye etal. [25] found a $1 0 \%$ reduction in effective absorptivity was necessary to match experimental data and ascribed it to this scattering mechanism.In keyhole welding applications,the plume often broadens the heating profile as well [66].However,this is largely due to inverse Bremsstrahlung heating [57] which is absent for the shorter laser wavelengths used in LPBF [67,68].For LPBF,it is even conceivable that a vapour concentration in the keyhole could trap radiation and narrow the heating profile,if that extra heat is efficiently transferred to the keyhole wall.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-45
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: Next,we turn our attention to the influence of the keyhole surface geometry on laser heating. The keyhole geometry is highly unstable because of the complex interplay between laser heating,multiple reflections,shadowing,vapour emission with associated recoil, Marangoni stirring and other factors.The considerable literature on this behaviour forkeyhole laserwelding,reviewed recently [62],is largelyapplicable to LPBF as well.A detailed description is not attempted here but we note some key observations from recent X-ray imaging of LPBF [69,70]. Because the melt surface is removed faster than beam velocity [71],a periodic series of'humps’run down the front of the keyhole surface, sized up toa few tens of $\mu \mathrm { m }$ 、Avariety of other surface oscillations are seen,some generated by the collapse of vapour pockets created by reflection concentrations on the rear keyhole wall. The fluctuations of keyhole shape increase with laser energy and create pinched-off voids that impact part quality as unwanted porosity.All these geometric perturbations increase the overall energy transfer by producing more laser reflections than would arise from a simple concavity.The Fresnel behaviour,i.e. that the intrinsic absorptivity passes through a peak at high angles of incidence,augments the overall absorption still further [13].Surface instabilities generated by melt evaporation on an even smaller scale,similar to or less than the laser wavelength,can enhance laser absorption by trapping reflections.This is usually regarded as an increase in intrinsic absorptivity. Such ‘micro-roughness’is thought to occur from surface ripples generated by vapour drag,predicted theoretically by Golubev[72],or from the related Rayleigh-Taylor instability of a gas moving over a denser fluid.The latter phenomenon was invoked by Schneider et al.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-46
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
[28] to explain a jump in absorptivity when high energy densities were reached during laser drilling of metal plates,after they eliminated alternatives such as plume absorption or multiple reflections.

The melt flow pattern constitutes another source of possible causes for the under-prediction of fusion dimensions since heat transfer from the melt to the substrate relies on convection as well as conduction.

High-speed X-ray imaging of tracer particles has recently provided the first detailed 3D visualisations of flow during LPBF [73].The melt circulation pattern in conduction mode is (relatively) simple and welldescribed by CFD simulations which incorporate Marangoni stirring and buoyancy,such as in the current work,so CFD heat transfer predictions should be accurate in this regime.However,as laser intensity increases into the keyhole regime,the observed flow pattern becomes more complex with at least half a dozen shifting vortices observed [73]. Vapour recoil and vapour shearadd to the fluid forces,with rapid smallscale surface fluctuations creating further complication.Even advanced simulations cannot accurately capture all this behaviour at present. Since convective heat transfer is thought to dominate conduction in the keyhole (Peclet numbers of order 10 are observed there [73]),any error in the simulated flow could affect the predicted fusion dimensions.Some sensitivity tests based on the Experiment 6 simulation were therefore conducted.To gauge the effect of the overall velocity magnitudes,melt viscosity was increased by a factor of 2.Although the melt kinetic energy decreased by about $3 0 \ \%$ ，the fusion width and depth changed (decreased) by only $1 \%$ and $5 \%$ ,respectively,and the HAZ even less.To determine the sensitivity to the degree of lateral circulation,the Marangoni driving force was increased by $5 0 ~ \%$ .The melt kinetic energy increased by about $1 0 ~ \%$ ,but the fusion and HAZ dimension changes were less than $2 \%$

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-47
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: The final aspect to consider is the possibility of turbulent melt flow effects.As with virtually all published CFD simulations of LPBF,melt flow has been modelled here as laminar.Although turbulence has not been detected by direct methods such as flow visualisation of welding [74] or LPBF [73] melt pools,the Reynolds numbers during LPBF exceeds the accepted criterion of 6oo for the onset of turbulence in locations where vapour production is strong [15].Detailed numerical analyses of turbulence generated by Marangoni flow in simplified melt geometries also indicate that turbulence is probably present in LPBF conditions [75].However,note that turbulence does not actually affect melt heat transfer unless convection dominates conduction and turbulent eddy thermal difusivity is significant compared to molecular thermal diffusivity.From a scaling analysis of Marangoni flow,Chakraborty and Chakraborty [76] defined Prandtl number threshold values required to satisfy these two conditions,each being a function of the pool aspect ratio and a dimensionless number involving the surface driving force and melt properties.It is not clear whether turbulence is important in the current experiments.We examined the Experiment 6 results and obtained ambiguous Reynolds numbers,above or below 600 depending on the method of estimation,but did find that the two Prandtl number criteria were satisfied.Using approximations described by Kidess etal.[75],we estimated the eddy diffusivity to be similar to the molecular diffusivity.To approximate that eddy diffusivity contribution, we re-ran the Experiment 6 simulation with the melt thermal conductivity doubled and observed a spreading of the melt pool,with a $1 0 ~ \%$ increase in fusion zone width and $7 \%$ reduction in depth. On the other hand, we directly implemented a k-ε turbulence model in another test simulation and found it had less than $2 \%$ effect on the fusion and HAZ dimensions.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-48
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: Taken together,all the above results indicate that errors in the flow pattern and turbulence were not significant contributors to the dimensional discrepancies observed here.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-49
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content:
We have successfully determined the absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by calibrating simulation against experiment.The value obtained of $0 . 2 7 + / - 0 . 0 3$ can be applied to simulate part production during normal (conduction mode) conditions.It is better suited to that purpose than laboratory-based data as it is obtained in-situ on the actual melt surface at realistic laser angles and wavelength $( 1 . 0 7 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ ．The value is consistent with Ti-6Al-4V absorptivities measured during other laser processes (milling and welding).It falls near the lower end of the range used in most Ti-6Al-4V LPBF simulations to date,which implies that many studies may have over-estimated the heat supplied to the part.

More importantly,the same method of calibrated simulation can be adopted to find the absorptivity of other materials commonly used in LPBF,such as ferrous,aluminium and nickel-based alloys.Having established the simulation methodology,the experimental procedure is relatively straightforward.The uncertainty in the fitted absorptivity value can of course be reduced by performing a larger set of experiments.Perhaps the greatest difficulty is in sourcing the hightemperature material properties required for accurate simulation,and upon which the absorptivity calibration relies.It is hoped that the table of material properties assembled here for Ti-6Al-4V will assist other researchers and be updated as better measurements are published.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-50
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: At high laser intensities,the system transitions from conduction to keyhole mode and the fusion zone dimensions,especially width,are observed to exceed simulation predictions.This is seen in other studies, but the current work goes further by also comparing the dimensions of the heat-affected zone in this regime with simulations.The HAZ is found to still be quite well-predicted,which implies that the fusion zone discrepancies stem mainly from under-estimating the breadth of heat transfer to the part,rather than the amount.Possible causes were examined in the three broad categories of vapour plume,keyhole surface geometry and melt pool flow effects.In the first category,broadening of the keyhole aperture by vapour drag and broadening of the laser beam by Rayleigh scattering off metal particles in the plume both appear possible.With regard to keyhole geometry,it is likely that multiple laser reflections are under-estimated by not fully capturing the detail of surface waves and perturbations,and micro-roughness of the melt surface would also increase absorption. In the third category,sensitivity analyses indicated that flow circulation error or turbulence were not significant causes,at least for the experiments here.

name: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c-part-51
fileName: 2023 - Optics and Laser Technology - Cook, Ritchie - Determining the laser absorptivity of Ti-6Al-4V during laser powder bed fusion by c.pdf
content: Further progress in delineating the under-prediction causes in keyhole mode will require advances in simulation capabilities.Most of the missing physical mechanisms have previously been simulated but only as part of models with a restricted scope. For example,one group has been able to simulate vapour-driven particle motion during LPBF [64],but not yet with a coupling to melt flow.Another group reconstructed actual keyhole surface geometries during laser welding from high-speed imagery and simulated laser absorption in considerable detail,including shadowing and the Fresnel angular dependence [77] of multiple reflections.Combining all the required individual capabilities into an all-encompassing model is very challenging but necessary for an accurate description of LPBF keyhole behaviour since most effects are strongly coupled.Reliable material data are essential to underpin such development and we believe that in-situ absorptivities determined by the method we have outlined will assist in that regard.

fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf

summary: Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and porosity in additive manufacturing of Ti-6Al-4V

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-2
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
# Abstract
Metal thre-dimensional (3D)printing involves a multitude ofoperational and material parameters that exhibit intricate interdependencies,which pose challenges to real-time process optimization, monitoring,and controlling.The dynamic behaviorof the laser-induced melt pool strongly influences the final printed part quality bycontrolling the absorptionof laser power and impacting defect creation,porosity,and surface finish.By leveraging ultrahigh-speed synchrotron X-ray imaging and high-fidelity multiphysics modeling, we identify correlations between laser processparameters, keyhole and melt pool morphologies,laser absorptance,and porosityin metal 3Dprinting of Ti-6Al-4V,aiding inthe developmentof effective printing strategies.Our models accurately predict the geometries and shapes of melt pools and keyholes,laser absorptance,and the size and shape of keyhole-induced pores duringtheadditive manufacturing processs using different laser parameters,forboth bare and powder cases. This work establishes robust correlations among processparameters,melt pool and keyhole morphology,and materials properties.These findings provide valuable insights into thecomplex interplay among diffrent design factors in metal 3Dprinting,laying astrong foundation forthe developmentof highly effective and efficient additive manufacturing processes.

Keywords Thermal-fluid model $\cdot$ Discrete element method $\cdot$ Finite element method $\cdot$ Multiphysics $\cdot$ Phase transformation $\cdot$ Solidification $\cdot$ High-speed X-ray imaging

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-3
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: Additive manufacturing (AM), also known as 3D printing, has emerged as a groundbreaking technique, offering unparalleled capabilities to fabricate intricate parts with fine structures.This transformative technology,however, includes many material and process parameters that exhibit complex interdependencies [1-4]. This inherent complexity poses significant challenges to fully understanding the transient behavior of the melt pool and keyhole dynamics,as well as the energy coupling mechanisms that occur between the high-power laser and the material. However, understanding these mechanisms is of paramount importance.Instabilities in the melt pool and keyhole (or vapor depression) can result in a multitude of structural irregularities that compromise the structural integrity and performance of the built parts [5-7]. Porosity, for instance, can be a direct consequence of these instabilities [8],along with phenomena like the balling effect [9], spattering [1O],and the emergence of anomalous microstructural phases [11]. These defects not only influence the mechanical properties of the printed components but can also pose a barrier to their implementation in critical applications,where the use of additive manufacturing parts for fracture-critical purposes remains a consideration. Therefore,a comprehensive understanding of the underlying phenomena governing the melt pool and keyhole dynamics is necessary for process optimization,real-time monitoring and control, and porosity mitigations.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-4
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: Among the various AM techniques,Laser Beam Powder Bed Fusion (LB-PBF) in particular is recognized for its adeptness in 3D printing metals, particularly Ti-6Al-4V, enabling the production of parts with intricate features, optimized geometries,and reduced weight [12-16]. Nevertheless,the LB-PBF processing of Ti-6Al-4V necessitates in-depth exploration of the fusion and melt pool dynamics to comprehensively understand the material-laser interactions.This understanding encompasses a wide range of multiphysical phenomena,including heat and mass transfer, phase transitions,and solidification. Given the challenges tied to experimentally characterizing these interconnected processes,the development of multiphysics models stands out as an effective approach to disclose the key parameters governing the process and defects throughout the AM process.Numerical simulations for Ti-6Al-4V within metal AM play a pivotal role in optimizing process parameters and ensuring the quality and performance of manufactured parts.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-5
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: Current numerical simulations in Ti-6Al-4V research primarily used advanced computational techniques,including finite element/volume methods (FEM/FVM) and control volume finite element methods (CVFEM),to investigate melt pool dynamics and defect formation [13,17-29]. These studies provide insights into phenomena such as melt pool dynamics, keyhole instability,and potential manufacturing defects including pore formation, surface roughness,lack of fusion between build layers,spatter, and balling.Martin et al.[13] conducted simulations focusing on the keyhole pores located at the end of the welding track to provide a strategy aimed at minimizing the occurrence of these pores. In another work,Lin et al. [3O] employed simulations to reveal that adjusting the incident angle of the laser beam could effectively reduce the prevalence of keyhole pores in laser welding processes. Bayat et al. [27] investigated the correlation between input power and the formation of keyhole pores and evaluated their simulation findings using experimental results.Wang et al. [26] studied the mechanisms of keyhole pore formation during AM process and examined the lifetime dynamics of keyhole pore generation mechanisms and their corresponding keyhole melting regimes under different conditions. Khairallah et al. [23] investigated the interdependent meso-nanosecond dynamics and defect generation in metal 3D printing using a combination of in situ diagnostics and simulations.Their study revealed that controlling the laser scanning conditions can circumvent spatter and reduce defect generation,and that the thermionic emission is correlated to laser scanning conditions that give rise to pore formation and regions where surface defects are pronounced.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-6
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: In metal AM, the heat transfer to Ti-6Al-4V parts depends on the absorbed fraction of laser power,which is affected by various factors such as laser wavelength, incidence and polarization angle, the part temperature, surface roughness,and oxidation [31,32]. The accuracy of the simulations depends strongly on the material parameters set in the models;specifically,material absorptance is defined as the ratio of absorbed versus incident radiant flux at a specific location during the AM process [33]. Notably, there have been very few investigations focused on simulating the absorptance of material, specifically for Ti-6Al-4V, primarily due to the complex interplay of various physics involved in the process [26, 32]. Cook and Ritchie [32] focused on determining the laser absorptance of Ti-6Al-4V during LBPBF by using calibrated melt pool simulation.Their study provided a better understanding of the laser absorptance of Ti-6Al-4V during LB-PBF and determining.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-7
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: While it is true that this titanium alloy has been extensively researched in the context of AM and LB-PBF, the focus of this study on Ti-6Al-4V was driven by the persistent challenges that limit its manufacturing efficiency and material properties. Furthermore, the majority of existing literature primarily emphasizes the development of models to examine these mechanisms and trends, often lacking rigorous experimental validation.This paper aims to enhance our understanding of process parameter effects on the melt pool and keyhole dynamics,material absorptance,and pore formation during LB-PBF of Ti-6Al-4V by using fully coupled multiphysics meso-scale simulations and ultrahighspeed synchrotron X-ray imaging.The approach used here is to(1) develop and calibrate a high-fidelity multiphysics model to simulate the LB-PBF process and the dynamics of different features including melt pool and keyhole,(2) evaluate quantitatively and qualitatively the simulation predictions against experimental results including in situ X-ray images and absorptance measurements,and(3) disclose interconnections and correlations among melt pool and keyhole dynamics,material absorption,and pore formation.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-8
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-9
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: Model validations were performed using data from experiments previously reported on by Simonds et al. [34]. The processing of Ti-6Al-4V material entailed a combination of high-speed X-ray imaging,laser melting,and in situ laser power absorptance measurements.These experiments were conducted at the 32-ID-B beamline of the Advanced Photon Source located at Argonne National Laboratory. The Ti-6Al-4V plate specimens were prepared from NIST Standard Reference Material 654b through wire electric discharge machining and further thinned to a target thickness of approximately $3 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ by polishing the surfaces facing the $\mathbf { X }$ -rays.In experiments involving powder,a Ti-6Al-4V sample was carefully sandwiched between two glassy carbon plates,each $1 \mathrm { m m }$ thick,creating a trough-like structure into which the powder was uniformly distributed.The Ti-6Al-4V powder, sourced from the Goodfellow Corporation in Pittsburgh,PA,USA and designated as Grade 23 [35],underwent gas atomization to preserve its spherical particle morphology, with a maximum particle size of $4 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-10
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
The laser utilized in the process operated at a wavelength of $1 0 7 0 \mathrm { n m }$ and was a Yb-doped fiber laser. For all simultaneous X-ray and absorptance measurements, the beam profile at the sample surface was meticulously assessed, resulting in a calculated diameter (with a $1 / \mathrm { e } ^ { 2 }$ value） of $1 2 2 . 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } \pm 3 . 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ 、This calculation was derived from a series of beam profile measurements conducted at various heights, which revealed a minimum spot size,or beam waist, of $4 9 . 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } \pm 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ . The beam profile,as measured within the observed range,exhibits an almost Gaussian distribution with a minor degree of ellipticity exceeding $9 2 \%$ . To control the laser duration and scanning,a galvanometer scanner is employed, ensuring a constant $7 ^ { \circ }$ angle of incidence between the process laser beam and the sample surface.

The Ti-6Al-4V samples were subjected to laser melting within a controlled environment, maintained through rough vacuum pumping and argon backfilling. Laser melting was carried out at a constant velocity of $7 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / \mathrm { s }$ ,employing a sky-write strategy to ensure consistent velocity during laser activation. The temporal duration of the laser pulse,which is approximately $2 \mathrm { m s }$ in length,is provided alongside the tabulated absorptance data.Detailed procedures specific to the beamline and integrating sphere radiometry can be found in references [34, 36-38].

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-11
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
The methodology employed in this study for multiphysics modeling closely aligns with a framework previously introduced and elucidated by Samaei et al. [39]. In this section, we explain the main aspects of this approach including the governing equations representing different physical phenomena in our simulations.Additionally, the thermophysical properties, geometric configurations,and process parameters are given for the models in detail.

The main goal of the simulations is to investigate the underlying correlations among different physical phenomena including effective absorptance,porosity,and process parameters duringLB-PBF.To increase the accuracy of the results for subsequent analyses,we consider physics relevant to both particle and part scales.Particle-scale features include particle size and distribution.However, the effect of particle shape on the resulting powder configuration is not taken into account in this study due to enhancing the computational expense as well as its negligible impact on the melt pool and keyhole morphologies,which is the subject of this study. The dynamics of the melt pool and surface morphology during the process are simulated, taking into account surface tension,Marangoni force,evaporation recoil pressure and heat loss,buoyancy,laser-material interactions, and solidification.

Three immiscible phases-metal liquid, metal solid,and gas phases-are present in the domain of numerical simulation.Mass and momentum conservation equations are employed to model the multi-phase flow problem:

$$
\frac { \partial \rho } { \partial t } + \pmb { \nabla } \cdot ( \rho \mathbf { u } ) = 0 ,
$$

$$
\begin{array} { r l r } {  { \frac { \partial } { \partial t } ( \rho \mathbf { u } ) + \nabla \cdot ( \rho \mathbf { u u } ) = \ - \nabla p + \nabla \cdot ( \mu ( \nabla \mathbf { u } + \nabla \mathbf { u } ^ { T } ) ) } } \\ & { } & \\ & { } & { + p \mathbf { g } \beta ( T - T _ { r e f } ) - A \mathbf { u } , } \end{array}
$$

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-12
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
where $\rho$ and $\mathbf { u }$ denote the fluid density,and flow velocity, respectively. Additionally, $p$ is the pressure, $\mu$ is the fluid viscosity, $\mathbf { g }$ is the gravitational acceleration, $\beta$ is the thermal expansion coefficient,and $T _ { \mathrm { r e f } }$ is the reference temperature. The coefficient $A$ represents the Kozeny-Carman permeability of a packed bed, dependent on the liquid fraction $f _ { \mathrm { L } }$ which pertains to the transition zone known as the“mushy region"[40, 41]:

$$
A = \frac { 1 8 0 \mu } { \lambda _ { 1 } ^ { 2 } } \frac { ( 1 - f _ { \mathrm { L } } ) ^ { 2 } } { f _ { \mathrm { L } } ^ { 3 } } ,
$$

where $\lambda _ { 1 }$ is the characteristic length of the mushy region. The liquid fraction linearly increases from O to 1 between the solidus temperature $T _ { \mathrm { { S } } }$ and liquidus temperature $T _ { \mathrm { { L } } }$

$$
f _ { \mathrm { L } } = \theta \big ( T - T _ { \mathrm { S } } \big ) \cdot \Bigg ( 1 - \theta \bigg ( \frac { T - T _ { \mathrm { S } } } { T _ { \mathrm { L } } - T _ { \mathrm { S } } } \bigg ) \Bigg ) + \theta \big ( T - T _ { \mathrm { L } } \big ) ,
$$

where $\theta$ is the Heaviside step function. The energy conservation equation is applied to compute the temperature field within the computational domain:

$$
\frac { \partial ( \rho h ) } { \partial t } + \pmb { \nabla } \cdot ( \rho \boldsymbol { u } h ) = \pmb { \nabla } \cdot ( \kappa \pmb { \nabla } T ) ,
$$

where $h$ and $\kappa$ represent enthalpy and heat conductivity, respectively. The volume of fluid (VOF) method is used to track the melt pool interface over time. The governing equation for the volume of fluid satisfies the advection equation:

$$
\frac { \partial \phi } { \partial t } + \mathbf { u } \cdot \pmb { \nabla } \phi = 0 ,
$$

where $\Phi ( x , t )$ is the volume fraction of metal including both liquid and solid phases. The VOF equation is solved after the mass and momentum equations and energy equation at each timestep.

The laser model integrates both laser physics and interactions between the laser and materials. Key laser parameters such as beam diameter, power,and scanning speed are set based on experimental setups.The ray tracing method [42, 43] is used to simulate the complex interaction between laser and materials during the AM process.This approach takes into account multiple reflections influenced by the shape of the keyhole. The calculation of absorptance follows from the Fresnel equation [27]:

In this study, the material constant $\varepsilon$ equals 0.15.

The thermal boundary condition applied to the energy equation includes both a surface heat flux from interaction with the laser,and heat loss due to surface convection,radiation,and evaporation. The laser beam is estimated to have a Gaussian profile,which is reasonable given measurements [44]:

$$
Q _ { \mathrm { L a s e r } } = \frac { 2 P } { \pi r _ { \mathrm { b } } ^ { 2 } } \exp { \left( - \frac { 2 r ^ { 2 } } { r _ { \mathrm { b } } ^ { 2 } } \right) } ,
$$

where $r$ is the radial distance from the laser beam center and $r _ { \mathrm { b } }$ is the effective radius of the laser beam,where the heat flux is $1 / e ^ { 2 }$ of its maximum value.The contributions to surface heat loss can be written:

$$
Q _ { \mathrm { C o n v } } = h _ { \mathrm { c } } \big ( T - T _ { 0 } \big ) ,
$$

$$
Q _ { \mathrm { R a d } } = \sigma \epsilon \big ( T ^ { 4 } - T _ { 0 } ^ { 4 } \big ) ,
$$

$$
Q _ { \mathrm { E v a p } } = \frac { 0 . 0 1 } { \sqrt { 2 \pi R _ { \nu } T } } P _ { a } \exp { \left( \frac { \Delta H _ { \mathrm { l v } } } { R _ { \nu } T _ { \mathrm { b o i l } } } \left( 1 - \frac { T _ { \mathrm { b o i l } } } { T } \right) \right) } ,
$$

$$
Q _ { \mathrm { L o s s } } = Q _ { \mathrm { C o n v } } + Q _ { \mathrm { R a d } } + Q _ { \mathrm { E v a p } } ,
$$

The evaporation cooling is approximated by Clausius-Clapeyron equation, where $\Delta H _ { \mathrm { l v } }$ stands for latent heat of Ti-6Al-4V evaporation, $P _ { \alpha }$ is the atmospheric pressure,and $R _ { \mathrm { v } }$ is the gas constant for evaporated Ti-6Al-4V material.

Surface forces provide a boundary condition on the momentum equation.These are the recoil pressure that causes a melt pool depression after the Ti-6Al-4V temperature rises above its evaporation point $T _ { \mathrm { b o i l } }$ ,and Marangoni and capillary effects resulting from the temperature-dependent surface tension field of Ti-6Al-4V:

$$
P _ { \mathrm { r e c o i l } } = 0 . 5 4 P _ { \alpha } \exp { \left( \frac { \Delta H _ { \mathrm { l v } } } { R _ { \mathrm { v } } T _ { \mathrm { b o i l } } } \left( 1 - \frac { T _ { \mathrm { b o i l } } } { T } \right) \right) } ,
$$

{ \bf F } _ { \gamma } = \gamma \kappa { \bf n } + ( \nabla T - { \bf n } ( \nabla T \cdot { \bf n } ) ) \frac { \partial \gamma } { \partial T } ,
$$

where $\gamma$ is the surface tension at surface temperature $T , \kappa$ is the curvature of the exposed Ti-6Al-4V metallic phase

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-18

content:
Four distinct configurations were modeled using FLOW3D [50] to replicate the experimental setups. These configurations included both stationary and scanning laser scenarios,each applied to solid substrates both with and without powder layers.To generate the powder layers, we conducted two sequential simulations using the discrete element method (DEM) [39]. In the first step,a cluster of 206,500 particles composed of Ti-6Al-4V was randomly set above a corresponding solid substrate.The particles were then allowed to fall naturally, accumulating on top of the substrate.In the following step,a layer of powder $1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ thick was created on the substrate by spreading particles using a recoater blade.The dimensions of this blade were $8 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $x$ -direction) by $5 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $y$ -direction) by $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ （ $z$ -direction).

Next, the simulated powder particle coordinates and sizes were used to establish the initial geometry within the thermal-fluid model. This approach was applied to two types of substrates including distinct powder beds due to changes in sizes,as shown in Fig.1(i, j).These powder beds were uniquely created for different scenarios to avoid anyparticle-substrate overlap.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-19
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
For the stationary cases,a 3D simulation domain was created with dimensions of $6 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ （ $x$ -direction) by $4 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ $y$ -direction） by $1 5 6 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ $z$ -direction).This domain was used for simulating thermal multi-phase flow associated with LB-PBF processes.The same configuration was used for all the models to ensure that the melt pool boundaries remain within the domain.When using higher energy levels,we observe wider melt pool widths and depths as a precaution to prevent them from exceeding the domain boundaries.In contrast, for scanning laser cases,the simulation domain extended across $1 7 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $x$ -direction), $4 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ （ $y$ -direction),and $7 4 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ （ $\scriptstyle { \bar { z } }$ -direction) to replicate a single-track scanning process. The dimensions of the substrates for both cases are shown in Fig. $1 ( i , j )$ . It is noted that the substrates across all scenarios including both stationary and scanning lasers were inclined at a $7 ^ { \circ }$ angle relative to the normal incidence, according to the experimental setup.(This slight angle was required for accurate absorptance measurements using the integrating sphere.)

To perform simulations,a structured mesh was used, characterized by $7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ cubical cells.The models included a total of 1,093,146 mesh cells for spot cases and 1,468,206 mesh cells for scanning cases.In scanning laser cases, the laser was moved along the positive $\mathbf { X }$ -axis from $( x , y ) = ( 5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ to( $1 6 5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ to form the track. The powder and material properties used for the simulations are listed in Table 1.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-20
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: In this work,a total of 95 simulations were carried out. These simulations encompassed two main categories: 45 simulations involving stationary laser setups (including 24 cases with bare solid substrate and 21 cases with substrates covered by a powder layer),and 50 simulations involving scanning laser configurations (including 27 cases of bare solid substrate and 23 cases with substrates covered by a powder bed). The models were set across a spectrum of power levels ranging from 100 to 450 W. Additionally, a wide range of scanning speeds, from $3 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m / s }$ to $1 3 0 0 \mathrm { m m / s }$ ,was considered. The spot size was also varied, featuring diameters of $8 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ， $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,and $1 2 2 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . The selection of laser parameters in our study was guided by the goal of covering a wide range of operational scenarios, specifically chosen for their relevance in current laserbased manufacturing processes and for comparison with experimental data. The parameters, including laser power, scanning speed,and spot size,were chosen to be similar to those of the laser available for experiments performed at the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Lab to ensure consistency and relevance in our simulations. Additionally,experimentally, these selections mimic typical build conditions and give a melt pool that can be measured.This comprehensive approach allowed for the exploration of an expansive parametric space.These simulations were performed to validate the models against experimental measurements and data,as well as to examine the interplay of these varied process parameters (e.g., laser power, scanning speed, and spot size). The latter specifically focused on the interactions between melt pool and keyhole geometries, as well as characteristics including absorption,and pore formation.

content:
To assess the developed models in this work, we compared the simulation results against the experimental data.Twodimensional cross-sections of the thermal-fluid simulations were automatically processed and evaluated using MATLAB's image processing toolbox.Experimental images were manually segmented to capture the melt pool boundaries in low-contrast conditions.Melt pool and keyhole depths/ widths were taken from the maximum vertical/horizontal distance between identified boundaries.For all images, pixel sizes were between $1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .L2 error normalized to the experiment was calculated using the formula:

$$
e _ { L 2 } = \frac { \left\| x _ { \mathrm { e x p } } - x _ { \mathrm { s i n } } \right\| _ { 2 } } { \left\| x _ { \mathrm { e x p } } \right\| _ { 2 } } .
$$

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-23
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: To evaluate the stationary laser models, three simulations were conducted,each involving different configurations and/ or process parameters.Specifically, two simulations were carried out on bare substrates exposed to laser powers of $1 7 2 \ \mathrm { W }$ and 201 W, respectively. Additionally, a simulation was performed for a substrate covered by a powder bed with a laser power of 2O1 W. The spot diameter is identical for all cases and is equal to $1 2 2 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .We maintained consistent process conditions and configurations during simulations to align with the experimental setups.Figures 2 and 3 show comparisons and analyses for the melt pool and keyhole shapes and geometries.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-24
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: Figure 2 presents measurements of both melt pool depth and width obtained from three abovementioned simulations during the AM processes,encompassing the entire processing time from the initiation of melting to the full resolidification of the material.It is noted that the depth of melt pool is measured from the upper surface of the solid substrate to the lowest point within the melt pool region. This measurement is consistent across all cases,including those with and without powder beds.The relative L2 errors for melt pool depth are 0.3246, 0.3877,and 0.7587 for Fig.2(a, c, e), respectively. The relative L2 errors for melt pool width are 0.1971, 0.1691,and 0.4592 for Fig. 2(b, d,f),respectively. While the melt pool depths obtained from simulations were overestimated compared to the experimental values, the melt pool widths were more closely captured by simulations.It is worth mentioning that quantifying certain aspects of the $\mathbf { X }$ -ray images were challenging,particularly in realizing the melt pool interface,as can be seen in Fig.2(c,e,f).As an additional resource, videos displaying the melt pool dynamics for different cases, which were captured using high-speed in situ synchrotron X-ray imaging,are provided as supplementary material to this paper and in these references [34, 51].

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-25
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: An interesting observation can be made when we compare the melt pool depths and widths between bare substrates and substrates covered with powder beds, both subjected to the same laser power, as shown in Fig.2(b, c, d, f).We note that both the melt pool depth and width for bare substrates exceed those of substrates with powder beds.This implies that the presence of a powder bed, even at a relatively modest thickness of $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,imposes a notable influence on (or delay into the bulk) the laser penetration dynamics. This leads to a reduction in both melt pool depth and width when compared to the scenarios involving bare substrates.This phenomenon can be linked to the inherent properties of the powder layer. The powder bed acts as a barrier that absorbs and disperses some of the incoming laser energy before it reaches the solid substrate beneath. Thus, the heat generation and subsequent melt pool formation are delayed and somewhat suppressed in the presence of the powder layer. This effect underscores the importance of considering powder bed characteristics when optimizing laser-based AM processes. Similar behavior can be seen for keyhole length and width shown in Fig. 3(b,c, d, f).

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-26
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
Figure 3 provides a comprehensive comparison of the keyhole length and width between simulation results and the corresponding experimental data for different cases. It is noted that, in these measurements,we used the upper surface of the solid substrate as the reference line for keyhole length and width analyses.In instances where both the continuous bulk and fragmented break-up regions (bubbles) coexist within the same frame (as shown in Fig. 4),we quantified the keyhole length by solely accounting for the continuous, connected portion while disregarding the separated break-up part. The relative L2 errors for keyhole length are 0.3928, 0.3601,and 0.5888 for Fig. 3(a, c, e),respectively. The relative L2 errors for keyhole width are O.352O, 0.2795, and O.359O for Fig. 3(b,d, f),respectively. In contrast to the relatively stable behavior of melt pool depth,keyhole lengths show significant temporal fluctuations in these cases. These significant temporal fluctuations in keyhole lengths are attributed to the dynamic nature of keyholes during the laser-powder interaction process.As the laser beam interacts with the material and/or powder bed,different factors come into play, such as the ejection of vapor and the interaction of the laser energy with the surrounding environment, that lead to variations in keyhole length over time [24,51]. Similarly,although to a lesser extent,fluctuations are observed in keyhole widths. These fluctuations,while smaller in range compared to keyhole length, can be attributed to variations in the deposition of materials and the local thermal conditions within the keyhole.In sum, the dynamic nature of keyholes,coupled with the intricate interplay of laser energy, material properties,and powder bed configurations, results in the temporal fluctuations observed in both keyhole length and width,as shown in the simulations and confirmed by experimental measurements.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-27
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
Figure 4 provides snapshots highlighting key features within the melt pool region, including the keyhole, bubbles, and pores,obtained from both experimental data and simulations.These in situ imaging snapshots serve as valuable sources for identifying the dynamics features that emerge during the AM process,enabling us to visually inspect and compare simulated melt pools.In particular, three prominent features are evident in Fig. 4: the melt pool region, keyhole,and pore. These features undergo continuous changes throughout the AM process,implying the interplay of heat transfer, material flow,and laser energy absorption.

with a laser power of 261 W. The other two simulations were performed for a substrate covered with a powder bed and had laser powers $2 0 1 ~ \mathrm { W }$ and $2 6 1 ~ \mathrm { W }$ , respectively. The spot diameter ( $( 1 2 2 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ is identical for all three cases.Process conditions and configurations were set to be consistent with experimental setups.Figures 5 and 6 show comparisons and analyses for the melt pool and keyhole shapes and geometries.The most likely uncertainties are in the model from the recoil forces and evaporation terms.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-28
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: The continuous increase in melt pool depth and keyhole length over time can be atributed to the complex dynamics involved. The continuous energy deposition into the material results in localized melting and subsequent expansion of the melt pool.As the laser continues to deposit over the same area,more energy accumulates,leading to a deeper and wider melt pool until the laser is turned off. The same behavior is seen for the keyhole during the process.The keyhole can lengthen as more laser energy is supplied for the stationary case in which metal evaporation is enough for deep keyhole formation.As the keyhole extends, it can sometimes become unstable,leading to breakage or collapse. When a keyhole breaks, it can leave behind voids or pores in the material. They are a direct consequence of the intricate and dynamic thermal and fluid interactions within the melt pool and keyhole regions during the AM process.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-29
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
In a similar manner to evaluating the stationary laser models,three scanning laser simulations were conducted, each involving different configurations and/or process parameters.For all three simulations,the laser velocity was set to $7 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / \mathrm { s }$ . One simulation was performed on bare substrates

Figure 5 shows the comparison of the melt pool depth and width measurements for the simulations and their corresponding experiments over the full duration of the LB-PBF process.As in previous analyses, the depth of the melt pool for all cases is measured from the upper surface of the solid substrate to the lowest point within the melt pool region. Relative L2 error for melt pool depth is 0.2852,0.3087,and 0.4654 for Fig. 5(a,b, c),respectively. For melt pool width,it is worth mentioning that meaningful experimental measurements were only feasible for cases involving bare substrates,as reported in Fig.5(d), due to the quality of images.The relative L2 error for melt pool width is 0.2899.Despite this limitation,our simulations still provide valuable insights.While the simulation slightly overestimates the maximum width of the melt pool observed in the experiment, it generally aligns well with the overall values and shape.As shown in Fig. 5(a,c), the melt pool depth is larger for bare substrates compared to substrates with a powder layer when process parameters are equivalent.This observation is consistent because of the choice to measure from the solid surface.Figure 5(b) demonstrates a very high similarity between our simulation and the experimental result.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-30
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: Figure 6 shows the comparison of keyhole length and width between the simulations and their corresponding experiments. Consistent with our previous measuring method for keyholes,we used the upper surface of the solid substrate as the reference line for keyhole length and width analyses.We also only measure the continuous,connected portion of the keyhole when fragmented regions exist.As shown in Fig. 6(a,b,c), our predicted keyhole lengths generally matched the longer-term behavior and values of the experiment.The relative L2 error is O.2044, O.5828,and 0.3131,respectively. For powder layer scenarios in Fig. 6(b, c), the simulations were able to capture the initial spike in keyhole length, though the values were underestimated. However, for the bare substrate case,the simulation was not able to capture the initial large keyhole length shown in Fig. 6(a). This is also observed when measuring the absorptance of the bare substrate scan case in the following section,and a detailed explanation of the possible causes is provided there.As with our melt pool width results,only the bare substrate keyhole width measurements are reported in Fig. 6(d), due to the quality of images. The relative L2 error is 0.2462.In general,our simulated keyhole width results slightly underestimate experimental measurements but follows a similar behavior as it grows over time along the track. Notably,challenges in simulating the initial large keyhole length in bare substrate cases suggest the presence of factors requiring further investigation.These findings emphasize the complexity of keyhole dynamics in laser-based processes and highlight the need for continued refinement and understanding in modeling such phenomena.

Figure 7 provides snapshots demonstrating the instantaneous melt region and keyhole for corresponding experiment and simulation scan track cases on bare substrates. Each set of images from a similar point in time shows the visual similarities in the shapes of these two key features. We can observe how the melt pool width reaches a steadystate profile in Fig.7(e,f).Moreover, the melt pool and keyhole depth reach a steady-state value and maintain it throughout the scan track.This stability in the melt pool and keyhole characteristics over time is indicative of the equilibrium achieved within the laser-material interaction process.This suggests that the energy dynamics between the laser beam and the substrate have reached a balance, resulting in the persistence of melt pool and keyhole dimensions throughout the laser scan.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-32
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
The absorptance across various cases were assessed through experimental measurements and simulations.This investigation into absorptance is a critical aspect of our study. It allows us to understand how effciently the laser energy is absorbed by the material during the laser-powder interaction process. Figure 8 provides a comprehensive comparison of the absorptance as a function of time for various scenarios,including stationary and moving laser setups.For stationary cases in Fig. 8(a, b,c), the relative L2 error is 0.1845, 0.1672, and 0.1876, respectively. For scanning cases in Fig.8(d,e, f), the relative L2 error is 0.1353, 0.1230,and 0.1902,respectively. It is noted that the standard uncertainty for the experimentally measured absorptance is in the range of $2 \% - 3 \%$ depending on laser power.For the stationary cases shown in Fig. 8(b,c), it can be found that the absorptance values for scenarios with and without powder bed exhibit nearly the same range of values throughout the process.This observation might seem counterintuitive,as one might expect a higher absorptance for substrates with a powder bed due to the additional surface available to absorb the laser energy [38].However, since the applied laser power is sufficient in both cases to quickly $( < 1 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { s } )$ generate a keyhole the fact that the initial material was either a solid or a powder is immaterial. Further discussions on laser absorptance in powders can be found in [31].

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-33
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: For moving laser cases,a distinctive feature in the absorptance curve emerges during the initial stages of the process.Notably, there is a noticeable increase in the absorptance at the very beginning $( 0 { - } 0 . 5 \mathrm { m s } )$ ,which is followed by a subsequent reduction.The absorptance then stabilizes until the end of the process.This event is particularly evident in the bare substrate case as shown in Fig. 8(d). The initial surge in absorptance can be attributed to a combination of factors [27]. There is initially a deep keyhole,which is formed due to the absence of convective flow in the early stages when there is no substantial melt pool trailing behind the laser [34, 52]. The same is true when a powder bed is present (Fig. 8e,f), except with a less pronounced effect due to a comparatively higher initial absorptance.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-34
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
To establish a comprehensive correlation among different aspects of the laser-based AM process,we conducted a total of 95 simulations that include a wide range of scenarios, each involving different configurations and/or process parameters.Here,the simulation matrix consisted of two distinct scenarios,stationary and scanning laser cases.These scenarios were explored on two types of substrates,bare substrates,and substrates with powder beds.The goal was to thoroughly explore how changes in the key process parameters (laser power, scan speed,and spot size) influence the melt pool and keyhole dynamics,as well as their interactions with the material properties.It is noted that physics models and other conditions were maintained as consistent for these simulations to ensure reliable comparisons and meaningful correlations and trends.

Here, we introduce NEI to explore correlations among different parameters for stationary laser scenarios as below:

$$
\mathrm { N E I } = \frac { \eta P } { \kappa r ( T _ { \mathrm { l } } - T _ { 0 } ) } ,
$$

where $\eta P$ is the effective laser power input, $\kappa$ is the thermal conductivity of material, $r$ is the laser spot radius,and $T _ { \mathrm { l } } - T _ { 0 }$ is the difference between melting and ambient temperatures.NEI represents the ratio of laser energy input within the track to sensible heat of melting [53, 54]. It is noted that $\eta$ is the average absorptance during the steadystate phase of the laser deposition process.

Figure 9 provides insight into how changes in normalized energy input (NEI) affect key features in the LB-PBF process for all 45 stationary laser cases.Bare solid substrate cases are compared against powder layer cases to determine the powder layer effect on different features.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-35
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: Figure 9(a) plots the melt pool aspect ratio,which is calculated as a melt pool depth over the projected crosssectional width.For both classes of cases,a small upward trend in the aspect ratio can be observed. However, it is noteworthy that the powder layer cases typically exhibit a more linear increase in aspect ratio when compared to the somewhat variable behavior observed in the bare substrate cases.This trend in the melt pool aspect ratio is a significant indicator of the evolving melt pool shape as NEI varies.The differences between bare substrate and powder layer cases suggest that the presence of the powder layer has a more consistent and predictable effect on the aspect ratio as energy input changes, possibly due to its role in energy absorption and dissipation within the laser interaction zone.This is also consistent with previous study that found the powder smooths out a lot of absorptance dynamics [37].A similar trend can be seen for keyhole aspect ratio in Fig. 9(c). In this case, both the bare substrate and substrate with a powder bed show a linear increase in aspect ratio,and these trends are described by linear fits with high $R ^ { 2 }$ values. Additionally, both lines overlap very closely, indicating that they follow the same keyhole aspect ratio function. It is worth noting that at higher NEI values, there is a notable increase in variance (or standard deviation) compared to lower NEI values. This higher variance at elevated NEI levels suggests that as the energy input becomes more substantial, the system response becomes less predictable,potentially due to the interplay of multiple dynamic factors at play.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-36
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: Figure 9(b,d) shows the behavior of both the normalized melt pool and keyhole widths as a function of NEI. For the melt pool width in Fig. 9(b),we observe that the width for bare substrate (solid) is generally higher than that of the solid with a powder bed. The differences in width are likely attributed to the unique energy absorption and dissipation dynamics associated with each substrate type.For the keyhole width shown in Fig. 9(d),we observe a similar behavior compared to the melt pool width plot.In this case,both the bare substrate and substrate with a powder bed show comparable behavior.Both sets of data exhibit linear fits with high $R ^ { 2 }$ values, indicating a strong correlation between normalized keyhole width and NEI. The positive slope of these linear fits signifies that as NEI increases,the normalized keyhole width also increases.While the presence of the powder bed affects the melt pool width, it does not significantly alter the correlation between NEI and keyhole width. This consistency in the keyhole width response suggests that NEI plays a predominant role in shaping keyhole dimensions, irrespective of the substrate type.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-37
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
Lastly,Fig. 9(e) shows keyhole angle as a function of NEI for both scenarios, namely, bare solid and solid with powder bed cases. As NEI increases, keyhole angle tends to approach a steady-state value that is near 9O degrees.This behavior aligns with the understanding that in stationary laser setups, there is no defined “front’or directional bias,which leads to keyhole angles that gravitate toward perpendicularity to the substrate. In essence,as the energy input intensifies, the keyhole angle stabilizes at a nearly right angle to the substrate surface.Crucially,both the bare solid and powder layer cases exhibit a very similar keyhole angle function with respect to normalized energy input.This indicates that the keyhole angle responds in a consistent and predictable manner as NEI varies,regardless of whether a powder layer is present. Additionally, it is noteworthy that there is a relatively high variance (standard deviation) in keyhole angles at lower NEI values when compared to higher NEI values.This variance reflects the sensitivity of keyhole angles to changes in energy input, with lower NEI levels leading to greater variability in the keyhole angle response.However,as NEI increases and approaches higher values, the keyhole angles become more stabilized and approach a near 9O-degree orientation.

We found that the keyhole aspect ratio exhibits scaling with only one dimensionless parameter, i.e., the Keyhole number Ke [54] (also known as normalized enthalpy [55]),

$$
\mathrm { K e } = { \frac { \eta P } { \left( T _ { \mathrm { l } } - T _ { 0 } \right) \pi \rho C _ { \mathrm { p } } { \sqrt { \alpha V _ { \mathrm { s } } r _ { 0 } ^ { 3 } } } } } ,
$$

Figure 10 presents a comprehensive comparison between scanning laser simulations of a bare solid (illustrated in blue) and a powder layer (depicted in magenta) across various parameters in relation to keyhole number. In the first plot (a),there is a linear relationship between the keyhole number and surface energy density,with both the bare solid and powder layer displaying substantial overlap.The second plot (b) elucidates a linear correlation between the keyhole number and the melt pool aspect ratio,where the bare solid tends to exhibit higher values than the powder layer. Interestingly, both appear to saturate the melt pool aspect ratio around 10 when the keyhole number exceeds 25. This saturation suggests that certain constraints or equilibrium conditions are reached as the keyhole number increases.As the keyhole number increases,it affects the energy distribution within the material and the dynamics of material flow within the melt pool. This influence of the keyhole on the melt pool becomes more pronounced as the keyhole number rises. Once a critical keyhole number is reached, the interaction between keyhole formation and melt pool behavior stabilizes,leading to a consistent melt pool aspect ratio. The third (c) and fourth (d) plots stress the normalized melt pool width and keyhole aspect ratio, respectively. In these plots,while

Overall, these plots offer valuable insights into steady-state measurements from both simulations,emphasizing the contrasts and similarities between the two cases with and without powder layer.

content: In Fig.11,we observe the analysis and comparison of various parameters concerning NEI (stationary) and energy density (scan) between powder layer and bare solid simulations.In subfigure (a),which plots NEI versus absorptance, it is evident that the powder layer exhibits a higher rate of absorption as compared to the bare solid, particularly at lower NEI levels. This is accompanied by a noticeable variance attributed to temporal fluctuations,with absorptance plateauing at around O.92.In (b),a close analysis of the energy density (during scanning) against absorptance demonstrates a marked similarity in trends between the powder layer and the bare solid.Notably, the absorptance is significantly lower at reduced energy densities, increasing to an approximate absorptance of O.8 at the largest energy densities,with a noted increase in variance at the lower end of the scale.Subfigure (c) presents the relationship between NEI and solidification rate,highlighting that the powder layer generally solidifies at a slower rate compared to the bare solid, with an upward trend observed as NEI increases.However, this plot shows only moderate $R ^ { 2 }$ values for the linear fits. Finally, (d) emphasizes the patterns regarding energy density,indicating that, akin to the stationary state,the powder layer maintains a lesser rate of solidification than the bare solid, with no clear functional relationship discerned between the solidification rate and energy density. This figure,thus,serves as a critical tool in understanding the interplay between various elements within the context of powder layer and bare solid simulations.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-41
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: In this section,we analyze pore formation and its connections with process parameters.We investigate this phenomenon in both stationary and moving laser scenarios,each involving distinct sets of process parameters.In Fig. 12,we observe the formation of pores resulting from deep keyholes formed during the stationary laser deposition for different process parameters. This pore formation arises from an inherent instability in the elongated shape of the keyhole,a characteristic often observed during laser-based AM processes (see supplementary videos). Deep keyholes, with their extended and slender profiles,are prone to instability.As the laser beam interacts with material and forms the keyhole,these deep keyholes frequently undergo a sudden collapse during the AM process. This collapse generates transient disturbances within the melt pool, resulting in the formation of bubbles.These bubbles,while initially suspended within the molten material, become entrapped within solidification fronts as the material cools and solidifies.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-42
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content: The consequence of these trapped bubbles is the creation of pores within the resolidified metal region. This is a welldocumented phenomenon in the AM literature,explored in several studies that investigate the physics of keyholeinduced pores [7, 22, 23,25-27]. These studies delved into the complex interplay of forces acting upon the keyhole, including surface tension, recoil pressure,and Marangoni force. They also examined the roles of buoyancy, gravity, and thermocapillary forces in governing the motion of bubbles throughout the AM process.A critical factor contributing to keyhole-induced pore formation is the depth of the keyhole.When the keyhole reaches a depth where the laser rays no longer reach its bottom, the temperature within this unexposed region experiences a significant drop.This localized temperature decrease induces an increase in surface tension forces while concurrently reducing the recoil pressure at the base of the keyhole.For a more in-depth understanding and comprehensive analysis of the underlying mechanisms driving pore formation, interested readers can refer to references [22, 23].

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-43
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
Our simulations,which closely align with experimental observations as shown in Fig. 4,consistently capture the phenomenon of keyhole-induced pore formation during the laser spotting.Figure 12 provides a comprehensive view of formed pores in stationary laser cases,both with and without powder beds.The snapshots are associated with different laser parameters including laser power and spot size.Several key points can be understood from these snapshots.In general, as laser power increases, there is a corresponding increase in pore volume.Moreover, the number of pores within the resolidified metal also in most cases rises with increasing laser power. These phenomena can be attributed to the fundamental principles of energy input and distribution.When higher laser power is employed during the AM process,it translates into a more substantial influx of energy into the material. This increased energy leads to higher temperatures within the melt pool, intensifying the likelihood
