of bubble formation due to keyhole breakage.Additionally, higher laser power (or energy) amplifies the thermodynamic conditions conducive to bubble generation within the melt pool as well as keyhole instability and collapse.This observation highlights the direct relationship between laser power and pore formation, emphasizing that higher energy inputs result in more significant pore formation.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-44
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
Furthermore, the number of pores is notably lower in bare substrate when compared to the substrate with a powder bed. This difference can be attributed to a combination of factors, including keyhole dynamics and the availability of nucleation sites,both of which are influenced by the presence of the moderately thick powder bed.In scenarios where a power bed is present, the dynamics are more complex.The powder bed not only offers additional material for bubble formation but also provides numerous nucleation sites.The vaporized particles can serve as nucleation sites where gas bubbles initiate and grow.

Moreover,an interesting phenomenon is observed when varying the beam diameter while keeping the laser power constant. Specifically,as the spot size increases,the size of individual pores tends to decrease.This trend can be attributed to the dynamics of heat distribution and energy concentration within the larger spot size.In scenarios with a larger spot size,the laser energy is dispersed over a broader area,which results in a more uniform distribution of heat. Consequently, the localized regions within the melt pool may not reach the threshold temperature required for the formation of larger gas bubbles.Instead,smaller bubbles form due to the more evenly distributed energy. Hence,an increase in spot size typically corresponds to a decrease in the size of individual pores within the resolidified metal.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-45
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
Figure 13 presents a series of snapshots capturing the formed pores in moving laser cases for both with and without powder beds.These snapshots correspond to different laser parameters including laser power and spot size.We observe that similar behavior to that seen in the stationary cases shown in Fig.12 is also evident in the scan cases.The presence or absence of a powder bed continues to be a significant factor, influencing both pore size and number. Furthermore, similar to what we observed in stationary cases,variations in laser parameters, such as laser power and spot size,continue to play a crucial role in pore formation within the moving laser setup. When the laser power is increased, there is a corresponding rise in pore volume.Higher laser power inputs provide more energy for vaporization and bubble formation, thus yielding larger pores.Similarly,altering the spot size while maintaining constant laser power can lead to changes in pore size,as demonstrated in Fig.13.These insights highlight the consistent patterns and complex dynamics governing pore formation in laser-based AM processes.

However, an interesting pattern emerges for moving laser scenarios:as the laser power (or energy) is increased, there is a noticeable increase in the likelihood of pore formation, particularly at the beginning part of the laser track.The observed increase in pore formation at the beginning part of the laser track in moving laser cases with higher laser power is a result of the intensified energy input, instable keyhole formation, and vaporization at the initial stages of the process.These conditions create a conducive environment for gas bubble formation, which ultimately contributes to the higher likelihood of pore formation in this phase.

name: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po-part-46
fileName: 2024 - Progress in Additive Manufacturing - Samaei et al. - Benchmark study of melt pool and keyhole dynamics, laser absorptance, and po.pdf
content:
This work used developed high-fidelity multiphysics models and experimental tools to investigate the interconnections among processing parameters,melt pool, keyhole morphologies,and pore formation in the LB-PBF process of Ti-6Al-4V.High-speed in situ synchrotron X-ray measurements were utilized to comprehensively analyze melt pool and keyhole size,morphology,and features during the LB-PBF process.The evaluation of both stationary and moving laser models demonstrated a remarkable level of agreement between simulations and experimental measurements.This agreement extended to key aspects such as melt pool depths and widths,keyhole lengths and widths, and absorptance,reinforcing the accuracy of the simulations. The key findings of the presented work here are as follows:

1.） The presence of a powder bed,at a thickness of $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ， has a significant impact on the dynamics of laser penetration during AM processes.It results in a reduction in both melt pool depth and width when compared to scenarios involving bare substrates.   
2.）Keyhole lengths show significant temporal fluctuations during the AM process,which can be attributed to the dynamic nature of keyholes and the intricate interplay of laser energy,material properties,and powder bed configurations. Similar, though smaller in range, fluctuations are observed in keyhole widths.These findings highlight the complexity of keyhole dynamics and its sensitivity to process parameters.   
3.）This study reveals that the absorptance during laserpowder interactions shows interesting dynamics.In stationary laser cases,both scenarios with and without a powder bed exhibit a similar range of absorptance values

4.） This study demonstrates a direct relationship between laser power and pore formation.Higher laser power leads to larger pore volumes and a greater number of pores within the resolidified metal. The spot size also affects pore size,with larger spot sizes resulting in smaller individual pores due to more uniform energy distribution.

throughout the process,despite initial differences.For moving laser cases,a distinctive feature emerges with a noticeable jump in absorptance at the beginning of the process,followed by stabilization. These findings emphasize the need to consider the dynamics of energy interactions in laser-based processes.

5.）In moving laser scenarios, there is an increased likelihood of pore formation, particularly at the beginning of the laser track, when higher laser power is employed. This is attributed to the intensified energy input, instable keyhole formation,and vaporization at the initial stages of the process. These findings shed light on the dynamics of pore formation in laser-based AM processes and highlight the importance of controlling laser parameters to mitigate porosity.

Overall, this study provides valuable insights for optimizing laser-based AM processes,emphasizing the importance of considering powder bed characteristics and recognizing the dynamic nature of keyhole-induced pore formation. These insights offer opportunities for enhancing the quality and effciency of AM processes.Further research could delve deeper into the influence of powder bed thickness on the LB-PBF process. Studying a wider range of powder bed thicknesses may provide insights into optimal bed configurations for specific applications.

Supplementary Information The online version contains supplementary material available at https://doi.org/10.1007/s40964-024-00637-6.

Data availability All the required data that support the findings of this study are available in this paper. Some of the data are available in the NIST Public Data Repository [44].

content:
Timothy Montalbano ${ \mathfrak { a } } _ { \oplus }$ ，Salahudin Nimerä,Mary Dafronä, Brendan Croom ${ \mathrm { a } } _ { \oplus }$ Somnath Ghosh ${ \mathrm { \Delta ^ { b } } } \oplus$ Steven Storck a,\*

# ARTICLEINFO
summary: Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-2
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
Keywords:   
Powder bed fusion   
Ti-6Al-4V

Machine learning

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-3
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content: While it is well established thatthe microstructure and mechanical properties of Ti-6Al-4Vallys are sensitive to their thermal history，a relatively small portion of the processing space has been explored.Additive manufacturing methods such as Laser Powder Bed Fusion (L-PBF)ofer extreme flexibility in processng conditions,but are still primarily limited through Edisonian experiments.This implies that thereare new processing domains that could yield Ti-6Al-4V with favorable mechanical properties or improved build productivity. Using efficient X-ray Computed Tomography methods to quickly screen the density and subscale tension tests to identify mechanical properties of L-PBF Ti-6Al-4V,we leveraged Gausian Process Regresion (GPR) machine learning models and Bayesian Optimization sampling strategies to eficiently explore the L-PBF processing space to discover new processing domains.This study revealed (1) a substantially larger procesing window to produce dense material (porosity $< 0 . 1 ~ \%$ by varying power,speed,and hatch spacing,(2) anability to tune processing conditions to achieve yield strengths ranging from 980 to 1o95 MPa and elongation from $4 . 6 \%$ to $1 3 . 5 \%$ (3)a unique high density processing regime associated with high laser power,high laser velocity,and small hatch spacing,which was previously avoided due toconcernof baling instabilities in single line trace experiments,and (4) new processing domains with improved mechanical properties and deposition rates. The new processing conditions resulted in extreme microstructural variation with differences in grain morphology,size,and texture. The degree of texture and grain refinement exhibited in the reconstructed $\beta$ grains of some samples partially explained the large amount of ductility and variations in strength in the tested samples,although more sophisticated microstructural representations are required to fully explain the observed behavior.

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-4
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content: This new processing windowand the associated material properties are valuable for informing the design of Ti-6Al-4V parts built by L-PBF.Furthermore,the machine learning methods employed hereare notlimited to this alloy or L-PBF method and can therefore serveas a template for other ally systems processed by additional additive manufacturing techniques.

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-5
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content: Titanium alloys such as Ti-6Al-4V are extremely appealing for additive manufacturing (AM) of aerospace components due to the alloy's unique properties such as low density and high strength [1],as well as AM's potential to bypass challenges with Ti-6Al-4V's poor machineability,and improve the“buy-to-fly"ratio-the ratio of the raw material prior to fabrication compared to the weight of the machined part [2]. However,the mechanical behavior of Ti-6Al-4Vis notoriously sensitive to changes in the material's thermal history during processing,as has been widely reported in many studies using Laser Powder Bed Fusion (L-PBF) to process Ti-6Al-4V [3].To mitigate L-PBF processing challenges such as microstructural embrittlement, cracking,and porosity [3], there is clearly a need to eficiently optimize the alloy's processing conditions to achieve desired tradeoffs between high strength,ductility and deposition rate.In this work,we propose the use of Bayesian optimization (BO) [4] that leverages Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) surrogate models to efficiently identify new L-PBF processing conditions with favorable tradeoffs between strength,ductility and processing speed. Coupled with high-throughput porosity and mechanical testing capabilities, this approach is shown to enable a much larger processing window than previously identified,including specific conditions with diverse microstructures and extremely variable mechanical properties.

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-6
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content: The mechanical properties of L-PBF Ti-6Al-4V are intricately related to its microstructure and defect content,which in turn depend on the material's processing history.The low ductility of L-PBF samples is generally attributed to porosity [5] and the presence of the $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ martensite phase [6].Higher ductility and strength can be achieved by the formation of low aspect ratio $\alpha$ -grains around Lack of Fusion (LOF) defects after a HIP treatment of built parts [7].A ductile mechanical response has also been shown in samples that have $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ or $\mathfrak { a } + \alpha ^ { \prime }$ microstructures [8, 9].It has been suggested that twinning at the $\alpha / \beta$ interface could be a contributor to plasticity during mechanical deformation [1O].The role of strain induced twinning in the plastic deformation of the alloy was verified with later work [2] as well as the importance of the initial texture orientation or the twinning systems.This ductile mechanical response was controlled by an intrinsic heat treatment during the build to promote the decomposition of the $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ into the $\alpha$ and $\beta$ phases.The spatial distribution and crystallographic orientation of the grains is therefore critical in the performance of L-PBF Ti-6Al-4V parts.Intrinsic heat treatment performed during the build was shown to increase the ductility of the parts [2].Samples intentionally built with keyhole (KH) defects showed larger strengths than those samples that had equivalent amounts of LOF defects [11].

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-7
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
Given the complexity of Ti-6Al-4V's processing-structure-defectproperty relationships,it is clear that the mechanical properties of AM parts are likely to vary substantially across the processing window. Historically,processing recipes for Ti-6Al-4V and otheralloys have been performed through heuristic approaches,such as linear parameter sweeps or heuristically-designed studies [l2,l3]．However，this approach is inefficient and ultimately impractical due to the multi-physics processes that govern the mechanical properties of L-PBF Ti-6Al-4V [14]. To overcome this,a combination of BO approaches to efficientlysamplethelargeprocessingdomain—aswellas high-throughput testing techniques to efciently generate more experimental data-are proposed as a pathway to navigate the potentially complex mapping between processing conditions,generated defects, and mechanical properties of Ti-6Al-4V.

BO methods leverage machine learning surrogate models such as GPR models to learn the response of a function across a design domain, and then use the predicted response of the surrogate model to intelligently sample the design domain to maximize a certain objective [4]. This makes BO approaches well suited to efficiently study design spaces with nonlinear responses with fewer experiments,especially in cases where human intuition or prior knowledge may be inadequate to guide the experiments.For instance,GPR models can effectively model the nonlinear relationships between L-PBF processing conditions and porosity [15],as demonstrated by Liu et al.who leveraged GPR models to identify an unexpectedly large processing window for $\mathbf { A l S i _ { 1 0 } M g }$ with high relative density [16].In other application spaces,GPR-based BO has been used to design mechanically tough lattice structures [17],and to accelerate the discovery of new materials [18].Notably, however,BO has not been adopted within the additive manufacturing community to learn process-defect-property linkages [19].

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-8
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
In the same vein, newer high-throughput methods as developed by [13,20] can obtain large quantities of data to guide process optimization studies,which can overcome cost constraints associated with performing large numbers of conventional experimental measurements.However,it has proven too costly to simultaneously quantify the porosity and quasistatic mechanical properties of large quantities of samples.For instance,Liu et al.screened the density of 99 samples,but only the tensile properties of a subset of them [l6].Agrawal characterized the density and hardness of 425 316 L stainless steel samples,though the hardness provided only indirect predictions of the actual mechanical behavior [2O].To the author's knowledge,no study has experimentally explored the density and mechanical properties acrossa three-dimensional parameter space consisting of laser power，scan speed,and hatch spacing for L-PBF Ti-6Al-4V. Such a multi-modal dataset would permit the discovery of new processing domains that are optimized for good mechanical properties,density and/or deposition rates.

This work aims to efficiently discover processing conditions using BO search schemes that lead to extreme variation in microstructure and mechanical properties.Refined methods of collecting high-throughput X-ray computed tomography (XCT) and sub-scale mechanical testing reduce the material needed for testing and the amount of time needed to run the tests.These high throughput methods also provide ML models with the necessary data to identify the new L-PBF build regimes with accelerated deposition rates and favorable mechanical properties.

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-9
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
# 2.1． Materials
Ti-6Al-4V powder obtained from EOS (EOS GmbH -Electro Optical Systems,headquarters located in Krailing,Germany) with a chemical composition in accordance with ASTM F1472 and ASTM F2924 was used to build all samples.The atomized powder had a D1o-D90 particle size of $2 0 \mathrm { - } 6 3 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ and an ISO 3369 density of $4 . 4 1 ~ \mathrm { g / c m ^ { 3 } }$ ：

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-10
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
# 2.2.Laser-Powder Bed Fusion
An EOS GmbHM290 SLM system Was used to consolidate the Ti-6Al4V powder into cylindrical and rectangular coupons.The system utilized a $1 0 6 4 \ : \mathrm { n m } \ : 4 0 0$ W continuous Yb fiber laser with a $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ spot size. In accordance with standard EOS processing parameters fora Ti-6Al-4V alloy,a constant powder layer thickness of $3 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ was used to produce samples for mechanical testing and microstructural characterization.A Ti-6Al-4V base plate supplied by EOS was used to minimize thermal mismatch and argon was used as the protective atmosphere.As described in Section 2.6,the laser power,speed and hatch were varied for each set of samples.

Three build plates—an example of which is shown in Fig.1—of samples were manufactured to incrementally identify processng conditions with more extreme mechanical properties and microstructures. The build plates contained over 2Oo cylinders for XCT porosity analysis, and tension coupons for mechanical property assessment (loading axis in the X direction,which was parallel to the recoater movement), whereby each cylinder and tension coupon was assigned a unique set of processing conditions,as described in the following sections.The second and third builds contained blocks of material for microstructural characterization for selected processing conditions，as identified by measured porosity and mechanical properties.Additional samples were included in the second and third build cycles to provide replicate tension samples for downselected processing parameters exhibiting extreme mechanical properties,as well as “vertical" test coupon with the loading axis perpendicular to the build plate in the Z direction.The dimensions of each type of sample are described in Fig.1.AfterAM, sampleswere removed from the build plate using electro-discharge machining (EDM).

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-11
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
To efficiently evaluate the porosity of samples produced by L-PBF, we used an efficient XCT inspection protocol. XCT can more efficiently quantify porosity in AM material than metallographic methods,particularly when large volumes of material must be analyzed to detect extreme,fatigue-critical defectsas revealed byarecent cost analysis [21].This method was leveraged here to quickly screen large quantities of small-volume specimens to define the dense process window.These measurements were used to generate data to train the GPR model,as discussed later in Section 2.6.

Samples were scanned using a North Star Imaging X-5O microfocus XCT at $1 2 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ voxel size resolution with scan times of less than three minutes per sample,compared to scan times of at least $2 0 \ \mathrm { m i n }$ per sample as reported in the literature [21],although typically used to inspect larger volumes and with imaging less noise.To achieve rapid scan times,we co-designed the sample geometry and scan procedure to maintain a high resolution of $1 2 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ voxel size,low scan noise and achieve fast scan times.This was achieved by designing a small but representative sample size of $6 \mathrm { m m }$ diameter and $6 \mathrm { m m }$ height,as well as using geometric magnification and $\mathbf { 2 x }$ image binning.The final sample size still permitted sampling of approximately 60 laser tracks per layer over 2oo layers.Internal validation studies have shown that this sampling volume is sufficiently representative of larger samples. The scan parameters enabled the use of higher source power,fewer radiographs,and shorter exposure times with no increase in noise compared to a larger sample imaged with $\mathbf { 1 x }$ binning.

![](images/d175f3317fbee00a175668f68c0a164ee21cd89b3b76f93fcc2a644d4c899c71.jpg)  
Fig1.Schatiedacedsildoeieo rztall XCT cylinders,and (d) microstructure blocks.

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-12
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
X-rays in the XCT system were generated using a tungsten target source operated at $1 3 0 \mathrm { k e V }$ and $1 0 0 \ \mu \mathrm { A } .$ For each sample,we acquired 1500 radiographs using continuous sample rotation,2x binning mode, and 9 frames per second acquisition rate.The reconstruction resolution and scan quality permitted reliable detection of pores larger than $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in size.Recent work has demonstrated that XCT inspections at $1 2 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ voxel size and similar scan quality can resolve the effects of microporosity on macroscopic quasistatic tensile mechanical behavior in L-PBF $3 1 6 \mathrm { L }$ stainless steel [22],such as precipitous drops in quasistatic yield strength and elongation to failure when microporosity exceeded $1 \%$ and $0 . 1 ~ \% .$ ,respectively.Thus,it is believed that this XCT scan recipe enabled not only differentiation of “dense"and“porous"regions of the process map,but also identification of porosity changes that would indicate different quasistatic tensile mechanical properties.

After reconstruction of each sample using filtered back projection, the porosity was quantified using the “EasyPore” segmentation algorithm in the Volume Graphics software.Porosity was only quantified more than $0 . 5 \mathrm { m m }$ from the exterior surface to ignore effects of the contour pass.Only pores larger than 27 voxels (equivalent spherical diameter of $4 4 \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ ）were considered.

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-13
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
# 2.4. Tension testing
To quantify the mechanical response of the additively manufactured samples across the processing condition design space,we performed quasistatic tension testing on subscale specimens as defined in Fig.1.In brief,the dovetailed tension grips enabled the use of drop-in grips to accelerate test throughput,as has been widely adopted by other highthroughput studies [23],and the reduced sample footprint enabled manufacturing of many coupons in a single L-PBF build.Small-scale tension coupons were directly manufactured using L-PBF and removed from the build plate with EDM. Using displacement control testing mode and strain rates in accordance with ASTM E8 [24],all coupons were tested to failure on an Instron 5984 electromechanical load frame at a $2 { \cdot } 1 0 ^ { - 3 } s ^ { - 1 }$ strain rate.An automated video extensometer (Instron AVE2) with a gage length of $8 \mathrm { m m }$ was used for non-contact strain measurement.

The samples were mechanically tested with as-built (rough) surfaces, which was anticipated to slightly reduce the measured mechanical properties.Recent work has shown that samples of $2 \mathrm { m m }$ thickness exhibitroughly $2 \mathrm { - } 6 ~ \%$ lower yield strength compared to bulk samples due to the effect of surface roughness [25,26]. Given the unique processing conditions of each sample,roughness was anticipated to vary slightly for each sample,and thus lead to additional variation in the measured mechanical properties.Thus,the reported mechanical properties should be considered as correlated to—but not exact measures—of typical, bulk mechanical properties.

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-14
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
# 2.5.Scanning electron microscopy and electron backscattered diffaction
Cylindrical coupons were embedded in a slow-cure epoxy,ground using successively finer SiC paper,and then polished with $1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ alumina. To obtain an acceptable surface finish for electron backscattered diffraction (EBSD),the samples were put on a VibroMetrM 2 forat least 17 hours with $0 . 0 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ colloidal silica.

A Thermo Scientific Scios DualBeam scanning electron microscope (SEM) that was equipped with an Oxford NordlysMax³ detector was used to perform EBSD along the build direction of samples and the Oxford AZTEC data acquisition software was used to acquire and store diffraction patterns.An acceleration voltage of $2 5 \mathrm { k V }$ was used during the collection of the EBSD patterns.The step size for all EBSD maps was $1 . 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .The Oxford Instrument's Channel 5 software was used to process the raw EBSD data. Grains were defined as having a misorientation angle greater than $^ { 1 0 ^ { \circ } }$ ：

The EBSD maps of the original microstructure were reconstructed to show the parent microstructure $\beta$ -grains.The reconstruction was performed in AZtecCrystaltM in order to determine the grain orientation and size of these $\beta$ grains.The $\beta$ -grains were related to the original $\alpha$ -lathes with the typical Burgers orientation relationship: $\{ 1 1 0 \} _ { \beta } \parallel$ $\{ 0 0 0 1 \} _ { \alpha }$ and $\langle \overline { { 1 } } 1 \overline { { 1 } } \rangle _ { \beta } \parallel$ （204 $\langle 2 \overline { { 1 1 } } 0 \rangle _ { \alpha }$ . The threshold misorientation angle to determine a parent grain was defined as $^ { 1 0 ^ { \circ } }$ . Once the grains were reconstructed,AZtecCrystal was used to measure the Multiple of Uniform Density (MUD) and the degree of grain misorientation to show the role of these microstructural parameters on the mechanical properties.
summary: 2.5.Scanning electron microscopy and electron backscattered diffaction

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-15
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content: At the core of our study,we employed GPR models to guide the discovery of L-PBF processing conditions through BO schemes that resulted in Ti-6Al-4V material with high density,unique microstructures and extreme mechanical properties.This was predicated on the belief that by comprehensively identifying and surveying domains of the processing space with good density (porosity below $0 . 1 ~ \%$ ,wecould efficiently discover all possible processing conditions samples with optimal mechanical properties and unique microstructures. Survey of high-porosity domains (e.g.,with large volume fractions of LoF or KH pores) was not prioritized since their mechanical properties were likely to be dominated by effects of gross porosity rather than microstructural variation.GPR models were selected for use in BO over alternatives such asrandom forest regression (RFR),support vector regression (SVR) and artificial neural networks (ANNs) by demonstrating better predictive performance (as measured by $\mathsf { R } ^ { 2 }$ ）during initial testing with the first build of porosity data $( R _ { G P R , t r a i n } ^ { 2 } = 0 . 9 6$ ， $R _ { R F , t r a i n } ^ { 2 } = 0 . 9 2$ ， $R _ { S V R , t r a i n } ^ { 2 } =$ 0.39, $R _ { A N N , t r a i n } ^ { 2 } = 0 . 7 6$ on $n = 4 2$ training datapoints; and $R _ { G P R , t e s t } ^ { 2 } ~ =$ 0.56, $R _ { R F , t e s t } ^ { 2 } = 0 . 4 2$ $R _ { S V R , t e s t } ^ { 2 } = \mathrm { ~ - ~ } 0 . 8 8$ ， $R _ { A N N , t e s t } ^ { 2 } = 0 . 1 0$ on $n = 1 1$ withheld data).These initial evaluations used GPR models as described later in this section,RFR models with 5O decision trees,SVRs with radial basis function (RBF) kernels,and several ANNs trained with varying depth,width,learning rates,batch sizes and optimization schemes;all models were implemented in Python using the scikit-learn (version 1.2.2) package.
summary: 2.6.Bayesian optimization guided discovery of novel processing conditions - Part 1/4

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-16
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
GPR models aim to provide the best linear unbiased prediction of an outcome as a function of a processing space,and also provide an estimate of uncertainty in the prediction.In this case,we trained the GPR model to predict the logarithm of measured porosity $l o g _ { 1 0 } ( P o r o s i t y )$ asa function of the processing parameters $X _ { i } = ( P _ { i } , 
u _ { i } , h _ { i } )$ for each sample i; due to the small dimensionality of this design space,feature engineering was not employed.The logarithm of porosity was used primarily to allow the model to discern differences between small values of porosity (e.g., $0 . 0 1 ~ \%$ vS. $0 . 1 ~ \%$ porosity),and also to ensure the prediction remained positive since negative porosity values are non-physical.Our GPR model used a kernel composed as the summation of an anisotropic RBF and a white noise kernel.The RBF kernel was anisotropic to account for the different characteristic magnitudes for $P , 
u , h ,$ and the length scalesofthekernel wereconstrainedto $1 0 \leq l _ { P } \leq 2 0 0 W$ $4 0 0 \leq l _ { 
u } \leq 2 0 0 0 m m / s ,$ and $0 . 0 5 \leq l _ { h } \leq 0 . 2 m m ;$ ：these constraints were designed to regularize the GPR predictions,and we note that anisotropic kernels in GPR models are known to improve fitting of complex behavior in materials science applications,which should in turn enable more efficient sampling of the AM processing space [27].The white noise kernel was used to estimate the independently,identically distributed Gaussian noise due to experimental variation (e.g., due to repeatability of the AM process, or porosity measurement),and also acted to regularize the GPR model.The GPR model was implemented in Python using the scikit-learn package (version1.2.2)[28].All other hyperparameters were set to the default values in the scikit-learn implementation of GPR. Performance of the models after each training step was validated with $2 0 \%$ of the withheld data.
summary: 2.6.Bayesian optimization guided discovery of novel processing conditions - Part 2/4

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-17
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
We used the GPR model to aid the discovery of novel processing conditions with unusual microstructures and extreme mechanical properties across three builds.The first design of experiment (DOE) was used to generate initial training data for the GPR model. This DOE was designed using a combination of engineering heuristics and space-filling statistical design of experiments methods.A total of 53 processing conditions were developed, including:one sample using stock processing conditions $( P = 2 8 0 W$ ， $\nu = 1 5 0 0 \frac { m m } { s }$ $h = 0 . 0 8 m m$ ，and $\begin{array} { r l } { V E D } & { { } = } \end{array}$ $7 7 . 8 J / m m ^ { 3 }$ ),eight samples defined using engineering heuristics by scaling power or velocity from the stock processing conditions,and 44 samples from an optimal space-filling Latin Hyper Cube design,as implemented in the DOE tool within JMP (Cary,NC).The LHC design of experiments enforced constraints $1 0 0 \leq P \leq 3 7 0 W$ $4 0 0 \leq \nu \leq 6 0 0 0 \frac { m m } { s } .$ $0 . 0 3 \leq h \leq 0 . 1 9 m m$ and $2 0 \leq V E D \leq 1 3 5 J / m m ^ { 3 }$ We manufactured one XCT sample and one tension coupon using each parameter set.

The second DOE was generated with the assistance of a GPR model. The GPR model was trained using the above procedures on the porosity data from DOE 1,and then was used to predict a processing domain with less than $0 . 3 1 ~ \%$ (equivalent to $1 0 ^ { - 0 . 5 } \%$ ）porosity. From this permitted processing domain,we selected 1oo unique processing conditions that were furthest from existing processing conditions using a greedy search algorithm. We manufactured one sample and one tension coupon using each parameter set,as well as 7 microstructural coupons selected from DOE 1.
summary: 2.6.Bayesian optimization guided discovery of novel processing conditions - Part 3/4

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-18
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content: Finally,we generated a third DOE after updating the GPR model using all available XCT porosity data from the first two builds.The third DOE model was generated using a batch-sampling Bayesian optimization search that aimed to discover processing conditions most likely to produce material with a porosity of $0 . 1 0 \%$ .A total of 50 sampleswere generated,with 25 having $7 0 \leq V E D \leq 1 5 0 J / m m ^ { 3 }$ to study the keyhole (KH) processing boundary,and an additional 25 samples having $2 5 ~ \leq$ $V E D \le 7 0 J / m m ^ { 3 }$ to study the LoF processng boundary.We manufactured one sample and one tension coupon using each parameter set,as well as seven coupons for microstructural characterization using parameters selected from DOE1 and 2.
summary: 2.6.Bayesian optimization guided discovery of novel processing conditions - Part 4/4

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-19
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
# 2.7.Data visualization
All processing,XCTand mechanical testing data were collected into a central dataset after all three builds.Machine learning regression models were trained to predict the density,yield strength,ultimate strength and elongation to failure as a function of the prescribed processing conditions (laser power,velocity and hatch spacing) to support data visualization and analysis.We found that GPR models best represented the variation in porosity across the processing space,while RFR models best represented the variation in yield strength and elongation across the processing domain. Implementation of the GPR models followed the methods outlined in Section 2.6.The RFR models were also implemented using scikit-learn,using 5O decision trees and default parameters.The performance of the three models was assessed using coefficient of variation $( R ^ { 2 } )$ on the test data, using an $8 0 \% \% - 2 0 \%$ train-test split of the full dataset of $\Nu = 2 0 3$ samples.

The porosity GPR model achieved $R _ { t r a i n } ^ { 2 } = 9 2 \%$ and $R _ { t e s t } ^ { 2 } = 8 0 \%$ S the yieldstrength RFRmodelachieved $R _ { t r a i n } ^ { 2 } = 8 1 \%$ and $R _ { t e s t } ^ { 2 } = 2 3 \%$ and theelongationRFRmodelacheved $R _ { t r a i n } ^ { 2 } = 7 8 \%$ and $R _ { t e s t } ^ { 2 } = 2 8 \%$ Thus， the yield strength and elongation models exhibited some degree of overfitting,but could visualize trends in mechanical properties across the training data.

Using these tools,the GPR and RF models were used to interpolate the porosity and mechanical properties across the studied parameter space,which was used to visualize new processing domains with low porosity,high yield strength/elongation,and fast build times.

# 3．Results and discussion

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-20
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
# 3.1．Porosity results
XCT porosity results are summarized in Fig.2.Using an efficient XCT scan protocol, the porosity of 199 samples with unique processing conditions was quantified.The diversity of pore morphologies and volume fraction is illustrated in Fig.2a and 2(b),which are presented for samples with LoF and KH pores,as well as samples with low porosity.As expected,the calculated porosity values for each sample revealed a strong sensitivity to processng parameters (Fig. 2c)，with samples exhibiting porosities from less than $0 . 0 0 1 { - } 9 . 5 3 ~ \%$ .In general, samples withavolumetricenergydensity $\begin{array} { r } { ( V E D ) < 3 5 \frac { J } { m m ^ { 3 } } } \end{array}$ exhibited high levels of irregularly shaped LoF porosity above ${ \sim } 0 . 2 5 ~ \%$ ，and samples with $V E D > 9 0 J / m m ^ { 3 }$ showed high levels of spherical KH porosity above ${ \sim } 0 . 2 5 { \% }$ .However there was substantial variation in the porosity at each VED; for instance,samples with $V E D > 1 1 0 J / m m ^ { 3 }$ showed porosity volume fractions as low as $0 . 0 1 ~ \%$ and as high as $5 . 5 ~ \%$ .Thiswas attributed to nonlinear relationships between processing conditions and the resulting density that could not be captured by VED [29].

![](images/5ebf334b7ee3af54d0331b5475ca303649ccb3a2f5e86d8fb127d3025a1dfc2b.jpg)  
Figesutcdfuld porosity. Each sample is $6 \mathrm { m m }$ in diameter. (b) Corresponding 2D slices for samples in (a), where scale bars are $1 \mathrm { m m }$ in length. (c) Summary of measured porosity as function of volumetric energy density.

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-21
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
# 3.2.Mechanical testing results
The quasistatic, tensile properties for all samples are summarized as a function of volumetric energy density in Fig.3.Ina similar manner to porosity,the yield strength,ultimate tensile strength and elongation to failure were highest over a broad processing window from approximately 35 to $1 2 0 J / m m ^ { 3 }$ ,but showed substantial variation as a function ofprocessing conditions. Within the dense processwindow $( 3 5 \leq \mathrm { V E D } \leq 1 2 0 )$ ),the average yield strength was observed to increase from 996 to $1 0 4 6 \mathrm { M P a }$ ,ultimate strength was found to decrease from 1152 to $1 1 3 6 \mathrm { M P a }$ ,and elongation was found to decrease from $8 . 1 ~ \%$ to $5 . 2 \%$ .As expected, samples with $V E D < 3 5 J / m m ^ { 3 }$ showed dramatically lower strength and elongation due to pervasive LoF porosity,although no pronounced negative effect on strength was seen at high $V E D >$ $1 2 0 J / m m ^ { 3 }$ associated with keyhole porosity.

We note that the observed variation in the mechanical properties was not attributed to experimental noise: mechanical testing of replicate samples with four identical processing conditions showed typical standard deviations of ${ \sim } 7$ MPa in yield strength,8 MPa in ultimate strength, and $1 . 6 \%$ in elongation.These levels of uncertainty were substantially lower than the observed range in mechanical properties (e.g.,yield strength ranging from 933 to $1 1 3 6 \mathrm { M P a }$ for samples with $6 5 <$ $V E D < 7 5 J / m m ^ { 3 } )$ ,indicating confounding sources of variation across the parameter space-in total, this motivates the use of machine-learning based approaches to understand the effect of processing conditions on the resulting properties,as discussed in Section 3.3.

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-22
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
The summary plots of porosity and mechanical properties as a function of VED in Fig.2 and Fig.3 allude to complex relationships between the material performance and the processing conditions. Using GPR and RFR models to visualize experimental data,Fig.4 presents the predicted porosity,yield strength and elongation as a function of the laser power,speed,and hatch spacing. Overall, the three models identified the nonlinear trends in the porosity and mechanical properties across the build space.We note that the GPR and RFR models were trained on $\Nu = 2 0 3$ samples,and high $R ^ { 2 }$ values during model training indicated that the models provided strong interpolation of the experimental data.In total, this indicated that the Bayesian optimization sampling strategy accurately captured the variation in mechanical properties across the processing space.

First, this dataset revealed a processing window capable of achieving dense material that was substantially larger than previously believed. Dense material was observed across a range of hatch spacing from 0.06 to $0 . 1 4 \mathrm { m m }$ ,whereas most studies have previously focused on a single hatch spacing.In particular,we identified a unique,low-porosity processing domain associated with small hatch spacing,high velocity,and high laser power. For example, the processing window to achieve samples with less than $0 . 0 1 ~ \%$ porosity is narrow at large hatch spacings,e. g.,requiring velocity between 75o and $1 8 2 5 \mathrm { m m } / s$ at $\mathrm { P } = 2 8 0 \mathrm { W }$ and H $= 0 . 1 4 \ \mathrm { m m }$ ,but similar densities can be achieved at velocities between 890 and $3 6 5 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ for $\mathrm { P } = 2 8 0 \mathrm { W }$ and $\mathrm { H } = 0 . 0 6 \ \mathrm { m m }$ .Previously, the high power and high velocity region has been avoided due to balling instabilities,[3O,31] but we demonstrate that small hatch spacing can mitigate these effects.

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-23
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content: Second,extremely diverse mechanical properties were obtained across the processing domain for yield strength,ultimate tensile strength (not shown but the trend is similar),and elongation to failure.We report opposite trends in yield strength and elongation to failure with respect to the processing conditions:yield strength tended to increase at higher VED (even in samples with elevated keyhole porosity),whereas elongation to failure tended to increase at lower energy densities.The highest yield strength was observed at large hatch spacings of ${ \sim } 0 . 1 4 \ \mathrm { m m }$ ,whereas the highest elongation to failure was observed at small hatch spacings of ${ \sim } 0 . 0 8 \ \mathrm { m m }$ .In other words,the mechanical properties depended not only on the VED,but also on the specific processing conditions-including hatch spacing.

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-24
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
As discussed in the previous two sections,the as-printed Ti-6Al-4V material exhibited substantial differences in the porosity and mechanical properties as a function of the processing conditions,and also showed large variation in defect content and mechanical properties for samples with nominally similar processing conditions.These findings permit the design of unique processing conditions to satisfy competing objectives.

![](images/267d4b08e31e28ba8cf9a4362ba6040f23c05b868ac9c4c0462fca563070e5bd.jpg)  
Figel (c) Elongation to failure.Lines of best fit are plotted for data with $3 5 \leq \mathrm { V E D } \leq 1 2 0$ to indicate underlying trends.Significant variation in properties was observed among specimens with similar VED.

summary: 3.4.Multi-objective optimization of Ti-6Al-4V processing conditions - Part 1/4

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-25
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
One possible application of these data is to select desirable tradeoffs in the mechanical properties，as summarized in Fig.5.While conventional performance tradeoffs between yield strength and elongation are widely acknowledged across most engineering metals,our study revealed a large range of achievable mechanical properties subject to the constraint of porosity $< 0 . 1 ~ \%$ as compared with previous work [32].As the dataset was expanded after each DOE,we were able to construct convex hulls that enclosed the achievable property space.For instance,after DOE 2,several parameter sets achieved high yield strengths of ${ \sim } 1 1 0 0 \mathrm { M P a }$ ,whereas the first DOE revealed samples with yield strengths of only ${ \sim } 1 0 5 0 \mathrm { M P a }$ .Inclusion of data from three DOEs resulted in a converged Pareto front of samples with optimal yield strength and elongation.This indicated that machine learning-enabled Bayesian optimization approaches succeeded in identifying new processing domains with unique properties.

![](images/fb0a9d886146901a9c9c3c6b00462cbb50e3b4cacd8e19dbb813730eeb109d3e.jpg)  
Fig.5.Achievable design space of Ti-6Al-4V mechanical properties.Mechanical properties of samples from each DOE are plotted,and a convex hull is presented to bound the design space for each subsequent DOE.Labeled samples were selected for further microstructural analysis and are discussed in Section 3.5.Only samples with less than $0 . 1 ~ \%$ porosity are plotted.

In particular,we highlight several samples from near the convex hull of achievable properties in Fig.5, which are annotated by their unique sample ID.1 The anisotropic mechanical properties and microstructure of these samples were analyzed as described in Section 3.5 in order to explain the observed diversity in mechanical behavior.
summary: 3.4.Multi-objective optimization of Ti-6Al-4V processing conditions - Part 2/4

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-26
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
The anisotropy of the highlighted samples is summarized in Fig.6, which reports the ultimate tensile strength of vertically built tension coupons.Here,the ultimate tensile strength is plotted for both in-plane (horizontal) and vertical directions for8 parameter sets,which reveals that anisotropy varies substantially across the processing space.Typically,at lower VED the samples exhibited higher strength in the vertical direction,and this trend reversed at higher VED.For moderate VED between 43 and $8 9 J / m m ^ { 3 }$ ,anisotropy was minimal—this included the “stock”parameter set A51.The degree of mechanical anisotropy can be optimized through further study in the future.

Third,this machine learning-enabled map of the parameter space highlights new opportunities to increase deposition rate without sacrificing mechanical properties (Fig.7).Pushing the build speed of AM parts is desirable to reduce the time to build the overall part and increase the yield of parts that can be built.As shown in Fig.7a and b,we identified several parameter sets with superior yield strength and deposition rate compared to stock parameters (i.e.,top right quadrant in Fig.7a),and several additional parameter sets with superior elongation and deposition rate compared to stock conditions (i.e.,top right quadrantin Fig.7b).However,we found only one parameter set (B4l,with $P$ $= ~ 1 7 5 W$ $V = ~ 6 5 0 m m / s$ ， $H = \ 0 . 1 6 m m$ ）with both improved yield strength and elongation to failure compared to stock conditions,but it resulted in a deposition rate of $3 . 1 2 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / s$ compared to the stock deposition rate of $5 . 0 4 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / s$ ，The fastest deposition rates exceeded
summary: 3.4.Multi-objective optimization of Ti-6Al-4V processing conditions - Part 3/4

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-27
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content: $9 . 5 \ : \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / s$ ,which was $9 0 \%$ higher than the stock conditions.Many of these “fast” parameter sets were characterized by smallhatch spacing, high laser power with extremely high scan velocities.As discussed in Section 3.3, this processing domain has not been previously identified in the literature to the best of the author's knowledge.
summary: 3.4.Multi-objective optimization of Ti-6Al-4V processing conditions - Part 4/4

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-28
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
To understand the microstructural origins of the diverse mechanical properties, EBSD characterization was performed on the samples produced with processing conditions identified in Fig.5.Inverse pole figure maps for seven of the Ti-6Al-4V built samples in the XY and XZ planes are shown in Fig.8(a) and (c).All samples exhibited an acicular $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ microstructure with similar lath sizes,making it difficult to identify microstructural differences.

Therefore, these EBSD maps were reconstructed to show the parent $\beta$ -grains which more clearly distinguishes the microstructural variation in the samples.The reconstructed parent EBSD maps from Fig.8(b) and (d) show marked variation in the orientation of the samples with some samples like B35 havinga preferred $< 1 0 0 >$ orientation while others like B84 havinga preferred $< 1 0 1 >$ and $< 1 1 1 >$ orientation. In addition,the size and shape of the parent $\beta$ grains varied tremendously from sample to sample as shown in the reconstructed EBSD maps.EBSD was therefore also used to determine the maximum ferret diameters of all the grains in the reconstructed parent grains as shown for all of the samples in Fig.8(e).The average of the maximum ferret diameters varies between samples with the lowest having a value $4 8 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (A01)and the highest having a value of $2 1 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (B35) in the XZ plane.The variation in the maximum ferret diameters in the XY plane is less significant with values ranging from $3 6 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $6 1 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ .Thereisa large variation in the grain size within each sample as well.This is in part due to some of the grains being so large that they do not fall entirely within the confines of the EBSD map but also because the number of grains within each map is different, e.g.,215 for A01 and only7 for B35 in the XZ plane (excluding hexagonal grains).
summary: 3.5.Microstructure of pareto-optimal samples by machine learning - Part 1/3

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-29
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
To understand the origin of the diverse mechanical properties observed in these samples,we quantified the Multiple of Uniform Density(MUD) and grain angle misorientation measured from the EBSD maps.These features were plotted as a function of VED and the peak stress for each sample in Fig. 9.

In particular,the strength of texture is known to influence the strength of Ti-6Al-4V,which is quantified by the MUD values.For instance,strong texture along the $\{ 1 1 \overline { { 2 } } 1 \} \alpha$ and $\{ 1 0 \overline { { { 1 0 } } } \} \alpha$ directions could facilitate mechanical twinning,leading to an improved mechanical response via the activation of slip and twinning deformation modes.The MUD values for the hexagonal grains $( \alpha ^ { \prime } )$ are shown in Fig. 9(a) for both the XZ and XY planes,while the MUD values for the cubic grains (prior $\beta )$ are shown in Fig. 9(b).In both cases, the MUD values were positively correlated with increasing VED,but were not correlated with the ultimate tensile strength.

Similarly, grain refinement is known to improve mechanical strength via the Hall-Petch effect [33-35],and rapid solidification of prior $\beta$ -grains of Ti-6Al-4V samples built by additive processes is often attributed to the complex thermal history that occurs during AM processing [36].The degree of grain refinement is quantified by the number of low-angle grain boundaries (LAGB) with misorientation angle less than 10 degrees,as shown in Fig.9(c).The number of LAGB increased as a function of the energy density for both orientations,but was again poorly correlated with the peak stress in both build orientations.
summary: 3.5.Microstructure of pareto-optimal samples by machine learning - Part 2/3

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-30
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
In total, this microstructural characterization revealed significant differences in the size,texture,preferred orientation,and grain misorientation of the parent $\beta$ microstructure,which correlated strongly with the processing conditions. This provided evidence that machine learning enabled search methods like BO could successfully identify new processing conditions that altered the microstructure of Ti-6Al-4V to influence the macroscopic mechanical properties.Additionally,the relatively weak correlations between the MUD values and mechanical response indicated that additional microstructural features were required to robustly predict the mechanical behavior that varied nonlinearly with processing conditions.

summary: 3.5.Microstructure of pareto-optimal samples by machine learning - Part 3/3

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-31
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
Machine learning enabled Bayesian optimization schemes were employed to efficiently discover new L-PBF processing domains for Ti6Al-4V.To enable data-driven exploration of the processing space, we developed new high throughput screening techniques based on efficient XCT scans to quantify porosity that are faster and more sensitive than the Archimedes’method [21],as well as sub-scale tension testing methods that are similar in size to those developed by Sandia National Laboratory [37]．These characterization techniques can enable machine-learning guided study of the processing-structure-property relationships in other materials such as aluminum,steel,and nickel-based superalloys.

Using Bayesian optimization and Gaussian Process Regression surrogate models trained on XCT data with $N = 1 9 9$ processing conditions, this work revealed a vast processing window that achieves porosity volume fractions $< 0 . 1 ~ \%$ .The high-density samples exhibited diverse variable mechanical properties.In particular,we identified a new,high density processing regime associated with high laser power,high laser velocity,and small hatch spacing,which was previously avoided due to perceived balling instabilities; this processing regime resulted in material deposition rates faster above $9 . 5 \ : \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / s$ ，which exceeded the deposition rate using stock conditions $( 5 . 0 4 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / \mathrm { s } )$

Additionally,we identified processing parameter sets with optimized mechanical properties and deposition rates.We found that yield strength could be varied systematically between 980 and $1 0 9 5 \mathrm { M P a }$ as well as the elongation from $4 . 6 \%$ to $1 3 . 5 \%$ 、Additionally,we found multiple parameter sets with faster deposition rates that had either improved yield strength or elongation compared to the stock parameter set.However,we did not identify any parameter sets with simultaneously improved strength,elongation,and deposition rate.

name: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V-part-32
fileName: 2025 - AM - Montalbano et al. - Machine learning enabled discovery of new L-PBF processing domains for Ti-6Al-4V.pdf
content:
The parts built exhibited extreme microstructural variation in grain morphology,size,and texture across the parameter space.All studied samples exhibited acicular $\alpha ^ { \prime }$ microstructure,yet some achieved high ductility above $^ { 1 3 \% }$ strain to failure.The preferential texture of the reconstructed $\beta$ -grains exhibited in some samples mayplaya role in this behavior,while also potentially inducing significant anisotropy.Simple quantitative analysis of the sample texture and grain size showed moderate correlations against the processing conditions,but could not fully explain the observed trends in mechanical properties.In total, this work emphasizes the need for robust microstructural and micromechanical models to predict the mechanical behavior as a function of processing conditions.
